author: Ferreira et al. 2021
title: Uncovering the geographical disparities in organ donation and transplantation in brazil during the COVID-19 pandemic
Objective(s): To analyze nationwide data from the Brazilian Organ Transplantation Association and Health Ministry on COVID-19 cases, organ donations, and solid organ transplants performed from January 1st to December 31st 2020
Population: COVID-19 cases, organ donations, and solid organ transplants (Data from the Brazilian Organ Transplantation Association and Health Ministry on COVID-19 cases, organ donations, and solid organ transplants)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis through percentages
Type of social stratification: Geographic - macro-regions: wealthiest (South, Southeast, and Midwest) / lowest-income (North and Northeast)
Main Results: 1. After three months of the first confirmed case, Brazil had suffered a decrease of 19% (wealthiest) and 30% (lowest-income) in organ donation and transplantation.2. Wealthiest states had decreased by 13% and 24% in organ donation and transplantation.3. Lowest-income states had reduced by 40% and 53% in organ donation and transplantation
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Pandemic exacerbated geographical disparities.2. Special attention should be focused on regions with less economic resources.3. Rescue measures for the time of the pandemic and for the long-term consequences

author: Jardim and Buckeridge 2020
title: Análise sistêmica do município de São Paulo e suas implicações para o avanço dos casos de Covid-19
Objective(s): To apply the BioNetStat systemic tool to the census data of the city of São Paulo. .To build on previous work by Nery et al. (2019) that distinguished eight urban patterns.
Population: Urban patterns and confirmed COVID cases
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The expansion of Covid-19 in São Paulo may have followed the expected pattern that regions with a deficient urban structure in the city were proportionally more affected by the disease.2. In the case of the incidence of Covid-19 cases, the variable high-income head of household and literate head of household seem to have been the main determinants (Figure 6A)..3. In the case of the mobility subgroup, as expected, the increase in the number of trips and the average travel time proved to be important factors in determining the increase in Covid-19 cases and deaths in São Paulo.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The urban structure seems to have a preponderant role in determining the effects that extreme events may have on the city of São Paulo..2. In contrast to the artificial administrative divisions that exist today, the municipality of São Paulo is clearly a set of “cities” with very different vulnerabilities in response to external factors..3. If the systemic analyzes shown here prove to be robust in the face of other extreme events, perhaps it is time to rethink São Paulo's urban management, better adapting it to the current reality, that is, to its urban standards.

author: Segatore and Seca 2021
title: Sin un cuarto propio: trayectorias juveniles y cuidado infantil durante el aislamiento por Covid-19 en Mendoza (Argentina)
Objective(s): To understand the experiences of young women who have performed unpaid child care work under this new context.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The data analysis is explanatory / interpretive in nature. A detailed reading of the interviews was made, the data was organized, thematic coding, and its integration.
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The testimonies allow to show not only the way in which the tasks are distributed, but who is responsible for the planning, management and organization of it, which generates a mental burden on the person in charge..2. All of them agree that, during the pandemic, the care tasks they carried out in their homes increased.3. The measure of cleanliness of the rooms taken by the national government meant a double damage for them: the loss of a care space and the increase in tasks from carrying out school activities, for which they did not feel qualified..4. The unequal distribution of care among the intervening actors, materialized in the social and political organization of care, reached the maximum point of familiarization, through the total absence of public offer of care by the municipal, provincial and national states and the prohibition of private supply for sanitary measures.5. They presented personal discomfort regarding the level of learning and the grades obtained..6. Regarding paid work, female participation and the hours dedicated to it present much lower levels than in men and to a greater extent when there are care responsibilities..7. By dedicating hours to care tasks, young women should organize their study time and paid work, as well as granting them (or not) space for recreational activities
Policy or intervention associate: Social isolation measures adopted by the national government in March 2020 with the slogan "stay at home"
Conclusions: 1. Inequality that throughout the analysis affects women in their trajectories and feelings, generating monetary and time poverty, influencing their autonomy and that, ultimately, are reproduced at the macrosocial level..2. A problem of a structural nature such as gender inequalities and the social, economic and health crisis fueled by the pandemic. The young women carried out direct and indirect care tasks, in an unpaid manner, for children in their homes

author: Travassos, Moreira, and Cortez 2020
title: The virus, the disease and the inequality
Objective(s): To dialogue with the perspective of environmental justice, discussing some impacts of territorial inequalities in the life and death of the people of São Paulo, due to the distribution of factors such as: characteristics, work, comorbidities, equipment and access to health, which maintains a center-periphery pattern.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: -Racial: Black/White/Brown.-Geographic: Municipalities
Main Results: 1. Unequal access to health care, during life  and the pandemic, can also explain the relations between inequalities and comorbidities, aggravated in COVID-19 crisis..2. The epidemiological bulletin (weekly), show an interpretations of death data that may suggest different patterns of lethality, however, it is most likely that the difference between the maps is related to the highest and lowest testing - the district with the highest number of confirmed cases is the more tested..3. The data by race shows differences on deaths, with the incidence of death being 62% higher in black people and 23%, in brown ones, both compared to the white.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The data and discussion demonstrate how the infection by SARS-CoV 2 and the death resulting from COVID-19 overlap with other territorial inequalities in the municipality of São Paulo..2. Include the priority addressing of public policies for the peripheries, considering the integrated approach of plans, programs and actions, to achieve transformative agendas..

author: Pacheco et al. 2021
title: Gender disparities in access to care for time-sensitive conditions during COVID-19 pandemic in Chile.
Objective(s): To evaluate disparities between men and women in access to medical care in Chile during the COVID-19 pandemic
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Stratified analysis to test heterogeneity by gender and age group.2. Set of nine time-sensitive conditions included in the National Explicit Health Guarantees Regime (“AUGE”).3. Interrupted time-series analysis using a segmented regression. Fitted generalized linear models with a Negative Binomial distribution..4. As a sensitivity analysis, we fitted unadjusted and adjusted models for all cancers, after excluding sex-specific cancers (breast cancer, cervical cancer, and testicular).
Type of social stratification: Gender: Male/Female
Main Results: 1. Total of 156 weeks with 327,477 cardiovascular events (83,034 strokes and 244,443 myocardial infarction) and 137,700 cancer diagnoses (23,135 gastric cancers, 24,579 colorectal cancers, 5,290 lymphomas, 2535 leukemia, 42,143 cervical cancers, 37,443 breast cancers, and 2,575 testicular cancers) .2. Larger immediate reduction (level effect) for cancer conditions (0.323; 95% CI 0.291–0.359) compared to the cardiovascular events (0.586; 95% CI 0.564–0,609). - the post intervention slope was larger for cancer conditions (1.022; 95% CI 1.016–1.028) than cardiovascular events (1.009; 95% CI 1.007–1.011).3. Cancer conditions, a greater immediate reduction was observed in colorectal cancer (0.229; 95% CI 0.199–0.265), gastric cancer (0.306; 95% CI 0.253–0.371), cervical cancer (0.335; 95% CI 0.287–0.392) and breast cancer (0.336; 95% CI 0.293–0.385).  A greater post intervention slope was observed in colorectal cancer (1.036 95% CI 1.028–1.043), breast cancer (1.028 95% CI 1.021–1.036) and gastric cancer (1.022 95% 1.011–1.032)..4. The sensitivity analysis results are observed on table 1.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Urgent need to integrate a gender perspective into the pandemic response..2. They demonstrate that women were far more affected compared to men. This differential effect by gender was observed for a broad group of time-sensitive conditions..3. The observed effect occurred in a set of severe time-sensitive conditions where care delays could worsen prognosis.
Funding sources: National Agency for Research and Development (ANID), Scholarship program, DOCTORADO BECAS CHILE 2020–21200241 and COVID research fund ANID-COVID0960.

author: Rezende et al. 2020
title: Adults at high-risk of severe coronavirus disease-2019 (Covid-19) in Brazil
Objective(s): To calculate the proportion and total number of the general adult population who may be at higher risk for severe Covid-19, based on routinely collected data from a nationwide, household-based survey in Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It estimated the prevalence and 95% confidence intervals of adults at risk for severe Covid-19 (Criterion 1 and Criterion 2) by sex, education, race/ethnicity and Brazilian state.
Type of social stratification: -Race/ethnicity: White/Non-white.-Gender: Male/Female.-Education Level: None or incomplete primary education / Complete primary or incomplete secondary education / Complete secondary education or incomplete.-Undergraduate course / University Graduate
Main Results: 1.  Compared with younger participants, older adults (= 65 years) were less educated, more likely women, white and presented higher  prevalence of risk factors for severe Covid-19, except for smoking. .2. Prevalence of one or more risk factors for severe illness was 47.3% in younger vs 75.9% in older adults..3. Proportion and total number of adults at risk for severe Covid-19 in Brazil varied from 34.0% (53 million adults) to 54.5% (86 million adults): see Table 3. .4. Overall, 46% of the sample presented no risk factor, 30.0% with one, 15.0% with two, and 9% with 3 or more risk factors for severe illness. .5. Sensitivity analyses considering older adults = 60 years and = 70 years suggested that prevalence could vary from 36.7%–56.2% to 32.3%–53.3%: see Table 4..6. It found no differences in prevalence estimates by sex and race/ethnicity.7. The highest prevalence was 39.5%–58.4% in Rio Grande do Sul, followed by 36.0–55.8% in Rio de Janeiro and 35.6%–58.2% in São Paulo. The lowest prevalence was found in Amapá (23.4%–45.9%), followed by Roraima (25.0%–48.6%) and Amazonas (25.1%–48.7%). .8. The highest number of adults at risk of severe illness was found in São Paulo (17-21 million), Minas Gerais (6–9 million) and Rio de Janeiro (5–7 million): See Table 5.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. It estimated that a third (53 million) to over a half (86 million) of Brazilian adults present at least one risk factor for severe Covid-19..2. Less educated adults present 2-fold higher prevalence of risk factors compared with university graduated..3. Proportion and total number of adults at risk of severe Covid-19 is high in Brazil, with wide variation across states and adult subgroups.

author: Alves, Souza, and Caló 2021
title: Poor sanitation and transmission of COVID-19 in Brazil
Objective(s): To analyze in the context of iniquities in Brazil (comparing these with the situation in other countries). A bibliographic search of texts relating to basic sanitation, socioeconomic development and transmission of COVID-19 in Brazil and worldwide was conducted.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. That vulnerabilities and the risk of transmission of COVID-19 transcend national and international scales..2. In Rio de Janeiro, it was observed that initially the neighborhoods in the South Zone were the most affected by the disease. The districts of the North Zone (in general, of lower-income populations) showed higher mortality rates due to COVID-19, which may have reflected a lack of access to healthcare services..3. Hand hygiene, a preventive measure for COVID-19, is still a privilege in Brazil, since in several regions of the country, many homes do not have access to water and basic sanitation.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Understanding the social conditions under which individuals live is central for implementing public policies based on solidarity, social rights and democracy, so as to ensure healthier socio-spatial environments and enable reduction of the effects of the pandemic. .2. It is necessary to analyze the information regarding the pandemic in terms of race/color, income and other social determinants, thus making it possible to have differentiated actions for the places, areas and regions of greatest vulnerability.

author: Hernández-Vásquez et al. 2020
title: Exceso de mortalidad en Lima Metropolitana durante la pandemia de COVID-19: comparación a nivel distrital
Objective(s): To compare excess deaths according to district quintiles of the Human Development Index (HDI) in Metropolitan Lima, capital of Peru, and analyze the socioeconomic factors associated with excess deaths in the context of COVID-19.
Sample size: n=20,093 non-violent deaths .n=2,979 confirmed deaths from COVID-19
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive analysis was performed using contingency tables and time series graphs by sex, age group, and quintile of the district of residence according to the Human Development Index (HDI).2. Presence of trends in the time series of excess mortality was evaluated using the Kwiatkowski-Phillips-Schmidt-Shin test (KPSS).3. Negative binomial regression model was performed to identify possible explanatory factors for excess mortality
Type of social stratification: -The Human Development Index.-Gender: Male/Female.-Population density.-Percentage of the population in poverty and extreme poverty.-Inhabitants over 60 years of age.-The self-identified Afro-Peruvian population.-The population working in the same district.-Houses with access to water from the public network with a computer and internet access
Main Results: 1. 20 093 non-violent deaths and 2979 confirmed deaths from COVID-19 were registered in Metropolitan Lima.2. The most affected group was that of men aged 60 and over residing in the districts of the third quintile according to the HDI, with 20 969 excess deaths per million inhabitants.3. In the 12 to 17 age group, only those residing in districts of the first quintile, according to the HDI, presented an increasing trend of excess mortality (p = 0.028). This was also observed in the residents of the districts of the second (p < 0.01) and third (p < 0.01) quintiles according to the HDI in the age group of 18 to 29 years. An increasing trend in excess deaths was detected in all quintiles for people aged 30 to 59 and 60 and over. .4. Socioeconomic characteristics of the districts, it should be noted that self-identification of the inhabitants as Afro-Peruvian was highest in the districts of East Lima, where 34.48% of the inhabitants of Pachacamac self-identified as Afro-Peruvian, closely followed by 31.26 % of Lurigancho and 30.30% in Cieneguilla and Ate..5. Five explanatory variables with significant individual contribution were selected, of which the multivariate analysis revealed that the HDI (relative risk: 0.02; 95% confidence interval: 0.00 to 0.35; p = 0.009) and the percentage of inhabitants in a situation of extreme poverty (relative risk: 0.57; 95% confidence interval: 0.37 to 0.89; p = 0.014) significantly decreased the rate of excess mortality in Metropolitan Lima: See Table 3.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This excess was greater in the quintiles of districts with the lowest HDI, in men, and people 60 or older. .2. Excess mortality beyond non-violent deaths caused by COVID-19 can be attributed to the catastrophic indirect impact of the disease on health systems, leading to neglect of other life-threatening diseases or conditions, as well as the large socioeconomic differences of the Peruvian population, even within Metropolitan Lima, which leads to a breach of compulsory isolation..3. The impact of the pandemic on health and the role of the economy in its outcomes should not be underestimated and should lead the government to take specific measures to reduce gaps in social and economic inequality, as well as to push investments to improve the Peruvian health system

author: Cifuentes et al. 2021
title: Socioeconomic inequalities associated with mortality for COVID-19 in Colombia: A cohort nationwide study
Objective(s): To identify the effect of some socioeconomic inequality-related factors on COVID-19 mortality in Colombia.
Sample size: n = 1'033,218 confirmed cases and 30,565 deaths for COVID-19 between 2 March 2020 to 26 October 2020 (Data from the national public health surveillance system (SIVIGILA) of the National Institute of Health)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Exploratory customary descriptions for distributions of continuous time-to-death variable and all categorical predictors, for the different outcomes (dead, recovered and censored) included means, medians, frequencies and percentages..2. Testing of proportional hazards assumption for all the predictors using hypothesis tests (p values of terms addressing time dependent factors) and graphs (Log minus log plots and partial residuals plots from models with no interaction terms). Using an extended multipredictor time-dependent Cox regression model, sex were dependent on time. .4. Survival functions were calculated using the Kaplan-Meier method..
Type of social stratification: -Age.-Gender: Male/Female.-Ethnicity: White, mestizo, other/ African-Colombian/ Indigenous/Gipsy-Roman /Raizal.-Type of health insurance: Contributory/ Subsidised/ Special/ Exception/ Uninsured/ Unknown or pending insurance.-Area of residence: Urban / Semirural (village) / Sparse rural / Unknown area.-Socioeconomic strata:  1 very low/ 2 low/ 3 middle low/ 4 middle/ 5 middle high/ 6 high / Non-registered strata
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Socioeconomic status .-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. Most confirmed COVID-19 cases were male, between 27 and 45 years old, living in urban areas, with the contributory regimen of health insurance, and living in residences that belong to the two lower levels of socioeconomic strata..2. The instantaneous risk of dying for COVID-19 among confirmed cases is 59% higher in males compared with females, 27% higher in indigenous people compared with whites/mestizos, and 97% higher in people with subsidised health insurance regime compared with contributory..3. There was evidence of a dose–response pattern by life-course age groups and SES levels..4. The instantaneous risk of death for people with confirmed diagnosis of COVID-19 living in the very low SES increases by 73% compared with the risk of people living in the high SES (HR 1.73 95% CI 1.48 to 2.04). .5. Living in a sparse rural area decreased the risk of mortality for COVID-19 (HR 0.83 95% CI 0.76 to 0.91).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. It provides evidence of demographic and socioeconomic inequalities in COVID-19 mortality in terms of age groups, sex, ethnicity, type of health insurance regimen and socio-economic strata..2. This is the first nationwide cohort study to examine socioeconomic and demographic disparities in time to COVID-19 mortality in Latin America..3. Being male, older than 60 years old, belonging to the subsidised health insurance regime, being indigenous and living in a residence in a very low or low socioeconomic strata shortened the time to death for COVID-19 among confirmed cases in Colombia..4. There was evidence of a dose–response pattern by age groups and socioeconomic strata..5. These results provide evidence to help support the prioritisation of public health interventions for COVID-19 prevention and detection in Colombia such as testing, contact tracing and vaccination directed to the more vulnerable groups according to the unequal mortality risks.
Funding sources: The Direction of Epidemiology and Demography of the Ministry of Health and Social Protection of Colombia.

author: Jara, Montesdeoca, and Tasseva 2021
title: The Role of Automatic Stabilizers and Emergency Tax–Benefit Policies During the COVID-19 Pandemic: Evidence from Ecuador
Objective(s): To quantify the distributional effects of COVID-19 in Ecuador and the role of tax and benefit policies in mitigating the immediate impact of economic shocks.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. The tax–benefit microsimulation model for Ecuador, which combines detailed country-specific coded policy rules with household survey microdata to simulate direct and indirect taxes, social insurance contributions (SICs), and cash transfers for the household population of Ecuador..2. The GINI index.3. The Theil index
Type of social stratification: Occupation: Formal earner/Informal earner/Formal non-earner/Informal non-earner/Unemployed/Inactive
Main Results: 1. The striking effect of the COVID-19 pandemic and lockdown measures in the Ecuadorian labour market. The total number of people in (un)paid work decreased by 15% (from 7.8 to 6.5 million), while a large fraction of earners who remained in work lost their earnings..2. Inactivity also increased, by around 10%. .3. Transitions from paid to unpaid work (i.e. earner to non-earner) or from work to unemployment/ inactivity are the most likely channel of labour market changes during the period when the economy was hit the hardest by the pandemic..4. The largest decrease in the number of earners (formal and informal) is observed in the wholesale and retail trade sector, with a drop of 549,000 earners..5. The results for agriculture and fishing highlight the importance of data availability to capture accurately the labour market changes under the COVID-19 pandemic..6. The decrease was particularly important for formal self-employed workers, amounting to a 66% reduction (from US$466.3 to US$158.0) in mean monthly earnings, compared to a 5% reduction (from US$691.5 to US$655.7) for formal employees..7. Inequality measured by the Gini coefficient increases from 0.461 to 0.592, whereas the Theil index increases from 0.395 to 0.601..8. As a result of the crisis, the poverty headcount increases substantially by 32.5 pp, meaning that 58.2% of the population are below the national poverty line in May/June 2020 compared to 25.7% in December 2019. Extreme poverty also increases strikingly, by 29.4 pp (from 9.2 to 38.6%). Significant and sharp increases are also observed in terms of the (extreme) poverty gap, which increases from 9.6% (3.6%) to 34.1%.
Policy or intervention associate: Policy Measures in Response to COVID-19
Conclusions: 1. The changes reflect the difference between the pre-COVID and the COVID scenarios, where the COVID scenario takes into account the role of the health emergency Family Protection Grant introduced by the Ecuadorian government. The change in disposable income is decomposed into the effects of: (i) earnings losses, (ii) automatic stabilizers, and (iii) COVID-related benefits..2. The COVID-related Family Protection Grant has, on average, a very small effect in mitigating the impact of the crisis in Ecuador..3. A dramatic increase in income poverty and inequality between December 2019 and June 2020. The national poverty headcount increases from 25.7 to 58.2%, the extreme poverty headcount from 9.2 to 38.6%, and the Gini coefficient from 0.461 to 0.592..4. From a policy perspective, our study highlights the need to rethink and enhance social protection in Ecuador and the region. In particular, the lack of benefits acting as automatic stabilizers is a limitation of many countries in the region that rely on proxy means-tested benefits as the main schemes for social protection.
Funding sources: UNU-WIDER project SOUTHMOD. The programme is financed through specific contributions by the Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (Norad).

author: Costa 2020
title: The pandemic and the labor market in Brazil
Objective(s): To show a brief synthesis of the consequences that the health crisis has brought to Brazilian workers and we propose coping measures that are not limited to emergency.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The pandemic affects with greater intensity the population living in informality and resides in precarious areas, that is, who have low and irregular incomes, without access to drinking water, decent housing, private health systems and social protection system linked to the signed work permit..2. One of the consequences of the pandemic is the increase in unemployment and, therefore, the increase in informalization of work, outsourced, subcontractors, flexibilizers, part-time workers and the sub proletariat..3. The sectors most affected by the coronavirus crisis have been those operating in retail, accommodation and food services and manufacturing..4. The Reform (Labor Reform) worsened the worker’s life and increased the number of precarious contracts, as well as insecurity, making him more dependent on the government’s social programs..5. The pandemic showed the absence of basic sanitation and the high density of human beings per square meter. .6. It is necessary to increase public and private investments in the area of health, basic sanitation, popular housing and urban infrastructure.
Policy or intervention associate: 1. Emergency Program for the Maintenance of Employment and Income. Created by the Brazilian government, through Provisional Measure No. 936, of 2020, betting on the “reduction of working hours and, proportionally, of salary, by written individual agreement or collective bargaining and with a maximum duration of 90 days”.2. The government has at its disposal several programs focused on the social and economic field that were able to reduce social inequalities at the beginning of this century, such as the CAP; the My House, My Life Program; the PBF and the Employment and Income Generation Program (Proger), with resources from the Worker Support Fund.
Conclusions: 1. It is expected to increase in the informality rate of the Brazilian economy, which is currently around 40.8%. Moreover, with the drop-in employment and the increase in delinquency, the subsequent cancellation of health plans will tend to burden the already disabled SUS..2. Many communities can benefit from urbanization projects and will be better prepared to face epidemic crises such as the one the world is currently experiencing..3. The exit from the crisis demands the abandonment of austerity and calls for the injection of resources for health and sectors identified as bottlenecks..

author: C. B. Soares, Peduzzi, and da Costa 2020
title: Nursing workers: Covid-19 pandemic and social inequalities Os trabalhadores de enfermagem na pandemia Covid-19 e as desigualdades sociais
Objective(s): NA
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Brazil was responsible for 30% of the deaths of nursing professionals by COVID-19 in the world, earning the sad mark of being the one that kills the largest number of nursing professionals on the planet..2. For this kill health workers and that anyone else? The answer to this question has its common thread in social inequalities, one of the structural axis of class society, marked in a shocking way by the neoliberals of the State imbricated in the state ones..3. Racial and gender inequalities are fundamental to understanding the employment force and its working conditions and deserve to be adequately explored based on specific data and approaches..4. Sao Paul showed SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence 2.5 times higher in poor districts than in rich districts and that decreases with increasing schooling, being 4.5 times higher among those who did not complete primary school and 2.5 times higher among participants who identified as black than among those who identified as white..5. The absence of resources or the supply of inadequate materials to carry out the work and to protect the worker, such as personal equipment (PPE); Insufficient or inadequate staffing of professionals with long hours of work with double guards and multi-employment,.6. They expose workers to risks and mistakes, causing, on the other hand, diseases, work overload and mental and exhaustion, resulting in illnesses, intense emotional suffering and even the death of nursing professionals.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: The insight and handling of reality that we have outlined requires nurses to organize themselves to:.1. Demand commitment from universities and institutions for the development of studies in this demand from unions, associations and professional councils the debate on labor, social security rights and current forms of at work , such as the struggles in defense of the worker and for better working conditions..2. Convene and join civil society organizations to debate and establish forms of collective struggle against social, class, racial and social inequalities..3. Develop actions with SUS users to guarantee its full operation and compliance with the right to health.

author: De Souza Santos et al. 2021
title: Disproportionate Impact of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) among Pregnant and Postpartum Black Women in Brazil through Structural Racism Lens
Journal: Revista Internacional de Planificación y Gestión de la Salud
Objective(s): NA
Sample size: n= 1,860 - pregnant or postpartum woman with complete data on ethnicity until July 14, 2020 .n= 669 - white and black women (maternal COVID ARDS cases in Brazil)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Black women had similar mean age and morbidity profile as White women but were hospitalized in worse conditions (higher prevalence of dyspnea and low O2 saturation), had a higher rate of ICU admission, mechanical ventilation, and death. .2. Barriers to access intensive care seem to play a role in the high number of COVID-19-related maternal deaths in the country.3. Data presented here may indicate that Black pregnant and postpartum women have been disproportionately affected by COVID-19 due to processes originated outside the hospital. .4. Biomedical lens can be used to approach racial disparities in health. .5. Clinical risk factors commonly associated with worse prognosis for COVID-19 were not significantly different between Black and White women. .6. This findings showed that maternal mortality in Black women due to COVID-19 was almost two times higher than observed for White women.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This study highlight the need to move forward for actions tackling social determinants of health outside hospitals, including social protection policies to reduce the likelihood of getting sick and strengthening widely accessible primary care services by offering culturally appropriate, effective, family-centered COVID-19 monitoring, diagnosis and treatment within vulnerable communities. .2. In Brazil, the intersection of gender, race and social class deepen the tragedy of COVID-19 maternal deaths, particularly when the country is not adopting truly effective pandemics containment measures.
Funding sources: Support to Teaching, Research and Outreach Activities – FAEPEX of University of Campinas (UNICAMP).

author: Lotta, Fernandez, and Corrêa 2021
title: The vulnerabilities of the Brazilian health workforce during health emergencies: Analysing personal feelings, access to resources and work dynamics during the COVID-19 pandemic
Journal: The International Journal of Health Planning and Managemen
Objective(s): To analyse the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil for different health professionals, considering the ways in which the health system does or does not protect them. Also, to analyse the role of pre-existing inequalities between different professions and social groups within the workforce in shaping their different experiences the pandemic.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: -Race: White/White.-Gender: Male/Female.-Percentage of perceptions of the material working conditions of public health workers..-Perceptage of changes to working procedures during the pandemic
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Occupation.-Gender/sex.-Social capital .-Features of relationships (e.g. smoking parents, excluded from school)
Main Results: 1. Most of the 870 community health workers (CHWs) are women (75,5%) and black (70,9%). 53,9% (n = 469) identified themselves as black women, 20% white women (n = 174), 15.7% black men (n = 137) and 10,3% others. Most respondents are between 30 and 49 years old (72,2%)..2. Most of the 445 nurses are women (84,4%) and white (52,8%). When we cross-tabulate the data, They can observe that 46% (n = 207) are white women, 36% are black women (n =162) and the other 17% are black and white men. 85% are aged between 30 and 59 years old..3. Most of 315 physicians are women (63,8%) and self-declared as white (75%). Overall, 48% are white women (n = 151), 27% white men (n = 86), 13% black women (n = 42) and 6% black men (n = 21), the other 5% did not declare either race of gender..4. Mental health and emotional consequences: 79% of physicians felt fearful and 56% did not feel prepared to work during the pandemic; 83% of nurses felt fearful and 68% felt unprepared. This situation is more critical among CHWs: 89% of them felt fear and 83% felt unprepared : Figure 2. Nurses and physicians feel slightly more stressed and anxious than CHWs..
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The first relates to inequalities within the health workforce that may also reproduce structural inequalities. The crisis exacerbated these inequalities and made the importance of gender, race and profession in health workers' experience of the pandemic more evident.2. The second contribution is about the importance of health workforce management especially at moments of crisis. Even strong health systems become fragile during health emergencies and it should not be expected that health workers themselves take sole responsibility for adapting to such situations..3. The findings cannot be generalized to Brazil as a whole.

author: Santos Saldanha et al. 2021
title: Persons with disabilities during the COVID-19 pandemic: Guaranteeing fundamental rights and equity in care
Objective(s): To search for original peer-reviewed articles published in indexed journals, in addition to specialized gray literature.
Population: Vulnerabilities of people with disabilities during the pandemic
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Occupation.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. Professionals should adhere to inclusive practice, guaranteeing the individual’s participation in the process of care, access to medicines, treatments, and essential equipment for life. Accessibility in the environment, information, and different forms of communication should be guaranteed..2. Recommends investigating problems related to disability that are potential risk factors, working with prevention, maintenance of remote care or homecare, orienting accompanying persons and caregivers on protective measures, and prioritizing the guarantee of human rights based on scientific knowledge in all the actions..3. Individuals should be placed on sick leave in case of a COVID-19 diagnosis.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Persons with disabilities were acknowledged as a risk group for COVID-19 by international and national health organizations, besides persons with disabilities rights advocacy organizations. Importantly, however, this group is not inherently vulnerable..2. Vulnerable populations such as persons with disabilities need specific policies that guarantee access to rights and equity in access to social protection policies, including in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.

author: Parreiras Martins et al. 2020
title: Preparedness of pharmacists to respond to the emergency of the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil: a comprehensive overview
Objective(s): To provide a complete overview of the challenges pharmacy services face in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic emergency in Brazil and discuss the role of clinical pharmacists in this context.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The early experience of pharmaceutical services during the outbreak of COVID-19 in China highlighted the indispensable work of community and hospital pharmacists in the emergency response to the pandemic..2. Global drug shortages were triggered by inadequate quantities of raw materials, procurement and manufacturing issues, and drug discontinuations..3. In Brazil, drug shortages also involved importation difficulties, exorbitant costs, compulsory advance payments, and non-compliance with agreed quantities and delivery deadlines.4. The fear of catching COVID-19 and free access to drugstores have caused a rush to buy medicines for self-treatment.5. Data presented by the Federal Board of Pharmacy revealed a substantial increase in drug sales involving ascorbic acid (180.0%), acetaminophen (77.4%) and hydroxychloroquine sulfate (67.9%) from January to March 2020 relative to the same period in 2019.6. The off-label use of chloroquine/hydroxychloroquine for preventing or treating COVID-19 imposes safety issues and requires the implementation of prescription monitoring strategies.7. Panic buying of alcohol-based formulations, face shields, N95 respirators and other personal protective equipment (PPE) has also occurred, leading to shortages in hospitals and other healthcare facilities.8. Clinical pharmacists should constantly seek updated knowledge on COVID-19 to improve the monitoring of effectiveness and safety of drug therapy, and to promote productive interaction within the multidisciplinary team..
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Pharmacists play a key role in the management of COVID-19 in Brazil by providing health interventions and specialized support to improve outcomes, especially in populations with underlying diseases and social inequalities..2. Pharmaceutical expertise has been relevant in managing drug shortages, redesigning workflow, and educating pharmacists in Brazil. Pharmacists can contribute to multidisciplinary teams, including antimicrobial stewardship programs, to improve outcomes of drug therapy in severe and critically ill patients.4. Further studies are needed to improve COVID-19 knowledge and patient care in low- and middle-income countries

author: Castro et al. 2021
title: Characteristics, outcomes and risk factors for mortality of 522 167 patients hospitalised with COVID-19 in Brazil: a retrospective cohort study.
Objective(s): To provide a comprehensive description of demographic, clinical and radiographic characteristics; treatment and case outcomes; and risk factors associated with in-hospital death of patients hospitalised with.COVID-19 in Brazil
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive analysys (medians and IQR ranges were assessed by Whitney U, ?2 or Fisher’s exact test). .2. Univariable logistic analysis..3. HRs were estimated using Cox proportional-hazards models...
Type of social stratification: -Age: groups separated by 10 years from 0 to 80 years or older.-Gender: male/ female.-Ethnicity: white/ black / brown/ other.-Region: North/ Northeast/ South/ Southeast / Center-West.-Comorbidities: diabetes/ asthma/ liver disease/ neurological disease/ lung disease/ chronic immunodeficiency / kidney disease / obesity.-Admission to ICU
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Gender/sex.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1. Age of patients was 61 years (IQR, 47–73), and much higher for non-survivors, 71 years (IQR, 60–80), median age of 65 years (IQR, 52–76) needed ICU admission..2. Patients were mostly males (56.0%) and from the Southeast region (49.3%)..3. Of all hospitalisations, 37.7% of the patients were White, and 37.9% were Black/Brown. Among survivors, 38.8% were White, while among non-survivors 41.7% were Black/ Brown..4. The most common comorbidities were chronic cardiovascular disease (34.5% of patients and 43.5% of non-survivors) and diabetes (25.7% of patients and 33.0% of non- survivors)..5. Univariable logistic analysis indicated that the odds of in-hospital death progressively increased with age, and were higher for patients who were male (males are 1.23 times that of females,) , non-white, from the North and Northeast regions (North and Northeast regions were,respectively, 1.83 and 1.48 times that of patients in the South east.), needed ICU care, were obese and had diabetes and other comorbidities (table 4).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Risk factors for in-hospital death were older age, being male, of Black/Brown ethnoracial self-classification, living in the North or Northeast regions, with a history of ICU admission and various co-morbidities.  .2. Observed associations of age, sex, obesity and diabetes with in-hospital deaththis reflects structural inequalities that made large fractions of the population more vulnerable to COVID-19 (eg, people living in areas with precarious infrastructure, overcrowded households, regions with low supply of physicians and hospital services and who depend on informal labour)..3. inequalities are also captured by a higher HR in the North and Northeast regions, where Brazil consistently reports worse socioeconomic indicators. this regions (..) had the worst indicators in terms of mortality and time to hospitalisation, and patients who were hospitalised in a municipality different from the one where they live had to travel 122.0km (IQR, 58.3–258.6), while those in the Southeast travelled 22.3km (IQR, 16.1–36.3).4. Agents could actively identify vulnerable people who face higher risk of mortality, could act as agents of information to sensitise the population and boost adherence to control measures (eg, use of masks) and could continue to deliver community- based primary care services
Funding sources: None: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.

author: Shadmi et al. 2020
title: Health equity and COVID-19: Global perspectives
Journal: International Journal for Equity in Health
Objective(s): To address the effects of the current pandemic on global health equity, we have compiled 13 country case studies that highlight the unique needs of vulnerable populations and some of the actions taken to address these needs in each country.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The risk of COVID-19 may be greater among the poorest Brazilians reflecting socio and economic inequalities..2. Racial inequality is also an important issue in Brazil as the majority of poor people are black. Moreover, it is already playing a role during the pandemic as the higher case fatality rate by COVID-19 is among blacks..3. Blacks represent 23.1% of hospitalized Brazilians with COVID-19, 32% of them died, and among whites, the situation is reversed, as the proportion of hospitalized cases is 73.9 and 64.5% died..4. Indigenous people are also a group of those most vulnerable  to the COVID-19 pandemic due to worse social, economic and health conditions than non-Indigenous, which can increase the risk of the disease..5. Brazil has the third-largest prison population in the world, 773,000 prisoners. It is estimated that 80% of the prison population will be infected with the virus, of which 20% may need hospitalization and 10,000 (8%) may need an ICU bed..6. With a strong health system and a clear understanding of the COVID-19 circumstances as a both a health and an economic crisis, Colombia has embarked on innovative measures .that aim to reduce the impact on inequality in the country..
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Brazil may face difficulties in responding to other health problems, such as those related  to sexual health during the pandemic. Experience from past outbreaks indicates the need to pay attention to the potential effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on sexual health outcomes, both at immediate and long term..2. The social, racial and regional inequalities present in Brazil are revealing themselves in rates of infection and lethality, as well as in the possibilities of conforming  to quarantine and other preventive measures, and in access to intensive care health services..3. It is too early to know what the impact of the economic/social and health sector policies will have on in equalities in Colombia, however, a few factors that have not been directly addressed by recent policies could prove to be continuing challenges.

author: Boschetti and Behring 2021
title: Assistência Social na pandemia da covid-19: proteção para quem?
Objective(s): To analyze the trends of social assistance in Brazil in the context of covid-19, which favors cash transfer programs with values ??far below social needs, which aggravate the condition of structural social inequality, deepened by ultra-neoliberalism and the neo-fascism
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The pandemic reveals new trends: 1) towards internalization; 2) a change in the age pattern of those infected between June and August, with growth among children and the elderly and a decline among adults; 3) greater chance of infection among blacks and browns and reduction among indigenous peoples; and 4) growth in families among the poorest 20% of the population, with a prevalence more than twice that observed among the richest 20%..2. When the pandemic arrives in Brazil, it finds a country with 12.6 million unemployed. This dramatic number masks the condition of gender and racial inequality that affects women and black people. Among the unemployed, 64.8% are black and brown, as designated by the PNAD/IBGE, while those who are white correspond to 34.2%. Women make up the majority (64.7%) of the workforce and are also the majority among the jobless population — 53.8%. The unemployment rate among women was 13.1% against 9.2% among men. The level of employment of men was 65%, while that of women was 46.2%. Thus, black women make up the main unemployed, precarious and low-wage workforce, which reveals the structurally racist and patriarchal nature of Brazilian capitalism.3. The pandemic unquestionably revealed to the country and the world what the country insisted on hiding: the dismantling of social security and labor rights by successive fiscal adjustments left Brazil immensely vulnerable to the devastation of the accelerated contagion process. On the one hand, the Unified Health System (SUS), legally universal and decentralized, but which was already suffering from a lack of resources - the federal health budget had been frozen since 2015 at the level of 1.7% of GDP, which it was not reversed with the slight recomposition made by the “war budget” in health — it collapsed in the face of new, unknown and immeasurable demands of covid-19..4. The intense precariousness of working relationships and conditions brings about a universe of male and female workers (more than 100 million people or almost 50% of the population) who find themselves, overnight, without work, without any type of remuneration, without assistance benefits and unable to continue searching the streets for some kind of precarious activity (informal activities) that would ensure them a form of income and survival..5. While among the white population the number of deaths in São Paulo (until 31/7) was 115 per 100,000 inhabitants, among the black population it reached 175 per 100,000. Among black men, it reached 250 deaths for every 100,000 inhabitants, while among white men it was 157 for every 100,000. Among black women, the number of deaths was 140 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants, while among white women it was 85 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants.
Policy or intervention associate: The timid, reticent and belated federal measures followed the same ultra-neoliberal policy already underway: scarce resources for health and emergency aid and trillions for banks and businessmen, as approved in the so-called “war budget” (EC no. 106/2020) , which instituted the “extraordinary fiscal, financial and contracting regime to face the national public calamity resulting from the pandemic”.
Conclusions: 1. What can be seen is an accelerated and expanded process of assistance/assistentialism aimed at absolute pauperism, which differs immensely from the right to social assistance. The latter can and should make up a social security policy, based on stable work with universal and public rights, welfare and health..2. As a social right, “universal basic income” programs can complement or temporarily replace the loss of labor rights, but they will never have the capacity to reduce inequalities in access to socially produced wealth..3. The replacement of stable jobs with rights by clientelist “income transfer” assistance programs reveals the most brutal form of subsumption of labor to capital: in addition to keeping the working class out of work at a low cost, within the limits of survival, it also acts to lowering the value of wages transfers to the state almost all the costs of reproduction of the labor force, since it relieves capital, and creates an even more perennial cycle of reproduction of inequalities, as it prohibits the access of men and women to possibilities of work with rights.

author: L. F. A. Magalhães, Bógus, and Baeninger 2021
title: Covid-19 e imigração internacional na Região Metropolitana de São Paulo
Objective(s): To analyze the impacts of Covid-19 among international immigrants in the Metropolitan Region of São Paulo, using data from the survey “Impacts of Covid’s Pandemic on International Migration” (PUC-MG, UNICAMP, 2020)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The overlapping of needs makes the social context a decisive variable, and for this reason international immigrants, whose socio-cultural interactions and labor insertions have been characterized in Brazil by housing precariousness, informality and segregation, have been particularly affected by the disease. even more susceptible to contagion by Covid-19..2. The relative proportion of those who were not working before the pandemic was 57.73%, and after the start of the pandemic, 80.61%. In other words, the pandemic resulted in an increase of 39.62% of this proportion among respondents.3. 261 (86.71%) are beneficiaries of the Bolsa Família Program, and 30 respondents (9.96%) are not beneficiaries of any social program of the Federal Government..4. 180 immigrants who did not request emergency assistance. Of these, 78 (43.33%) said they did not ask because they tried to access the site by phone or computer and were not successful; 74 respondents (41.11%) said they did not apply because they are not from the group that can have access to this benefit and 11 respondents (6.11%) said they did not ask because they needed help to apply and they could not find anyone to help them.
Policy or intervention associate: PL 2699/2020, authored by Deputy Fernanda Melchionna, which seeks to institute “emergency measures for migratory regularization in the context of the COVID19 pandemic”. This PL, benefited by the work of migrant associations and immigrant reception entities, is based on the understanding that: The COVID-19 pandemic and its severe and lasting socioeconomic impacts tend to further deepen the exclusion and vulnerability of immigrants and refugees, especially those with irregular migratory status, face in Brazil. In addition to harming these people's living conditions, irregular migration threatens the effectiveness of public policies in the fight against the pandemic and the economic crisis in the country, and it is urgent that this Parliament take initiatives to remedy it. It is notorious that this pandemic has affected the most vulnerable populations in different ways around the world, and it is known that migrants and refugees have always been among the people facing the greatest challenges in accessing services and public policies. Still, according to the International Labor Organization, when they manage to find a job, immigrants mostly also face alarming informality and precarious work conditions.
Conclusions: 1. Lack of official data on Covid-19 cases and deaths among international immigrants in Brazil. This scarcity, as we have seen, is an expression of a structural xenophobia, which conditions the invisibility of foreigners in hospital records and which is added to the structural racism itself, considering that race/color is not mandatory in these same records..2. The absence of such information, on the one hand, hinders the identification of the specificities of race/color and nationality, thus making it difficult to elaborate specific public policies for blacks, browns, blacks and immigrants, on the other This side generates mobilizations, both institutional and civil society itself, which are important and extremely necessary for social and labor interactions based on welcoming, decent work and the universality of rights in Brazil.3. The initiatives of civil society itself, especially those led by immigrants, have been of fundamental importance so that the strategies to confront Covid-19 in Brazil take into account the specificities of the migrant population..4. The current scenario requires theoretical reflection on this and other points capable of unveiling the new and complex dimensions of the relationship between human mobility and epidemiological emergencies.

author: Niembro and Calá 2021
title: El potencial impacto económico de la pandemia por COVID-19 en las regiones argentinas y sus patrones productivos sectoriales en el periodo abril-junio de 2020
Objective(s): To describe the evolution of these potential impacts between the months of April and June 2020 is analyzed, which comprise the quarter with the greatest economic contraction in the country after the interruption of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: Index of territorial economic affectation by COVID-19 (IAET-COVID): a) the sectoral productive structure of the different provinces and AEL in terms of salaried employment registered in the private sector; b) the degree of operability of each sector; c) the mobility of workers in the different provinces and AEL; and d) the possibility of remote work in the different activities and sectors.
Main Results: 1. The economic impact on the provinces as a whole is falling over time..2. Those affected, predictably, are areas specialized in tourism and in various industries that were restricted in the period considered. Several of these Local Economic Areas (AELs) also have an extractive profile of natural resources, such as oil and minerals, which have been limited both by the pandemic and by the previous sectoral crisis in the case of hydrocarbons..3. The productive pattern of the most and least affected AELs shows relatively low levels of diversification, with a type of specialization that leans towards less affected and less affected sectors, respectively..4. The production patterns most affected by the pandemic and isolation are those linked to tourism, some extractive activities and various heavy industries that were restricted in their operation..5. Due to the IAET calculation method, the recovery over time may be reflecting improvements in sector operations at the country level..6. The recovery of labor mobility in the context of productive patterns - which on average were more affected by the pandemic and isolation (in shades of red and orange) - tends to be slower than in the least impacted patterns (in shades of orange and green).
Policy or intervention associate: Preventive and Compulsory Social Isolation (ASPO)
Conclusions: 1. The scarcity of data or official statistics that allow us to measure the regional economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, especially in many developing countries, not only represents a problem of academic interest, but also a limitation for the correct management of policies in this critical context..2. The application of strict restrictions for weeks in industrial and commercial activities not considered essential, even in cities with few or no confirmed cases of COVID-19, deserves to be rethought, since it implied very unequal regional impacts according to the type and degree of productive specialization of each region.

author: M. A. dos Santos, Oliveira, and Oliveira-Cardoso 2020
title: Inconfidências de abril: impacto do isolamento social na comunidade trans em tempos de pandemia de COVID-19
Objective(s): To analyze the impacts of social distancing measures in the trans community, seeking to offer subsidies to articulate an understanding that favors an ethical-political management of the pandemic
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The results were analyzed considering the socio-political context of the country and the government management of the health crisis, considering that the meanings about the impacts of the pandemic are produced in the social fabric in which trans lives and bodies take place.
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. “Trans people were made invisible and continue to be forgotten during the pandemic”. The pandemic fosters a space-time of exception, which tends to deepen pre-existing social and gender contradictions and inequalities, intensifying transphobia and the systematic violation of transgender people's rights, including the right to health..2. “Trans sex workers are literally desperate because they can't earn a living. In public spaces, the need to make public policy for these people was never mentioned” (participant)..3. The various facets of exclusion intersect. Social exclusion. Economic exclusion. Digital Exclusion..4. “A quarantine is going on and poor people cannot survive. Then they return to the streets, take crowded buses, crowd into bank lines, where they will get infected and transmit the virus to other people”. .5. WHO recommends that people avoid being in crowded and poorly ventilated environments, “but many transgender people live in precarious housing conditions”..6. The body that harbors HIV is a source of stigma and a locus of psychological suffering in interactional processes, and this stigmatization path is repeating itself with SARS-CoV-2, as it is displaced to the periphery and it reaches the most vulnerable bodies and the least capable of offering resistance..7. The pandemic has also exposed the situation of women who have been more exposed to episodes of domestic and family violence, and who are faced with the total absence of institutional care, support and integral protection policies for themselves and their children..8. Most LGBTs do not live with their families. Transgender women were and continue to be invisible and are now out of work, without income”. With the pandemic, they suddenly found themselves deprived of their livelihood. The violent and abusive discrimination they are subjected to in their families contributes to trans people becoming more dependent on social support networks and, for this reason, they may have negative experiences with social isolation, accentuating feelings of loneliness and helplessness triggered by the omission of the public power
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. It is already known that the pandemic is accentuating asymmetries in the hierarchical relationships of social and gender inequality, exacerbating historical disparities and deepening preexisting inequities..2. The silence that hovers in Brazilian society regarding the devastating consequences of the pandemic on the lives of trans people highlights its persistent social invisibility..3. It also shows the perverse face of the chronic indifference of the middle and upper social strata in relation to the living conditions of marginalized population segments..4. The virus has been reconditioned and converted into a powerful instrument of domination, oppression, and necropolitical exploitation..5. Social isolation measures have also produced violence, as well as other risks and abuses against people in which the sex-gender system does not conform to the cis-heteronormative pattern, with a dramatic increase in lethal violence and the number of suicides among young transgender people and other LGBTQIA+..6. Activism, in the midst of the challenges of combating Covid-19, appears in the participants' speeches as a confluence of efforts to protect the lives of those who struggle for a fair and shared life, while democracy was hit and vilified by largest representative of the Republic in its April inconfidences.
Funding sources: Research Productivity Scholarship from the National Council for Scientific and Technological Development – CNPq, PQ-1A

author: Núñez-Cortés et al. 2021
title: Social determinants of health associated with severity and mortality in patients with COVID-19.
Objective(s): To determine the relationship between SDH and COVID-19 severity and mortality. .To Identify the relationship between underlying comorbidities and mortality and severity caused by COVID-19.
Population: COVID-19 patients in a public hospital (patients outpatient and hospitalized patients)
Sample size: n=1,012 cases with Laboratory confirmed COVID-19.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Normality: Shapiro-Wilk test..2. Socks and standard deviations of the quantitative variables and percentages of the categorical variables..3. Comparison of categorical variables: chi square test..4. Association between mortality and severity of COVID-19 and DSS: odds ratio (OR), with a 95% confidence interval (95% CI).
Type of social stratification: Main variable: Mortality and severity..Others variables: gender (male, female)/ age (<65 years, = 65 years)/ secondary education (completed or not)/ work condition (active, inactive)/ income economic (<USD 320, = USD 320), state of disability (mental, intellectual or sensory) / the category of adult institutionalized.
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Gender/sex.-Education.-Socioeconomic status.-Plus: Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).
Main Results: 1. The average age was 64.2 ± 17.5 years. A total of 364 (36%) patients were hospitalized and 70 patients (6.9%) they were admitted to the ICU. (see Table 1).2. Mortality of the total sample was 14.5%, while the mortality of the hospitalized cases was 39.3%..3. A significant association was found between DSS and COVID-19 mortality and severity. .4. In relation to mortality, a large effect was observed age = 65 years (OR = 24, 95% CI = 14.7-39.2, p <0.001), educational level (OR = 9.6, CI 95% = 4.6-20.3, p <0.001), work condition inactive (OR = 16.3, 95% CI = 9.8-27.3, p <0.001) and lower income (OR = 8.5, CI 95% = 5.1-14.4, p <0.001)..5. An analysis adjusted by age maintained a significant association with inactivity employment (OR = 6.1, 95% CI = 2.2-16.8, p<0.001) and lower income (OR = 6.8, 95% CI = 1.9-23.9, p = 0.001). .6. Disability status also showed a large effect associated with mortality (OR = 8.3, 95% CI = 4.7-14.4, p <0.001). .7. In regarding severity, a measure of large effect of educational level (OR = 9.4, 95% CI = 4.4-20.3, p <0.001). (see Table 2).8. The most prevalent comorbidities in deceased patients were hypertension (78.9%), diabetes (44.9%) and cardiovascular diseases (24.5%). A large effect measure was observed for hypertension (OR = 10.7, 95% CI = 7.0-16.4, p = 0.001) and cerebrovascular diseases (OR = 8.2, 95% CI = 4.5-15, p = 0.001). (see Table 3).
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Structural social determinants of health (SDH) had a strong association with mortality and severity of COVID-19, in particularly age, educational level, unemployment and economic income. .2. Socioeconomic conditions can influence both the health of the population as the individual characteristics of the persons. .3. It is important that SDH are considered a public health priority and focus political efforts on reducing health inequalities for future generations.

author: Villela 2021
title: Household crowding hampers mitigating the transmission of SARS-CoV-2.
Journal: Revista da Sociedade Brasileira de Medicina Tropical
Objective(s): To evaluate the association between household crowding and COVID-19 incidence
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Linear and Poisson regression analyses: associations between indices of household crowding (high, average, low)  and COVID-19 incidence estimates.
Type of social stratification: -Levels of household crowding (high, average, low).-The proportion of households with = 3 residents per room: low, average, and high crowding levels.
Main Results: 1. The mean value of the cumulative incidence in the given period was 88 cases per 100,000 inhabitants..2. Municipalities with a high index of household crowding had higher incidence estimates, whereas those with low and average indices had very similar distributions of cumulative incidence estimates. (see Figure 1).3. A linear regression analysis that used the incidence estimate as the outcome and household crowding index (low, average, high) as the explanatory variable revealed that the group with a high index of household crowding was associated with a significantly higher COVID-19 incidence (an excess of 461 persons per 100,000; 95% confidence interval (CI): 371-558 cases per 100,000; p-value<0.001) than the group with a low index of household crowding..4. Poisson regression analysis that used the cumulative number of confirmed cases as the outcome, proportion of households with = 3 residents per room as the explanatory variable (log-transformed), and city population as the offset (log-transformed) revealed a significantly increasing effect of household crowding on COVID-19 incidence (factor: 0.824, 95% CI: 0.819-0.831).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The findings in this study demonstrated that household crowding may be a potential factor that could hamper transmission mitigation measures by evaluating the link between cumulative COVID-19 incidence and an indicator of household crowding..2. There are potential factors that may be considered as confounding variables and warrant further research, namely sociodemographic structures in municipalities, as well as local adherence to mitigation strategies.
Funding sources: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico (Ref. 309569/2019-2).

author: Caqueo-Urízar et al. 2020
title: Mental health and the COVID-19 pandemic in Chile.
Journal: Psychological Trauma:Theory, Research, Practice, and Policy
Objective(s): NA
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination.-time-dependent relationships
Main Results: 1. The mental health indicators in Chile prior to the outbreak indicated high levels of alcohol and substance abuse.2. A high index of depressive disorders among adolescents and adults.3. Chileans' mental health has been affected by aggravated socioeconomic and environmental conditions, such as natural disasters, significant social and economic inequalities, lack of trust in government institutions, and disparity in the access to health care and education.4. It is likely that the levels of stress and anxiety will peak during the social distancing, especially in contexts of social and economic vulnerability. This may lead to intimate partner violence, depression, suicide, self-harm, and harmful alcohol/drug use .5. Civil society, especially schools and faculties of psychology in many universities, have offered online psychological care services.6. Various nongovernmental organizations have also set up psychological  support networks to deal with anxiety and violence arising from this pandemic.7. The palliative measures have not been sufficient to support the economic decline that many of these small businesses are experiencing..8. Some religious institutions also provide social support to people in need by sharing food and other basic products.
Policy or intervention associate: 1. The Chilean government has provided some financial support for small and medium-sized businesses to try to maintain the jobs and wages of the workers..2. The government has adopted a multidisciplinary approach by involving the different ministries and universities in Chile in developing a national mental health strategy for COVID-19.
Conclusions: 1. The mental health challenges posed by COVID-19 are undoubtedly far reaching. As key public health responses such as testing, contact tracing, isolation, and management of confirmed cases of COVID-19 are being ramped up, it is expedient to prioritize measures to safeguard the mental health of Chileans.

author: Martines et al. 2021
title: Detecting space-time clusters of COVID-19 in Brazil: mortality, inequality, socioeconomic vulnerability, and the relative risk of the disease in Brazilian municipalities.
Objective(s): To detect new emerging clusters of COVID-19 in 5,570 Brazilian municipalities, contrasting two time intervals, from February 25 to June 7, 2020 and from February 25 to July 20, 2020.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Non-spatial modeling: To analyze the correlation between the RR and the selected independent variables, They used the RR value of each municipality located in the space–time clusters, from February 25, 2020, to July 20, 2020 (n = 3304). They evaluate the effect of socioeconomic variables and mortality rate on RR using a Generalized Linear Model (GLM).2. Spatial modeling: They applied the Lagrange Multiplier (LM) test to identify the model with the strongest explanatory power for the variable Y. A spatial regression may capture some of the spatial effects that affect the behavior of the Y variable; if both models are significant, the best model should be selected according to the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC)
Type of social stratification: -The GINI index.-The Brazilian Social Vulnerability Index (SVI)
Main Results: 1. Emerging space–time clusters of COVID-19 in Brazil from February 25 and June 07, 2020, with relative risk (RR) greater than 1: Figure 2 and Table 1 + Table 2 (3 states with RR >1).2. It detected nine emerging space–time clusters of COVID-19 with a RR>1, which occurred in all Brazilian regions (p<0.001) for this second period (147 days), while two more clusters were detected compared to the first period of analysis: Figure 3 and Table 3 and 4. .3. The results obtained through the GLM showed that there was a signifcant positive correlation between the predictor variables in relation to the relative risk at the level of the municipalities belonging to the nine emerging clusters. The GLM result showed that all variables have a statistically impact on the RR of the municipalities located in the clusters. For each one-unit increase in the GINI, For each one-unit increase in the GINI variable, the relative risk increases by 2.02, while the impact of SVI is 0.82, and mortality rate is 0.021.: Figure 4. .4. The results of the LM-Lag showed that all variables analyzed have a statistically signifcant efect for RR, except for the SVI: Table 9.5. According to the results of the model, the variables GINI and mortality rate have a signifcant efect (p<0.001) on the relative risk of municipalities within the clusters. The GINI variable has the greatest positive direct (1.280) and indirect (1.414) efects, resulting in a total efect of 2.695. This indicates an increase in the RR within the municipalities due to inequality, but mainly due to the role of spillovers from neighboring municipalities. The same pattern was also observed for the mortality rate for the direct (0.015), indirect (0.016), and total (0.032) efects. In the case of SVI, no signifcant efects were observed for RR: Table 10.
Policy or intervention associate: Preventive measures and targeted interventions to combat the pandemic in Brazil
Conclusions: 1. Therefore, this space–time approach to detect emerging clusters will allow decision-makers to identify statistically signifcant hotspots of COVID-19 cases..2. This approach may also allow authorities to pay attention to municipalities that still have little-to-no cases, so they can be prepared to face the burdens of COVID-19. .3. This can improve the management of resources to the States and Health Regions.
Funding sources: University of Eastern Finland (UEF) including Kuopio University Hospital.

author: Torres et al. 2021
title: Impact of COVID-19 Pandemic on Sexual Minority Populations in Brazil: An Analysis of Social/Racial Disparities in Maintaining Social Distancing and a Description of Sexual Behavior.
Objective(s): To understand how social distancing measures and the COVID-19 pandemic are impacting their personal lives, sexual behavior, and PrEP/ART access and use
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Chi-square test to compare sexual behavior, Pre-exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) eligibility criteria and HIV perceived risk between PrEP users during social distancing period (on PrEP vs not on PrEP)..2. Logistic regression modeling to assess the factors associated with unattainability of maintaining social distancing.
Type of social stratification: -Age at the time of the survey (categorized in 3 brackets: 18 to 24; 25 to 35 and > 35 years).-Gender: cisgender men/ transgender men/ transgender women/ non-binary/gender fuid.-Sexual orientation: Gay/ bisexual/ heterosexual/other (e.g. pansexual, asexual).-Race/color: white/ black/ pardo or mixed-black/ native or indigenous /Asian.-Schooling: low [=12 years or completed secondary school or less] / high [>12 years or more than secondary school]
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Gender/sex.-Education.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. Black/Pardo/native race (adjusted odds ratio [aOR] 1.23; 95% confdence interval [CI] 1.05–1.44), lower schooling (aOR 1.47; 95% CI 1.23–1.75), lower income (aOR 1.30; 95% CI 1.03–1.66), and binge drinking (aOR 1.28; 95% CI 1.09–1.49) were associated with unattainability of maintain- ing social distancing in the logistic multivariate analysis.2. 17.2% (138/800) reported impact of social distancing measures on antiretroviral therapy (ART); most frequent reasons were: fear of going out (68/138; 49.2%), non-availability of public transportation (29/138; 21.0%), and closing of health care unit (21/138; 15.2%)..3. Social distancing measures had highly impacted most of participants’ lives (2195; 63.0%), and the economic aspect was the most affected (1474; 42.3%)..4. Drug use was reported by 23.1% (n=806), and the most common were marijuana (586; 16.8%) and cocaine (233; 6.7%); 30.4% reported increased use of illicit drugs during social distancing period..5. Non-white individuals accounted 44.0% (n=1534), about a third (1252; 35.9%) had low schooling and 38.0% (n=1323), low family income
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Maintaining social distancing is challenging, particularly for the most vulnerable sex with men (MSM) and transgender/non binary (TGNB) people..2. These individuals may also sufer the biggest consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic on the health care system, thus impacting their HIV care and prevention.3. Tailored social, economic and mental health support policies during the COVID-19 pandemic should be made available to those individuals.

author: Santos Ferreira and de Camargo 2021
title: Vulnerabilidade da população negra brasileira frente à evolução da pandemia por COVID-19
Objective(s): To identify the municipalities’ socioeconomic vulnerability in the State of Ceará, the epicenter of the COVID-19 pandemic in the Northeast of Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis: the indices ‘broad socio-economic vulnerability’ (BV), ‘territorial vulnerability’ (TV) and ‘dynamic vulnerability’ (DV).
