Type of social stratification: -Broad socio-economic vulnerability (BV): 1: ‘position in the supply chain' / 2: ‘potential of human contact’ ( the size of the companies, the possibility of working from home, and the professionals’ direct contact with customers or other employees.) / 3:  level of internationalization).-Territorial vulnerability (TV): demographic density (D)/ tourist mobility (M)/  indicator of the municipalities’ social development (ID) / human development index (HDI).-Dynamic vulnerability’ (DV): period of the infection’s duration.-Local economy: comprises 610 (economic activities in the primary /secondary/ tertiary sectors).-Tourist mobility.
Main Results: 1. Fortaleza leads with an index of 296,864 formally employed persons, followed by Juazeiro do Norte (24,700), Maracanaú (18,500), Sobral (18,300), and Caucaia (15,600). As for territorial characteristics, these municipalities are among the ten with the highest  human development index (HDI), tourist mobility, and demographic density of the state..2. The high HDI was not sufficient to reduce the strong effects of tourist mobility and demographic density on the vulnerability of municipalities..3. That even shorter periods presented higher vulnerability indices, as is the case of the scenario between days 120 and 180 of the residual phase (GDP: BRL 11.5 billion; employed persons: 104.2 thousand)..4. Social distancing establishes less dynamic vulnerabilities both for the value of productive activities and for formal jobs in the state.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The low Human Development Index and the reduced economic dynamism of the other municipalities, explain the development of a relationship of dependence, which limits the state’s.2. This ends up in increasing insecurity, jeopardizing the state’s action to face the pandemic without serious economic repercussions..3. Social distancing makes the economy less exposed. This phenomenon usually occurs during the first 120 days,.4. Measurement of vulnerability indices assists in decision making regarding the strategies to reduce the susceptibility of these areas..5. Interregional development policies must be conducted with the aim of decentralizing this dependency between municipalities and capital city.6. It is essential for some municipalities to implement instruments to encourage companies and generate wealth directly. In other cases, the government must intensify measures to support and minimize the economic effects of the pandemic, such as the loss of jobs.

author: Barbosa et al. 2020
title: Incidência e mortalidade por COVID-19 na população idosa brasileira e sua relação com indicadores contextuais: um estudo ecológico
Journal: Revista Brasileira de Geriatria e Gerontologia
Objective(s): To analyze the incidence of and mortality caused by COVID-19 in the older population in Brazil and its relationship with contextual variables
City or municipality: Amazonas, Alagoas, Bahia, Ceará, the Federal District, Espírito Santo, Goiás, Maranhão, Minas Gerais, Pará, Paraíba, Paraná, Pernambuco, Piauí, Rio de Janeiro, Rio Grande do Norte, Rio Grande do Sul , Rondônia, Roraima, Santa Catarina, São Paulo and Sergipe.
Population: Confirmed cases of COVID-19 and deaths
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The variables were analyzed in a descriptive and bivariate manner, through Spearman correlation analysis, considering a significance level of 5%.
Type of social stratification: -Number of hospital beds per 1000 inhabitants.-Number of doctors per 1000 inhabitants.-Percentage of coverage by the Family Health Strategy.-Percentage of Primary Health Care coverage.-Rates of aging and overaging.-Proportion of older adults.-Human development index (HDI).-Percentage of black (Afro-Brazilian) and brown (mixed race) skinned people.-Income ratio and demographic density per km2
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Place of residence.-Socioeconomic status
Main Results: 1. The state of São Paulo has the highest number of cases and deaths from COVID-19, with 82,161 cases and 6,163 deaths. The state with the lowest number of cases due to the disease is Roraima with 2,514 cases, and this state also has the lowest number of deaths due to the disease, with 86 .2. The state of Ceará has the highest number of cases of COVID-19 among older adults with 6,896 cases, and the state of Roraima has the lowest number of cases in the older population, with 198. Although the state of São Paulo did not present case data by age group, the highest number of deaths among older adults was registered in the state, with 4,495. The lowest number of deaths in this age group was also observed in the state of Roraima, with 43 (Table 1). .3. The highest proportion of cases and deaths among older adults, respectively, were observed in the states of Pará (22.36%) and Rio Grande do Sul (84.44%), and the lowest proportions, respectively, were in the states of Bahia (3.90%) and Amazonas (37.66%) (Table 1). .4. 12.47% of the population in the evaluated states is made up of older adults, with an average mean aging rate of 58.40. In contrast, Primary Health Care coverage is around 78.47% of the population, with an average rate of 1.65 doctors and 2.38 hospital beds for every 1000 inhabitants..5. The highest rate of accumulated incidence and mortality due to COVID-19 was registered in the state of Pará, with 763.37 cases per 100,000 older adults and 219.06 deaths per 100,000 older adults. The lowest accumulated incidence was observed in Bahia with 28.24 cases per 100,000 older adults and the lowest mortality rate was in the state of Minas Gerais (5.16 deaths per 100,000 older adults). Regarding lethality, it was found that the highest rate was registered in Bahia (56.46%) and the lowest in Santa Cantarina (8.05%) (Table 3)..6. When assessing the correlation between the indicators of cases and deaths in older adults and independent sociodemographic variables, coverage by health services and population aging indicators, a significant negative moderate correlation was observed between the accumulated incidence and mortality rates, respectively, with the aging index (rho = -0.662; p=0.001 and rho = -0.520; p=0.013) and the proportion of older adults (rho = -0.659; p=0.002 and rho = -0.502; p=0.017). .7. The accumulated incidence and mortality rates showed, respectively, a significant positive correlation with the proportion of black and brown skinned people (rho=0.524; p=0.018 and rho=0.558; p=0.007) and with the income ratio (rho=0.665; p=0.0001 and rho=0.683; p<0.001) (Table 4).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The COVID-19 epidemic in Brazil has revealed that, in the states analyzed, the accumulated incidence and mortality in the older population are related to demographic issues - age, skin color/race and income, highlighting the need for specific care and monitoring of older adults. .2. At the present moment, when social distancing is considered a priority strategy for disease control, Primary Health Care (PHC) becomes an essential pillar for the care of older adults, both for its principles and its territorial scope – especially in the areas of greatest vulnerability. .3. This demonstrates the need for the structuring and strengthening of this level of health care, which plays an extremely important role in reducing health inequities. .4. It is important to rethink the working processes of PHC professionals and to introduce information and communication technologies as a complementary strategy for monitoring the health of older adults, which have been shown to be an important tool for integrated healthcare at this level.

author: Cozzi 2021
title: Inequalities, resistances and COVID-19 in popular neighborhoods in the city of Rosario, Argentina
Objective(s): To describe the difficulties identified by referents of social, community, political or human rights organizations in relation to the health emergency and, especially, compliance with the measures of social isolation
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Social capital .-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. People complied with the isolation order not for fear of the virus (COVID-19), but for fear of reprisals from the public force.2. Compliance with mandatory isolation was linked to a decrease in the daily sustenance of food and hygiene products, with an increase in overcrowding and poor living conditions (houses included, over population, among others)
Policy or intervention associate: Political-institutional response to the pandemic
Conclusions: 1. Mandatory social isolation has differential impacts and shows long-standing structural inequalities that deepen in critical contexts like this one..3. Collective resistance strategies were created (activism against police violence or popular organization for the provision of food), among other novelty that are inscribed as sediments of these accumulated social experiences.

author: Staniscuaski et al. 2021
title: Gender, Race and Parenthood Impact Academic Productivity During the COVID-19 Pandemic: From Survey to Action
Objective(s): To provide a comprehensive assessment of the various elements of academic productivity relevant to a wide range of knowledge areas and research institutions.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: -Gender: Male/Female.-Race/Ethnicity: White /Black /Asian /Indigenous /ND.-Region.-Work setting: workplace closure/ remote activities/ online teaching.-Children care.-Productivity during the pandemic.-Impacted their remote work: childcare / routine care and/or homework assistance/ children with disabilities/ elderly care, /household chores
Main Results: 1. Manuscript submission among male academics was less affected by the pandemic circumstances than that among women Manuscript submission among male academics was less affected by the pandemic circumstances than that among women.2. Positive association between women with children and the non-submission of manuscripts. However, no association was observed for women without children..3. No overall race effect (Black vs. White researchers) on productivity during the pandemic period with respect to submissions (? 2 = 2.29, p = 0.1304).4. Significant effect of race and gender on the submission of manuscripts (?2 = 91.01, P < 0.0001) Positive associations were observed between White men and the submission of manuscripts as well as between both Black and White women and the non-submission of manuscripts.5. Significant difference between men and women depending on the age of their youngest child with respect to the submissionof manuscripts . same with meeting deadlines)  2 = 147.95, P < 0.0001).6. Negative association between women whose youngest child ranged from 1 to 6 years old and the submission of manuscripts and lower than that of men with children of the same age (P < 0.001, submissions observed for men whose youngest child’s age ranged from 7 to 12 were higher than that observed for women with children of the same ages (P < 0.001).7. Respondents were asked whether the pandemic situation impacted how they met deadlines. There was a significant difference between men and women (? 2 = 21.73, P < 0.0001).8 . White men reported a negative impact less frequently than Black men and Black and White women (P < 0.001, Bonferroni post hoc test for all comparisons).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. White mothers and Black females, regardless of whether they are mothers, are the groups taking the strongest hit in academia..2. Working mothers, including those in academia, might be disproportionately affected by the COVID-19 crisis. This exacerbated disparity during the pandemic reflects.3. Significant barriers to women’s progress include gender stereotypes and implicit gender bias, which are invisible and powerful forces preventing women from advancing in their careers..4. Young children require much more attention and care, and parents face additional demands related to having time to homeschool children during the social isolation period..5. Black female academics, regardless of the motherhood factor, are the group most affected by the pandemic circumstances..6. White women without children was not affected as much as that of Black women without children, but in both groups, the effect was higher than that observed for childless men

author: Paiva and Miguel 2021
title: Overcoming enduring inequalities in Global Value Chains? Interpreting the case of Brazil’s Covid-19 vaccine supply through a chess metaphor
Objective(s): To show how the highly unequal vaccine distribution between the Global North and the Global South is shaped by the concentration of high-added value activities of vaccine development and production in the Global North and their nationalistic economic policies
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Brazil has faced several problems with the secondary role of the local companies in the VSC. Ever since the first vaccines were approved by the national health agency, the volume of products being delivered in the country has been insufficient for speedy vaccination of the whole population..2. Brazil is one of the countries most affected by the pandemic. When the number of cases accelerated, the country faced a lack of beds in intensive care units in the majority of hospitals. To reduce the number of cases, the country needed an intense immunisation programme, but this was delayed due to government resistance and inefficiency in planning and procuring the amount of vaccines needed.There are two possible scenarios for the healthcare GVCs: .1. Global South actors will remain unimportant actors in GVCs. The concentration of product development and production will remain in the Global North. This case does not consider immunisation and healthcare services on a global scale, and prioritises vaccine and medical goods distribution in advanced economies. Current national policies reflecting this approach will increase regional inequalities and vulnerability..2. From the South will seek to upgrade their activities, thereby creating a more polycentric configuration, leading to GVCs with lower power concentration in terms of geographical location. Thus, vaccines and medical goods controlled by actors in the South will also be distributed to these countries as other examples of GVCs. A potential increase in the number of healthcare sources could lead to more balanced access to health in the world. This would result from increased innovation, production capacity and distribution in low- and middle-income countries, thereby expediting their recovery.
Policy or intervention associate: Covid-19 vaccine supply
Conclusions: 1. To be better prepared for risks in the future and to overcome some of the barriers against the more vulnerable economies that render them and local companies ‘mere pawns’, governments in low- and middle-income countries should invest in industrial infrastructure, systems reforms and technological standardisation. .2. The current pandemic has revealed how decisions concentrated in the Global North may lead the world to a highly risky situation in terms of health, economic and social issues. Moreover, current ‘friction’ related to nationalism, asymmetric power and short-term policies may further exacerbate current inequalities and increase future world vulnerabilities.

author: Durán 2021
title: COVID-19 and heterogeneous vulnerabilities in the Peruvian labor market: implications for social inequalities and for gender gaps
Objective(s): To estimate the diferentiated impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on a set of labor market indicators, such as labor participation, occupational categories, informality, and number of hours worked.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis of before and after the start of the Peruvian lockdown for the main labor characteristics of individuals, intersecting them with other characteristics associated with vulnerability
Type of social stratification: -Urban/rural area .-Geographic region.-Headed by: Male/Women.-Headship or household management, (monoparental/ biparental household).-Gender gaps.-Level o education: secondary education / incomplete higher education/ incomplete primary education.-Employment: informal/ formal / unemployment.
Main Results: 1. Principal adults, ( that takes decision in the household) men and women, sufered a drop of about 26 percentage points ( in employment) with respect to pre- pandemic levels.2. Male employment levels experienced a much greater recovery (22 percentage points compared to the second quarter) than female employment levels (only 14 percentage points compared to the second quarter)..3. Lower percentage of households headed by a lone female register participation in the labor market. Considering that 71% of these households have children (compared to only 27% of households headed by a lone male; data nor pre- sented in the graph).4.  Women and young people represent the higer risk sector in emplouyment matters.proportion of women employed in high-risk sectors is 56% the percentage of young people aged 15–29 in high-risk sectors is 30%. .5. Urban areas is similar in magnitude and direction to what happened in the national average, while in rural areas the drop in employment was much smaller, (...) However in rural areas (...) Female job loss in the second quarter was nearly three times greater than male job loss..6. Greatest drops in employment occurred for households headed by women..7. (...) after pandemic times (..) female proportion of unpaid family workers was higher than it was at the beginning of the year, while for men the category that has not fully recovered is that of employers..8. In urban areas the greatest change was a decrease of the gap in the category of wage earners, with virtually no change of the gap in unpaid family workers. In rural areas, on the other hand, practically all gender gaps increased, in particular those among unpaid family workers and independent workers..9. Formal and informal employment decreased in about the same amount among men, while for women the reduction in informal employment was between 3 and 4 times greater than the reduction in formal employment..10. The proportion of men working between 40 and 60 hours per week fell by 15 percentage points, while the proportion working more than 60 hours per week fell by 13 percentage points.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Gradual economic reactivation worsened the gender gap in employment..2. Reason why women were less likely to recover compared to men is because of the pre-existing gendered nature of the labor market, where women are typically employed in more vulnerable kinds of employment compared to men and hence, it was more difcult or took longer for them to go back to work..3. Heads of households without a partner, who live in rural areas, are the group that has borne the greatest burden in dealing with the economic and social disruptions that accompany public health crises..4. Total or partial confnement demands that women dedicate more time to housework and caring for others, which hinders their reintegration into the labor market...5. Although in the third quarter commerce and services were being reactivated, caring for their children probably stopped these women from rejoining the labor force..6. The policies that the government implements in the coming months, or that it designs for the next couple of years, prioritize those that were already in a disadvantageous position before the pandemic..7. Specifc cash transfers for women with the aforementioned vulnerabilities could be a short-term policy option.

author: Gianella, Gideon, and Romero 2021
title: What does COVID-19 tell us about the Peruvian health system?
Journal: Revista canadiense de estudios sobre el desarrollo / Revue canadienne d'études du développement
Objective(s): To analyses what the COVID-19 pandemic reveals in the case of Peru, with particular attention to the structural weaknesses of the health system, namely its fragmentation and persistent inequalities, which have undermined an effective government’s response to the pandemic.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. COVID-19 has exposed, and even intensified, pre-existing weaknesses of the health system..2. The impact of COVID-19 in Peru has been unevenly spread among the population, given the centrality of the social health determinants in the transmission and impact of the virus.3. Metropolitan Lima statistics reveal the highest death rates in poorer districts..4. Wealthy districts, with a large percentage of senior citizens (which are population at risk), have recorded lower mortality rates than poor districts with younger populations.5. COVID-19 has exposed the state’s weak capacity to deliver services in the public interest and ensure inequalities are effectively addressed..6. Within Peru, the indigenous peoples in the Amazon region are among those who have suffered most from the epidemic. The lack of access to health services, water and sanitation, as well as the high rates of poverty and child malnutrition, once again placed these ethnic groups in a situation of greater vulnerability.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Neither the current development model, nor mechanisms for global health reporting have been able to prevent the crisis generated by COVID-19 in Peru.2. The pandemic has starkly shown that the need to effectively address inequalities must be firmly placed at the centre of future endeavours..3. Given the deeply embedded inequalities within the Peruvian health system, questions must be asked about the promotion of public private partnerships (PPPs) and its implications for public finances, equity considerations and the effectiveness of the wider health system.

author: de Castilho and Silva 2020
title: Socio-spatial injustices and covid-19 in recife (BRAZIL)
Objective(s): To problematize the COViD-19 pandemic crisis, taking into account social inequalities, reflected in socio-spatial injustices, in a city located in an underdeveloped region, such as Recife, in northeastern Brazil
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. It is the large cities that concentrate the most significant occurrences of the COVID-19 outbreak, which, in turn, expand into their respective surroundings as social contacts and networks structure the organization of life in and between cities (see figure 1).2. The main sources of origin and expansion of the COVID-19 outbreak are located in the largest urban centers in the regions with the highest density of the technical-scientific-informational environment in the country (Southeast), in the Federal District (Brasilia) and in other urban centers that have relevant economic dynamics, interconnected by their respective airports. The same happens on the scale of the municipality of Recife..3. The epicenters of COVID-19 are territories whose technical-scientific-informational means are, therefore, denser, sheltering a large part of the city's dominant and middle classes, that is, people who, having access to the set of goods and services necessary for modern social life, introduced or became “active pioneers” in the spread of the virus in the city upon returning from their international travels..4. Living in slums or stilts, under precarious living conditions, overcrowded houses, informal work, without access to information technologies and with access only to already saturated and precarious public health services, the dominated classes are the least able to react to COVID-19 crisis that is common to everyone, but does not affect everyone in the same way.5. Overcrowding, in confined spaces with an insufficient number of rooms available for families with more than four people, prevents the necessary isolation in case a family member becomes infected with COVID-19. The risk of contamination for these people is very likely, as heads of households have to leave their homes every day in order to get some money to buy food.6. The deficiency in terms of coverage of internet services leaves these people unable to use their creativity in order to seek safe opportunities to obtain some form of income. Finally, the precariousness of public social health services makes it difficult to provide care and follow up on suspected cases of contamination by the above virus..7. The biggest victims of the new coronavirus, in the world and in Brazil, are the poor and black people, which was justified exactly by some of the reasons mentioned above
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. As Brazilian cities have strong territorial inequalities that persist in the historical period of national formation, despite COVID-19 reaching all social classes, the most impoverished classes are the most susceptible to the physical and economic consequences of the ongoing pandemic..2. Currently, this situation is even more aggravated due to the current political situation that deepens socio-territorial inequalities, increases the interest in privatizing essential public services and disrespects labor rights..3. The consequences of the aforementioned socio-territorial inequalities are, therefore, intrinsically related to the main purpose of neolbeira capitalism, which lies in the generation of wealth above all, which is why the territory is permanently used, predominantly, as an economic resource

author: M. M. Santos et al. 2021
title: Brazilian Older People Hospitalized by COVID-19: Characteristics and Prognostic Factors in a Retrospective Cohort Study
Objective(s): To understand survival and its predictive factors for death by COVID-19
Population: Hospitalized older people aged 60 years or older confirmed having COVID-19
Sample size: n=12,199 (Data from the national health surveillance system from open, anonymous, and public data)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Multiple Cox proportional-hazards model.
Type of social stratification: -Age: 60-69/70-79/80 or more.-Gender: Female/Male.-Race: White or Asian/Black or Mixed.-Level of education: Illiterate or low education/Intermediate-Elementary education/Higher education.-Geographic: urban/rural.-Clinic
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Education.-Gender/sex.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination.-Time-dependent relationships
Main Results: 1. The mean time of survival was of 13.13 days (95% CI = [12.83, 13.42]), with a median of 9.00 (95% CI = [8.76, 9.24]). .2. The overall survival rate estimated was 71.26% (95% CI = [70.43%, 72.08%]) in 5 days of hospitalization and 47.70% (95% CI = [46.72%, 48.67%]) in 10 days.3. A significantly lower estimate of survival in 10 days for ages above 80 years, 37.3% (95% CI = [35.6%, 39.0%]); was Black or Mixed-race, 37.2% (95% CI = [35.4%, 39.0%]); has a lower education level, 40.6% (95% CI = [38.3%, 42.8%]); and lives in rural areas, 39.0% (95% CI = [31.9%, 45.9%])..-Comparing at the same cutoff point in 10 days, survival estimates were significantly lower when the patients present different symptoms.-use of antiviral showed better survival, 50.2% (95% CI = [48.7%, 51.6%]).-The covariates of the clinical signs showed a better estimate of the survival for patients in 10 days when they presented fever, 49.3% (95% CI = [48.2%, 50.5%]); cough, 49.5% (95% CI = [48.4%, 50.5%]); a sore throat, 48.9% (95% CI = [46.6%, 51.2%]); or diarrhea, 53.0% (95% CI = [50.0%, 55.9%].5. After assessing the proportional risks:.- the statistically significant covariates that presented the highest risk of death were the age of 80 years or more, 1.62 (95% CI = [1.53, 1.71]); Black or Mixed-race, 1.59 (95% CI = [1.51, 1.69]); lower education, 2.05 (95% CI = [1.79, 2.35]); living in rural areas, 1.29 (95% CI = [1.10, 1.52]), and others.- Patients had a better prognosis when they presented signs or symptoms such as fever, 0.88 (95% CI = [0.83, 0.93]); cough, 0.87 (95% CI = [0.82, 0.93]); sore throat, 0.94 (95% CI = [0.88, 0.98]); diarrhea, 0.86 (95% CI = [0.80, 0.93]); or use of antiviral, 0.91 (95% CI = [0.86, 0.96]. .6. No significant differences were found in the survival curves or the proportional risks of the covariables sex, hospital-acquired infection, heart disease, diabetes, if the hospitalization was due to influenza syndrome, vomiting, obesity, pneumopathy, immunodepression, X-ray result, or some type of antiviral.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Older patients who have been confirmed to present COVID-19 infection have a low survival ratio. .2. The prognosis of infection is associated with sociodemographic and hospital predictors..3. These results emphasize the relevance of inequality and access to health services as determinants for death in this segment of the population.
Funding sources: All authors are employed by the government or other public funded institutions, and all expenses were covered by themselves.

author: Hernández-Vásquez, Barrenechea-Pulache, and Azañedo 2021
title: COVID-19 testing in Peru: low access and inequalities
Journal: Journal of Public Health | Oxford Academic
Objective(s): To evaluate the factors associated with performing diagnostic tests in a representative sample of Peruvians with symptoms compatible with COVID-19
Population: People with symptoms compatible with COVID-19
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Reported the prevalence ratios (PR) (obtained by Poisson regression) as measures of association with their 95% confidence intervals (CI).
Type of social stratification: -Regions: Metropolitan Lima/Coast/Andean/Amazon.-Area: Rural/Urban.-Health insurance: Yes/No.-Gender: Men/Women.-Age
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Gender/sex.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).
Main Results: 1. 1142 (4.0%) participants reported having had some symptom of COVID-19 during the 4 weeks prior to the survey. Of these, 50.6% had undergone some COVID-19 test. .2. Age was positively associated with a higher performance of a COVID-19 test (PR: 1.01; 95%CI 1.00–1.01).3. Living in the Amazon in comparison to living in Metropolitan Lima (PR: 0.66; 95%CI 0.48–0.91) and having some form of functional limitation (PR: 0.56; 95%CI 0.32–0.99) were negatively associated with undergoing a diagnostic test. .
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Only half of Peruvians with COVID-19 symptoms during the last 4 weeks had undergone diagnostic tests..2. Those living in the Amazon or with functional limitations had lower access to a diagnostic test, as the result of possible limitations like the health system and socioeconomic inequalities (scarcity of diagnostic tests, lack of infrastructure and trained staff throughout the country, lack of access to social programs, an increase of poverty after a prolonged period of compulsory nationwide quarantine and the informality of the workforce)

author: Lalwani et al. 2021
title: SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence and associated factors in Manaus, Brazil: baseline results from the DETECTCoV-19 cohort study
Objective(s): To determine disease attack rates; and to monitor the serological status of residents of Manaus, and the relevance of demographic and socio-economic factors and their association with the prevalence of infection in a setting of high transmission and low non-pharmacological containment measures.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Poisson regression model with robust variance to estimate prevalence ratios. Variance was corrected per cluster (administrative area), and models were adjusted for sex, age, family income, presence of household members with COVID-19, use of preventive self-medication, and prior COVID-19 diagnosis
Type of social stratification: -Age .-Gender: Male/Female.-Occupation: Professional higher /Professional middle /Worker/informal /Unemployed.-Family income: 0–3 minimum wages /4–6 minimum wages /> 6 minimum wage.-Related to COVID-19 (symptoms since the start of the pandemic / prior diagnosis /preventive self-medication /prescribed medication used to treat symptoms) laboratory results.
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status .-Occupation.-Gender/sex.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage
Main Results: 1. Anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody levels were elevated in symptomatic patients compared with asymptomatic patients, and positively correlated with patient age..2. SARS-CoV-2 antibodies was significantly higher in men compared with women .3. The highest and lowest age-stratified seroprevalence rates were observed in individuals aged between 50 and 59 years and =60 years of age, respectively. .4. Prevalence was higher among the poorest (35.50% vs 24.45% among the wealthiest) (Table 1). .5. Individuals living in detached or conjugated houses had higher SARS-CoV-2 antibody prevalence compared with individuals living in condo houses and apartment buildings.  Households with four or more adults, or with three or more children, had a staggering proportion of positive cases (>40%). .6. Increasing in the number of adults or children in the family household increased the seropositivity rate significantly..7. Individuals with or without comorbidities had similar antibody prevalence..8. Taking self-medication of over-the-counter drugs or controlled drugs to prevent SARS-CoV-2 infection was 38.64%, compared with 25.99% among individuals who did not self-medicate.
Policy or intervention associate: Conflicting stances between the state and federal governments in Brazil on strategies to face the pandemic could have played a role in its course
Conclusions: 1. Socio-economic disparities, as well as inequalities in access to primary health, have amplified the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic..2. Governmental policies that do not consider the syndemic nature of COVID-19 will have disproportionate long-term economic, social, and health consequences for those who are already disadvantaged..3. It is possible solution is to employ centralized isolation in government-sponsored facilities, strict follow-up of diagnosed patients, and their family members and contacts, is recommended to reduce virus transmission.
Funding sources: PL received funding from the Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado do Amazonas (FAPEAM). WHO by the COVID-19 Solidarity Response Fund and the German Federal Ministry of Health COVID-19 scholarships from CAPES. DSSS, TBNM and MFF received scholarships from FAPEAM.

author: Reyes-Vega et al. 2021
title: SARS-CoV-2 prevalence associated to low socioeconomic status and overcrowding in an LMIC megacity: A population-based seroepidemiological survey in Lima, Peru
Objective(s): To estimate the seroprevalence of SARS-CoV-2 in Lima, stratified by age, sex, region, socioeconomic status (SES), overcrowding, and symptoms.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: To estimate prevalence ratios, we fit generalised linear regression models to the survey data, with inverse-probability weighting and design-based standard errors. The outcome distribution for seropositivity was defined by a Poisson distribution with log link function. Multivariable regression models were adjusted for sex, age groups, region and socioeconomic status (SES), defined as potential confounders.
Type of social stratification: -Socioeconomic status: High /Middle-High /Middle /Middle-Low /Low.-Ethnicity (by self-identification): Mestizo /Quechua/White /Other, including Afro-descendant.-Overcrowding: living with six or more people.-Households with water .-% of people with secondary or higher education.-Gender: Male/Female.-Province of residence.-Type of health insurance.-Epidemiological clinical: Symptomatic / aSymptomatic
Main Results: 1. Seroprevalence was similar between men and women (19-8% versus 21-4%, aPR=0-96 [95%CI 0-851-09, p = 0.547]),.2. Seroprevalence was similar across age groups including 60 versus 11 years old (14-6% versus 21-2%, aPR=0-96 [95%CI 0-731-27, p = 0-783].3. Seroprevalence was highest in the lowest socioeconomic status (SES), (25-8%; 95%CI16-636-4), a gradual decrease in SES was associated with a gradual increase in seroprevalence (aPR=2-24 [95%CI 1-273-96, p = 0¢006] in medium-high SES; and aPR=3-41 [95%CI 1-906-12, p<0-001] in low SES..4. Seroprevalence was also associated with contact with a suspected or confirmed COVID-19 case (living in overcrowded conditions), whether a household member (48-9%, aPR=2-67 [95%CI 2-063-47, p<0-001]), other family members that not reside in the same household (27-3%, aPR=1-66 [95%CI 1-152-40, p = 0-008]) or a workmate (34-1%, aPR=2-26 [95%CI 1-533-35, p<0-001]).5. Higher seroprevalence was also observed in participants who reported symptoms. (58-6% and 71-1% versus 14-2%, aPR=3-56 [95%CI 2-914-37, p<0-001] and aPR=4-33 [95%CI 3-525-34, p<0-001].
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Seroprevalence was higher in lower socioeconomic status (SES), in overcrowded households, and in subjects with suspected or confirmed contact within the household or workmates..2. Informal workers have precarious income, little access to social protection and health care. They have to continue working and mobilising daily to earn a living, from suburbs with precarious and very crowded public transportation, facilitating transmission..3. The proportion of susceptibles in Lima is almost equal across ages. .4. If physical distancing interventions are relaxed, possibly by opening schools or allowing gatherings, older adults could once again become the most affected group due to their high vulnerability.
Funding sources: Centro Nacional de Epidemiología, Prevencion y Control de Enfermedades (CDC Peru), INS from the Peruvian Ministry of Health, Direccion de Redes Integradas de Salud (DIRIS) of Lima and Direccion Regional de Salud (DIRESA) Callao

author: C. L. T. de Andrade et al. 2020
title: COVID-19 hospitalizations in Brazil’s Unified Health System (SUS)
Objective(s): To study the profile of hospitalizations due to COVID-19 in the Unified Health System (SUS) in Brazil and to identify factors associated with in-hospital mortality related to the disease.
Population: Patients aged 18 years or older diagnosed with COVID-19
Sample size: n=89,405 (Data from from the reduced type (RD) files for each state and Federal District, freely available on the DATASUS portal)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive and bivariate analyses were performed to characterize the population studied and to test the relationships between the independent variables (attributes of the patients, the care process and the hospital, place of residence and geographic location) with the dependent ’in-hospital death’ variable..2. For the correlation among observations occurring in each hospital, resulting from the process of care and case-mix.3. Using the generalized linear mixed model (GLMM) with random effects intercept.
Type of social stratification: -Etnicity: White / Black / Mixed race / Yellow / Indigenous / Unspecified.-Gender: Male/Female.-Clinic
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Gender/sex.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination.-Time-dependent relationships
Main Results: 1. It observe higher hospital mortality for men and an increasing gradient of the likelihood of dying as age (age group) increases. Among individuals aged 18 to 39 years, 8.5% of hospitalizations resulted in death. For individuals between 70 and 79, 80 and 89, and 90 years old and above, the proportion of hospitalizations that resulted in death increased to 36.0%, 44.5% and 50.8%: Table 1.2. There is a higher occurrence of deaths among blacks (31.9%), followed by indigenous people (28.9%) and mixed race people (26.1%)..3. Higher occurrence of deaths among patients with greater severity according to the Charlson and Elixhauser comorbidity indices or patients with diseases such as hypertension, diabetes and obesity, which show a pattern consistent with expectations..4. Based on the bivariate analyses, there appears to be a greater con centration of deaths in the extreme categories of LOS, with a lower occurrence of deaths (20.0%) among those with LOS between 2 and 7 days..5. blacks had higher odds of death during the hospital stay (OR = 1.14; 95% CI 1.05–1.25), compared to the reference category including whites, yellows, indigenous and individuals without a record of the variable..6. The odds of death were 37.2% and 88.1% (model 3) higher among patients with Charlson index scores equal to 1 and > o = 2, respectively, compared to those with a score equal to zero, controlling for other variables..7. Presence of hypertension (OR = 0.85; 95% CI 0.73–0.99) and diabetes (OR = 0.75; 95% CI 0.61- 0.91) had protective effects, regardless of the inclusion of the other comorbidity measures..8. Obesity was statistically associated with higher odds of in-hospital death (56.3% higher among obese people, compared to non-obese people).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This study ratifies the association of a higher risk of COVID-19 in-hospital mortality with being black.2. One relationship of interest is that among being black, COVID-19 and the risk of venous thrombosis.3. Controlling for confounding variables, the occurrence of shorter hospitalizations is significantly associated with the occurrence of death.

author: Borret et al. 2020
title: Reflexões para uma Prática em Saúde Antirracista
Objective(s): To describe the problems that involve the black population, analyze the context of the Sars-Cov-2 pandemic in the process of vulnerability of this group, highlight the situation of teaching blacks and brunettes in medical education and reflect on care black doctor.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Education.
Main Results: 1. The first to present data disaggregated by race/color, indicated 49.7% of SARS notifications with this item ignored, demonstrating the non-recognition, by health professionals, of the importance of considering the impacts of racism in the disease process.2. The black population represents the highest percentage among the population in precarious living conditions, the majority among people without basic sanitation, with poor housing conditions, including urban density, unemployed or informally employed, demonstrating that the racism that has crossed all the country's structuring process continues to make the black population vulnerable..3. The black population has a higher prevalence of chronic cardiovascular comorbidities when compared to the white population, representing a risk factor for an aggravated condition of Covid-19.4. The black population still faces important barriers to access the health system, although it is the majority of the Brazilian population, it has less access to consultations and exams..5. The Covid-19 mortality rate among black people is always higher than among white people in the country.6. Among women in the pregnancy-puerperal period who died from Covid-19 in Brazil, more than 75% were black. Later, a study by Brazilian researchers showed that pregnant black women hospitalized with SARS by Covid-19 had a similar mean age and morbidity profile to white women, but they were admitted in worse conditions and had a higher rate of admission to the intensive care unit, mechanical ventilation and death.7. The Covid-19 pandemic has opened wide the attempts to make the impacts of racism invisible in the process of illness and death of the black population. In the absence of strategies to guarantee access to health care or in the absence of public policies to address the vulnerability of the black population to Covid-19, Brazil reproduces the genocide policy in force since the slavery period.
Policy or intervention associate: Five actions are proposed: recognition of the privileges of being white in a racialized society; the understanding of racism as a current practice that is maintained and reproduced in social relations; the understanding of race as a dynamic and variable social construction; assume and reproduce a racial grammar and vocabulary, perceiving naturalized oppressions in speeches and expressions; and the development of the ability to interpret situations, practices and codes in a racialized manner, in order to identify possible naturalizations of the reproduction of racism.
Conclusions: 1. After 11 years of politics, the Covid-19 pandemic reinforces the existence of institutional racism in health and the damage caused by it, once again calling on health professionals and medical schools to reflect on their role in combating structural racism in society or in its reproduction..2. Changes are always difficult processes that require commitment, self-knowledge, recognition of limitations and facing difficulties..3. It is also difficult for the black population to live in a country that insists on denying racism as a factor that impacts the health and illness process, even though this is causing the death of black lives on a daily basis..4. It is up to each health professional, each higher education institution and each medical entity to make the daily decision to silence and reproduce or actively involve themselves in the fight against racism in health and in all social spheres.

author: Crochemore-Silva et al. 2020
title: Prática de atividade física em meio à pandemia da COVID-19: estudo de base populacional em cidade do sul do Brasil
Objective(s): To describe lei-sure-time physical activity (LPA) during the COVID-19 pandemic in a municipality of Rio Grande do Sul state, southern Brazil, according to gender, level of education, and adherence to social distancing.
Population: All residents of Bagé’s urban area (adults 18 years of age or older)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis based on the presentation of proportions and their respective confidence intervals for categorical variables. The chi-square test of heterogeneity.and linear trend was used to test statistically significant differences in the outcome according to nominal and ordinal categorical variables, respectively. Considering the study’s effect of design (svy command).
Type of social stratification: -Gender: Female/Male.-Education level: none or only attended elementary school/attended incomplete secondary or incomplete higher education/ complete higher education
Main Results: 1. 37.1% of men reported leisure-time physical activity during the pandemic against 16.9% of women, resulting in a difference of 20 percentage points between the two groups..2. The prevalence of physical activity ranged from 9.8% among participants with lower schooling to 50.9% among those who reported having completed higher education (p < 0.001), an absolute difference higher than 40 percentage points between groups..3. More than half of the respondents who engaged in physical activity reported the home as a place of activity (53.5%) and received no help from professionals (64.8%)..4. Significant gaps were identified according to the gender of participants regarding leisure-time physical activity during the pandemic (p < 0.001)
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Some sociocultural impediments play a central role in Brazilians’ lives, and this study provides visibility to this scenario by describing the magnitude of inequalities in engaging in leisure-time physical activity..2. The promotion of physical activity that reproduces health recommendations without discussing the statements, in the sense of humanization and reading Brazilian people’s unequal life, especially in class, skin color/ethnicity, and gender relationships, hardly contributes to health production, which can traverse more significant involvement in physical activities if the inequalities preceding the pandemic are contextualized.

author: Goes, Ramos, and Ferreira 2020
title: Desigualdades raciais em saúde e a pandemia da Covid-19
Objective(s): To discuss historical aspects and their relationship with the conditions of the vulnerability of the black population and present a plan of specific actions to combat racism and its consequences within the context of Covid-19.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. National data have shown a higher prevalence of chronic and neglected diseases among the black population, as a result of the greater social and economic vulnerability to which they are exposed and less access to health services. .2. Blacks report worse self-rated health rates when compared to whites. Data from the National Health Survey (PNS) show that the black population has higher prevalences of hypertension (44.2%) and diabetes (12.7%), when compared to the white population (22.1% and 6.2%, respectively).3. Segregation creates adverse health conditions, as, historically, the places where most black people live are precarious, with inadequate housing in relation to structural conditions, without access to basic sanitation services, drinking water, health equipment, for example, health clinics, pharmacies, parks and recreational spaces, contributing to greater exposure to risk factors, in addition to high levels of violence, resulting in the accumulation of health problems.4. According to the racial map of Brazil, cities such as Porto Alegre (RS), Vitória (ES), São Paulo (SP), Belo Horizonte (MG) and Salvador (BA) are among the five most racially segregated cities in the country. Among them, São Paulo is considered the epicenter of the epidemic in the country..5. Racism also conditions the adoption of preventive measures for Covid-19, considering that social distancing is not a privilege for everyone, especially in Brazil, where black men and women represent the majority of informal workers, domestic, commercial, food, transport, storage and mail, which remained active even during the pandemic..6. For the black population, the pandemic scenario is associated with unequal conditions determined by structural and institutional racism, as it has less access to health services and is in greater proportion among vulnerable populations, who have experienced the absence of the State in their territories for centuries. .
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. They need the social protection policies implemented in the face of the Covid-19 emergency to guarantee equity, also reaching quilombola communities, slums and suburban populations that, in order to receive government emergency aid, need to expose themselves to infection in the agglomeration of queue hours at banks and lottery outlets. .2. They need to ensure that access to Covid-19 diagnosis, whether through rapid testing or immune reaction testing, is evenly distributed to the population and that so-called 'mass' testing initiatives have sufficient capillarity to cover with it effectiveness in the rich and impoverished areas of cities. .3. They must demand greater transparency from the bodies responsible for pandemic data in the country so that they: include race or ethnicity markers in data referring to the entire course of the disease, from testing, hospitalizations and possible deaths; maintain a systematized and agile routine for disclosing this data to society and expand the testing capacity in the country and do it differently in areas of greater vulnerability, such as people deprived of liberty, populations that live and survive on the streets and quilombola communities.

author: Natividade et al. 2020
title: Distanciamento social e condições de vida na pandemia COVID-19 em Salvador-Bahia, Brasil
Objective(s): To analyze the trend of social distancing in this pandemic and its relationship with the context of living conditions in Salvador, Bahia, Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis: time trend and spatial distribution
Type of social stratification: -The Urban Health Index (UHI): a proxy for living conditions.-Municipal Vulnerability Index (MVI).-The Global and Local Moran Indices
Main Results: 1. The neighborhoods considered to have the highest poverty rate are those with the lowest percentage of Social Distancing Index (SDI)..2. The municipality has a high vulnerability index, which places it at a disadvantage in facing the pandemic, when compared to other Brazilian capitals, such as São Paulo (global score 41.2) represented in specific dimensions of the vulnerable population with a score of 55.4, local economy aspects (34.5), the structure of health services (40.1), organization of health services with the best score 26.1, and municipal administration capacity (39.9)..3. Low adherence to social distancing measures can be determined by social inequality because the distribution of health and disease in populations is not random, and is associated with social status, which in turn defines the people’s living and working conditions..4. Essential portions of the population that survive informal work find it difficult to adhere to distancing, as they need to supplement their income, although they are on a temporary income transfer program. Furthermore, the informal work context limits the conditions for protecting workers, with greater exposure to risks and the need to maintain informal activity as a means of survival..5. The quality of information, government officials’ credibility, and uncertainty about the virus also affect adherence.
Policy or intervention associate: Social Distancing Index (SDI)
Conclusions: 1. The findings reveal that the analysis of containment measures such as social distancing should not be done in isolation and should consider the profile of local vulnerability for the correct measurement of prevention and control strategies..2. The planning of the municipality be based on the epidemiological scenario, considering the differences and inequities between different neighborhoods, recommending the implementation/maintenance of social protection policies, and the development of actions that contribute to the maintenance of jobs and workers’ income, giving priority to the most vulnerable groups..3. While social distancing in the analyzed municipality and its respective neighborhoods has not achieved the desired values, it remains one of the most critical COVID-19 control and prevention measures.

author: Salas et al. 2020
title: COVID-19: impacto psicosocial en la escuela en Chile. Desigualdades y desafíos para Latinoamérica
Objective(s): To addresses the psychosocial impact of the main measures taken in Chile at the educational system level, with the purpose of maintaining teaching and learning practices despite the closure of educational establishments, mainly through the program Aprendo en Línea a cause of COVID-19.
Population: Population related to the educational context (students, parents, teachers)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Occupation.-Education.-Socioeconomic status.-Social capital .-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. By implementing a program with an online education approach, it marks an inequality since, despite being Chile one of the most developed Latin American countries, it does not have coverage and access by the entire population to the internet service..2. The psychosocial impact of the health emergency on teachers is traversed by the tensions inherent to the political structuring of the school system and teaching work..3. Job dissatisfaction and overwork among teachers usually translate into stress that is exacerbated by the circumstances of uncertainty and overload derived from the health emergency and forced pedagogical adaptations..4. Thinking about parental involvement at school during the time of health emergency implies becoming even more aware of the conditions of materiality, the differences in the cultural capital of families, as well as parental burden and the way in which hyper-responsible and blaming approaches of fathers and mothers increase it, which also deepens the country's inequality gaps.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The questioning of both modes of education (virtual - face-to-face) is actually a questioning of the thoughtlessness of adapting school obligations, as if the emergency were not occurring in a psychosocially vulnerable, socioeconomically unequal and politically in crisis country..2. Homes converted into schools have multiple limitations and biopsychosocial consequences..3. Societies are traversed by a series of recurring problems and challenges, and the implemented measures generate unnecessary additional stress, in a system that overvalues efficiency and academic knowledge, over socio-emotional skills. That allow to generate interpersonal relationships in a healthy way..4. It is suggested that the physical and psychological health of the students be evaluated and monitored during the time of exposure to the pandemic

author: Horta et al. 2021
title: Prevalence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 according to socioeconomic and ethnic status in a nationwide Brazilian survey
Journal: Pan American Journal of Public Health (PAJPH)
Objective(s): To investigate socioeconomic and ethnic group inequalities in prevalence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 in the 27 federative units of Brazil
City or municipality: 133 sentinel cities located in the 27 federative units of Brazil
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The seroprevalence analyzes were stratified according to the socioeconomic variables by region of the country (north, northeast, southeast, south, and center-west) using Poisson regression with solid variance to estimate prevalence rates. All analyzes were adjusted for the cluster sampling design with the prefix svy.
Type of social stratification: -Regions: North/Northeast/ Southeast/South/Center-west.-Wealth quintiles: More poor/Second/Third/Bedroom/Richer.-Education level: =4/5-8/9-11/=12.-Etnicity: White/Brown/Black/Asian/Indigenous
Main Results: 1. In the first, second and third rounds the prevalence of positive results was 1.4%, 2.4% and 2.9%, respectively. It is observed that the proportion of tests with a positive result was higher in the northern region (6.7%), while in the southern region only 0.2% of the participants tested positive..2. An inverse relationship was observed between the prevalence of antibodies and the wealth quintiles; the poorest people were about twice as likely to have antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 as it was among the richest..3. The highest prevalence ratio (almost five times higher) was observed among indigenous and white people. White people were less likely to test positive, followed by Asians, compared to any other ethnic group..4. The proportion of people with antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 was higher in the North region (Amazonas), where indigenous and poor populations are concentrated, the prevalence of seropositivity was also lower in the richest quintile. The prevalence among indigenous people continued to be higher than among whites (prevalence ratio 2.25; 95% CI: 1.74-2.91), and this was also the case for people classified in the black and brown categories. In the Northeast region, an inverse relationship was also observed between seroprevalence and wealth, but not with ethnic group. Among indigenous people, the prevalence was 2.27 times higher than among whites. In the other regions, no defined pattern of relationship with wealth was observed, but people with black or brown skin presented a significantly higher risk than those with white skin.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The COVID-19 pandemic is affecting the poorest and most disadvantaged population groups in Brazil with the greatest intensity. The proportion of tests with a positive result was higher among indigenous, black and brown people compared to white people, and it was observed an inverse relationship with socioeconomic position..2. Ethnic inequalities in health and nutrition in the country, several studies have revealed higher mortality in indigenous children and adolescents than in other ethnic groups, as well as similar differences in adult mortality.3. That indigenous people presented a substantially higher risk than other ethnic groups, in part because they are concentrated in the Amazon region, where the prevalence was the highest in the country at the time of the survey, and also because they have the level lower lifespan compared to other groups..4. That in the north of the country brown people, who presented a seroprevalence of 7.1%, are genetically closer to Amerindians than brown people in other parts of the country..5. This analyzes show that people from poor families with little education were exposed to a higher risk of infection. Regarding ethnic group and skin color, white people presented the lowest risk, while people from the indigenous, black and brown population were the most affected.
Funding sources: Ministerio de Salud de Brasil, el Instituto Serrapilheira, la Asociación Brasileña de Salud Colectiva y la iniciativa de JBS SA “Fazer o Bem Faz Bem”.

author: Passos et al. 2021
title: Higher mortality during the COVID-19 pandemic in socially vulnerable areas in Belo Horizonte: implications for vaccine prioritization.
Objective(s): To assess mortality during the COVID-19 pandemic according to social vulnerability by areas of Belo Horizonte (BH), aiming at strategies for vaccination.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The disparities in mortality by age group and by HVI are even more evident when analyzing the difference in the observed versus expected rate
Type of social stratification: The health vulnerability index (HVI): low/medium/high/very high risk
Main Results: 1. In 2020, most of the population (39.8%) lived in the tracts of medium vulnerability, while 34.8 and 25.4% lived in the tracts of low and high health vulnerability, respectively. Women were the majority, 53% in the municipality, with proportions varying from 52, 53 and 55% between the tracts of high, medium and low vulnerability..2. The standardized mortality ratio showed an increase of 16.1% in deaths by natural causes in Belo Horizonte, with increases of 11.1, 18.8 and 19.4% in the low, medium and high vulnerability tracts..3. For every 100,000 inhabitants, there was an excess of 59 deaths in the municipality, varying from 31 to 95 between the low and high vulnerability tracts.4. There were 1,524 deaths by COVID-19 in Belo Horizonte. The age-standardized mortality rate by COVID-19 was 63 per 100,000 inhabitants, varying from 35 to 78 and 105 per 100,000 inhabitants as health vulnerability increases.5. The values of the SMR (standardized mortality ratio) show little or no impact of the pandemic on mortality among the youngest (99.9%), with an increase of 16.4, 23.1 and 15.5% in individuals aged 40–59 years, 60–74 and 75+ years old..6. When comparing SMR of the low HVI to the SMR of medium and high HVI in all other age groups, the impact of the pandemic is clearly greater in the medium and high vulnerability tracts, when compared to low vulnerability tracts.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Confirms the hypothesis of a differential increase in mortality by natural causes and by COVID-19 in populations in greater social vulnerability and, among older adults, with urgent implications in the vaccination strategy of the population..2. The number of deaths by COVID-19 was responsible for a smaller share of the excess deaths by natural causes in areas of high vulnerability compared to areas of low and medium vulnerability. This suggests a underdiagnosis of COVID-19 in these areas, potentially due to unequal access to health services and diagnostic tests, as already shown in other Brazilian cities.3. Socioeconomic inequalities are the main determinants of the occurrence and distribution of diseases and deaths worldwide and, in Belo Horizonte, this inequality was exacerbated by it.4. People who live in most vulnerable areas are the population group with the greatest risk of exposure not only because they usually work in essential services, but also because they have difficulties with physical distance and hygiene inherent to their housing and transportation conditions..5. The evidence of higher mortality among the older adults in the most vulnerable tracts, which generally concentrate a lower number of older adults and, consequently, of deaths.6. Better use of available doses of the vaccine and its feasibility, given the municipality’s experience in articulating health surveillance actions with territorial bases defined in areas covered by the Family Health Strategy.

author: K. B. Ribeiro et al. 2021
title: Social inequalities and COVID-19 mortality in the city of São Paulo, Brazil.
Objective(s): To address this issue and aims to characterize mortality patterns from COVID-19 in the city of São Paulo, Brazil and to identify risk factors of mortality considering various socio-demographic indicators.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Age-standardized mortality rates (ASRs) (2010 Brazilian Census population) and crude rate ratios (RRs) [with corresponding 95% confidence intervals (95% CIs)].2. The association between place of death, type of hospital administration and racewith odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CIs. They have tested whether age modifies these associations using the Breslow-Day test for the homogeneity of ORs..3. They also analysed time trends in COVID-19 mortality according to race using a Joinpoint Regression Model with the age-standardized mortality rate as the dependent epidemiological week (from Week 12: 15–21 March to Week 39: 20–26 September) as the independent variable.
Type of social stratification: -Household crowding (calculated as the average number of persons/household).-Educational attainment (calculated as the percentage of the population with a university degree).-Income level (calculated as the percentage of persons living with less than one-quarter of the minimum wage in 2018).-Percentage of households located in subnormal areas (irregular settlements, also known as ‘favelas’).-Age.-Gender: male/female.-Race: White/ Black/ mixed/ Asian/ indigenous.-Educational level: years of study to 0/ 1–3/ 4–7/ 8–11/12+/ unknown.-District of residence.-Tpe of hospital administration: public state government/ public city government/private non-profit
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Education.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Socioeconomic status.-Gender/sex.-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1. Males presented an 84% increase in COVID-19 mortality compared with females [relative risk (RR) = 1.84, 95% CI 1.79–1.90]. Higher mortality rates were observed for Blacks (RR = 1.77, 95% CI 1.67–1.88) and mixed (RR = 1.42, 95% CI 1.37–1.47) compared with Whites, whereas lower mortality was noted for Asians (RR = 0.63, 95% CI 0.58–0.68)..2. The highest mortality rate was observed in the district of Brás (192.3 deaths/100 000 inhabitants) and the lowest in Jardim Paulista (48.1 deaths/100 000 inhabitants).3. Stratified analysis examining racial disparities in mortality according to area-based measures of school attainment revealed that differences between Whites and Blacks were higher in areas with a better educational level..4. Among all indicators, the educational level was the one showing the most substantial disparity between the categories. .5. In the young/adult population, among those living in areas with the lowest percentage of the population with a university degree, mortality was four times higher compared with that in the most educated group (RR=4.02, 95% CI 3.42–4.72); in the elderly population, the same comparison denoted a 96% increased risk of death.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. A positive gradient was found for all socio-economic indicators, i.e. increases in disparities denoted by less education, more household crowding, lower income and a higher concentration of subnormal areas were associated with higher mortality rates..2. A decrease in mortality over time was observed in all racial groups, but it started earlier among Whites and Asians..3. These finding of a higher percentage of deaths occurring in primary-care or isolated emergency-care units observed for Black and mixed populations may be related to barriers in healthcare access..4. These results reveal striking social inequalities in COVID-19 mortality in São Paulo, exposing structural inequities in Brazilian society that were not addressed by the governmental response to COVID-19. Without an equitable response, COVID-19 will further exacerbate current social inequalities in São Paulo.

author: Figueiredo et al. 2020
title: Social determinants of health and COVID-19 infection in Brazil: an analysis of the pandemic.
Objective(s): To analyze the influence of socioeconomic, demographic, epidemiological factors, and the health system structure in the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Estimate the magnitude of the association between the independent variables and the response variables, it was performed the Spearman’s correlation analysis..2. It was performed a multiple linear regression analysis, with separate models for incidence and mortality, to verify whether the independent variables could explain or predict the dependent variable. In order to meet the assumptions of data normality and homogeneity, the incidence rates were transformed logarithmically.
Type of social stratification: -Gini Index of household income per capita.-Unemployment rate.-Percentage of uneducated population.-Percentage of people living with household income per capita in dollars below the poverty line, access to water and sewage systems, and overcrowding (households with three or more inhabitants per dormitory)
Main Results: 1. Since the beginning of the pandemic, the time varied from 151 days in Roraima to 176 days in São Paulo, being 16.6% higher in this state. The lowest incidence was 919.3 cases per 100,000 inhabitants in Minas Gerais, and the highest in Roraima, with 6,688.9 cases per 100,000 inhabitants. .2. The lowest mortality was 22.6 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants in Minas Gerais, and the highest mortality was in Roraima, with 95.6 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants. The average mortality rate in Brazil was 2.77%, ranging from 1.34% in the Tocantins to 7.3% in Rio de Janeiro. .3. The incidence rates presented a moderate correlation with overcrowding (r = 0.562; p < 0.01) and with the Gini Index (r = 0.471; p < 0.05)..4. Mortality rates correlated with the Gini Index (r = 0.605; p < 0.01), overcrowding (r = 0.556; p < 0.01), vacancy rate (r = 0.459; p < 0.05), lethality rate (r = 0.408; p < 0.05)..5. The regression model, considering as a dependent variable the incidence of COVID-19 included three independent variables as predictors, those being the Gini Index of household income (ß =0.365; t = 2.355; p = 0.027), household overcrowding (ß = 0.353); t = 2.289; p = 0.032) and the lethality rate (ß = - 0.489; t = -3.630; p = 0.001) generating a model with better adjusted R2 and better level of statistical significance [F (3.23) = 111.387; p < 0.001; R2 = 0.598]. In this model, 59.8% of the variation in incidence can be explained by independent variables. It was not identified any dependency on residuals or multicollinearity.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This results indicate that socioeconomic factors and social inequities influenced the dissemination and mortality of COVID-19 in Brazil..2. It suggest that the coping strategies contemplate intersectoral actions, aiming at guaranteeing sanitary and economic conditions so that vulnerable populations can carry out the recommended prevention actions..

author: Thomé et al. 2020
title: Differences in the prevalence of risk factors for severe COVID-19 across regions of São Paulo City.
Objective(s): To estimate the prevalence of risk factors for severe COVID-19 for people living in São Paulo City according to sociodemographic characteristics and city region using data from a population-based household survey.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: -Self-reported health conditions .-weight and height.-Chronic diseases (cardiovascular disease, diabetes, chronic respiratory disease, hypertension, (current) cancer, history of stroke, obesity (BMI = 30 kg/m2), current smoking, or moderate to severe asthma).-Gender: Male/female.-Age.-Education: None/Primary complete or incomplete/Secundary or technical school/University complete or incomplete.-Income (in minimun wages): <1/1-1.9/2-4.9/>5.-Race/ethnicity: White/ no-White.-São Paulo City region
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Education.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. Prevalence of single risk factors for severe COVID-19 among older adults (= 65 years old) were as high as 58% (hypertension), whereas for younger adults (< 65 years old) obesity was the most prevalent risk factor (21%)..2. More risk factors for severe COVID-19 was 56.4% (4.7 million) in São Paulo City.3. Less educated adults, that is, those who had no formal education reported, 86% had at least one risk factor for severe COVID-19, as compared to 49% among those with university education initiated..4. Distribution of risk factors was similar ( to point (3)) according to income or race.5. The Southeastern (59.8%), Northern (58.7%), and Southern (56%) regions had higher prevalence of one or more risk factors,
Policy or intervention associate: Describing the distribution of risk factors for severe disease in the population is important to identify vulnerabilities and tailor prevention and care strategies.
Conclusions: 1. Large number of adults, presented with at least one risk factor for severe COVID-19 in São Paulo City, including those under 65..2. Northern and Southeastern regions in São Paulo City:, these risk factors were more prevalent, (higher death rates, alongside with inequalities in resources for care, particularly in the Northern region..3. Subgroups with lower education rates, a robust indicator of lower socioeconomic status, had higher prevalence of risk factors for severe disease..4. COVID-19 deaths were concentrated in the Northern, Southeastern and Eastern regions, probably also reflecting disparities in accessing the necessary health services.

author: Heroy et al. 2021
title: COVID-19 policy analysis: labour structure dictates lockdown mobility behaviour.
Journal: Journal of the Royal Society Interface
Objective(s): To analyse the impact of lockdown policies on urban mobility in Colombia
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Mapping individuals to spatial units, individual-level regression analyses,and aggregate analyses
Type of social stratification: -Socioeconomic status: 1 to 6
Main Results: 1. The extent of the gender-based  policy enforcement/adherence is generally unclear across municipalities, especially in the informal labour sector..2. Most users across all municipalities reduced their daily distance travelled during lockdown. .3. Most municipalities had a mean lockdown trip frequency of 25–30%  This represents a reduction in mobility from baseline levels that were 20–45% higher, with the largest reduction in Bogotá.4. Smaller municipalities permitted fewer people out daily (Pearson’s ? = 0.43, p = 0.04).5. Larger cities that better enables residents to reduce mobility despite less severe mobility quotas. .6. COVID-19 growth is slower on a per capita basis in larger cities levels.7. Mobility reduction are significantly associated (p < 0.01) with municipality-level economic variables including GDP per capita and labour formality rate economic advantages of larger cities favour mobility reduction.
Policy or intervention associate: Needing for future policy measures to increase aid-based measures alongside or even in place of mobility restrictions.
Conclusions: 1. Larger, wealthier cities reduced mobility the most, even though they generally imposed less severe mobility quotas. .2. Smaller cities, with more informal employment, did not experience a comparable reduction..3. Urban residents are more influenced by their economic capacity to comply with rules than by the precise measures implemented locally..4. Mobility reduction is influenced by other factors such as degree of enforcement of the policy, the availability of economic aid to workers and firms, population density and the number of infections in the city..5. Residents of cities with larger caseloads early in the pandemic are likely to have been more willing to lock down.6. Less wealthy, often informal firms have less financial capacity to close operations..7. Workers particularly in smaller cities—often informally employed and rarely in teleworkable occupations—cannot work from home (...) and (...) continue working despite mobility restrictions.
Funding sources: UKRI’s Global Challenge Research Fund and MIT Connection Science research alliance

author: Bolaño-Ortiz et al. 2020
title: Spread of SARS-CoV-2 through Latin America and the Caribbean region: A look from its economic conditions, climate and air pollution indicators.
Objective(s): To design a strategy to tackle the current COVID-19 pandemic and prevent future epidemics similar to COVID-19, that generate health and socioeconomic problems for nations and the world
City or municipality: Bogotá (Colombia), Guayaquil (Ecuador), Manaus (Brazil), Lima (Perú), Santiago (Chile), São Paulo (Brazil) and Buenos Aires (Argentina).
Sample size: n=7,413 Bogotá (Colombia)  / n=2,654 Guayaquil (Ecuador) 2.654 / n=1,802 Manaus (Brazil)  / n=9,674 Limae (Perú) / n=12,176  Sao Paulo (Brazil) / n=6,257 Santiagoe (Chile) / n=3,063 Buenos Aires (Argentina)
