Method of inequalities/inequitie: The Spearman rank correlation tests were used to examine the correlation between climate indicators and COVID-19 variables (daily cases and deaths), because the dataset had a non-normal distribution. This was verified previously by the Shapiro-Wilk normality test. Finally, the spread of COVID-19 is related to the economic characteristics observed in LAC.
Type of social stratification: -Gini index .-Human development index
Main Results: 1. The cities analyzed have a high and very high Human Development Index. However, they have a large inequality gap as shown by the Gini index (Table 1). .2. Gini Index: Bogota (colombia)= 51.5, Guayaquil (Ecuador)=53.4, Manaus (Brazil)=53.2, Lima (Perú)=53.7, Sao Paulo (Brazil)=53.2, Santiago (Chile)=57.2, Buenos Aires (Argentina)=46.8.3. Human develop index: Bogota (colombia)= 0.792, Guayaquil (Ecuador)=0.863, Manaus (Brazil)=0.737, Lima (Perú)=0.90, Sao Paulo (Brazil)=0.843, Santiago (Chile)=0.916, Buenos Aires (Argentina)=0.925..4. Chile, Brazil and Perú have the highest Gini index values in LAC and this coincide with those with the highest number of infections (shown in Fig. 2). In addition, among.the cities analyzed, these three countries have the three cities with the highest infection rate by COVID-19 per 100,000 inhabitants.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. These findings can be used by researchers and policymakers as a starting point for supporting further research and measures, in order to stop and prevent the spread of COVID-19 in the LAC region. .2. This study has explored the evolution of COVID-19 through LAC and provides interesting insights that should be further explored. .3. Future research should carry out a comprehensive study that considers epidemiological aspects, social distancing policies, socioeconomic issues, different air pollutants, and the different lockdown and mobility restriction measures implemented in each country.
Funding sources: Agencia de Promoción Científica (project PICT 2016 1115), FRM-UTN and CONICET in Argentina; GORE-FNDR-V Regi´on in Valparaíso and Programa de Asignación Rápida de Recursos para Proyectos de Investigación Sobre el Coronavirus (COVID-19) (project COVID0581-2020), ANID, Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnología, Conocimiento e Innovaci´on, both in Chile; and Coordenaçao de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior (CAPES) Finance Code 001 in Brazil

author: Bitencourt and Andrade 2021
title: Trabalhadoras da saúde face à pandemia: por uma análise sociológica do trabalho de cuidado
Objective(s): a) to discuss the contributions by gender studies for analyzing care work by women, especially healthcare, in its dual dimensions, productive and reproductive, emphasizing the specificities of care as work..b) to analyze work conditions, illness, and death of female and male healthcare workers in the context of Covid-19 in Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Female healthcare workers make their decisions in this moment of the pandemic concerning who will care for their children and family members in general, since daycare centers, preschools, and schools are closed to contain the spread of coronavirus, creating difficulties for reconciling productive and reproductive work..2 Female healthcare workers, unlike a major portion of the population, who are in social isolation or distancing due to coronavirus control, are leading the high-risk care, since the virus has intense and extensive global spread..3. Gender relations and women´s disadvantages in the labor market.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Government attention to healthcare work and professional societies, perceiving the adverse work conditions in confronting the pandemic..2. The sociological analysis of healthcare work allowed understanding that many women, as healthcare workers, are experiencing countless challenges

author: Cobre et al. 2020
title: Risk factors associated with delay in diagnosis and mortality in patients with COVID-19 in the city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Objective(s): To investigate the risk factors associated of delay in the diagnosis and mortality of patients with COVID-19 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Sample size: n=3,656 (Data from the Painel Rio COVID-19 database13, maintained by the City Hall of Rio de Janeiro)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. A descriptive statistical analysis using the median and interquartile range (IQR).2. Kaplan-Meier method was adopted to estimate the delay in diagnosis.
Type of social stratification: -Age group.-Gender: Male/Female /Not informed.-social development index (SDI): Low / High.-Evolution of the disease..-Time to diagnosis..-Mortality (‘dead / ‘alive’)
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Gender/sex.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. Cox regression multivariate analyses revealed that males (HR = 0.846 [95% CI, 0.739-0.968]; p= 0.015), patients living in regions with a low SDI (HR = 0.721 [95% CI, 0.614-0.847]; p = 0.000), patients with active disease (HR = 1.960 [95% CI,1.574-2.440]; p = 0.000) had longer delays in diagnosis..2. Multivariate analysis of logistic regression showed that male patients had a higher odds of death from COVID-19 than female patients (OR = 0.150 [95% CI, 0.051-0.440]; p = 0.001)..3) The age groups that were statistically associated with death were: 70-79 years (OR = 1.495 [95% CI, 1.121-1.994]; p = 0.006), 80-89 years (OR = 3.146 [95% CI, 2.256-4.387]; p < 0.001), and 90-99 years (OR = 5.100 [95% CI, 2.024-12.852]; p = 0.001). .4) Patients from regions with a low SDI had increased odds for death from COVID-19 (OR= 1.833 [95% CI, 1.565-2.148]; p < 0.001). Delay to diagnosis greater than eight days was also a risk factor for death (OR = 3.537 [95% CI, 2.769-4.519]; p < 0.001).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Delays in diagnosis and risk factors for death from COVID-19 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil were associated with male gender, age under 60 years, and patients living in regions with lower social development index, including favelas..2. Delay between the onset of symptoms until diagnosis greater than eight days may increase mortality rates..3. These results highlight the continuous challenges to contain, mitigate, and control the disease in environments with scarce resources, including the lack of mass testing. Further preventive measures are still needed, especially for vulnerable groups.

author: Hossain 2021
title: Unequal experience of COVID-induced remote schooling in four developing countries
Objective(s): To assess possible disparities in access to remote education in four countries, including Peru
Population: People aged between 5 and 26 years old who were also reportedly active learning through educational institutions.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Logistic regression model to estimate the association between different sociodemographic factors and remote schooling.
Type of social stratification: 1. Education level of the household head: no education/ primary/ secondary/ higher/ adult or religious/other education.2. Gender: male/female.3. Geographic: Rural/Urban.4. Age: primary (5–11 year-olds) / secondary (12–18 year-olds) / higher education (19–26 year-olds) age learners/students
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Education.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. The urban coefficient appears significant only after controlling for all other covariates. Rural people may have limited access to facilities and public amenities that urban dwellers regularly enjoy. One may argue that greater remote schooling in urban areas could be triggered by being more affected by the pandemic than rural areas..2. Tertiary education age students are less likely to experience remote schooling compared to primary education age ones while the coefficient for the secondary education age group is not significant. Peru’s case suggests that younger students are more likely to experience remote schooling..3. Male students are less likely to experience remote schooling than female students. The non-significant gender differences possibly indicate the widespread effect of the pandemic irrespective of gender..
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This suggests that socioeconomic disparities are the main determinants of who gets to access alternative schooling during the pandemic, which can affect female and male students similarly. .2. Not to suggest that gender disparity may not exist during the pandemic as this data is limited to merely showing who are likely to experience remote schooling. They do not know whether girls are learning similarly by accessing remote learning materials and whether other indirect factors may be affecting them..3. It gives a snapshot of disparity at the early stage of the pandemic which may gradually intensify. Distance teaching for deprived communities should be prioritised in the budget to account for any future crises.

author: Viezzer and Biondi 2021
title: The influence of urban, socio-economic, and eco-environmental aspects on COVID-19 cases, deaths and mortality: A multi-city case in the Atlantic Forest, Brazil
Objective(s): To explore COVID-19 influence of urban, socio-economic, and eco-environmental aspects on people’s health in Brazil .
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Bivariate non-parametric correlation between every COVID-19 parameter and urban, socio-economic, and ecoenvironmental indexes, with the application of Spearman’s and Kendall’s.correlation coefficients.2. Multivariate analysis (PCA) for both sets of data (total and >100,000 inhabitants) and for each group of parameters composed by independent variables (urban, socio-economic, and eco-environmental)
Type of social stratification: -City urbanization.-Socio-economic conditions: population / demographic density/ absolute built area / built area / average per capita income / number of people vulnerable to poverty / illiteracy rate of the population aged 18 / human development.-Eco-environmental: absolute vegetation cover / vegetation over relative to municipality area /absolute forest cover / forest cover relative to municipality
Main Results: 1. Correlation between cases and the C1 urban index was also the strongest (rs = 0.564; t = 0.401), followed by the C2 urban index, that represents demographic density and relative built area, mainly related to COVID 19 reported deaths (rs = 0.493; t = 0.339).2. Mortality rate for municipalities > 100,000 inhabitants (rs = -0.301; t = -0.207), possibly indicating a smaller mortality rate in big cities with better socio-economic conditions..3. Correlation was found between health parameters and the socio-economic index, that represent positive socio-economic conditions..4. Socio-economic index was also correlated with cases (all municipalities rs = 0.268; t = 0.185; municipalities > 100,000 inhabitants rs = 0.261; t = 0.181),.5. No strong correlations between health parameters and the eco-environmental indexes were found considering all municipalities, but there may be some association, nonetheless.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Urbanization is the strongest COVID-19 predictor among the parameters considered in this study..2. Urbanized cities, with a higher population, demographic density, and absolute and relative built areas, have higher COVID-19 confirmed cases and deaths..3. Some connection between worse socio-economic variables (higher poverty and illiteracy rates, and lower income and human development index) with higher COVID-19 total and relative cases..4. Eco-environmental aspects were more meaningful when considering the big cities data set (> 100,000), rather than all municipalities with COVID-19 confirmed cases..5. Less absolute vegetation and forest covers were to some degree related to higher deaths per 100,000 inhabitants and mortality.

author: Tavares and Betti 2021
title: The pandemic of poverty, vulnerability, and COVID-19: Evidence from a fuzzy multidimensional analysis of deprivations in Brazil
Objective(s): To measure multidimensional poverty within the context of the coronavirus pandemic (States in Brazil)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Alkire-Foster (AF) method and a fuzzy-set multidimensional analysis. Spearman and Kendall rank correlation coefficients.
Type of social stratification: -Unidimentional poverty (monetary poverty).-Vulnerability indicators (sanitation, home shelter, physical distance, and recovery from illness).-Health access.-Multidimensional poverty.-Health Recovery Index and Monetary Poverty
Main Results: 1. The northern and northeastern regions have the highest proportion of vulnerability and severe risk of infection with COVID-19. .2. Amazonas state (AM) has the most deaths per million people and among the highest risk: the incidence of vulnerable people according to the health recovery index.is 50.5%. .3. In São Paulo (SP), the state with the most infections in absolute terms, it is 3.9%. More infection in the richest regions, which are less vulnerable..4. Initially, all the measures show a negative relation between the vulnerability indicators and deaths per million people. Beginning in week 14, the correlations increase, meaning that states with the highest vulnerability and severe risk scores have increasing numbers of deaths per million people..5. The health recovery index has greater correlations than the prevention index. The highest Spearman coefficients in the prevention index are 0.41 and 0.44 (for headcount ratio.(HCR) vulnerability and fuzzy severe risk), whereas for the health recovery index they are 0.46 and 0.53 (for fuzzy severe risk and fuzzy vulnerability)..6. Risk of infection of COVID-19 is not favorable for the Indigenous population, which has the worst conditions in all indicators. Brown and Black groups also are at a disadvantage to the White and Asian groups and the total population.
Policy or intervention associate: Recommendations for prevention as well as they can, and to guarantee universal coverage by public health services.
Conclusions: 1. Big part of the population cannot fully implement the recommended preventive measures and because the social conditions and the health-care system do not meet the basic requirements for avoiding preventable deaths..2. Inequality among regions and ethnic groups..3. Most states with the highest vulnerability and severe risk outcomes also have the largest increase in death rates..4. Money is very important in battling the threat of the pandemic

author: I. Pereira and Patel 2021
title: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the hours lost by self-employed racial minorities: evidence from Brazil
Objective(s): To explore if during the COVID-19 pandemic self-employed racial minorities in Brazil lost more hours of work relative to employed racial minorities
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: -Race: black/ white.-Employment: public / provate / self employement.-Income: deciles of the reported income / the value of remuneration in the form of goods or products.-Education: complete elementary but not high school/High School/ some college/College/Graduate school..
Main Results: 1. Decline in hours worked is approximately 5.73 h on average.2. The self-employed were more likely to lose hours (r=0.18, p<0.05)with mixed race individuals facing a small increase in hours lost (r=0.01, p<0.05). Self-employment seems negatively correlated with black, yellow, and mixed race. Both age (r=0.03, p<0.05) and female (r=0.02, p<0.05) are associated with increased hours lost..3. Those reporting race as yellow or indigenous, due to small prevalence rates, had substantially overlapping confdence intervals between the employed and the self-employed.
Policy or intervention associate: “one-size-fts-all” policy approaches may not work in improving the conditions of the self-employed from racial minority groups..Impact on social, flial, and health costs from the deteriorating economic conditions of the self-employed from racial minority groups must be of special concern to policymakers..Needing for greater responsiveness from policymakers in devising policies that are more conducive to this group’s long-term wellbeing.
Conclusions: 1. Self-employed racial minorities in developing countries with limited health and physical infrastructure, less stable macroeconomic conditions, and weaker or non-existent safety nets face distinc tive challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic..2. Careful consideration must be given to the self-employed from racial minority groups in developing countries..3. Self-employed sustaining lower and more volatile income than the employed, business closures and reduction in hours could spell permanent decline in the economic standing of the self-employed. .4. Precarity may have been exacerbated for such groups during the COVID-19 pandemic.5. Small businesses may not fully recover from the economic malaise of the COVID-19 pandemic..6. Deterioration in economic status resulting from COVID-19 may not only further increase income inequality between racial majority and minority groups, but it may also have adverse long-term economic and social consequences for the Brazilian economy.

author: Ponce et al. 2021
title: Effect of inequality and economic activity on COVID-19 in Ecuador: An outline of its possible economic, social and demographic determinants
Objective(s): To examine the effect of income inequality and economic activity on COVID-19 infections in Ecuador.
Sample size: n=70,093 people infected and 5,460 people died cut to July 24, 2020.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Ordinary Least Squares (OLS).2. Logarithm of cases of contagion by COVID-19 White's test
Type of social stratification: Independent variables: inequality (Gini coefficient), formal sector, primary sector, secondary sector, tertiary sector, sector, urban population, age and female population..Dependent variable: number of COVID-19 infections
Main Results: 1. The inequality of income has a positive and statistically significant effect on COVID-19 cases in Ecuador..2. It is key to mitigate income inequality since it has a direct impact on the increase in the population living in poverty and extreme poverty..3. People do not have the money to buy all medical supplies that help prevent infections, since money is required to purchase them frequently since they are of short duration and their price is not affordable to the general public..4. The formality variable also shows a positive and statistically significant relationship, which may be associated with the fact that in the cantons with the highest percentage of population that work in the formal sector of the economy, whether in private companies or public institutions or companies, there has been a requirement that determined number of employees returned to their jobs while the pandemic was still raging..5. When the percentage of the economically active population is concentrated in economic activities belonging to the secondary or tertiary sector, COVID-19 infections increase due to which are activities that take place in places where you have contact with a large number of people..6. Economic activities carried out in the primary sector of the economy indicate the presence of a negative and statistically significant relationship..7. The urbanization variable shows the presence of a positive and statistically significant relationship, because the places where there is a higher concentration of urban population there are more crowd of people. In contrast, when there is a higher percentage of people living in rural places, that is, unlike the variable urbanization, infections decrease..8. Age presents a negative and statistically significant relationship, which means that the increase in the average age of the canton causes a decrease in the cases of contagion of the virus..9. COVID-19 can infect people of all ages, although older people and those with pre-existing medical conditions, appear to be more vulnerable to becoming seriously ill with the virus, thus reporting a mortality rate greater than 8% in people older than 70 years..10. According to the sex of the people, in this case there is no significant difference between the number of women and men that can be determined the number of infections of the virus.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The results obtained give clear indications that the regions with the most inequality are related to greater cases of COVID-19 since they reduce the possibilities that people can access on their own all medical devices that help prevent the spread of COVID-19..2. Economic activity is a clear driver of COVID-19 infections: primary sector, activities take place outdoors, which follows the line of what the health entities affirm, the activities with agglomeration of people provoke greater amount of virus contagion..3. These findings contradict what was found in the results of the secondary and tertiary sector variables, which indicate that the activities that have greater contact, interaction social or that develop in closed spaces, become a source of contagion of the virus.

author: Zapata and Prieto Rosas 2020
title: Structural and Contingent Inequalities: The Impact of COVID-19 on Migrant and Refugee Populations in South America
Objective(s): Systematic comparative assessment of the pre-pandemic living conditions of migrant and refugee populations (henceforth, ‘migrants’), combining microdata from census and household surveys with an analysis of the political-institutional response to COVID-19 adopted by six South American countries: Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Uruguay.
Population: Immigrant and refugee populations on 6 different countris of South America
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The income of informal workers in Latin America and the Caribbean decreased by 81 percent in the first month of the crisis; and 1.2 million Venezuelans in Colombia and Ecuador are expected to suffer severe food insecurity.2. The historical fragility of the region’s health systems means that although many countries pledge to offer universal health coverage, in practice only partial coverage is available.3. COVID-19 is fuelling racism, discrimination and xenophobia against migrants in Chile, Ecuador, Peru and Brazil, where negative attitudes towards migrants have increased in recent years. In Chile and Peru, expressions of social, institutional and media racism have involved stereotyping and scapegoating, and blaming migrants for the spread of.COVID-19. .4. T+he pandemic is reconfiguring mobility dynamics in the region, leading to ‘mobility in immobility’, that is, the emergence of two distinct but interrelated processes: return and forced
Policy or intervention associate: Political-institutional response to the pandemic by South American countries are increasing the vulnerability of migrants who attempt to cross militarised/closed borders and irregular migration as a consequence of the suspension of migration and asylum procedures.
Conclusions: 1. The structural and contingent inequalities and vulnerabilities laid bare by the COVID-19 pandemic may accelerate processes leading to social exclusion..2. Migrants and refugees are particularly exposed to the harmful effects of the pandemic given their segmented incorporation into precarious labour markets and limited and fragmented access to and exercise of health, labour, housing, and other social rights..3. It seems that these elements may combine in such a way as to make future intra- and inter-regional migration flows and governance unpredictable.
Funding sources: Project of the Research Group ‘Comparative Analysis on International Migration and Displacement in the Americas’ (CAMINAR).

author: Kühn, Alcoforado, and Farias 2020
title: New normalcy? Consumption and identity between reproduction of social inequalities and social transformation in Brazil
Objective(s): To critically analyze the narratives of change and the consumption practices of Brazilians interviewed during the period of social distancing
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The identity perspective will be used as theoretical ground to analyze and explore the symbolic meanings that individuals give to consumption and to understand how these meanings have changed during the course of the pandemic.
Type of social stratification: Changes in social perception and related feelings, the sense of belonging, social relations, political attitudes, consumption changes, and measures taken to tackle the pandemic
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Occupation.-Features of relationships (e.g. smoking parents, excluded from school.-Social capital
Main Results: 1. interviewees who have salary security, the quarantine period has been one of greater rest, decreased work rhythm and greater enjoyment of the family members..2. The less secure one’s own income is, the more threatening one’s own dependence and integration into the consumer sphere becomes. People feel under pressure and face the danger to feel socially excluded, to lose their status and control over their own life.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Pandemic encourages people to reflect on their consumption..2. Symbolic meanings of consumption in the identity construction were found to be ambiguous and It can understand them in two dimensions.3. even in times of pandemics, consumption contributes to the reproduction of social inequality and even leads to polarizations within society becoming more significant.

author: Cardoso et al. 2020
title: Characterizing the Impact of Social Inequality on COVID-19 Propagation in Developing Countries
Objective(s): To characterize the impact of social inequality on epidemic of COVID-19 propagation in developing countries
City or municipality: 27 capitals (26 states and the Federal District in Metropolitan Region of Belém (MRB), State of Par).
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The outbreak prediction model for charactering the impact of social inequality: The SEIR (Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, Recovered) model
Type of social stratification: -Poor Housing conditions ( high demographic density per room of residence and inadequate basic sanitation services).-Posibility of isolating (GROUP a. infectious individuals that can reduce their contamination rate ( as per restrictions advised by health agents) /  GROUP ß. infectious individuals that cannot effectively reduce their contamination rate).
Main Results: 1. Contamination rate reduction, from the 70th day, was 20% to 85% for those infectious individuals in group a.  For those people in group b, contamination rate was kept to the initial value..2. 14.54% of the population cannot reduce their contamination rate as they live in overpopulated households and with or without clean water..3. Social inequality has a strong effect in the results. While reducing contamination rate by 70% in a real scenario considering social inequality, there is still a peak of more than 55,000 active infected around the 225th day..4) Occupation, income, housing conditions, sanitation, access to water and public transport make up the worrying scenario that can become worse during the COVID-19 pandemic. These different aspects of socioeconomic status affect  the capability of isolation/quarantine of populations in social  vulnerability that depend on daily work for subsistence..
Policy or intervention associate: Governments must adopt special measures for those who live in precarious housing conditions and can allow these people  to be more protected as well and to be able to protect their peers. The reduction in the rate of contamination is not only affected by social distancing or restricted mobility, but also by the tracking and control of suspected cases..
Conclusions: 1. Overpopulated houses and with difficulty in accessing basic sanitation and clean water are unable to carry out the recommendations for social distancing and hygiene even though they are in home quarantine and, therefore, fail to decrease their rate of contamination..2. Non pharmaceutical interventions are crucial to break the disease transmission chains, thus minimizing their effects in health infrastructure

author: Valencia Londoño et al. 2021
title: The exacerbation of violence against women as a form of discrimination in the period of the COVID-19 pandemic
Objective(s): To analyze the determinants of violence against women in the period of pandemic in countries with contexts of criminal violence based on the understanding that violence against women is a form of discrimination, which implies understanding violence not only its physical, sexual and psychological manifestations in the private sphere, but also the forms of inequality that women face as a group (horizontal inequality) that perpetuate said violence.
City or municipality: Colombia: Medellin -  Valle del Río Lerma of Toluca
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Institutions, therefore, support and perpetuate discrimination against marginal populations like women, placing them in situations of precar iousness, ignoring due diligence, and turning their backs in periods of pandemic..2. Women are considered an expendable population group in the new normaleconomic model. The pandemic accelerated the shift to informality, or unpaid work, and the exacerbation of related violences..3. Public sphere remains the site of greater risk for women in terms of gender violence in countries like Colombia and Mexico. During the pandemic, the total number of homicides of women dropped dramatically, which speaks to the fact that the homicide of women and femicide more often occur in the public sphere than in the private..COLOMBIA.1. Of the women who are occupied, 70% dedicate themselves to commerce, for the most part hospitality, tourism, and the service industry. These economic sectors were some of the & hardest hit by the pandemic; commerce dropped by 3.3 percentage points in the period from March to June 2020, in comparison with the same period in 2019..2. The number of occupied men dropped by roughly 30%, whereas the number of women, by approximately 40%. The inoccupation and inactivity rates show corresponding increases; though the difference between men and women is less, the affection is consistently greater for women than for men..3. Unemployment rates shows labor deterioration and the persistence of inequality between men and women. In July 2019, the difference in the underemployment of men and women was 5%, with women more likely to be underemployed. The pandemic has exacerbated this difference, and in July 2020, female underemployment was 10% high than male underemployment.4. A statistical comparison for the period January to July in 2019 and 2020 was carried out in relation to three crimes: intrafamilial violence, sexual violence, and the homicide of women..5. Where intrafamilial violence increased in the period from January to March 2020 with respect to the same period in 2019. In March, April and May, a decrease to levels lower than the same months in 2019 was observed.
Policy or intervention associate: COLOMBIA: the national implementation of the preventative isolation measure, both cities declared a practice isolation that fed into the presidential measure..MEXICO: the State mandated the Jornada Nacional de Sana Distancia (National Healthy Distancing Campaign)
Conclusions: 1. In Colombia, like in Mexico, the prioritization of the study of the homicide of women in the intimate sphere obscures the risks women face in the public sphere..2. Structural violences take on the form of increased unemployment and inoccupation for women, a situation that places them in a position of economic dependency..3. It was believed that the confinement measures implemented in response to COVID-19 would increase the violence perpetuated against women including intrafamilial and gender violence and femicide..4. In the case of sexual violence, the reduced number of occurrences could be by explained the increased presence of the social help networks in the familial environment..5. The statistics regarding gender-related crimes during the confinement measures adopted as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic show that the home is a space of protection and not of risk..6. In countries with contexts of criminal violence like Mexico and Colombia, the analysis of violence against women must move beyond the private sphere and recognize the threat of violence in the public or community sphere, in which women -specifically young women-face high risk of experiencing violence..7. The design, construction and instrumentalization of integral, efficient, and effective public policies directed to wards stopping and overcoming the acts and practices that perpetuate different forms of gender-based violence.

author: J. Silva and Ribeiro-Alves 2021
title: Social inequalities and the pandemic of COVID-19: The case of Rio de Janeiro
Journal: Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health
Objective(s): To describe what socio- demographic and socioeconomic factors were asso- ciated with the greatest risk of COVID-19 infection and mortality
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: -Age (aggregated by 20-year windows).-Gender: Male/felame.-Neighbourhoods of only confirmed cases and deaths (disaggregated geographic level).-Socioeconomic issues:.crowding ( bathroom per person).education (% of illiteracy of neighbourhood residents from 10 to 14 years old).income (annual household per capita income as minimum wage fraction, 2010 R$510 current) .race/ethnicity (% of black or brown self-declared neighbourhood residents).
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Education.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Gender/sex.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).
Main Results: 1. Women were nearly 0.73 times more likely to be infected or die with COVID-19 than men..2. Statistically significant differences in age-standardised mortality rates unfavourable to males..3. Probability of dying when infected was higher for women, 18%..4. People aged over 80 years had a mortality risk 12 times higher.5. Case fatality rate was almost five times higher than individuals aged 40–59 years..6. Socioeconomic factors (crowding, education, income and race/ethnicity) were correlated with a higher age-standardised mortality rate, although the age-standardised incidence rate showed the opposing or mixed trend depending on which socio- economic factors were considered..7. People living in high-income neighbourhoods (highest quartile) had 37% more risk to be infected than low-income ones (lowest quartile), even though in low-income areas, they had 56% more risk to die (36.4 vs 57 per 100000 persons)..8. People living in high-income neighbourhoods (highest quartile) had 37% more risk to be infected than low-income ones (lowest quartile), even though in low-income areas, they had 56% more risk to die (36.4 vs 57 per 100000 persons)...
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Social inequalities are associated with COVID-19 burden distribution in Rio. .2. Cases moving towards the urban periphery and more vulnerable communities. .3. Comorbidities in these areas pointed out the necessity of fast interventions to protect people by reducing COVID-19 risk exposure..4. Despite higher COVID-19 age-standardised incidence rate in wealthy areas, both age-standardised mortality rate and case fatality rate behaviour indicated a health gradient..5. Pre-existing conditions are risk factors to COVID-19 and therefore increase their susceptibility, which is confirmed by the higher risks of death in these deprived areas..6. People over 80 years old were more likely to become infected and die than any other age group.

author: Bernardo, do Rosario, and Conte-Junior 2021
title: Covid-19 pandemic in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil: A social inequality report
Objective(s): To perform a retrospective report on the lethality of COVID-19 in different realities in the city of Rio de Janeiro (RJ).
Population: Confirmed cases of COVID-19 and deaths (Data from from the Rio de Janeiro City Health Secretary)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis. A one-tailed student’s t-test was executed for two independent samples comparing the CFR means between the two groups, at a significance level of 0.05.
Type of social stratification: -Social development index (SDI) ((i) adequate water supply, sewage and garbage collection network, (ii) number of bathrooms per resident per household, (iii) illiteracy rate, and (iv) per capita income per household).-Neighbourhood: high social developed / Favelas (of households with at least 51 housing units, irregularly occupying public or private properties, and without access to essential public services .
Main Results: Neighbourhoods:.1) The highest case-fatality rate (CFR) was obtained in Ipanema (7.06%), while the lowest CFR was determined in Jardim Botânico (2.94%), and the average presented was 4.87%..Favelas.2) Average CFR calculated for the favelas of RJ was 9.08%, with the lowest rate being Complexo do Alemão (6.12%) and the highest rate being the favela Acari (17.39%)..3) The difference between CFR averages among neighborhoods and slums was significant (p < 0.05).
Policy or intervention associate: (...) Rio de Janeiro is one of the main cities affected by the coronavirus but has shown evidence of suppression of mortality from SARS-CoV-2 (...) THIS is due to follow the WHO recommended control strategies by adopting short-term (e.g., implementation of a lockdown system) and long-term (e.g., early self-isolation, social distancing, remotely medical advice, and efficient support for diagnosis and treatment at home) mitigation measures.
Conclusions: 1. Lethality of COVID-19 in the favelas of RJ is higher when compared to the high social developed neighborhoods..2. This problem is directly related to food restriction and food quality access, which may be responsible for malnutrition..3. Only a small portion of the population has been benefited from these damage mitigation strategies due to unequal access to primary health-care conditions and public policies aimed at the city’s needy communities, aggravated by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Funding sources: The Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (FAPERJ) and  the Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico (CNPq)—and the Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior (CAPES) Brazil—Finance Code 001.

author: M. V De Albuquerque et al. 2020
title: Inequality, geographic situation, and meanings of action in the COVID-19 pandemic in brazil
Objective(s): To reflect on how the concepts of socio-spatial inequality and geographic situation can help understand COVID-19’s spread in Brazil
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The results show the places with the greatest risk or vulnerability to the pandemic and mainly that the socio-spatial inequalities bear a direct relationship to the spread and case-fatality of COVID-19 on various regional and intraurban scales..2. Processes of metropolization facilitate the spread of the virus, since they are characterized by high population concentration and circulation, diversification of resources, infrastructure, commerce, services, fluidity, and regional, national, and international connections, in addition to the simultaneous production of poverty, shortages, and contradictions..3. Metropolises concentrate and reproduce inequalities through intensified processes of production of wealth and scarcity, polarizing and draining values, energies, and resources..4. There are also important differences in the pandemic between state capitals, metropolitan areas, and the hinterlands of Brazil. Brazil’s territory is highly diverse and unequal..5. This is further complexified the places’ degree of adherence to the neoliberal agenda, which further increases the vulnerability of living conditions, functioning of public systems, and the organization, distribution, and use of available resources..6. Considering the necessary supply of healthcare services, workers, and equipment to care for COVID-19 patients, publications point to major regional inequality in Brazil..7. In Brazil, certain places may be especially vulnerable to the COVID-19 pandemic. First, the metropolises and areas with consolidated urbanization. Second, the places marked by corporate uses with intense spoliation of the territory, modernizations, and selective investments linked to certain productive specializations. Third, places of conservation use and lands occupied by traditional populations..8. The denial of the pandemic’s seriousness and of its repercussions by a minority of the population and mainly by the Federal Executive Branch has jeopardized coordinated actions at the national level and the adoption of necessary measures. The meaning of responses to the pandemic at the national level has caused the extension and exacerbation in time and space of the health, economic, and social crises resulting from the pandemic..9. Plans and policies may not present the proper consistency or correspond to the country’s different realities, vulnerabilities, and geographic situations..10. The political variable is crucial to the directions the pandemic takes and cannot be totally grasped by models and projections of risk and vulnerability. This also highlights the importance of analyzing geographic situations as meaning and condition for action by all persons, companies, and governmental and nongovernmental institutions in the territory.
Policy or intervention associate: HELP: The COVID-19 Observatory in the Quilombos monitors nationwide data on the pandemic among members of the maroon communities, having been created by the.National Coordinating Body for Quilombola Black Rural Communities (Conaq) and the Socioenvironmental Institute (ISA). .Crisis cabinets were created in the favelas in Rio de Janeiro, for example in the Complexo do created by the Voice of the Communities, Women in Action in and the Straight Talk Collective..There are many such examples of action by the population, committees, fronts, and social movements in fighting the pandemic in Brazil. Such actions lend new meanings for people living in socially vulnerable places.
Conclusions: 1. Socio-spatial inequalities and geographic situations relate to the degree of globalization and vulnerability for places and are conditioning factors for COVID-19 as well as for actions to fight the pandemic..2. The pandemic’s risks and problems are not only conditioned by poverty or lack of healthcare services, but above all by the unequal conditions of risk, protection, and care in all dimensions of life..3. Action strategies in the common sense, with solidarity and social protection, aimed at reducing vulnerabilities, show that overcoming the pandemic and its consequences depends fundamentally on the decision to confront the socio-spatial inequalities on multiple scales – local, regional, national, and global – and the understanding and knowledge of the conditions for action.

author: R. G. B. De Oliveira et al. 2020
title: Racial inequalities and death on the horizon: Covid-19 and structural racism
Objective(s): To focus the debate precisely on the world’s racial division and its visible repercussions on the COVID-19 pandemic
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: Race: White/Black
Main Results: 1. The COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil shows that regions and populations are subjected to conditions of increased vulnerability to the risks of infection and death..2. During the pandemic, the risk of infection for nurse attendants is 97.3%, due to direct handling of patients’ bodies. The use of personal protective equipment is crucial for the worker’s protection, but the supply of personal protect equipment has been inadequate. Nursing is a mostly female and black professional class, working on frontline care of COVID-19 patients. As women, they also work a double workload..3. The association between frontline care of COVID-19 patients, precarious housing, and overload of household work increases both the probability of infection at home and the illness itself..4. The blackest territories of the city also suffer from the unequal distribution of ICU (intensive care unit) beds, 60% of which are located in the wealthier city center..5. Given the shortage of precise epidemiological data disaggregated for the favelas and the erratic state government agenda and insufficient response to COVID-19 in these neighborhoods, local collectives have launched their own initiatives, demonstrating the organizational power of local action in emergency situations..6. The proportions of COVID-19 hospitalizations and deaths were initially higher in whites than in blacks. However, over the course of the EWs, there was a reduction in the proportion of deaths and hospitalizations in whites, while they increased in the black population..7. This highlights the magnitude of the drop in hospitalizations and deaths in whites and the increase in blacks in just a few weeks, underscoring the trend in racial inequalities and the maintenance of the racialized political and social conditions affecting black lives..8. The number of deaths in blacks exceeds that in whites, even though hospitalization does not follow this trend..9. This emphasizes the black population’s difficulty in accessing health services, especially higher-complexity services such as intensive care beds, a critical resource in the current pandemic.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This unequal behavior of the disease between the white and black populations, with an unfavorable trend in the latter, corroborates the analyses on racial inequalities in Brazil, resulting from the country’s colonial background, which takes for granted the place destined to each person depending on their race, which is also a political construction..2. COVID-19’s impact on the black population is already visible in some spaces: the media, scientific debates, and certain government agendas. The problem’s visibility, pressured by black voices, mainly from the periphery, continues to be part of the antiracist struggle’s banner, raised especially by the black people.

author: Ranzani et al. 2021
title: Characterisation of the first 250 000 hospital admissions for COVID-19 in Brazil: a retrospective analysis of nationwide data
Objective(s): To analyse characteristics of patients admitted to hospital with COVID-19 in Brazil, and to examine the impact of COVID-19 on health-care resources and in-hospital mortality.
City or municipality: Five regions: North, Northeast, Central-West, Southeast, and South.
Population: Patients diagnosed with COVID-19 admitted to hospital
Sample size: n=254,288 COVID19 patients (Data from the Influenza Epidemiological Surveillance Information System, SIVEP-Gripe (Sistema de Informação de Vigilância Epidemiológica da Gripe), a nationwide surveillance database used to monitor severe acute respiratory infections in Brazil)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive analysis (medians and IQRs or means and SDs to summarise continuous variables, and calculated frequencies and proportions for categorical variables. It calculated age-adjusted and sex-adjusted rates for each macroregion by the direct method).2. They stratified the analysis by the following variables: age; sex; number of comorbidities (cardiovascular, renal, neurological, haematological, or hepatic comorbidities, diabetes, chronic respiratory disorder, obesity, or immunosuppression); level of education; self-reported race or skin colour (Branco [White], Preto [Black], Pardo [Brown], Amarelo [Asian], or Indígena [Indigenous]), hereafter referred to as self-reported race; ICU admission; and respiratory support.
Type of social stratification: -Level of education: Illiterate / Up to high school /High school /College or university.-Race: White/Black/Brown/Amarelo /Indigenous.-Macroregions: North /Northeast/ Central-West/ Southeast/South.- age.- Gender: Male/Female.-self-reported symptoms.-Comorbidities: cardiovascular/ renal/ neurological/ haematological/  hepatic comorbidities/ diabetes/ chronic respiratory disorder/ obesity/ or immunosuppression.- ICU admission .-Ventilatory support.-In-hospital outcome (death /discharge)..
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Education.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1.  There were notable disparities in the number of hospital and ICU beds between macroregions and between state capitals and towns..2. Black or Brown patients accounted for more than two-thirds of COVID-19 cases in the North, Northeast, and Central-West regions (table 1). In-hospital deaths was higher in Black or Brown (34 345 [43%] of 80 392), or Indigenous (202 [42%] of 477).3. In-hospital mortality for patients without comorbidities was 32% (4494 of 13836 patients;).4. Severe acute respiratory infection was present in 128 958 (61%) of 211 032 patients and was more frequent in the North than in other regions (table 1).5. In the Northeast, 1545 (16%) of 9960 patients received invasive mechanical ventilation outside the ICU, compared with 431 (8%) of 5388 in the South..6. in-hospital mortality was 38% (87 515 of 232036 patients), increasing steeply with age (...) 22 651 [55%] of 41 434 patients aged 70–79 years; and 22 787 [66%] of 34 385 patients aged =80 years); In-hospital mortality was higher overall in the North and Northeast.7. In-hospital deaths was higher among patients who were illiterate (3146 [63%] of 4993), .8. In-hospital mortality was higher in patients admitted to the ICU (47002 [59%] of 79 687) than in those admitted to the ward (29361 [29%] of 125806). It was also higher in patients who received invasive mechanical ventilation (36 046 [80%] of 45 205) than in those who did not (36 942 [24%] of 151043). .9. ICU admissions per ICU bed, the North had the highest rate of admissions (2246 per 1000 ICU beds), followed by the Southeast (2217 per 1000 ICU beds), Northeast (2073 per 1000 ICU beds)..10. 54% of patients were admitted to hospital in the state capitals, but this proportion was lower for the South (32%) and higher for the North (61%), Northeast (70%), and Central-West (71%) regions (table 1)..11. Patients that were admitted to the ICU and mechanically ventilated was similar across age groups in the North, but the proportion of patients admitted to the ICU was higher than those receiving invasive mechanical ventilation in the other regions.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article.
Conclusions: 1. Existing regional heterogeneity of the health system, followed by the temporal spread of the epidemic, and disparities in adherence to best practices for clinical management of.severely ill patients, have contributed to the differences observed in mortality and resource use among the regions.2. The North and Northeast regions have the lowest number of hospital beds per person in Brazil. The difference is even more pronounced when analysing ICU beds: the Southeast had approximately two times more ICU beds per person than the North at the beginning of the pandemic in Brazil..3. Patients admitted to hospital in state capitals, which was noticeably lower in the South and Southeast regions, possibly reflecting better availability of health services to meet the demand across these regions..4. Organisational factors and implementation of the best practices available result not only in better outcomes, such as mortality, but also in improved ICU efficiency (...) high-quality care provided in some hospitals contrasts sharply with that provided in most facilities, which is frequently of lower quality.
Funding sources: National Council for Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq), Coordinating Agency for Advanced Training of Graduate Personnel (CAPES), Carlos Chagas Filho Foundation for Research Support of the State of Rio de Janeiro (FAPERJ), and Instituto de Salud Carlos III.

author: P R Martins-Filho et al. 2021
title: Socio-economic inequalities and COVID-19 incidence and mortality in Brazilian children: a nationwide register-based study
Objective(s): To estimate the incidence and mortality rates of COVID-19 in Brazilian children and (2) to analyze its relationship with socio-economic inequalities in a state-level analysis.
Population: Children aged 0 to 19 years with COVID-19 (September 3, 2020)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The relationship between COVID-19 rates in Brazilian children and socio-economic vulnerability at the state level using Spearman's rank correlation (r), categorizing correlations as very weak (0e0.19), weak (0.2e0.39), moderate (0.4e0.59), strong (0.6e0.79), or very strong (0.8e1.0). P-values <0.05 were considered  statistically significant
Type of social stratification: -Social Vulnerability Index (SVI).-Gini coefficient.-Region: Northeast /North/Central-West /Southeast /South /Brazil
Main Results: 1. Not clear evidence of a relationship between the incidence of COVID-19 in children and socio-economic inequality in a state-level analysis, a correlation was found between mortality rates and social (p=0.519; P-value=0.007; effect magnitude: moderate) and economic (p=0.615; P-value < 0.001; effect magnitude: strong) inequalities..2. A low mortality rate of approximately one death from COVID-19 per 100,000 in the pediatric population in the country, this population-based study showed a moderate to strong relationship between mortality and socioeconomic inequalities..3. It is important to recognize health inequalities among vulnerable populations to improve access to health care, the surveillance system, protocols for diagnosis and management, and effective social protection response during disease outbreaks.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The knowledge of sociogeographic differences in the estimates of COVID-19 is crucial to planning societal strategies and local decision-making to mitigate the effects of disease in the pediatric population..2. Exploratory analysis using publicly available data has limitations associated with the lack of accuracy, this population based study found important regional differences in COVID-19 estimates for children in Brazil and a relationship between mortality rates and socio-economic inequalities.
Funding sources: Coordination for the Improvement of Higher Education Personnel -CAPES/Brazil (Finance code 001), Research and Technological Innovation Support Foundation of the State of Sergipe - FAPITEC/SE (EDITAL CAPES/FAPITEC N. 11/2016 - PROEF; and EDITAL CAPES/FAPITEC N. 10/2016 - PROMOB) and National Council for Scientifi and Technological Development - CNPq/Brazil (Finance code 09/2018). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript.

author: Martins et al. 2020
title: How socio-economic and atmospheric variables impact COVID-19 and influenza outbreaks in tropical and subtropical regions of Brazil
Objective(s): To investigate the associations of COVID-19 cases and the number of hospital admissions by Influenza with atmospheric variables, social distancing and socio-economic conditions for different climate regions in Brazil.
Sample size: Five Brazilian states representing different climate: The Amazonas, Maranhão, Ceara, Espírito Santo and Paraná.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Generalized Additive Model for Location, Scale and Shape (GAMLSS), combined with the negative binomial distribution, a distribution belonging to the exponential family
Type of social stratification: - Human Development Index (HDI): income/education/ health.-Climatic regimes: humidity/ rainfall frequency/ insolation.-Mobility restrictions imposed by COVID-19 (different levels of intensity).-Mobility Reports trends, an indicator provided by Google.-Access to clean water supply.-Elderly fraction (=60 years old),.
Main Results: 1. The reduction in mobility was not significant, but much worse for Amazonas, where the adhesion to social distancing was lower and mobility was reduced by only 20% in the studied period..2. Despite the sub-notification, the number of infected people is lower in Paraná (PR), which is the most populous of all analyzed states in this study. Also, PR is a neighbor of Sao Paulo, which is by far the state with the highest number of cases in Brazil.3. The minimum temperature is a risk factor only for PR, which has a subtropical  climate. These results suggest that minimum and maximum temperatures in this type of climate are a risk factor for cases of COVID-19..4. Socio-economic conditions (HDI) proved to be the most important risk factor among the states. This suggests a difficulty for people to understand the importance of hygiene measures and social distancing on the spread of COVID-19..5. HDI index indirectly measures the difficulty that people have to keep social distancing due to the daily need to search for resources for their livelihood. Therefore, income and education levels are the main relevant factors..6. Access to the health care system is another important factor related to socio-economic conditions that can also help explain the high number of deaths in Amazonas (AM), Ceará (CE), and Maranhao (MA), the states with less ICU available by inhabitant.7. Fraction of elderly, is also an important risk factor, as(...) because (...) The elderly are the most vulnerable group to COVID-19..8. Maximum temperature and humidity are the main atmospheric risk factors for hospital admissions by influenza in all analyzed climate regimes..9. Age is the most important risk factor for influenza, as demonstrated by an RR of 1.7151 (95% CI: 1.6742–1.7574)..10. HDI showed statistical significance for COVID-19 and Influenza, and Amazonas was the state with the highest significance for this variable (see the p-value in Table S3). HDI and the elderly are important factors for COVID-19 cases, while the elderly fraction is remarkably the main factor for Influenza in the set of variables and states.
Policy or intervention associate: The president’s speech against the WHO recommendations forced the Federal Court of Justice to determine (on April 08) that the competence to adopt or to maintain measures during the COVID-19 pandemic should be shared between the three levels of government: federal, state and municipal administrations. However, only the last two moved to do something in their own way, without any coordination or effort from the Ministry of Health.
Conclusions: 1.  Despite the relevance of social distancing, indicated in this study by mobility, the climate had an important influence on both COVID-19 and Influenza suggesting that, for the tropical region (AM, MA, and CE), COVID-19 arrived in a favorable time (abnormal rainy season that influenced humidity). 2. COVID-19 arrived in unfavorable periods and atypical meteorological conditions for PR state(drier and sunnier conditions + solar radiation) that contributed to the control of COVID-19 spread in the state..3. Age is the most important risk factor for influenza, while for COVID-19 the HDI is the most important factor to explain the differences among regions in the number of COVID-19 cases followed by age and social distancing.
Funding sources: The Brazilian National Council for Scientific and Technological Development (Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnol´ogico -CNPq), process grant No. 306862/2018-2.

author: E. A. Oliveira et al. 2021
title: Clinical characteristics and risk factors for death among hospitalised children and adolescents with COVID-19 in Brazil: an analysis of a nationwide database.
Objective(s): To characterise the clinical features of children and adolescents hospitalised with laboratory-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and to evaluate the risk factors for COVID-19-related death in this population.
City or municipality: Five regions: North/ Northeast/ Central-West/ Southeast/ South
Population: Patients diagnosed with COVID-19 admitted to hospital
Sample size: n=11,613 COVID19 patients (Data from the Influenza Epidemiological Surveillance Information System, SIVEP-Gripe (Sistema de Informação de Vigilância Epidemiológica da Gripe), a nationwide surveillance database used to monitor severe acute respiratory infections in Brazil)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive analyisis (medians and IQRs or means and SDs).2. Death was evaluated by competing risks analysis using the cumulative incidence function. Discharge was analysed as a competing event by competing risks analysis..The proportional sub-distribution hazards model by Fine and Gray was fitted to estimate the effect of covariates on mortality. Results are expressed as adjusted hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% CIs.
Type of social stratification: -Race: White/Black/Brown/Amarelo /Indigenous.-Macroregions: North /Northeast/ Central-West/ Southeast/South.- age.- Gender: Male/Female.-self-reported symptoms.-Number of comorbidities.-In-hospital outcome (death /discharge)..
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1. Risk of death was increased in infants younger than 2 years (HR 1·88 [95% CI1·58–2·24]) and adolescents aged 12–19 years (1·98 [1·65–2·36]) .2. Risk of death was increased in  (...) patients from the Northeast region (2·03 [1·72–2·38]) and North region (1·53 [1·25–1·87]) relative to those from the Southeast region. .3. Compared with White patients, children of Black or Brown ethnicity (1·30 [1·11–1·53]) and Indigenous ethnicity (3·27 [2·17–4·93]) were also at increased risk of death.4. The presence of any comorbidity and the number of comorbidities increased the risk of death in the univariable analysis, (...), with the exception of asthma, which decreased.the risk of death (0·60 [0·42–0·85])..Figure 4 shows the cumulative incidence functions for death in the presence of these risk factors.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Death from COVID-19 was associated with age, indigenous ethnicity, poor geopolitical region, and pre-existing medical conditions.  .2. In this study, patients of Black or Brown ethnicity represented about 50% of our overall sample, but 85% of the sample from the North and Northeast regions (data not shown). Therefore, both variables are probably providing similar information related to social inequalities and low socioeconomic..3. Prevalence of comorbidity was around 30% in the overall sample, but around 50% in patients who died, (...)  with risk of death increasing with number of pre-existing medical conditions..4. Health-care disparities and social inequalities, exacerbated by interweaving comorbidities, might have contributed synergistically to magnify the COVID-19 burden for more socioeconomically deprived and vulnerable individuals..
Funding sources: National Council for Scientific and Technological Development, Research Support Foundation of Minas Gerais.

author: Mena et al. 2021
title: Socioeconomic status determines COVID-19 incidence and related mortality in Santiago, Chile.
Objective(s): To analyze incidence and mortality attributed to SARS-CoV-2 infection and its association with demographic and socioeconomic status across the urban metropolitan area of the capital of Chile, known as “Greater Santiago.”
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Parsimonious Gaussian process model to study excess deaths and their uncertainty and reconstructed true incidence from the time series of deaths with a new regularized maximum likelihood deconvolution method..2. To estimate infection fatality rates by age and socioeconomic status, we implemented a hierarchical Bayesian model that adjusts for reporting biases while accounting for incompleteness in case information.
Type of social stratification: -Socioeconomic status (SES): It is not clear the categories.-COVID-19 deaths and cases.-Human mobility.
Main Results: 1. Municipalities with highest Socioeconomic status (SES) exhibited a reduction in mobility by up to 61% during the full lockdown compared with the ones with lowest SES, which, on average, reduced their mobility to 40% during the this period..2. Poorer regions cannot afford to stay at home during lockdowns..3. Significantly higher number of tests performed in municipalities with high SES..4. Early peak of reported cases was only observed in high-SES municipalities during the middle of March, even though several COVID-19 deaths, which are lagged with respect to infection by up to several weeks, were reported in low-SES municipalities during the same period..5. Early failure of health care systems in informing the population with sufficient situational awareness about the real magnitude of the threat. strong negative association between positivity and SES further denotes difficulties in access to health care that is even more pronounced in lower-SES municipalities..6. Municipalities with low SES, on average, get their test results later than the ones with high SES.7. Age group 80+ exhibits the highest expected mortality values for 2020, the group that contains people between 60 and 80 years old displays the highest weekly count (936 during epidemiological week 24), the biggest deviation from the predicted values, and the highest values of excess deaths (645 more deaths than expected)..8. Suggesting a higher death burden in lower-SES municipalities, independent of their age composition..9. Higher infection fatality rate (IFR) in the low-SES group in people younger than 80 years old, age groups 60 to 80 and 40 to 60 IFRs = 1.4 and 1.7 times higher, respectively, in the low-SES category compared with the high-SES one.  more pronounced in the younger age group (0 to 40 years old), which shows values of IFR that are 3.1 times higher for the municipalities with the lowest SES.
Policy or intervention associate: Public health measures were taken in response to nominal case counts, these places were underprepared, with a poor health care response that resulted in higher death counts.
Conclusions: 1. How socially and economically deprived populations are more vulnerable to the burden of epidemics.2. That municipalities with lower Socioeconomic Status (SES) were less compliant with stay-at-home orders, possibly because people from lower-SES areas are unable to work from home, which leaves them at a higher disease risk..3. Underreporting of infections in low-income areas at the start of the outbreak..4. Anomalies in the overall excess deaths are higher in low-SES areas, particularly in people younger than 80 years old, suggesting that more vulnerable municipalities were hit the hardest..5. Needing for greater testing and detection. slower turnaround in test results can lead to greater potential for transmission.6. Slower turnaround in test results can lead to greater potential for transmission, a higher infection fatality rate may reflect limited access to health services during the pandemic, and the strong association between the number of tests per death and SES supports this claim..7. Health coverage division South and West zones have four times fewer beds per 10,000 people and four times lower proportion enrolled in the private health system than the East zone, which contains all the municipalities with an SES of 60 or higher. Notably, more than 90% of the COVID-19 attributed deaths in the South and West zones occurred in places other than health care facilities, compared with 55% in the East zone..8. low-SES municipalities are more likely to be overweight and to live in overcrowded conditions (supplementary materials), factors that ultimately can put these populations at higher disease risk..9. More resilient and socially aware public health strategies can be planned in advance of future pandemics.
Funding sources: Partially supported by a Harvard Data Science Initiative fellowship and P.P.M. by a grant from the National Institute of General Medical Science (U54GM088558). and  Schmidt futures award  and the National Institute of General Medical Science (R01GM130668).

author: Baqui et al. 2020
title: Ethnic and regional variations in hospital mortality from COVID-19 in Brazil: a cross-sectional observational study.
Objective(s): To characterise the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, particularly regarding risk factors related to comorbidities, symptoms, and ethnicity, similarly to previous analyses
Population: Patients diagnosed with COVID-19 admitted to hospital (Data from SIVEP-Gripe public dataset)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Used descriptive statistics to quantify the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, and mixed-effects Cox regression to investigate the importance of record-level risk factors and estimate hazard ratios (HRs)..2. Regional variations in patients with COVID-19 admitted to hospital by state and by two socioeconomically grouped regions (north and central-south).
Type of social stratification: -Ethnicity: Branco (White)/ Preto (Black)/ Amarelo (East Asian)/ Indígeno (Indigenous)/ Pardo (mixed ethnicity)..-Macroregions: North/Northeast/Central-west/Southeast/South.-Age.-Gender: Male/Female.-Comorbidities: Cardiovascular disease/ Asthma / Diabetes / Pulmonary disease / Obesity / Immunosuppression/ /Renal disease / Liver disease / Neurological disease
Main Results: 1. Survivors in both north and central-south regions were younger and more likely to be White and women, whereas non-survivors were older and more likely to be Black and Pardo..2. Almost all comorbidities were more common in non-survivors in the north than in the central-south, suggesting structural health disparities..3. In the north region, the pattern of younger patients having a higher likelihood of survival was even more pronounced than in the central-south region..4. Compared with White Brazilians, Pardo and Black Brazilians admitted to hospital had significantly higher risk of mortality (HR 1·45, 95% CI 1·33–1·58 for Pardo Brazilians; 1·32, 1·15–1·52 for Black Brazilians: Pardo ethnicity was the second most important risk factor for death after age..5. Cox regression results were qualitatively similar for north and central-south regions, metropolitan and rural subgroups, and public-predominant and private-predominant health-care subgroups, suggesting robustness to differences in outbreak start and outliers.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Survivors were more likely to be younger, be women, and have fewer comorbidities. .2. Increased death rate of Pardo Brazilians might be partly due to non-ICU admission, raising concerns regarding the organisation of public and private medical resources..3. The disproportionately large percentage of survivors with no comorbidities in the central-south region is remarkable. Comorbidities seem unlikely to be associated with ethnicity in our study, but rather they might be associated with regional socioeconomic development (education, income, and health)..4. It observed similar proportions between White and Pardo ethnicities when comparing total hospitalizations with deaths after ICU admission..5. The present evidence suggesting a higher risk of death among Pardo and Black Brazilians and in the north region of Brazil. .6. Major metropolitan areas might be particularly affected, and that it is highly plausible that viral spread might be particularly rapid in these settings.

author: Bonfiglio 2021
title: Efectos de la pandemia Covid 19 sobre la inseguridad alimentaria
Objective(s): To evaluate a series of aspects related to the impact of the Covid 19 pandemic context on the food insecurity situation for households in the Buenos Aires Metropolitan Area (AMBA).
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis and logistic regression models looked to account for the explanatory factors of the regressive transitions experienced by households in relation to situations of total food insecurity and severe food insecurity.
Type of social stratification: -Occupational: middle professional/ non-professional/ integrated worker/marginal worker.-Health insurance: Yes/No.-Poverty: Yes/No
Main Results: 1. The most vulnerable categories such as marginal status households, those that were income-poor in 2019, marginal working status households, those with children, and those that were not affiliated with the social security system, for these profiles, the incidence of moderate food insecurity is maintained and even decreases as severe food insecurity increases. .2. The severe food insecurity, on the other hand, affected in 2020 more households that were not in it in 2019 (5.6%) and the exits represent a lower in relative..3. Households in the marginal working status were between 5 and 6 times more likely to go to severe food insecurity or total food insecurity than households in the middle professional status..4. The household does not have any income from registered employment or contributory retirement gives 3 times more chances of experiencing food insecurity and 60% more than.chances of falling into severe food insecurity compared to those who have another type of link with the health insurance..5. The condition of poverty was a relevant factor to explain the fall in severe food insecurity, although with no net effect on total food insecurity.
Policy or intervention associate: Social policy: social assistance, in this sense a positive effect of the Alimentar Card
Conclusions: 1. The impact of the COVID 19 pandemic resulted in a significant increase in food insecurity, accentuating the increase in the most extreme situations, that is, those of households that experienced severe food insecurity, implying in these cases a reduction in diet and experiences of hunger at home..2. The structural inequality that manifests itself in a heterogeneous and segmented labor market constitutes an explanatory factor for the unequal impact of food insecurity on households..3. Parallel to a downward movement (either from security situations to moderate or severe insecurity or from moderate insecurity to severe insecurity) there were also dynamics of exit from situations of food insecurity, we believe that this could be explained mainly by transfers from social policy.

author: Carvalho et al. 2021
title: Índice de vulnerabilidade à COVID-19: uma aplicação para a cidade de Fortaleza (CE), Brasil
Objective(s): To propose an index of vulnerability to the spread of COVID-19 using multivariate and geospatial analyses
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. In order to avoid redundancy between information, Spearman's correlation was applied. The technique was used in order to estimate the correlation between variables, as it allows the assessment of monotonic relationships between them, whether linear or not..2. The classification was performed using four different methods (K-means, Jenks, Quantil and HClust), in order to avoid methodological bias.
Type of social stratification: -Population density.-Subnormal and precarious housing.-Percentage of elderly people by residence and location of bus terminals.-Vulnerability Classification to COVID-19: Jenks/ K-means/ Quantil / Hclust
Main Results: 1. Several regions of the city have homes inhabited by the elderly (over 60 years), the population being more vulnerable to the virus and more likely to develop the most severe symptoms of the disease..2. Residents who do not have access to a bathroom or toilet, or whose sewage discharge is carried out in the open, are more likely to acquire the disease and transmit it to their families..3. The variable proximity to a bus terminal (TERM) reflects a greater probability of the existence of agglomerations between infected people and residents of the region. Despite the measures of social distancing, the reduction in the vehicle fleet tends to result in overloading the bus terminals..4. The terminals are located in the most socially vulnerable areas of the city, where a large part of the subnormal agglomerates are concentrated, where public services are insufficient and the infrastructure of residences is inadequate..5. Figure 3 allows us to visualize the socioeconomic discrepancies between the different regions of the city.6. For the low and very low Human development Index sectors of the East Coastal Zones (Vicente Pinzon and Cais do Porto/Serviluz) and West (Grande Pirambu and Barra do Ceará), concentrate a population dependent on the public health system, being identified as neighborhoods with the highest deficits in infrastructure, sanitation conditions and housing situation, in addition to a more socially and economically vulnerable population with a higher incidence of comorbidities.7. An analysis of the numbers of cases verified by neighborhood also highlights the considerably higher response capacity in upscale neighborhoods, which, despite the alarming number of confirmed cases, have a lower number of deaths, unlike peripheral neighborhoods with lower infrastructure conditions. Thus, vulnerability shows a close relationship with the precarious conditions to which the various regions of the municipality are subjected
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The evolution of the COVID-19 contagion rate in the city of Fortaleza shows that, at first, neighborhoods with the highest per capita income in the city had higher numbers of confirmed cases, due to the return of people from countries where they already there was sustained contamination of the disease..2. However, it was not long before the contagion rate increased in poorer regions. At the moment, the number of infections is decreasing in areas with the highest Human development Index and there is already a sustained spread of the virus in all neighborhoods of the city..3. What should be highlighted is the fact that the number of deaths is disproportionate between regions.4. The results obtained highlight the need for urgent and severe measures in regions detected, classified and mapped as immunocompromised, which present high levels of vulnerability..5.
