The methodological processes applied to construct the index can be replicated in other Brazilian cities and in the world, as techniques considered technically robust and widely disseminated in the scientific community were used..6. For regions assessed as highly vulnerable, measures such as mass quarantine, extensive restriction of mobility and sanitization in the most critical regions are recommended..7. In addition, it is essential to provide drinking water, soap, masks and monitoring of daily infections in a city that has the highest rate of infected people per inhabitant in a country that already has the highest rate of infection in the world
Funding sources: National Council for Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq) (ALOCA Project, No. 420882/2018-9), Ceará Foundation for Scientific and Technological Development Support (FUNCAP) and Coordination for the Improvement of Higher Education Personnel — Brazil (CAPES).

author: Demenech et al. 2020
title: Desigualdade econômica e risco de infecção e morte por COVID-19 no Brasil
Objective(s): To evaluate, based on space-time analyses, whether there is a relationship between income inequality and infection and death by COVID-19 in the Federative Units (FUs) of Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Gini coefficient, a measure adopted for estimating the degree of income concentration of the population of each FU.2. Population density, by the Spearman’s correlation test..3. The Prais-Winsten regression, based on the Durbin-Watson test, for the weekly temporal evolution of the incidence and mortality rates due to COVID-19. .4. Spatial autocorrelation between the outcomes (incidence and mortality due to COVID-19) and the independent variables (Gini coefficient and population density).5. Diagnosis of spatial autocorrelation of two regression models was conducted, one using the weekly variation in incidence as the outcome and the other, the weekly variation in mortality..6. Moran’s and Lagrange Multiplier tests (of the types of lag and errors, including robust tests for testing the spatial autocorrelation).
Type of social stratification: The GINI index
Main Results: 1. The Federative Units (FUs) with the highest income inequality, according to the Gini coefficient, is Amazonas (0.6664), followed by Roraima (0.6398) and Acre (0.6394).2. The FU with the lowest concentration is Santa Catarina (0.4942), followed by Paraná (0.5416) and Rio Grande do Sul (0.5472)..3. There was an increasing mortality rate in all Brazilian FUs, with a greater increase in Ceará (+64.54/1 million inhabitants per week), Amazonas (+61.08/1 million inhabitants per week), and Pará (+56.38/1 million inhabitants per week); and with a modest increase in Mato Grosso do Sul (+3.85/1 million inhabitants per week), Santa Catarina (+4.85/1 million inhabitants per week), and Minas Gerais (+5.28/1 million inhabitants per week).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. In both models (linear and spatial), even with the control for population density of the Federative Units (FUs), the Gini coefficient remained associated with both the evolution of incidence and mortality due to COVID-19..2. Considering demographic (population density) and spatial (spatial autocorrelation) aspects, it can be stated that the Gini coefficient was associated with an increase in the incidence and mortality rates of this disease..3. The absolute effect concerns the direct impact of income distribution on health outcomes: small changes in the income of poorest individuals produce significant changes in health outcomes, whereas among the wealthier individuals the same changes in income do not produce a major change in health standards. .4. The contextual effect, demonstrates that people (regardless of socioeconomic status) who live in unequal societies end up paying a health fee. Such conditions degrade everyone’s quality of life, but the poorest people are more severely affected within the social structure..5. Differential exposure, susceptibility, and consequence can produce higher rates of illness and death in these subgroups..6. That income inequality can play an important role in the impact of COVID-19 on the Brazilian population, either by the unequal distribution of opportunities, which has negative cascading impacts on those at greater socioeconomic disadvantage, or by contextual effects that hinder the capacity of a locality to adequately respond to this health crisis.

author: Ghiraldelli 2021
title: Trabalho, reformas ultraliberais, desigualdades e pandemia no Brasil: os sentidos da crise
Objective(s): To present a recent overview of the labor market in an ultraliberal context of regressive reforms approval in the scope of Brazilian social protection
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. In April 2020, 860 thousand formal jobs were closed. In the period under analysis, 598,596 hires and 1,459,099 layoffs were registered, resulting in a negative balance of 860,503 formal jobs..2. The pandemic gave visibility to the dramatic situations experienced by a significant portion of the population that finds itself in a condition of poverty and extreme poverty..3. In the case of populations living in slums, it becomes a great challenge to keep people isolated in shared environments and to ensure hygiene measures, such as periodic hand washing, in areas with difficult access to water..4. About 13 million Brazilians live in favelas, and these communities become more exposed to the virus and its social consequences due to the high number of residents in the houses, poor basic sanitation and insufficient public health policies..5. The economic and social impacts are filtered through evident discrimination, as, for example, the workforce that takes care of the sick, people with disabilities and the elderly, such as caregivers, has sex/gender , race and ethnicity. This working class is at greater risk of contracting the virus through their jobs or being fired because of the economic downturn imposed by the pandemic..6. In the first quarter of 2020, the unemployment rate was 12.2%, up 1.3 percentage points from the previous quarter, reaching around 13 million Brazilians. The informality rate reached 40% of the employed population, representing 37 million people. Underemployment reached 28 million workers.7. In the third quarter of 2020 only the public administration, defense, social security, education, human health and social services sectors were not severely affected by the effects of the pandemic crisis. All sectors registered a strong decrease, with emphasis on industry in general, commerce, housing and food, other services and domestic service.8. As one of the only and possible alternatives to unemployment in a context of corrosion of protected labor and a predatory neoliberal logic, many workers are inserted in the services of digital platforms and applications such as Amazon, Uber, Cabify, Rappi and iFood..9. The long working hours associated with the drop in the remuneration of these workers who risk their health and that of their families in performing an essential service for the Brazilian population..10. The rates show a picture of a significant drop in the generation of jobs in 2020 and a significant increase in unemployment, demonstrating the effects of the pandemic crisis and greater inequality for women.
Policy or intervention associate: The Brazilian state took some urgent and emergency measures, such as the approval of constitutional amendment n. 106, on May 7, 2020, which instituted an extraordinary fiscal, financial and contracting regime, which was also called the 'war budget'. In the wake of these government measures, law n. 14,020, of July 6, 2020, which established the Emergency Program for the Maintenance of Employment and Income with the objective of reducing social impacts in light of the crisis and health emergency. The law called for the creation of an emergency benefit to preserve employment and income in cases of proportional reduction in working hours and wages and temporary suspension of the employment contract..Law n. 13,982, of April 2, 2020, which instituted emergency income assistance in the amount of R$ 600.00 for informal workers, self-employed, unemployed, individual micro-entrepreneurs and people over 18 years old (except pregnant teenagers) with monthly per capita family income of up to half the minimum wage (that is, R$ 522.50) or monthly family income of up to three minimum wages (referring to R$ 3,135.00).7 In September, under allegation government of need to reduce public expenditures, following neoliberal guidelines of austerity and fiscal adjustment, the permanence of emergency aid until the month of December was approved, however in the amount of R$ 300.00. This reduction by half in the amount of the aid has a direct and negative impact on the income of families in poverty and unemployment.
Conclusions: 1. Recent experiences demonstrate the need for investment in quality public health services, education, culture, training and professional qualification, in addition to redistributive public policies that ensure income and social protection for the population in situations of poverty and unemployment..2. It is also urgent to formulate strategies and policies that enable the generation of jobs and jobs, especially for the young population, as a way to face youth unemployment, and that these occupations are of quality, considering that precariousness has become a rule in the world of labor..3. Other issues such as gender and wage inequalities in the labor market also need to be addressed. Therefore, in relation to employment, it is also necessary to think about policies of job stability, permanent qualification and appreciation of the minimum wage..4. The economic, social and environmental crisis aggravated by the pandemic demonstrated the importance of the State, public investment, services and social policies, which has raised questions about the ultraliberal theses defending the reduction of state interventionism..5. Government planning for the recovery of economic activity in tune with the demands of the population and aimed at improving employment, income, social protection and living conditions for the working class is essential.

author: Kalache et al. 2020
title: Aging and inequalities: social protection policies for older adults resulting from the Covid-19 pandemic in Brazil
Journal: Revista Brasileira de Geriatria e Gerontologia
Objective(s): To analysis of the role of the health system during the COVID-19 pandemic in health services for older people
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Millions of Brazilians have failed to follow the preventive guidelines, not because they do not want to, but because they cannot: social exclusion and structural discrimination deny them full access to their rights..2. Lack of testing, resulting in an underestimating of the problem; and the shortage of respirators and personal protective equipments (PPE’s), putting the infrastructure and workforce at risk in order to support the growing need for services.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: They call for the urgent strengthening of primary health care policies, the creation of remote monitoring strategies, the guarantee of survival and protective equipment, the offering of concrete guidance and support for LTCFs, care for homeless older adults, support for older adults who care for other older people or who still depend on casual labor for their livelihood, as well as the assurance of a humanitarian approach andpalliative care, when necessary.

author: Nassif Pires, Carvalho, and Lederman Rawet 2021
title: Multi-dimensional inequality and Covid-19 in Brazil
Objective(s): To present empirical evidence from Brazil on the bidirectional relationship between inequality and the Covid-19 crisis
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Low-income populations are more exposed to contamination. Access to healthcare is not evenly distributed in Brazil. Low-income populations infected with the novel coronavirus tend to have worse outcomes..2. Minorities in big cities are concentrated in neighborhoods that experience outbreaks, and the higher population density and likelihood of sharing smaller houses with more people increase contagion rate..3. Once infected, poor and minority populations are more likely to have worse outcomes due to a higher prevalence of comorbidities and more precarious access to healthcare..4. The United States and Brazil share two crucial characteristics: High income inequality and a history of slavery..5. Manaus, the capital of the Northern state of Amazonas, appeared to have the fastest contagion rate and an explosion in mortality in the first months of the pandemic.6. For all racial groups, women are less vulnerable than men..7. Only white and Asian persons are less vulnerable than average..8. Previous inequalities in health access and outcomes lead to inequalities in the severity of cases..9. The Northern region’s population is the most dependent on the public system (80%) and is home to the lowest proportion of those that have been to a doctor in the last year (61%). .10. Black, brown, and indigenous populations and those that did not complete middle school being more dependent on the public system and less likely to have been to the doctor in the last year..11. Considering those who had to be hospitalized for one or more days, 60% are black and brown (this share goes up to 70% of those who required a ventilator).
Policy or intervention associate: Auxílio Emergencial. The program, originally approved for three months and already extended by another six, transferred R$600 (around $110) per adult on a monthly basis in the first five months (and will transfer R$300 in the last four months) to unemployed and informal workers, as well as to beneficiaries of the cash transfer program Bolsa Família. However, as the original benefit (approved for three months and then extended for another two) has been reduced by half as of September and is only approved to last until December.
Conclusions: 1. This measure of the number of social risk factors to Covid-19 contamination, built around several dimensions of inequality (i.e., work, transportation, infrastructure, and living conditions) is positively associated with Covid-19 cases across Brazilian states and represents deep racial, income, and regional inequalities..2. The country’s stark inequalities in access to healthcare due to the duality between the private and public systems contribute to explaining why social risk factors alone do not account for observed disparities in the number of deaths..3. The comorbidities associated with more severe cases of Covid-19 are unequally distributed, thus helping explain the observed gap between the top of the distribution and the rest of the population in terms of ventilator use during the pandemic..4. Problems of multidimensional inequality and structural racism are of paramount importance and racial and regional differences need to be addressed through a government effort to permanently strengthen social welfare programs and public health, education,and infrastructure systems..5. This analysis suggests that Covid-19 has exacerbated inequalities that made the pandemic worse, thus requiring an even more substantial effort by governments to counterbalance these tendencies.

author: Olmos and Stuardo 2020
title: Distribución de la COVID-19 y tuberculosis en la Región Metropolitana de Chile: diferentes enfermedades, similares desigualdades
Objective(s): To describe the epidemiological behavior of COVID-19 in response to the control strategies implemented by the Chilean Ministry of Health and its similarities with the socio-economic distribution of TB in the Metropolitan Region (MR) of Chile.
Population: Confirmed cases of COVID-19 and tuberculosis cases
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Pearson correlation analysis was applied between the rates of incidence of both diseases (TB and COVID) of the 2018 during the epidemiological weeks 14,15, and 16, to assess similarities in the epidemiological distribution patterns on the territorial units belonging to Central Metropolitan Health  Services (SSMC), North (SSMN) and South (SSMS) and other 21 territorial units.
Type of social stratification: - Incidence rates of COVID-19 and TB .-Average income monthly (in USD per month) per person at the territorial unit level
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. In the first period, three communes that were not considered for selective quarantine (San Miguel, Huechuraba and San Joaquín) had higher COVID-19 incidence rates than other communes where the strategy was applied. .2. It is observed that the four territorial unit with the highest increase in accumulated cases of COVID-19 between both periods (Pedro Aguirre Cerda, San Joaquín, Central Station and Recoleta), exhibit an average income of USD $ 235 per person. Four territorial unit present a decrease in the number of cumulative cases of COVID-19 after quarantines (Vitacura, Las Condes, Providencia and Lo Barnechea), have an average income of USD $ 1,191 per person..3. The territorial units with the highest increase in COVID-19 cases between the first and second observed periods were Pedro Aguirre Cerda, San Joaquín: highest rates of South Metropolitan Health Services (SSMS) Tuberculosis rates (TB) during 2018 (40.8 and 37.1 x 100,000 inhab.). Estación Central was the territorial unit with the highest Tuberculosis rates in the SSMC (47.6 x 100,000 inhab.) and Recoleta, was the territoria with the highest TB rate in the SSMN (50.2 x100,000 inh.)..5. Figure 2: Simple correlation analysis between the 2018 Tuberculosis rates and the rate of COVID-19 by territorial units, a high degree of correlation was observed (r = 0.6063). .6. Recoleta and Estación Central are correlated to a lesser extent measured with their respective incidence rates of COVID-19 and are excluded from the calculation with a correlation coefficient of: 0.8812.
Policy or intervention associate: Selective quarantine strategy implemented by the Ministry Chilean Health Department in the Metropolitan Region (RM) and its similitutes with the distribution of the Tuberculosis. Two periods are distinguished in relation to the containment measures of COVID-19: .1. The first, from the start of the outbreak until the week in which the selective quarantine is implemented (Weeks 10 to 13).2. The second, which is during the implementation of this strategy (Weeks 14th to 16th).
Conclusions: 1. In spite of that the concept of vulnerability is dynamic, health and humanitarian crises increase these social inequalities and make visible the shortcomings structural states.2. The social determinants of health are persistently present when it comes to understanding the behavior of the disease and the highest risk groups..3. Territorial units who belong to a high socioeconomic level are more protected both by their living conditions and by their ability to access health services, while the most vulnerable populations lack precisely that..4. Health protection is based not only on a well-functioning health system with universal coverage, but also on social inclusion, justice and solidarity. In the absence of these factors, inequalities are magnify and they persist over time.

author: Ramos Barroso and Bolívar Restrepo 2020
title: Brecha de género en el mercado laboral colombiano en tiempos de la COVID-19
Objective(s): To analyze the impact of the global public health crisis derived from COVID-19 on women and their role in the Colombian labor market.
Population: General population (Data from the Large Integrated Household Survey (GEIH) for the years 2019 - 2020)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis (average of the indicators)
Type of social stratification: Most relevant GEIH labor indicators according to the gender, that is:.- Unemployment rate and gap between men and women..- Employment rate and gap between men and women..- Inactive..- Branches of economic activity.
Main Results: 1. The unemployment gap has increased dramatically. .2. For the April-June 2019 quarter, the unemployment gap stood at -4.95%, while for the same period of 2020 this indicator increased to -7.25%, for a difference of 2.3 percentage points. (see Figure 1).3. The job the male recovers faster than the female, or the impact of the COVID-19 in the medium term has more profound impacts for women..4. The rate of occupancy was reduced in all periods compared to 2019, the largest reduction it occurred in the April-June quarter when it went from 46.04% in 2019 to 33.1% in 2020. The occupancy gap between 2019 and 2020 has registered slight decreases, without However, women continue to participate less in the labor market..5. Average hourly pay for employees salaried workers is slightly higher for the female population in the three months analyzed. For January and February, it is observed that women earn in average 2.8% and 4.6% more than its counterpart. In June, times of COVID-19, it is possible to perceive a decrease in the average salary of the female population, achieving a difference of only 0.15% between both genders (June)..6. Wage gaps widen in the lowest income groups, with women being the most affected. For the higher income groups, there is not a very clear trend..7. Regarding the average income, a decrease can be observed in the female versus male wages in both February and June..8. The activities where more pay equity is shown by gender are the employees of government and private company; even in these two cases, the female population it enjoys a slightly higher average remuneration than its counterpart. .9. In self-employed workers, a wage gap of 18.5% in favor of men. Regarding domestic work, an activity that has been historically feminized, the gaps amount to 26.6%, with women being with lower salary. (see Figure 4).10. A trend is evident growing in the amount of inactive population, this trend is shared by both in men as in women, the latter being the ones with the highest inactivity figures..11. For 2019, the average inactivity rate for women was 11.1 pps more higher than that of men, while by 2020, this difference increased at 11.8 pps, which shows the macroeconomic shock caused by COVID-19. (see Figure 6).12. The reasons for the greater increase in inactivity of women in compared to men are associated with increased care domestic work and unpaid work resulting from confinement, closure of schools and nurseries, which has placed the responsibilities of the home on women..13. Both before and after the pandemic, 98% of the people who left their work because of “family responsibilities” were women, a finding confirming the overload of domestic work and care within the home for the female population. (see Figure 7 and 8).14. Only two sectors registered positive variations: financial activities and insurance and real estate activities. The sectors with the greatest amount of female labor have been the most affected by COVID-19, consequently, production has been reduced, leading to business closures and job losses for a large number of women in the labor market. (see Figure 10)..
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The health crisis worldwide has had harmful effects on the labor markets of the different countries, increasing in a certain way the existing gaps in the nations with deficiencies and imperfections in labor markets, imperfections due to which the Colombian labor market is characterized by..2. It is observed that in a general way, for all the quarters between 2019 and 2020 the gap has increased..3. When looking at hourly earnings in aggregate differentiating by sex, no major differences were found for the case of the employees.4. These results show the strong persistent inequality in the roles gender, and, consequently, is one of the greatest barriers to insertion and permanence of women in the labor market..5. Faced with the impossibility of teleworking or the need for domestic care due to confinement, it is to be expected that gender gaps continue to widen in the female labor market..6. The results presented here can serve as input for the design of public policies with a gender perspective, aimed at addressing this problem that has persisted for years and has worsened with the current health emergency.

author: R. G. da C. Silva 2020
title: Pandemia e desigualdades socioespaciais no Brasil. O caso de Manaus, Amazônia
Objective(s): To adopt the propositions of Milton Santos’s social theory of space to relate the pandemic and globalization
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. In COVID-19's global geography, Brazil has become one of the most impacted countries. Data updated on October 27, 2020, indicate that the country ranks third in number of confirmed cases (5 439 641) and deaths (157 946), which may be more expressive, considering the underreporting and politicization of the statistics made by the Brazilian government.2. Currently, the pandemic of the new coronavirus empiricizes globalization in its systemic perversity, which produces a crisis in public health and, above all, in the beginning of the 21st century, a great economic and social crisis encompassing the world, as it affects mainly , the poorest population, who do not have access to quality healthcare and who cannot even afford quarantine, as they have to work daily to ensure their family income..3. Currently (10/26/2020), the city of Manaus registers 61 422 confirmed cases (39% of the state rate - 157 688 total), 2834 deaths (63.5% of the state - 4460 total), fatality rate of 4, 6% (the state is 2.8%, the national is 2.9%), and the mortality rate is 132.1 (109.3 in the state and 75.2 in the country). These numbers express the critical situation that the pandemic has brought to the state of Amazonas. .4. The incidence rates of Covid-19 above 1000 cases per 100 thousand inhabitants reached almost all municipalities and practically the entire city of Manaus, where 40 of the 61 districts had a high degree of incidence..5. With restrictions on the commercial and service sectors, informal workers are the most affected, increasing the situation of social vulnerability.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Nationally, unemployment reached a record rate of 14.4%, that is, 13.8 million people without work, being the country's biggest social problem, and the informality rate reached 38.0% of the employed population, which means 31 million informal workers, called Brazil's new “entrepreneurs” by the corporate press..2. In turn, between January and October 2020, food inflation reached 9.75%, in part caused by food exports, resulting in more socio-spatial inequalities, which led the country to return to the hunger map . .3. While Brazil took third place in the global ranking of mortality rate, the federal government proposed the privatization of the Unified Health System - SUS, opposed the Chinese vaccine (coronavac) and opposed the vaccination of Brazilians, acting in yet another time in the politicization of life and public health. .4. Unemployment, hunger and public health show the face of perverse globalization, which affects all regions of Brazil.

author: L. aparecida de Souza and Cassab 2020
title: “Se eles lá não fazem nada, faremos tudo daqui”: desigualdade e solidariedade nas periferias brasileiras
Objective(s): To reflect on the many diverse actions of solidarity carried out by those individuals to ease the impacts of the disease that deepens and highlights the social-spatial inequalities in the country, focusing on the “Periferia Viva” campaign, in the city of Juiz de fora, Minas Gerais – Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. What is seen today in Brazil is the result of political options that historically privileged economic interests rather than the guarantee of basic rights conquered by the mobilization of workers and enacted in the Federal Constitution of 1988. In this way, the lethality of the disease in popular territories is configured as unfolding "of the lack of assistance, lack of protection, lack of public services, the absence of universal social protection policies"
Policy or intervention associate: National Campaign “Periferia Viva” – solidarity to fight the corona virus. A space for articulating rural and urban movements, public universities, popular and pastoral organizations and especially collectives that originate and work in the peripheral territories themselves, the initiative began in April 2020, intending to associate and strengthen actions that are happening in cities all over Brazil, including Juiz de Fora.The main action developed in the campaign is the donation of baskets containing food, masks and hygiene and cleaning materials, but specific activities are also carried out.
Conclusions: 1. As in other countries in the world, in Brazil, the virus first spread among the population living in valued areas of large cities..2. The situation shows that although the forms of transmission and the risk of illness and death are not selective, they are, however, exponentially enhanced as a result of socio-spatial inequalities..3. The pandemic exposes the inequalities and vulnerabilities to which impoverished workers are subjected, on the other it accentuates the networks of organization, protection and solidarity that affect the peripheral territories of Brazilian cities..4. In the Campaign, families receive the donation at the same time as they open a channel of communication with the organizations involved, establishing territorialities stitched together by solidarity.

author: Rosario Undurraga, Simbürger, and Mora 2021
title: Desborde y desazón versus flexibilidad y concentración: Teletrabajo académico y género en tiempos de pandemia
Objective(s): To analyze the experience of in Chile during the COVID-19 pandemic, in the benefits and of teleworking and classes from home, in conjunction with other demands and online responsibilities.
Population: Teachers women between 39 and 53 years old
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Semi-structured interview photo provoked in remote mode. The analysis of the interviews and the photographic material was inspired by Grounded Theory
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Work times have increased to achieve quality results when the "official" time is not enough to achieve the commitment..2. The workload has increased. In addition, in a tangible way as a consequence of incipient budget reductions in universities as a result of the pandemic..3. Work intensification is expressed in the simultaneity of tasks..4. The shift from the classroom to the virtual classroom via online platforms has meant an intensification of work..5. Online teaching involves simultaneous tasks and attention to focus, such as presenting, responding to the students' Chat, considering technical issues of connection and platforms, as well as dealing with content, visuals and promoting oral interaction..6. The daily arrangements in the distribution of space and the growth of the total workload, especially for women, have resulted in an evident tension between paid and unpaid work..7. Work, emotional, and domestic care overload is evident among many participants..8. The pandemic and the shift towards teleworking has upset the order of academic priorities, focusing on possible tasks: teaching, management and, finally, research, which is the most valued “commodity” in universities..9. For the second group of academics, those without children or with older children, teleworking has not had the same impact on research and productivity. On the contrary. For them, teleworking has meant carrying out these tasks without interruptions: students and non-academic subjects of the university have disappeared.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Academic women face similar challenges to other female workers: an overload of care work that puts teleworkers at a disadvantage in a pandemic, most of whom do not have external care support services (school, domestic service)..2. The inevitable relationship between work and personal / family life during the pandemic and its effects on the work trajectories of academics in Chile is problematized, which can be extrapolated to other academics around the world..3. Fear of contagion and social tensions coexist with economic uncertainty, which adds significant stressors to people's daily and work lives.

author: Romero et al. 2021
title: Idosos no contexto da pandemia da COVID-19 no Brasil: efeitos nas condições de saúde, renda e trabalho
Objective(s): To characterize the elderly Brazilian population during the COVID-19 pandemic, considering their health, socioeconomic conditions, gender inequality, adherence to social distance, and feelings of sadness or depression.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The variables described above were analyzed according to gender and level of adherence to social distancing during the pandemic, through their percentage distribution and respective 95% confidence intervals (95%CI) of the estimated proportions
Type of social stratification: -Gender: Male/Female.-Family composition with presence of spouse or partner and household situation: lives alone/lives with one person/ lives with two or more people.-Working before the pandemic: yes/ retired/ not working for any other reason / working without pay.-Employment relationship: yes - which includes civil servants, formally employed workers and business owners / no - workers not formally employed and self-employed workers.-It was investigated whether during the pandemic the work done was an essential activity (such as health care, security, transport, banking, etc.) and whether there was a change in working status (not working before and continued not working; continued working normally; continued working from home; started working after the pandemic; took paid time off; lost job; stopped working)..-Household per capita income in minimum wages: less than 1 / 1 to less than 2 / 2 to less than 4 / 4 or more..-The Chronic non-communicable diseases (NCDs): Diabetes/ high blood pressure/ asthma-emphysema-chronic respiratory disease or other lung disease/ heart disease and cancer/ prevalence of smokers.- Symptoms associated with COVID-19 were verified by a positive answer to at least one of the following symptoms: fever, chills, headache, dry or chesty cough, fatigue, tiredness, sore throat, runny nose, nasal congestion, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or joint pain. Feelings of distress or nervousness, depression, sadness and loneliness due to being distant from family and friends..-The effect of the pandemic on the income of older adults
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Occupation.-Gender/sex.-Socioeconomic status.-Social capital .-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1. 9,173 older adults who took part in the ConVid survey, 3,969 were men and 5,204 were women..2. Half of them were working before the pandemic (95%CI: 47.0; 53.9), 42.1% of them (95%CI: 37.4; 47.0) without a formal employment relationship..3. The percentage of those formally employed was higher among men (62.6%; 95%CI: 55.5; 69.2) compared to women (53.1%; 95%CI: 46.7; 59.3)..4. One third of older adults (33.9%; 95%CI: 27.8; 40.6) worked in essential activities..5. Extreme social distancing was practiced by 30.9% (95%CI: 27.8; 34.1) of older adults, 56.9% (95%CI: 53.5; 60.3) practiced intense social distancing and 12.2% (95%CI: 10.1; 14.7) did not adhere (or hardly adhered) to social distancing measures..6. Extreme distancing was higher among women (39.1%; 95%CI: 35.3; 42.9) compared to men (20.2%; 95%CI: 15.6; 25.8).7. Men have more comorbidities associated with risk for severe COVID-19 compared to women, with 7.1% of them reporting three or more diseases (95%CI: 4.3; 11.7)..8. A frequent feeling of loneliness due to being away from friends and family during the pandemic was reported by half of older adults (95%CI: 47.1; 54.0), more often by women 57.8% (95%CI: 53.9; 61.7) than men (41%; 95%CI: 35.4; 46.9). Habitual distress or nervousness was also being higher among women (38.1%; 95%CI: 34.2; 42.2) compared to men (23.2; 95%CI: 18.8; 28.4)..9. A recurring feeling of sadness and depression (27.5%; 95%CI: 24.6; 30.6) was also more frequent among women (35.1%; 95%CI: 31.3; 39.1) than men (17.5%; 95% CI: 13.7; 22.1).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Feelings of distress, loneliness and sadness during the pandemic were more pronounced among older women than among older men. These results may be a consequence of women’s burden of housework, which was increased during the pandemic when many older women became responsible for caring for grandchildren, husbands, other older people and even their children..2. The greater economic vulnerability of women stemming from their background, the devaluation of their work and fewer opportunities of formal employment when compared to men may also lead to greater feelings of distress in periods of increased unemployment and poverty..3. The fragile labor and economic conditions of older Brazilians is evidenced in this survey by the high percentage of older people who were still working, most of them in informal activities (self-employed or with no employment relationship). In addition, the survey found a marked decrease in income during the pandemic among older adults with poorer socioeconomic conditions.

author: J. O. M. de Albuquerque et al. 2021
title: Prevalence evolution of SARS-CoV-2 infection in the city of São Paulo, 2020-2021.
Objective(s): To estimate the evolution of the prevalence of SARS-CoV-2 virus infection among residents aged 18 years or over in the municipality of São Paulo.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Prevalence and their 95% confidence intervals (CI) .2. The Rao-Scott chi-square test was used to compare the frequencies between the categories of each variable, considering a significance level of 5%.
Type of social stratification: -Human Development Index (HDI).-Gender: Male/Female.-Age group. -Ethnicity: White/Black-Brown/Asian/Indigenous /Unknown. -Education: Middle School/High school/Higher education/Illiterate/Unknown. -Variables associated with risk or prevention of infection (household size/ symptoms potentially related to COVID-19, healthcare service use, previous SARS-CoV-2 test, contact with suspected or confirmed cases of COVID-19.).-Regions of the city: Central-West/ East/ North/ Southeast/South
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Gender/sex.-Education.-Socioeconomic status.-Social capital .-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1. The highest prevalence of of SARS-CoV-2 infection, was found in the age group (from 35 to 49 years, and...)  the difference among age groups was significant..2. In all phases, women had the highest prevalence.3. prevalence of black and brown people was the.highest in all phases. There was a significant difference in ethnicity in all phases..4. The highest prevalence estimates were found in the groups with the lowest education levels..5. Human Development Index (HDI) ranges to estimate regional differences: range A (0.84 to 0.95) had the lowest prevalence, whereas range C (0.62 to 0.73) had the highest estimates. The difference among HDI ranges and family income categories were significantly different.6. Those in telework had lower prevalence when compared to the other categories, especially in phases 1 and 4 (3.9% and 4.4%, respectively).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Prevalence of individuals with positive results was higher among black and brown people when compared with white people..2. Prevalence was inversely associated with education level, income, and with the HDI of the primary healthcare unit coverage area (CA-PHU).3. Lowest prevalences were associated with protection measures against the disease..4. Highest prevalence was initially found in the age group from 50 to 64 years, which is a vulnerable population, most affected at the beginning of the pandemic..5. In the following phases, the younger age groups were the most prevalent, which is the economically active population circulating around the city..6. The risk associated with the work situation was lower among individuals working from home when compared to those who work at the office

author: Lorenz et al. 2021
title: Examining socio-economic factors to understand the hospital case fatality rates of COVID-19 in the city of São Paulo, Brazil.
Journal: Transactions of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene
Objective(s): To understand differences in hospital case fatality rates (HCFRs) of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Spatial analysis methods to compare hospital case fatality rates (HCFRs) in sociodemographically
Type of social stratification: -Age.-Sex.-HDUs (Brazilian Atlas of Human Development) (homogeneous socio-economic areas based on information garnered from the 2010 Brazilian Demographic Census.) per capita income ( in UK pounds)
Main Results: 1. Men accounted for 55.1% of hospitalizations and 56.4% of deaths and had an hospital case fatality rate (HCFRs) of 28.2% (compared with 26.7% for women)..2. Two of the socio-economic covariates presented collinear-ity (Pearson correlation coefficient=0.92): percentage of people =18 y of age who have completed elementary school and per capita income..3. The adjusted model: per capita income (in log scale) had a nega- tive association (RR 0.91 [95% CI 0.87 to 0.95]) and risk factor ( of death) rate of hospitalized people had a positive association (RR 1.11 [95% CI 1.06 to 1.15])..4. In higher income in the central regions,  there is a sug- gestion of an inverse association with death among the COVID-19 hospitalized people..5. HCFRs (Figure 1A), there was an indication of higher risk in the peripheral regions of the municipality.  .6. Spatial risk in the first model ranged from 0.79 to 1.23 and that the values below the unit were in the centre of the city and those above were in the peripheral areas. (Figure 1B). .7. Increase of 1 SD in each one of these two covariates would result in a decrease of 9% and in an increase of 11% in the risk of death among COVID-19 hospitalized people, respectively.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Areas of São Paulo with the highest socio-economic levels have the lowest COVID-19 fatality rates..2. Enhanced testing, contact tracing, social distancing and self-isolation are particularly needed in vulnerable communities..3. Future studies should focus on the identification of these vulnerable groups, in addition to elderly people and front-line healthcare workers, when determining prioritization in vaccination distribution plans

author: R. C. da S. Magalhães 2021
title: Covid-19, distance education, and the intensification of educational inequalities
Objective(s): To discuss the adoption of distance education modalities within the context of the covid-19 pandemic and the intensification of educational inequalities in Brazil
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. In addition to the data presented, any measure aimed at encouraging distance education or forms of remote learning in the country must also consider the reality of students who have some domestic responsibility, those who need to work at school age and those who, despite having a cell phone, cannot pay for a data package sufficient to access educational platforms and applications..2. It is also worth noting that many Brazilian students unfortunately had sick family members, who lost their jobs or died as a result of the covid-19 pandemic, and that a considerable number are facing serious food problems, as, for many, school lunch is the only daily meal. The problem for these children and adolescents goes far beyond the difficulties in accessing the most modern technologies..3. They are not guaranteed the minimum conditions of food security and physical and mental health, without which living becomes an extremely difficult task and studying practically impossible..4. In this sad reality, normally accepted by a portion of society, it is difficult to imagine that this gigantic number of Brazilian citizens lacking the assistance of the State in their basic rights, who do not have clean water to wash their hands and perform their personal hygiene, are able to to study at a distance through digital technologies.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1.The exceptional situation in which we find ourselves does not give the federal government the right to create barriers in accessing education, especially for children and adolescents who are already in a vulnerable situation..2. Before thinking about distance education and other modes of remote learning, it is necessary to massively invest in education and develop public policies in this field that take into account the social and economic conditions in which most Brazilian students live, especially the poorest and most vulnerable, on whom the consequences of the covid-19 pandemic have hit the hardest..3. In the current Brazilian reality, distance education or any other form of remote learning mediated by digital technologies only makes sense to those who see education as an exclusionary activity that, instead of attenuating, enhances the country's social and economic inequalities .

author: Paulo Ricardo Martins-Filho, Araújo, et al. 2021
title: Racial Disparities in COVID-19-related Deaths in Brazil: Black Lives Matter?
Objective(s): To evaluate the risk of death and the case-fatality rate (CFR) from COVID-19 among Brazilian black people comparing the mortality estimates among the five macro-regions (Northeast, North, Central-West, South east, and South) in the country.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The relative risk (RR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) of COVID-19 mortality among black Brazilians compared to white Brazilians.
Type of social stratification: Race: Black/White
Main Results: 1. The incidence rates of COVID-19 were higher among whites, all regions of the country showed higher fatality rates in the black population..2. An increased risk of death for blacks compared to whites (RR 1.50; 95% CI,1.461.54; P < 0.001) regardless of the Brazilian region.3. A 1.5-fold increased risk for mortality from COVID-19 among black people throughout the national territory, with slight regional differences.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. These finding may reflect the plethora of regions with different levels of development, social heterogeneity and serious racial problems that remain until nowadays in the Brazilian society and reinforce the misconception of a harmonious multiracial society..2. Racial disparities in Brazil are strongly associated with socioeconomic environments and precarious conditions of basic sanitation and housing, and therefore these racial disparities have important implications on health outcomes.

author: Bermudi et al. 2021
title: Spatiotemporal ecological study of COVID-19 mortality in the city of São Paulo, Brazil: Shifting of the high mortality risk from areas with the best to those with the worst socio-economic conditions.
Objective(s): To unveil the spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 mortality in a higher spatial resolution (in the city of São Paulo), considering the socio-economic context of the population.
City or municipality: city of Sao Paulo, state of Sao Paulo, Brazil
Population: Confirmed cases of COVID-19 and deaths
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Spatial approach to model the confirmed and total COVID-19 death per epidemiological week (EW) to evaluate the role of the socio-economic covariate in each EW..2. Models in a Bayesian context using the integrated nested Laplace approximation (INLA) approach
Type of social stratification: The Socioeconomic Index of the Geographic Context for Health Studies (GeoSES) obtained with the spatiotemporal models
Main Results: 1. Mortality was higher in men and that it increased with age, (mortality rate of 460.9 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants (in 14 weeks) for people aged = 60 years..2. A high socio- economic level protected against the risk of mortality due to COVID-19 .3. Increase of one unit in the socioeconomic indicator represented a 25% reduction in the risk of mortality due to COVID-19 (for the model using only confirmed deaths) and 33% reduction in the risk of dying for the model using total deaths of  COVID-19. Risk of mortality due to COVID-19 in the sample areas with the best socio-economic conditions (GeoSES close to 1), compared with that in areas with the worst conditions (GeoSES close to - 1), was 50% lower for the model with confirmed deaths and 66% lower for the model with total deaths..4. Best socio-economic level presented itself as a risk factor for COVID-19 deaths in the first two epidemiological weeks (EW) in the city of Sao Paulo. From the 15th EW, for total deaths, and from the 16th EW, for confirmed and total deaths, the worst socio-economic condition became a risk factor.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. A high socio-economic level was shown to protect against the risk of mortality due to COVID-19 throughout the study period. .2. This was not a uniform pattern in (...) Sao Paulo through time ( highest risk in the best socio- economic contexts during the first two EWs that then shifted to the worst contexts from the 16th epidemiological week (EW)) .3. Men and elderly individuals were at the highest risk of mortality due to COVID- 19.

author: Gozzi et al. 2021
title: Estimating the effect of social inequalities on the mitigation of COVID-19 across communities in Santiago de Chile.
Objective(s): To estimate the effect of social inequalities on the mitigation of COVID-19 across communities in Santiago de Chile
Sample size: 22% of the total population in the comunas under consideration (Data from 1.4 million mobile devices provided by a major mobile phone operator in South America (Telefónica Movistar))
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The spatial and temporal spread of SARS-CoV-2 in 37 comunas of the urban area of Santiago with stochastic mechanistic epidemic model integrating mobility, physical contacts, and census data. .
Type of social stratification: -Matrices describing mobility: (1) before any restrictions/ (2) during the partial lockdown/ and (3) during the full lockdown.-Nonpharmaceutical interventions: night curfews/ dynamic quarantine/ lockdowns restricted to a few comunas across the region.- Mobility among comunas: rates at which people travel among different comunas.- Contacts reduction between individuals (what extent physical contacts varied in time in each comuna).- Human Development Index (HDI)
Main Results: 1. Freater decrease in mobility is generally associated with a higher HDI (Pearson correlation coefficient ? = - 0.80, p < 0.001)..2. It show the attack rates versus the HDI of different comunas. We find a strong correlation between attack rates computed on officially reported cases and HDI (? = -0.74, p < 0.001), providing evidence that wealthier comunas experienced significantly smaller outbreaks..3. Comunas with higher HDI have a higher mean age and the infection fatality rate for COVID-19 is significantly higher in older age brackets..4. Significant correlation between HDI and both simulated (? = -0.50, p < 0.002) and officially reported (? = -0.40, p < 0.02) deaths, hinting that wealthier comunas experi- enced also a smaller burden in terms of casualties.
Policy or intervention associate: Nonpharmaceutical interventions: night curfews/ dynamic quarantine/ lockdowns restricted to a few comunas across the region
Conclusions: 1. Lower burden of COVID-19 (i.e., cases, deaths) in the comunas characterized by a higher HDI..2. While lockdowns are unquestionably effective in mitigating the epidemic activity, they may as well augment social and health inequalities, penalizing more vulnerable communities..3. Earlier implementation of more stringent nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) may be beneficial in quickly mitigating the outbreak without extending for a long time policies that poten- tially might unequally affect communities..4. The model suggests that the total blockade was decisive to control the epidemic. The total blockade prevented a further increase of 34.7% in the total number of deaths. .5. Challenges faced in reducing their mobility and contacts, communities exhibiting systemic social disparities are affected differently by government-mandated NPIs and burden of disease. .6 The key issue of health disparities is raised in the management of emerging infectious diseases like COVID-19.
Funding sources: Fondazione Cassa di Risparmio di Torino (Fondazione CRT). AND Telefónica R&D Chile and CISCO Chile. M.T.

author: Kerr et al. 2020
title: COVID-19 in Northeast Brazil: achievements and limitations in the responses of the state governments.
Journal: Revista Ciência & Saúde Coletiva da Associação Brasileira de Saúde Coletiva
Objective(s): To explore the experience of the COVID-19 epidemic in the Northeast Region and to discuss the differences and similarities across the states of this region with respect to COVID-19, the social distance measures implemented, and how these differences can explain the epidemiological indicators of the epidemic in this region
City or municipality: Northeast Brazil, nine states (Alagoas, Bahia, Ceará, Maranhão, Paraíba, Pernambuco, Piauí, Rio Grande do Norte and Sergipe)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptice analysis
Type of social stratification: -HDI - Human Development Index.-GINI index.
Main Results: 1. There are a large number of cases of COVID-19 that are not being registered as such in these states,.2. Only people with a high probability of COVID-19 are being tested, i.e., the very symptomatic and the most severe cases.3. The percentage of households with excessive occupancy rates have a direct association with transmission.4. People with formal jobs, do not have association with transmission.5. Maranhão,= highest levels of values negatively associated with the health of the population. Ceará = important percentage of the population below the poverty line and in extreme poverty, and has fewer households with piped water -> The highest incidence for COVID-19 was record ed in Ceará, followed by Maranhão and Pernambuco. (Ceará reached 161.1/100,000, followed by 112.5/100,000 in Pernambuco) The highest mortality rates were also observed in these three states..6. 2 out of the 12 states with higher unemployment rate, also have the the highest case rates for COVID-19
Policy or intervention associate: Government’s lack of leadership in formulating a consistent national response has led state governments and municipal administrations to take decisions to respond to the epidemic and to mitigate it..Emergency aid approved by Congress, due to a series of operational failures, a large portion of this population had to expose themselves to large gatherings while waiting at banks and national lottery stations to receive the aid.
Conclusions: 1. People with low incomes are more exposed to infectious diseases, including SARS-CoV-2, due to the lack of access to basic sanitation and treated water, the lack of access to education and health services, the use of public transport, subject to crowding and the difficulty of self-isolating, living in precarious housing and/or with an excessive number of residents, or also because they are more often unemployed or engaged in informal jobs..2. High rates of unemployment or informal work, without government assistance for income support, lead to a daily search for an income and, consequently, to low adherence to social distance measures, and high rates of disease transmission.3. Factors that could amplify the epidemic, such as high urban density, high levels of inequality, high rates of informal work, presence of an international airport and being internal domestic tourism destinations..4. Poorest neighborhoods had almost a quarter of its population affected by COVID-19, the richest neighborhoods, producing the first cases, had six times less, staying in the 4% range.5. Despite the fact that the authorities in Ceará launched a technically solid and effective set of preventive actions dated from the detection of the first official case, this state had the highest number of reported cases of COVID-19..6. Weaknesses in the epidemiological surveillance system that did not have access to the first cases of COVID-19.7. Epidemic entered, in most states, through its capitals and the more affluent population, and after community transmission was established in these cities.

Main Results: 1. Black individuals had no record of etiological diagnosis for SARS in 22.127 (36.40%) of cases.     .2. Black people is strongly affected by the pandemic and suffers from difficulties in accessing the health system and in achieving social distancing    .3. Racism in Brazil (...) leads in (...) 33% of patients with SARS had no record of race data, while 36% of black individuals did not have a definite testing diagnosis.Information on the race of the patients only started to be collected when the Ministry of Health declared community transmission of the disease throughout the national territory.  .4. The lethality of SARS by COVID showed that for every 100 people with SARS or SARS and COVID-19, black population suffer 3 more deaths when compared to the general population 28.8% of patients in Brazil with SARS and COVID-19 were allocated to ICU beds, while the allocation rate in ICU beds for black patients was 31.09%
