Conclusions: 1.  Skin color is a determinant of several other social and health vulnerabilities in Brazil    .2. Black person infected with SARS-CoV-2 is exposed to the risk factors that precede an infection.3. Black people are also judged by the color of their skin within the health system, which determines who will be better or worse assisted by the health team.    .4. In Brazil, systemic racism culminates in socioeconomic disadvantages, although there has never been an officially consolidated political system of racial segregation.   .5 It reinforces the UN's finding that racism is a factor that limits health care for black individuals, related to the way knowledge and hegemonic biomedical rationality were built, in a scenario full of racism, social injustice, domination and brutality..6. To promote health and human rights it is necessary to offer a universal health access system interconnected with anti-racism advocacy public policies..7. Disparity between rates of lethality observed in our study about black people and general population.

author: Santana and Melo 2021
title: Pandemia de covid-19 e população LGBTI+. ( In)visibilidades dos impactos sociais
Journal: Sexualidad, Salud y Sociedad (Rio de Janeiro)
Objective(s): To reflect critically about the social impacts of covid-19 pandemic, and the strategies to deal it on the everyday life of Lesbian, Gays, Bisexuals, Transgender, Intersex, and other identities
Population: Lesbian, Gays, Bisexuals, Transgender, Intersex, and other identities (LGBTI+)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. LGBTI phobia modifies and enhances the impact of covid-19 on the LGBTI+ population, in addition to altering the protection capacity of this group in some areas, such as: insufficient ways to implement general prevention measures; pre-existing health inequities that can be potentiated by covid-19; and difficulties in accessing health services..2. Social distancing due to the covid-19 pandemic can generate challenging and dangerous situations for LGBTI+ people, especially for those who are homeless and/or unemployed and, therefore, need to return to their relatives. In these circumstances, these people may suffer some type of violence while sheltering in the home of LGBTIphobic relatives, in which respondents reported being more likely to suffer violence and abuse by relatives, given the need for shelter during quarantine.3. These contexts of emotional suffering are produced from lack of family support, difficulty in accessing health services, the stereotype and stigma that permeate the relationships and experiences of LGBTI+ people and insufficient work opportunities. During the covid-19 pandemic, prevention strategies, such as social distancing, can intensify these problems and, consequently, emotional distress..4. There are studies that prove that there are a large number of elderly people deprived of liberty and living with chronic diseases, which places them in "risk groups" to covid-19.5. Thus, the adoption of individual hygiene measures, adequate ventilation, social distance, use of masks and mass vaccination is recommended. Measures that in the context of Brazilian prisons are challenging, given the history of negligence and invisibility of this population, especially when it comes to LGBTI+ people.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. From the contextualization of the historical processes that the LGB-TI+ population is facing, it was possible to observe how the emergence of the covid-19 pandemic had a major impact on this social group. .2. Its consequences are immeasurable and add to the inequities and social processes linked to LGBTIphobia. .3. In addition, there is at multiple levels the reproduction of a process of invisibility of the demands of LGBTI+ people, which converges to the current political scenario in Brazil, making it extremely important to understand this context and produce coping strategies.

author: E. de P. Nunes, Leite, and Carvalho 2020
title: Rastreamento Geográfico da COVID-19 Segundo Fatores Socioeconômicos e Demográficos no Município de Uberlândia, Minas Gerais
Journal: Journal of Health & Biological Sciences - JHBS
Objective(s): To analyze the spatial distribution of COVID-19 according to socioeconomic and demographic factors in the city of Uberlândia, Minas Gerais.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: To characterize the sample, a descriptive statistical analysis was performed. For the spatial analysis of COVID-19 by neighborhood, data from the IBGE were used, which were plotted on a thematic map.
Type of social stratification: -Age group (in years).-Neighborhood.-Income
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Place of residence.-Socioeconomic status
Main Results: 1. The mean age of confirmed cases was 38.83 (±14.29) years, as the most affected age groups were people between 20 to 29 years old (23.2%), 30 to 39 years old (27 .7%), 40 to 49 years (22.5%), 50 to 59 years (13.7%) and 70 to 79 years (5.7%)..2. The highest incidence rate was in Jardim Europa (10.9 per 1,000/inhabitant), followed by Shopping Park (7.8 per 1,000/inhabitant), Jardim Holanda (7.2 per 1,000/inhabitant), Centro (6.9 per 1,000/inhabitant), Mansour (6.1 per 1,000/inhabitant), Jardim Karaíba (5.8 per 1,000/inhabitant) Jardim Brasília (5.3 per 1,000/inhabitant), Taiaman (5, 2 per 1,000/inhabitant), Chacaras Tubalina and Quartel (5.0 per 1,000/inhabitant) and Panorama (4.9 per 1,000/inhabitant)..3. It was observed that the western sector was the most affected, with a large concentration of cases in several districts, especially in Jardim Canaã (60 cases), Jardim Europa (55 cases), Luizote de Freitas (48 cases) and Mansour (44 cases ), followed by the northern sector in Jardim Brasília (77 cases) and Presidente Roosevelt (59 cases)..4. The eastern and central sectors accounted for a large concentration of cases in some specific neighborhoods, namely: Santa Mônica (84 cases), Morumbi (51 cases), Osvaldo Resende (75 cases) and Centro (50 cases). In the southern sector, the highlight was the districts of São Jorge (52 cases) and Shopping Park (32 cases)..5. Of the 20 neighborhoods with the highest total number of confirmed cases, 11 are neighborhoods with an average per capita income below one minimum wage (R$1,045.00 reais), eight neighborhoods with an average per capita income of up to two minimum wages and only one neighborhood with an average per capita income above two minimum wages..6. The Jardim Brasília neighborhoods, with a per capita income of R$ 979.63 reais, stand out as the second neighborhood with the highest number of confirmed cases and the Jardim Canaã neighborhood, which has the second lowest per capita income in the municipality and the fourth neighborhood with the highest number of cases of COVID-19.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The number of confirmed cases for COVID-19 in Uberlândia was high, spreading quickly to all sectors, mainly affecting low-income neighborhoods, where the average per capita income of the population was below a minimum wage, concentrating the worst scenarios of COVID-19..2. The COVID-19 pandemic in the city continues to spread, and the population is divided between staying at home and going to work so as not to lose their jobs..3. While healthcare systems are stressed, local businesses are at risk of closing and the crisis in the country is getting worse..4. The global public health crisis brought about by COVID-19 has revealed the inequalities and injustices that threaten the well-being, security and lives of people.

author: Denny et al. 2021
title: COVID-19 magnifies the vulnerabilities: The Brazilian case
Journal: International Journal of Discrimination and the Law
Objective(s): To discuss inequalities of the health system in Brazil and advocates that now, more than ever in light of the Covid-19 pandemic, the world needs to put in place a more collaborative and egalitarian way of financing health research and investments in public health systems.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The challenge of coping with a global pandemic brings the opportunity to comprehensively address the serious human vulnerabilities it has revealed; and presents a rare opportunity for instituting bold structural reforms that can revive and sustain prosperity in the post-Covid-19 world..2. An effective global initiative is needed and it could focus on several important functions. First it could strengthen multisectoral approaches such as the COVAX global collaboration in order to accelerate the development, production, and equitable access to COVID-19 tests, treatments, and vaccines. .3. An effective global initiative could support the creation and funding of a Global Intellectual Property Repository, to accelerate the assemble and deployment of existing and newly established intellectual property in relevant pharmaceutical molecules, diagnostics, health data, software, 3D printing codes etc..4. The initiative could foster the creation and funding of a Global Logistics Centre to help monitor and coordinate the worldwide demand and supply of urgently needed goods and services, such as medicines, diagnostics, medical supplies and machinery, personal protective equipment, trained medical personnel and transport capacities..5. The creation and funding of a Global Pre-emption Taskforce that would identify and protect populations that lack resources or pose particular risks to others.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The inequitable response to the pandemic so far only reinstates that healthy life expectancy and mortality rates are markedly disproportionate between the richest and poorest populations..2. Disinformation and miscommunication disproportionally affect individuals with less access to information channels, who are thus more likely to ignore scientific recommendations such as physical distancing measures..3. Brazilians are particularly prone to believe on the information they receive through any communication media. Unfortunately fake news spreads 70% faster than real news even in traditional media. .4. The most effective reforms will come about through concerted intergovernmental cooperation, not isolationist measures: a view of the state as responsive and aware of its responsibilities accordingly to the theory of vulnerability..5. Made possible rapid availability of the vaccine worldwide, in an equitable and efficient manner, not prioritizing only the rich countries that can afford the price and the technology (freezers, energy etc) needed to complete the distribution..6. The repository would have to receive donations from national governments as well as public, and private sectors, relating to health to the amount it should be prepared to pay competitive prices so as to encourage a stream of useful innovations continuously. .7. The goal is to overcome poor information, bureaucratic execution and deliveries disruptions due to higher bidders..8. Collaboration with national health systems, international agencies and NGOs would foster a strong public-health strategy around the innovator product and enable the research focus on the diseases more common among the poor..9. The global architecture for taxation and the illicit flows of money hinders this funding. The injustice that misplaced taxes plays results in systemic damage to human rights, especially women’s rights and across a whole range of intersectional inequalities. .10. The global disruption must be taken as an opportunity to implement major structural reforms such as the ones this paper outlines, on the expectation to inspire public policies capable of shaping a fairer new normality.

author: Mesquita and Bezerra 2021
title: “Brazil cannot stop”: Meritocratic ideology in an unequal country
Objective(s): To reflect on the measures adopted by the Brazilian government in the scope of education amid the COVID-19 pandemic.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Many low-income families who registered to receive emergency aid from the government had not yet received even the first installment, jeopardizing their health by having to stand in long lines and agglomerations at government bank agencies, as many did not have access to a smartphone to request help through the digital application provided by the government..2. With the COVID-19 pandemic, this scenario worsens, as many Black youngsters have no adequate material conditions or psychological conditions, as due to their socioeconomic vulnerability, Black persons are the most affected victims of the new coronavirus as well as its consequences, such as unemployment..3. The measures adopted by the government in the scope of education in view of the COVID-19 pandemic reflec society's structural racism and MEC's institutional racism.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Actions and initiatives reflect the Brazilian society's structural racism and MEC's institutional racism, which naturalizes meritocratic discourses in a country with profound social and racial inequality..2. It is necessary to improve the quality of public basic education, to increase the competitiveness of high school graduates; continuously improve teacher training and the infrastructure of the entire education system; ensure good conditions for students to remain in basic and higher education.

author: Li et al. 2021
title: Higher risk of death from COVID-19 in low-income and non-White populations of São Paulo, Brazil
Objective(s): To characterise the differential risk of hospitalisation and death in São Paulo state, Brazil, and show how vulnerability to COVID-19 is shaped by socioeconomic inequalities.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Individual-level analysis to estimate the probability of reporting a SARI hospitalisation given a patient’s race and average income level in their census tract of residence: Probabilities for each age-sex group were estimated empirically using relative frequencies. ORs using White patients and the highest income level as reference groups were computed .2. Ecological spatiotemporal regression analysis was conducted at the municipality level for São Paulo state: The relative risk of hospitalisation was estimated using a hierarchical Bayesian model composed of a generalised log-linear model with spatially structured and unstructured random effects to account for spatial autocorrelation and time-varying random effect.
Type of social stratification: -Race: White/ Black/ Asian/ (East or Southeast Asian)/ Pardo (mixed ethnic ancestries with diverse skin colours) / Indigenous. .-Household income per capita.-Income inequality (Gini Index). .-Proportion of residents with a primary education or lower.-Employment to population ratio and the proportion of the working population without a formal labour market contract or social security..-Administrative type of the health facility where the patient was hospitalised (public or private). .-Age.-Gender: Male/Female.-Comorbidities: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease/ diabetes/ hypertension or cardiovascular disease such as myocardial infarction, angina or heart failure
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Education.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Occupation.-Gender/sex.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. During this time, 232?540 patients were notified, from these 223?455 were hospitalised (98.4%) or died without hospitalisation (1.6%). From the non-hospitalised cases, we only selected deaths; 54?108 patients died, of which 52.5% were White, 20.2% were Pardo, 6.13% were Black, 1.96% were Asian, 0.052% were Indigenous and 19.6% did not have race information.2. During March in Brazil, hospitalised patients were more likely to be White or Asian and come from census tracts with higher income per capita. During this period, people living in low-income areas were less likely (OR: 0.44, 95% CI 0.42 to 0.46) to be hospitalised with SARI compared with high-income areas..3. In August, patients were less likely to be from low-income census tracts (OR: 0.95, 95% CI 0.91 to 1.00). Similarly during this time period, Black Brazilians and Pardos became more likely to be hospitalised with SARI than Whites (OR: 1.41, 95% CI 1.37 to 1.46; OR: 1.26, 95% CI 1.23 to 1.28, respectively), while Asians became the least likely to be hospitalised (OR: 0.88, 95% CI 0.82 to 0.94)..4. Once hospitalised, Black and Pardo patients were more likely to die from SARI than White patients between March and August (OR: 1.14, 95% CI 1.07 to 1.21; 1.09, 95% CI 1.05 to 1.13, respectively)..5. Patients treated in public hospitals were more likely to die than patients treated in private hospitals throughout the epidemic (OR: 1.40%, 95% CI 1.34% to 1.46%)..6. They found a lower risk of SARI by SARS-CoV-2 hospitalisation in municipalities with high income per capita (fixed effect=-0.87, 95% CI -1.12 to -0.62) and high proportion of adult residents with a primary education or lower (-0.90, 95% CI -1.12 to -0.68)..7. Municipalities with fewer nearby public health facilities were also found to have lower risk of hospitalisation (-0.31, 95% CI -0.55 to -0.08). We also found a higher risk of SARI hospitalisation in municipalities with higher population density (0.31, 95% credible interval: 0.07–0.54).8. 14 days after the introduction of NPIs, isolation levels were 8.2% (95% CI 7.2% to 9.2%) higher in predominantly White areas compared with predominantly Black areas. Similarly, 27 days after the introduction of state-level NPIs, isolation levels were 11.2% (95% CI 10.6% to 11.9%) higher in the wealthiest than in the poorest areas..9. Nonetheless, because Black and Pardo populations are disproportionally employed in informal and low-skilled jobs, these racial groups were, in general, more likely to be working face to face during our study period..10. Workers with pre-primary education were more likely to work in occupations that require in-person contact than workers with tertiary education (probability (PR): 0.89, 95% CI 0.87 to 0.90 compared with PR: 0.58, 95% CI 0.57 to 0.60) and less likely to work in occupations that allow teleworking (PR: 0.005, 95% CI 0.004 to 0.007 vs PR: 0.36, 95% CI 0.35 to 0.37, respectively).11. Individuals with primary education or lower are more likely to have one or more comorbidities (OR: 1.36, 95% CI 1.27 to 1.45). Similarly, Black individuals were also more likely to have one or more comorbidities than White individuals (OR: 1.29, 95% CI 1.19 to 1.39).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This study shows that socially disadvantaged groups are disproportionately more likely to be hospitalised and die from SARI. .2. Differential health outcomes can be explained by structural inequities linked to the incidence of comorbidities and to socioeconomic conditions, which limit the ability of low-income and non-White populations to socially isolate and reduce their access to quality health services..3. It found that hospitalisation risk is higher for populations living in municipalities that travel to and from the Região Metropolitana de São Paulo (RMSP), with low income per capita and high population density compared with the rest of São Paulo state..4. Patients living in the 40% poorest areas were more likely to die when compared with patients living in the 5% wealthiest areas (OR: 1.60, 95% CI 1.48 to 1.74) and were more likely to be hospitalised between April and July 2020 (OR: 1.08, 95% CI 1.04 to 1.12)..
Funding sources: Medica Research Council-São Paulo Research Foundation (FAPESP) CADDE partnership award (MR/S0195/1 and FAPESP 18/14389-0) (http://caddecentre.org/).

author: Rivera and Castro 2021
title: Between social protests and a global pandemic: Working transitions under the economic effects of COVID-19
Objective(s): To explore the employment trajectories of workers throughout the ongoing pandemic in Chile: a neoliberal country with a strong male breadwinner culture and high levels of income inequality.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Exploratory (sequence analysis) and predictive (multinomial logistic regression) methods
Type of social stratification: -Unemployment rate .-Market indexes for mobile quarters: labor informality/working hours/ employment relationships.-Family variables: relationship status (lives with a partner -either married or cohabiting-, and 0 = otherwise), presence of children 0 to 5 years, presence of children 6 to 13 years, and breadwinner..-Economic sector: primary sector/ manufacture and construction/ commerce / services.
Main Results: 1. Although women had a lower percentage of employment, they had more unsteady and diverse trajectories than men. entropy index of women is always higher than of men, i.e., they have more diverse states in each time position than men..2. Higher proportion of men (69%) remained continuously employed throughout the first months of the pandemic than women (55%), and in the cluster the men cluster had a partner (71%) and were the main breadwinner of the household (74%) at a higher rate than their female counterparts.3. A higher percentage of women (18%) were on furlough when compared to men (11%), probably because women are employed to a greater extent in the service sector, one of the economic sectors most affected by the measures to halt the spread of the pandemic.4. A higher percentage of men transitioned to unemployment (20%) than women did (14%). However, an important group of women stopped working and were dedicated to care work (13%). This would not be the case for men,.5. Men and women who remained continuously employed throughout 2020 had good working conditions, i.e.,low self employment, low labor informality, and most of them worked under contracts. .6. They were also the most educated groups, with women having a higher percentage of higher education (53%) than men (36%).
Policy or intervention associate: Employment status was introduced by the Law of Employment Protection, which allows employers to either suspend the contract of the employees by “authority act” (that is, when the authority obliges the partial or complete cessation of activities due to, for example, quarantines)
Conclusions: 1. Men remained in continuous employment in greater proportion than women. .2. Male workers with family remained employed in a higher proportion than female workers with family. .3. At least half of the women who stopped working after the start of the pandemic did so for care-giving reasons, which would not be the case for men. .4. Women who moved into care work had the worst working conditions..5. Association between poorer working conditions, family responsibilities, and the transition to care work, which leaves unemployed women with young children economically dependent on their partners.

author: Nogueira, Rocha, and Akerman 2021
title: Políticas públicas adoptadas en la pandemia de la COVID-19 en tres países de América Latina: contribuciones de la Promoción de la Salud para no volver al mundo que existía
Objective(s): 1) Their low social immunities prior to the pandemic are pointed out.2) Their public policies in response to the pandemic are analyzed, considering the different approaches to health intervention: risk groups, population, vulnerability and universal proportionalism.3) It indicates how Health Promotion (HP) could influence public policies not to return to the world that existed
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. There are signs of disarticulation between the spheres of government, less marked in Argentina and Chile, countries with greater federal centralization, and more marked in Brazil, where there is greater autonomy guaranteed by the Constitution to entities of states and municipalities..2. Degrees of solidarity with the workers and employers in flexibilization of labor legislation and payment of taxes, notably more generous in Argentina than in Brazil or Chile and the absence of concern on the part of governments for the environmental balance..3. Actions are seen aimed at increasing the collective empowerment, most noted in Argentina, where policies seem to create possibilities for mutual support among citizens, favoring greater commitment and prioritizing social investment, while in Brazil and Chile the legislation seems to prioritize individual protection, holding people responsible for their care..4. The pandemic uncovers social inequalities in all three countries. However, there are emergency protective measures for ensure the survival of the most fragile who, however, they do not alter the structure of distribution of resources, services and power..5. Argentine policies make explicit the perspective of life cycle, supporting retirees and pensioners, pregnant women, students and workers in sectors most affected. Chile look with attention to the students. Brazil does not adopt life cycle perspective in your policies.
Policy or intervention associate: 1. Brazil: The boarding in specific subpopulations with focus on groups risk can be represented by the measures of selective confinement of the elderly and carriers of comorbidities. It's has been widely criticized, since it does not consider social barriers and economic for confinement and does not raise health levels in the most vulnerable groups. .2. Chile: alternating total confinement and by regions, predominantly considering the biological risk and not social vulnerabilities. Socio-spatial inequities and conditions of housing, and use of military troops to night curfew emphasize intervention with low social participation in making decisions..3. Argentina: decreed social confinement mandatory horizontal at the national level (agreed with the different ministries in an intersectoral manner) and with additional resolution of income transfer for pensioners and beneficiaries of social programs. Also, through inter-institutional articulation and intersectoral, adopted measures to confront of situations of gender violence, including fiscal actions of the Public Ministry. Seeks to reverse trends and align health equity policies with policies more spacious.
Conclusions: 1. Situations of austerity and pandemic generate decrease in income, pessimism, seclusion, loneliness, violence, illness and death..2. Governments should guarantee systems of protection to increase social immunity and resilience. As an indispensable part of an answer coordinated policy for the crisis, people need have access to health care, safety employment and income and education, particularly among the most vulnerable, but without ignoring the rest of the population..3. As the goal of improving the health of the population may not necessarily be compatible with the aim of reducing disparities, public health strategies should include approaches universal populational, considering the gradients with a view to promoting equity..4. The intersectoral governance through actions coordinated that favor the protection of life notes the harm reduction of the pandemic.5. The need to adopt multiscale approaches considering the articulation of the dimensions micro, medium and macro for the confrontation of the structural causes of health inequities.6. The need to advance in the recognition of the climate crisis and include the environmental dimension in the actions undertaken.

author: Candido et al. 2021
title: Social Sciences In The Covid-19 Pandemic: Work Routines And Inequalities
Objective(s): To analyze the consequences of the covid-19 pandemic in the academic work routines of Social Sciences in Brazil.
Population: Professional associations in Anthropology, Political Science, Sociology and International Relations
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: -Race/color: white/ yellow/ indigenous/ black or brown.-Gender: Female/ Male/ Other and unresponsive.-Impact of the pandemic on work
Main Results: 1. Although most survey participants reported that the pandemic negatively impacted their academic work routines, the results for those most affected varied according to the social profiles of gender and race. Self-declared black, brown, yellow and indigenous people, grouped in the non-white category, are the ones who most indicated the option “very negatively” to qualify the consequences of covid-19..2. 29% of men and women report negative impacts of covid-19 on their professional lives. Among the small portion that declared positive consequences, in turn, this group was also more recurrent, with 10% for both men and women..3. In terms of academic career stages: in all cases the perception that the pandemic was negative for work routines is dominant. There is, however, a slight oscillation in the frequency of those who considered the impacts “very negative”. This option was more recurrent among graduate students, with 36% of the responses from masters and 25% of the choices from doctoral students.4. Covid-19 and social isolation affected the work of social scientists, in the first place, due to the increase in time spent taking care of the home and/or family members (61%). The disorganization in the routine caused by the pandemic was demarcated as an obstacle to meeting deadlines by 44% of the interviewees and also generated uncertainty about the future for 38%. In addition to an increase in domestic tasks, an increase in the demand for academic (35%) and administrative (24%) work was reported..5. Women have their work routines significantly more affected by the pandemic and perceive an increase in academic demands more intensely than white men. White women, in turn, report feeling more the effects of covid-19 in relation to care issues than non-white women, although the difference between them is small..6. Anthropology was the most affected discipline, with 79% of researchers indicating that they had problems continuing their research, followed by other areas (61%), sociology (58%), political science (38%) and international relations (21%)..7. Non-white women have lower proportions of productivity than the other groups (32%), while white men have the highest levels of production (42%).8. Submission of articles by respondents who have children was 41%, and by people without children, 36%. On the other hand, among people who have children, 33% said they had not produced anything in the period, while respondents with children indicated a higher percentage, 37%..9. In the group of teachers, 73.8% indicated an increase in housework, which rises to 80.5% in the case of teachers who take care of children.10. White and non-white women indicate more time spent on care activities than men, and inequality is significant.11. A little more than 20% stated that they “are better concentrated at home” and/or that “the structure of my house is better for working”. More than 30% stated that they save transit time and therefore can work harder. Men report more than women that working at home during the pandemic is good, as it allows them to spend more time with their children.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. As consequences of the recent crisis, they tend to reverberate differently, with areas such as anthropology being more harmed in terms of conducting their traditional research methods; women, especially black, more overloaded with work routines, and white men maintaining advantages in professional development, even declaring losses in this crisis scenario..2. An academic community as a whole reported an increase in job demands. Contrary to what might be expected, teachers continued to have high productivity rates. This is likely to lead to fatigue and challenges to mental health, especially in groups that have less access to leisure activities and are overloaded with care functions and household chores..3. Graduate students experience the health crisis and are exposed to insecurity about how professional opportunities will be provided..4. The data on inequalities presented demonstrate the relevance of maintaining and expanding policies such as affirmative action for black people in accessing undergraduate, graduate courses and public examinations.

author: A. L. M. de Oliveira and Alloatti 2021
title: Gendering the crisis: austerity and the Covid-19 pandemic in Brazil
Objective(s): To investigate the specificities of the gendered impacts of austerity in the country that have rendered Brazilian women structurally more vulnerable to the Covid-19 crisis
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities - Extensive qualitative documentary analysis
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Studies conducted thus far highlight that gender inequality may be exacerbated by austerity measures/policies since they worsen women’s labour-family life balance and render them more vulnerable to recession due to being predominantly engaged in part-time, temporary jobs, informal work, and self-employment, as well as accentuating inequalities between women..2. Women are also more vulnerable to gender-based violence when welfare provisions and entitlements impact women's equality, safety and financial autonomy..3. In Brazil, public policy responses during the Covid-19 crisis have been severely lacking and have not specifically considered its gendered effects, indicating a significant shortfall.
Policy or intervention associate: 1. Emergency Benefit. This benefit consisted of R$600 per month bestowed on individuals with informal jobs, monthly/annual incomes below a defined threshold and was limited to two people per household. The National Congress added teenage mothers and single mothers who live in a single parent home with their children among the recipients of two instalments per month. The monthly value of the benefit was later reduced by 50%, as the federal government protested its “enormous” fiscal cost.
Conclusions: 1. This analysis focuses on aspects of the pandemic in Brazil, while underscoring their relation to direct and indirect gendered effects of the existing austerity approach..2. The complexity of these topics and the paucity of data must be addressed in order to fully comprehend the aftermath of the pandemic, as well as the effects and accountability of political decisions.
Funding sources: None: No funding was received for conducting this study

author: Sousa et al. 2021
title: The LGBTI+ people and covid-19: For us to think about health issues
Objective(s): To reflect theoretically and critically the scenario of the health situation of LGBTI+ people in face of the Covid-19 in the context of a pandemic in Brazil.
Population: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Intersexed (LGBTI+) people
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis): the interpretation and analysis of the theoretical elements obtained through the bibliographic survey, it was decided not to present a tablesynthesis about the state of the art.
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. In the moment we live the virus itself does not discriminate, but inequalities are operated in our society in the historical process that has intertwined nationalism with poverty, racism, xenophobia and capitalism, so that this dynamic promotes an accentuation of the spurious distinction between lives that are susceptible and not susceptible to mourning, where the production of precariousness elects those forms of life that are protected against death and those whose lives are considered not worth enough to be safeguarded against sickness and death.2. From this perspective, also concerned with the health of the LGBTI+ population in this scenario, the Brazilian Association of Collective Health (Abrasco) published a note with considerations that call for the breaking of silence and invisibility destined by several agencies and institutions, such as the State and civil society, to guide the subject as an essential agenda in public health in Brazil and in the rest of the world..3. It is important to emphasize that virtual meeting platforms under the perspective of users have been part in a more vehement way of the daily life of people who make use of these devices. In this aspect, if the moment calls for distance and social isolation, physical encounters occasioned by means of these platforms can put the health of their users at risk, constituting another aspect to be observed..4. Another factor that increases the harms to the lives of LGBTI+ people in Brazil during the pandemic are the daily attacks generated by presidential representation on the rights of this population segment, in spite of the constant potential for generating stress on the wellbeing of people who live with the violation of basic human rights, as well as the negative, obscurantist, reactionary, LGBT-phobic and delegitimizing position of the existence(s) of LGBTI+ people just as Brazil has been internationally recognized.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The study theoretically reflected initial questions on the health dimension of LGBTI+ people from the occurrence of the ongoing pandemic of the new Coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) causing Covid-19 in Brazil, and elucidated in a denouncing manner the aspects that generate impacts and negative repercussions that intensify and overlap inequalities, vulnerabilities that revert to inequities in health. .2. Rethinking the practices of segregation, discrimination, violence and prejudice to which biopolitics exposes certain human groups, as happens with LGBTI+ people, will make there an emerging need to ensure the protection of all liveable lives. .3. Specifically in the field of health care, it is relevant to consider the confrontation of the pandemic associated with the intervention of measures to correct inequalities in service provision, which has expressive potential for the precarization of lives. .4. It is recommended to deepen the research on the reflected problem, as a way to broaden the knowledge about the phenomenon and consequently to encourage effective interventions to be implemented in the daily practices throughout the national territory and other planetary contexts.

author: Menezes and Contipelli 2021
title: The covid-19 crisis and its impacts on social welfare in brazil: The rise of poverty and inequalities
Journal: Middle Atlantic Review of Latin American Studies
Objective(s): To analyze the rise of poverty and social inequality in the world caused by the COVID-19 crisis, in addition to considering how to address the issue in the context of new perspectives on the social welfare state.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Restrictive measures to combat the pandemic, layoffs in the period skyrocketed with the closing of companies in various sectors, leaving the scenario even more fragile in a health crisis..2. This pandemic reproduces the naturalization of structural inequalities in Brazilian society..3. A humanitarian emergency, with precarious urban infrastructures: more than 13 million people live in favelas; some live on the streets; others are deprived of their liberty—Brazil is the third country in the world in terms of prison population; and local indigenous communities do not have access to infrastructure (transport, basic health, education, electricity)..4. The structural and historical problem, Brazil is experiencing an unfavorable political moment. .5. Brazil’s robust public health system that guarantees access to all health procedures for the entire population. Problems emerge, such as the lack of sufficient money to meet all needs, but the issue of access to health services by the poor has been resolved.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Without control of the pandemic, it is impossible to think about economic recovery..2. Confront the pandemic in all its phases, policies regarding health, social, and economic issues must be integrated, coordinated, participatory, and adapted to each national and subnational context and guided by related fundamental principles or bases..3. The prioritization of health and the strengthening of health systems based on the primary healthcare strategy should be considered the necessary foundations to respond to the crisis in all its aspects..4. Policy options to address the pandemic involve consolidating a national plan and an intersectoral consensus..5. The central problem today is the economic relationship between the social objectives pursued by the welfare state and the economic behavior of private agents. This results in greater control of economic activity by the  tate so that its social and economic ends are achieved.

author: Fernandes et al. 2020
title: Covid-19 and the Brazilian Reality: The Role of Favelas in Combating the Pandemic
Objective(s): The consequences of coronavirus in favelas in Rio de Janeiro (Brazil) point to social inequality as a structuring factor in Brazilian society.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. One of the most serious moments of the pandemic, police operations killed dozens of young black people..2. Important initiatives have been filed in the legislative houses, most of them have not been approved and those that were are still not being implemented. The slowness of implementation of the measures makes explicit the relationship that governments establish with such territories, where efforts to preserve life are less frequent than the imminence of death..3. The social inequalities discussed here have intimate relations with historical and contemporary political processes, which have existed since long before the pandemic and will still exist after its end. Thus, it is possible that the experience of the pandemic in Brazil potentiates an unprecedented crisis..4. In the midst of the crisis caused by the new Coronavirus, people living in slums and peripheries have been mobilized through community articulation and strengthening of solidarity networks to fight the virus and reduce social and economic impacts in the territories..5. Faced with the uncertainties of the scenario, the networks of solidarity have played the role that the State is not playing when it comes to facing the spread of the new disease.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. A crisis contained within other existing and once again, socioeconomic factors, closely linked to the color race class, determine who lives and who dies, not only in Rio de Janeiro, despite this being part of the scenario..2. The pandemic has been an important device to make the harsh reality of inequality of the slums and peripheries in the country be seen and talked about..3. The slums are the social that is most organized and active in the fight against the coronavirus..4. The initiative to think about public policies to confront the chaos that is being placed has also been of the favelas, articulated in their collectives and leaders..5. The coronavirus shows the particularities of the slums and peripheries and the negligence in the face of the demands of the poorest.

author: M. Gil and Undurraga 2020
title: COVID-19 Has Exposed How ‘The Other Half’ (Still) Lives
Journal: The Bulletin of Latin American Research (BLAR
Objective(s): To illustrate how socio-spatial inequalities are heavily shaping the pandemic, amplified by the fact that decision-makers have failed to take these inequalities and marginalised livelihoods into account.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The COVID-19 pandemic started in high-income neighbourhoods; it was initially described as the ‘disease of the rich’..2. The dramatic spatial inequality of Santiago, with elites living in the northeast and low-income neighbourhoods concentrated elsewhere..3. By overlooking critical socio-spatial factors such as segregation, sanitation, and overcrowding, decision-makers were blind to the potential consequences of their strategy of localized lockdowns..4. The data show that the higher the rate of multidimensional poverty, the less effective the lockdown in reducing mobility, with up to a threefold difference in mobility reductions at the extremes..5. Low-income municipalities people were not quarantining as intensely as in better-off municipalities..6. COVID-19 risk perception in the country was high and comparable across socioeconomic groups..7. The problem is that the effectiveness of pandemic mitigation strategies depends not only on the willingness of the population to comply with them, but also on their ability to do so..8. Political discussions about economic measures to support low and middle-income households were slow, and the resources failed to arrive in time to avoid further spread of the virus.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Overcrowding and inadequate hygienic conditions were constructed as social problems by Chilean elites at the beginning of the twentieth century..2. Decision-makers and authorities in Chile believed they would be able to control the pandemic because of the initial success of partial lockdowns in the richest area of Santiago..3. People in cities are interdependent; the wellbeing of communities depends on the health of all their members. They can only hope this sanitary crisis brings about much needed spatial justice for Chile in general, and Santiago in particular.
Funding sources: The ANID Millennium Science Initiative grant ‘Millennium Nucleus for the Study of the Life Course and Vulnerability (MLIV)’, the ‘Millennium Initiative for Collaborative Research on Bacterial Resistance (MICROB-R)’, [NCN17_081] and the Research Center for Integrated Disaster Risk Management (CIGIDEN), [ANID/FONDAP/15110017].

author: Barreto Jr. 2020
title: The COVID-19 Pandemic and the Ongoing Genocide of Black and Indigenous Peoples in Brazil
Journal: International Journal of Latin American Religions
Objective(s): To reflect on the tragedy of the Brazilian experience with the COVID-19 pandemic and the deeper wounds it reveals and magnifies. How its impact magnifies and intensifies the continued genocide of black and indigenous Brazilians.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Black Brazilians are also the majority of those losing their jobs and experiencing hunger during the pandemic..2. The significant rise in the selling of weapons is taking place during the unprecedented public health crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, when the country and its population have been also economically strained. Armed attacks against indigenous lands in the Amazon rainforest and in the Midwest wetlands have spiked since Bolsonaro took office and continue to take place during the pandemic..3. The pandemic is added to other historical problems, which we already face, such as deforestation, fires, violence, internal conflicts, and the very Brazilian political situation that at the moment does not contribute to the protection of rights..4. Neighborhoods with the highest proportions of people identified as black and brown accumulate the highest number of deaths from COVID-19..5. Neighborhoods with more slums tend to have more cases and deaths..6. The Mapa da Desigualdade makes a clear correlation between race and low income. The correlation between COVID-19s reference for black and brown lives reinforces the impact of social and economic inequality on public health..7. The pandemic has revealed to the whole world the severity of the environmental crisis in which we find ourselves, and the limits not only of capitalism as our social model but also of the colonial, patriarchal, and racialized cultural structure.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The pandemic has amplified structural injustices, including racism and the continuous genocide of indigenous and black Brazilians, ongoing initiatives among grassroots Christian communities during the pandemic point to the contrasting roles of Christianity in the region..2. Resulting from a participatory process, of which the voices of the indigenous and other peoples of the Amazon were constitutive, these documents offer language that may prove to be in coming years a significant roadmap for a future epistemological turn, through which the ancestral wisdom of the peoples of the Amazon emerges in a situation of parity with the traditions and teachings of Christianity.

author: Dadalto, De Lucena Mascarenhas, and Matos 2020
title: Also save the elderly: Etarism and the allocation of resources in the brazilian reality of combating Covid-19
Objective(s): To discuss ageism in Brazil during the Covid-19 pandemic and the allocation of scarce resources.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. What is observed is a growing number of people who will die for lack of material and financial resources to fight Covid-19. At first, the doctrine points out that the miserable, premature and avoidable death would be called mythanasia. From this perspective, although the lack of respirators may represent one of the biggest causes of death in the context of Covid-19, this would not be a situation of mythanasia, as its extraordinary nature and abrupt demand are not predictable situations, despite the effects of the pandemic may be compounded by human actions or omissions..2. Considering the exclusively age criterion, especially in the case of Covid-19, is to enable a denial of the right to health, especially due to the greater risk for the elderly who, as a rule, also have comorbidities such as diabetes and hypertension.3. In extreme situations, using an ICU admission age criterion to save resources for those with greater probability of survival and longer life expectancy, as these elderly people would be mere resource consumers..4. The proposal to restrict access to health care for the elderly under the argument that they have already completed the life cycle or that they will not generate social return as a young person, in addition to being fallacious, is based on a supposed utilitarianism that is not necessarily correlated with age, since there is an intrinsic paradox to this supposed correlation, as a lower life expectancy does not mean that the elderly person has “less to contribute”. Many of the greatest minds of our time are elderly people. If we think in a utilitarian way and under the argument of social return, younger people would benefit at the expense of such people.
Policy or intervention associate: Some private hospitals, such as Albert Einstein and Sírio Libanês, both located in the city of São Paulo, have published their protocols and age is not an exclusion factor. Specifically in relation to the document published by the Hospital Albert Einstein, age is a factor taken into account only to compare the patient with the expected situation for people of their age, through the assessment of frailty, physical and clinical condition of the patient. In this way, the age criterion becomes fair, as it does not compare subjects in different conditions, but the subject with his own age group, thus effecting a treatment..The Regional Council of Medicine of Paraná (CRM/PR), on the other hand, stated that it is up to the Bioethics Commission or the Crisis Management Committee to set the criteria for allocation of resources and, in their absence, to the doctor himself, including choosing for using the order of arrival criterion.
Conclusions: 1. The pandemic required public authorities and society to reflect on the ethical criteria for allocating scarce resources..2. It fell to some private entities and, in a decentralized manner, to some Regional Councils of Medicine, in view of the state vacuum, issue resource allocation protocols. This action presents two insecurities: creation of multiple parallel protocols and a private invocation of content..3. The existence of multiple protocols may generate individual decisions to seek Institutions or States that value a certain allocation criterion, creating, on the part of the patient, the search for the subsumption of their staff to the health unit that does not place them at an excessive disadvantage or in a potential advantage..4. The decision to allocate scarce resources has always been inherent in the reality of managers, especially in peripheral countries and was only evidenced and exponentialized in the pandemic, which also highlighted the need for allocation criteria to be widely debated and avoided criteria that exclude specific groups, such as age criteria, under penalty of representing eugenic practices to eliminate the most vulnerable population..5. Despite being a tragic choice and one that entails an opportunity cost, the elderly cannot be sacrificed so that the younger ones have the means to try to survive. The current pretense of ageism practice of denying the elderly access to health care, in addition to being discriminatory, can translate into a death sentence, as access is denied to the means known by current science to fight Covid-19..6. Finally, it is necessary to extrapolate the legal argument and defend that the neglect of the elderly at that time constitutes a true disregard for the future of Humanity, because, by assuming that the young will have preference, it is, in fact, opening a dangerous precedent for future societies to be able to ignore the old age that will be represented by all contemporaries of this pandemic, after all, if today the world is fighting Covid-19 it is precisely so that everyone is able to live longer.

author: Dutra, Bastos, and Cardoso 2020
title: Covid-19 and social inequality: Economic measures in mercosur countries
Journal: Revista Relações Internacionais no Mundo Atual
Objective(s): To investigate the economic measures taken by the governments of each MERCOSUR country and how they will affect household income, increasing social inequality
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The Covid-19 pandemic is a reflection of inequality. A health emergency that makes us think about how the less favored are historically treated..2. While there are female workers who can reduce their exposure to the risk of contagion by working remotely or benefiting from preventive measures, many people do not have this advantage, as they are already in a situation of inequality..3. Brazil: While there are female workers who can reduce their exposure to the risk of contagion by working remotely or benefiting from preventive measures, many people do not have this advantage, as they are already in a situation of inequality..4. Argentina: In order to offset the financial impacts of the economy, the Argentine government instituted the Emergency Assistance Program for Work and Production. The program envisages reducing the payments of contributions made by companies with up to 60 employees to the pension system by up to 95%, postponing the maturity of employer contributions to the pension system, granting salary allocations to private sector companies with up to 100 employees. The Argentine government has also implemented the Ingreso Familiar de Emergencia (IFE) benefit for informal workers and workers from private homes, social transport drivers and category A and B drivers. own or family members or receive another state benefit and reside for more than 2 years in Argentina. The benefit consists of 10,000 pesos a month for aid during the pandemic period..4. The Uruguayan government also made the granting of unemployment insurance more flexible during the pandemic period. In the months of April and May 2020, workers who had contributions between three and five months to the Social Security Bank will be able to receive temporary unemployment insurance. These workers will receive a lower benefit than those who had a contribution for more than six months..5. With the extension of the pandemic and pressure from the business sector, the Paraguayan government made it possible to approve the temporary suspension of activities for companies that apply to the Ministry of Labor and, after approval of this petition, workers in these locations will receive a subsidy by the Institute of Social Security.
Policy or intervention associate: Argentina: Emergency Assistance Program  for Work and Production;  Ingreso Familiar de Emergencia.Brazil and Paraguay: subsidy
Conclusions: 1. The adoption of short-term measures to face the crisis must not lose sight of protecting low-income families. .2.Income support measures must be broad enough to cover vulnerable female workers and the companies that employ them. COVID-19 is a test of societies, governments, communities and people. .3. The suspension of the employment contract is a common action by the four Mercosur governments. Argentina and Paraguay stipulated the need for action by some public authority in this suspension negotiation

author: de Freitas, e Silva, and Cidade 2020
title: COVID-19 as a global disaster: Challenges to risk governance and social vulnerability in Brazil
Objective(s): To understand this pandemic as a global disaster that can evolve into a complex emergency presenting risks for a humanitarian crisis in many countries, including Brazil. In this context they face two challenges: the governance of risks and coping and reducing vulnerabilities.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. A model of economic inequality, income concentration and growing poor population exists, increasingly concentrated in urban areas and their peripheries, in precarious living conditions and the weakening of institutions and capacities of global governance to deal with disasters and pandemics that require coordinated policies and actions have intensified social inequalities and income concentration resulting in a large vulnerable population with precarious living, working and income conditions..2. The vulnerable population is the most dependent on the actions carried out by universal health systems, such as the Brazilian Unified Health System (SUS), healthcare for groups at higher risk of COVID-19, such as the elderly, people with chronic diseases (diabetic, hypertensive, cardiac insufficiency, renal or chronic respiratory disease)..3. The health sector plays a key leadership role in the risk management of a pandemic, a process that includes and depends on the participation of the civil society (NGOs, residents' associations, local movements such as the ones in favelas and indigenous communities, among others) and other government sectors relevant to response (Civil Defense, economy, education, transportation, water and sanitation, environment, social protection, agriculture, among others)..4. In Brazil, the president has been threatening to edit a decree to prevent the autonomy of states and municipalities to issue social distance measures and, at the same time, boycotting them through presidential decrees that amplify what is considered essential activities, including religious centers, fitness centers, beauty salons and barbershops..5. Brazil is a country of vast dimensions and with great heterogeneity in its socioeconomic and cultural contexts, as well as regional and intraregional inequalities, making the country 7th in terms of social inequalities in the world..6. The lack of a specific position by the federal government for the situation of such areas leading to self-management initiatives by popular movements highlights two aspects: 1. The absence of state and municipal policies that take into account these vulnerabilities, 2. The capacity for local and regional management, pointing to ways that can be incorporated by public policy.
Policy or intervention associate: 1. Covid Action Plan in the Favelas of Rio de Janeiro: a catastrophe to be avoided.2. “Street presidents".
Conclusions: They live in a context in Brazil where the threats of the political, social and economic have intersected with the hazards caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. These threats undermine risk governance capabilities and widen and intensify social inequalities, making Brazil the new epicenter of the global disaster by COVID-19 and a potential humanitarian crisis in poor areas

author: Hughes et al. 2021
title: The Impact of Health Disparities on COVID-19 Outcomes: Early Findings from a High-Income Country and Two Middle-Income Countries.
Journal: Journal of Racial and Ethnic Health Disparities
Objective(s): To discuss the relationship of race/ethnicity with COVID-19-associated factors in the three countries.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities
Type of social stratification: NA
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).
Main Results: 1. Prepandemic health disparities.a. The relatively higher burden of chronic diseases, among specific ethnicities in the three countries, is believed to reflect lower access to healthcare, primary care providers, or disease prevention strategies..- In Brazil, analysis of the 2010 data on elderly access to health services in São Paulo showed that populations classified as Black (74.3%) or Brown (69.8%) were more likely to be uninsured compared to Whites (46.9%)..2. About Covid-19 Experience.a. More females were infected in the USA (51.7%) and South Africa (58.3%) while in Brazil, more males were infected. In South Africa, the higher number of female cases may be due to exposure in roles related to healthcare and teaching, along with their health-seeking behaviors..b. In the USA and Brazil, confirmed infections were highest in the age groups 18–29 years (21.8%) and 60–69 years (20.5%), respectively. In South Africa, the age groups 30–34 and 35–39 years accounted for 12.5 and 12.8% of cases, respectively, which collectively comprised 25.3% of cases..c.While more cases of confirmed infection were recorded among females in South Africa and the USA, there were more deaths among males.d. Across all three countries, those who were more likely to develop severe disease were older individuals, males, and those with comorbidities..e. Heart disease (45.4% and 9.2% in individuals above and below 60 years, respectively) and diabetes mellitus (33.6% and 9.0% in individuals above and below 60 years, respectively) were the most frequent comorbidities among individuals who died..f. In the USA, hypertension (59.3%), obesity (47.0%), metabolic disease (42.9%), and cardiovascular disease (34.0%) were the most frequently reported comorbidities among hospitalized adult patients over a 3-month period..g. An increased prevalence of underlying health conditions has been noted to contribute to higher COVID-19 mortality in people living with HIV in the USA..h. In South Africa being of Black African, Colored, or Indian ethnicity was associated with in-hospital mortality. In Brazil, an ethnicity effect was noted, where individuals of Brown and Black ethnicity had increased risk of mortality. In the USA, rates for hospitalization were higher for minority populations (American Indians/Alaskan Natives (1.9), African Americans (1.8), and Hispanics/Latinos (1.6) compared to Whites (0.5)).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The COVID-19 mortality among people of African descent and some other minorities in the USA, Brazil and South Africa may reflect their increased level of exposure to the virus, burden of comorbidities, or challenges with access to healthcare resources..2. The ongoing pandemic has highlighted the importance of addressing social health determinants, the importance of basic functional amenities in different sectors, and the need for collective global effort in infection control.

author: Feter et al. 2021
title: Ethnoracial disparity among patients with dementia during COVID-19 pandemic TT - Disparidade étnico-racial entre pacientes com demência durante a pandemia da COVID-19 TT - Disparidad étnico-racial entre pacientes con demencia durante la pandemia de COVID-19
Objective(s): To examine the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on the ethnoracial disparities in hospitalizations due to dementia and its related outcomes, in Brazil
Sample size: n=4101(Data from Hospital Information Systems of the Brazilian Unified National Health System (SIH/SUS))
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive analysis: Continuous data were reported as absolute values.2. One-way analysis of variance with Bonferroni’s post-hoc was carried out to examine differences in hospitalization rate, mean inpatient spending, and mortality rate across regions. .Odds ratios for death during hospitalization were calculated by ethnoracial groups in each year..
Type of social stratification: - Hospitalization rates per 100,000 inhabitants..- Inpatient spending( total/ mean) .- Mortality rate.- Ethnicity: white/ black/mixed.- Geographic region: Central-West/North/Northeast/South/Southeast
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1. The decrease in hospital admissions was more pronounced among mixed (-42%) and black (-39%) individuals..2. The mean inpatient spending related to these hospitalizations was 56% lower in the black population in 2020 than in 2019. .3. A remarkable increase in mortality rate among black (65%) and mixed (43%) was followed by a decrease (-9%) among whites. in 2020, both black (1.79; 95%CI: 1.12, 2.86) and mixed (1.61; 95%CI: 1.20, 2.18) patients with dementia reported a heightened risk of mortality compared to white patients..REGIONS.4. The reduction by 32.2% in hospitalization rate in the Southeast region offsets the difference observed between this region with the North and Northeast in 2019. Hospitalization rates decreased in most ethnoracial groups in the Northeast and Southeast regions..5. The Southeast region had the highest mean inpatient spending, in 2020, compared to other regions. the disparity in the inpatient spending was attenuated between the periods as a result of lower (-44.9%) inpatient spending among black and higher inpatient spending (258.8%) in the mixed population..6.  In 2019 the Central-West and Southeast regions had the leading inpatient mortality rate due to dementia in the country, .7. Disparity between white and black patients declined from 2019 to 2020 in the South and Central-West regions, with the mixed race population being less hospitalized during this period..8. Although a reduction in hospitalization rates was observed across all groups, the reduction among black and mixed people was, respectively, 105.3% and 121.1% greater than in whites..9. Mortality rate was decreased by 9% in whites and increased by 65% and 43% in black and mixed populations, respectively.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. In the first semester of 2020, black and mixed patients had a higher risk of losing their lives due to dementia, when compared to white patients. This disparity was not observed in the same period of 2019..2. The remarkable decrease of hospitalization rates in black and mixed subjects needs to be highlighted. The role genetics play in the race-specific difference, regarding the progression of dementia, seems to be overcome by cultural and social factors.3. The belief in dementia as a part of normal aging, differences in educational achievement, and inequity in access to health care may impact the diagnosis and treatment of such disease across ethnoracial groups..4. White patients had the lowest mean inpatient spending amongst ethnoracial groups. (...) Inequalities in accessing primary care, diagnostic services, and awareness about the neurodegenerative process, associated with dementia, are related to delay in seeking health services..5. Public health policies need to assure that people with dementia will have access to healthcare services during and after the pandemic regardless of skin color, and strategies to promote the diagnoses, treatment, and prevention of dementia must be sustained during social distancing. Otherwise, not only the burden of dementia might be heightened after – and during – the COVID-19 pandemic but also the ethnoracial disparity of such burden..
Funding sources: Brazilian Graduate Studies Coordinating Board (CAPES; Finance Code 001).

author: N. R. A. de A. Nunes, Rodriguez, and Cinacchi 2021
title: Health and social care inequalities: The impact of covid-19 on people experiencing homelessness in Brazil
Journal: International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health
Objective(s): To reflect on the challenges affecting people experiencing homelessness in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, due the COVID-19 pandemic.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis through percentages
Type of social stratification: -Age.-Race: Black/brown // White // Yellow/Indigenous // No answer.-Education: Literate /Illiterate /Complete high school /Incomplete high school /Complete elementary school /Incomplete elementary school /Complete higher education /Incomplete higher education /No answer.-Income-generating activities, health status, street life-related attitudes and behaviors
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Education.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Features of relationships (e.g. smoking parents, excluded from school)
Main Results: 1. There is a predominance of low education. The most predominant education level corresponds to Incomplete Primary School with 42.8% of individuals, followed by Complete Elementary School (18.8%), and Incomplete High School (17.1%). Less than one percent of our audience had completed Higher Education..2. Women stated more health problems before the pandemic (43% women against 24% for men). Had more levels of unemployment (20% of women without any source of income and 7% for men in the same position). Higher levels of education when compared to men (25% for women with high school degree and 16% of men)..3. The services that most appear to be accessed before and during the pandemic were from social care sectors (56.3%). Almost one-quarter of the sample (23.7%) said they had been approached by public security agencies..4. Some people reported not having been approached by any service (18.8%) during their life on the streets..5. A significant number of respondents (80.3%) pointed out the use of public services to address health issues..6. The Basic Health units would be able to solve 69.1% of cases of those searching for care..7. The economic activities (recycling, selling products on the streets, cleaning jobs, construction, and by begging for money and food in front of restaurants, stores, and cash machines) were dependent on the movement of the cities, and with empty streets, it became extremely difficult for this group to earn money even to buy food..8. When asked what kind of extra help they were receiving during the pandemic, 83.2% said they were receiving food from NGOs (meals or breakfast), and 10.2% said they received basic food baskets.9. More than half of participants said they received this type of product coming from non-governmental organizations as an extra help during the pandemic.10. When asked if they had pre-existing health conditions 26.3% of individuals responded positively. 27.5% mentioned they had a heart problem, with the highest reports being arterial hypertension. The second highest health issue was respiratory problems (tuberculosis, bronchitis, pneumonia, sinusitis, or the flu), with 22.5% of the total. 17.5% percent of respondents reported having HIV, with only one case of coinfection with syphilis. A representative percentage of 14% reported having diabetes..
Policy or intervention associate: 1. Consultório na Rua. This service is configured as a strategy from the National Primary Care Policy and states that health care for this specific population should be the responsibility of all health professionals in the Brazilian Unified Health System (SUS), especially in Primary Care, as it is to any other citizen..2. `Pia do Bem`. A social project called ‘Pia do Bem’ (good sink) installed more than one hundred mobile sinks in the municipality and the Metropolitan Region of Rio de Janeiro in April 2020 to help with the hygiene maintaining of this population.3. Bolsa Família Program. The federal government provides social benefits for the poor population such as the Bolsa Família Program (for those without work and with children in school age), and for old people aged 65 years and over who did not contribute to social security. An extra emergency support aid of R$ 600.00 (the equivalent of 85£) was provided to address the impacts of COVID-19 from April 2020 to January 2021.
Conclusions: 1. The prevalence of men within the homeless population is globally observed. The black population is particularly susceptible to this condition..2. The COVID-19 pandemic is increasing poverty and impacting people’s lives in Brazil..3. There is a visible rise in the numbers of those experiencing homelessness and rough sleepers..4. The lack of official data on this population in Brazilian leads to reflect on how to carry out health surveillance when there is no specific record on information and knowledge about this population in most health information systems..5. Several testimonies reinforced the worsening of the situation of extreme vulnerability and poverty already experienced by these groups before the pandemic.
Funding sources: None: This research received no external funding

author: R. H. M. Pereira et al. 2021

( can be considered insufficient in an epidemic situation, posing a risk of overload in scenarios for COVID-19 contagion indicated in previous studies.).3. Thirteen out of the 20 cities analyzed are below the recommended level of service.4. Availability of ICU beds and ventilators to serve patients with severe COVID-19 tends to be considerably lower in the peripheral regions of these cities.
