Conclusions: 1. Vulnerable populations (with low-income and black communities) with poor access to health services, lower healthcare system capacity, are mostly located in urban peripheries..2. High population density coupled with low incomes and poor sanitation services create a worrying scenario with strong potential for propagation of the COVID-19 .3. Thirteen out of the 20 cities analyzed have fewer ICU beds/ventilators than the minimum level recommended by national authorities..4. Urban peripheries areas which would be good candidates for local policy interventions, such as setting up field hospitals or engaging pre-hospital mobile units  or community health agents.

author: Macchia et al. 2021
title: COVID-19 among the inhabitants of the slums in the city of Buenos Aires: A population-based study
Objective(s): To summarise the unfolding of the COVID-19 epidemic among slum dwellers and different social strata in the city of Buenos Aires during the first 20 weeks after the first reported case.
City or municipality: Slums in the city of Buenos Aires
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis: differences between groups of interest were tested using the ?2, test for discrete variables and the T or Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test
Type of social stratification: Social gradient in the distribution of incidence rates between the different neighbourhoods of the city and the slums: Socioeconomic status in quintiles (1/2/3/4/5/slum)
Main Results: 1. Incidence rates of COVID-19 infection were 160.0 (155.4 to 164.7) per 100000 people among the inhabitants who did not reside in the slums (n=2 841 997) and 708.4 (674.5 to 742.5) among those who had a residence in the slum (233749) (IRR 11.08 (10.51 to 11.68), p<0.0001).2. Incidence rate for COVID-19 was related to the level of unsatisfied basic needs for each of the city’s neighbourhoods..3. Hospitalised persons, those with residence in a slum were significantly younger (35.6±20.8 years) than those living out of slum (50.0±23.9 years, (p<0.0001)).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Although slum dwellers represent 7% of the city’s population, they contribute 40% of the cases..2. Age-adjusted stratified incidence rates differ in astronomical proportions..3. Half of the households in slums do not have sewage disposal, those one-third are critically overcrowded and that one in four does not have main water. Eighty per cent of adults over 25 years of age have not completed secondary education..4. Slums constitute an individual reality with its own identity and a dynamism that can only be managed as such.

author: Raymundo et al. 2021
title: Spatial analysis of COVID-19 incidence and the sociodemographic context in Brazil
Objective(s): To analyze the spatial distribution of COVID-19 incidence in Brazil's municipalities (counties) and investigate its association with sociodemographic determinants to better understand the social context and the epidemic's spread in the country.
Sample size: n=26 states and the Federal District
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Data analysis used global regression models: ordinary least squares (OLS), spatial autoregressive model (SAR), and conditional autoregressive model (CAR) and the local regression model called multiscale geographically weighted regression (MGWR)
Type of social stratification: -Demographic: Estimated total population of municipality/ Proportion of elderly in municipality/ Proportion of black or brown population in the municipality/ Population density. .-Healthcare: Physicians with employment contract per municipality per 1,000 inhabitants/ Nurses with employment contract per municipality per 1,000 inhabitants /Number of state primary outpatient clinics per municipality....-Socioeconomic: Log of mean monthly nominal household income/ GINI index/ Unemployment rate/ Proportional mortality ratio or Swaroop and Uemura index/ Municipal human development index–MHDI....
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Place of residence.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. The highest crude incidence rates of the disease occurred in the North of Brazil and on the coastline, especially in the Northeast and Southeast..2. Municipalities with low COVID-19 incidence surrounded by municipalities with low incidence were located mainly in the Central-West region, the interior of the Northeast and Southeast, and in much of the South..3. The higher the GINI index, the higher the incidence of the disease at the municipal level. FIGURA 6. (North region, except the west of Acre State. In addition, in the parts of Maranhão, Piauí and Bahia states (Northeast region); in the Central-West region, in the north of the state of Mato Grosso; in the Southeast region, including the entire Espírito Santo and Rio de Janeiro states, as well as part of the Minas Gerais..4. The nurse ratio per 1,000 inhabitants showed a positive association with COVID-19 incidence throughout the North and Northeast of Brazil (except the far south of Bahia state), in Southeast Brazil, in the north, east, and south of Minas Gerais state, in the Central-West region, in the north of the states of Mato Grosso and Goiás; in the South of Brazil. FIGURA 8.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Spatial distribution of COVID-19 incidence was high in the North of Brazil and part of the Northeast region, including its coastline, extending to a large part of the Southeast region..2. Multivariate analyses identified three covariables as predictors of COVID-19 incidence in Brazilian municipalities: GINI, nurse ratio per 1,000 inhabitants, and proportional mortality ratio (PMR)..3. Proportional mortality ratio was inversely associated with COVID-19 incidence in most Brazilian municipalities (the higher the incidence, the lower the PMR)..4. High PMR values are related to low levels of social vulnerability, as in the comparison with ethnic groups..5. Populations with increased social vulnerability are more exposed to the risk of infection. These populations experience limitations in adhering to social distancing measures, due to their work situation, largely informal, and precarious housing and sanitation conditions, factors that hinder maintenance of the hygiene needed to prevent and control transmission of the disease
Funding sources: None: The author(s) received no specific funding for this work.

author: C. D. F. de Souza, Do Carmo, and Machado 2021
title: The burden of COVID-19 in Brazil is greater in areas with high social deprivation
Objective(s): To analyze the spatial association between the Social Deprivation Index (SDI) and the incidence, mortality and case fatality rate (CFR) by COVID-19 in the state of Bahia, northeastern Brazil, to identify priority areas for intervention.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The analysis was performed using the Moran Local Bivariate statistic. Moran’s index defines the degree of spatial association.
Type of social stratification: The Social Deprivation Index is composed of four variables: (i) municipal socioeconomic performance index—economy and finance; (ii) average monthly per capita income; (iii) proportion of extremely poor and (iv) the number of households with a density greater than three people per bedroom. The indicator varies between 0.142 and 0.699, the higher the greater the social deprivation experienced by the population.
Main Results: 1. The Case fatality rate (CFR) was 1.42 times higher in the municipalities with very high social deprivation, when compared with those with low deprivation (2.2 and 1.54%, respectively)..2. It was also observed that the social deprivation index (SDI) in these priority groups was higher than the state SDI.3. The relationship between the transmission of COVID-19 and social deprivation is mutual and complex. At the same time that social deprivation increases the risk of illness, COVID-19 also increases social deprivation.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. It is urgent to adopt public policies that can reduce the degree of municipal social need. .2. Without such a measure, the degree of suffering of poor populations tends to be even greater than that already observed today. .3. There are reasons to believe that confronting the pandemic should include a wide range of measures, from those directly linked to the health sector to the adoption of social protection mechanisms for the population.

author: M. P. A. dos Santos et al. 2020
title: População negra e Covid-19: Reflexões sobre racismo e saúde
Objective(s): To contribute to the reflection on the impacts of the covid-19 pandemic on the black population, having as a trigger point the urgent need to analyze the asymmetries that the global health emergency produces, particularly in contexts of social inequality
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).
Main Results: 1. Studies on the population's demography and socioeconomic conditions show the social profile of the Brazilian population as mostly black, being strongly impacted by social deprivation, housing, sanitation, education, employment and income..2. These conditionalities accumulate and interrelate in a scenario of health crisis as in the case of the Covid-19 pandemic..3. Despite this context, the race/color item was not eligible for analysis of the Covid-19 epidemiological situation in the first epidemiological bulletins, even though it was included in the notification forms for Flu and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SRAG), both used as instruments for recording, monitoring and evaluating the suspected mild and severe cases of Covid-19, respectively, in the primary care network, in triage centers, in emergency care units and in the hospital network, as well as in the formSUs initially created for Covid-19 records..4. The incorporation of the issue of race/color as a category of analysis took place after positioning by the Racism and Health Working Group, the Black Coalition and the Brazilian Society of Family and Community Physicians..5. Despite this inclusion, the frequency of incompleteness of the race/color item in the different Covid-19 notification forms remains almost double those recorded..6. The same observation is made for Brazil when adopting the epidemiological bulletin referring to week 21 of the Covid-19 pandemic as a reference. It was evident that the number of confirmed cases with ignored race/color stratification totaled 51.3% (60,382) of the total of 117,598 confirmed cases. This represents more than half of confirmed cases whose race/color is unknown
Policy or intervention associate: Recomendações para reduzir impactos negativos da Covid-19 em grupos vulnerabilizados propostas pelo grupo de trabalho Racismo e Saúde da Abrasco, 2020
Conclusions: 1. No pandemic context, in the first place for the black population and the strengthening of the SUS (Sistema Único de Saúde)..2. The Covid-19 pandemic is revealing that popular groups that have been historically neglected, those with low protection or employment in the population with access to adequate health care, are among the most affected, especially those at the highest risk of death..3. The concentration of efforts to approach Covid-19 in medical-centered care measures, decontextualized not only in relation to people's way of living and falling ill, but also, with other knowledge, also corroborate the high rates of incidence and lethality of Covid-19, positioning Brazil in May 2020 as the epicenter of the pandemic worldwide..4. Above all, the response to the Covid-19 pandemic involves protecting lives and communities obviously at risk in our unequal society. Anything less is an insult to the tens of thousands of people who lost their lives in a pandemic that Brazil had the opportunity to anticipate, but did not.

author: L. P. Dos Santos et al. 2021
title: Trends and inequalities in food insecurity during the COVID-19 pandemic: Results of four serial epidemiological surveys
Objective(s): To analyze trends and inequalities in the prevalence of food insecurity during the COVID-19 pandemic according to sociodemographic factors and social distancing measures
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1.To test the association of food insecurity with demographic characteristics and social distance, the chi-square test was used, considering a 5% significance level and 95% confidence interval (95%CI)..2. The temporal trend analysis of the prevalence of food insecurity between May and June 2020, according to the sociodemographic characteristics and measures of social distancing analyzed, was performed using linear regression models..Formal analyzes of absolute and relative inequalities in the prevalence of food insecurity according to age, education and number of residents in the household were carried out complementary using the slope index of inequality (SII) and the concentration index (concentration index – CIX).
Type of social stratification: -Gender: Male/female.-Age (20-39, 40-59 and = 60 years).-Education: none/ Elementary School, High School or Higher Education.-Self-reported skin color (white, black or brown).-Number of residents per household (1-2, 3-4 and = 5 residents).-Presence of residents under 18 in the household: No/Yes.-Number of workers per household, capacity to meet the measures of social distancing guided by the authorities and the routine of activities in times of pandemic.
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Gender/sex.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Education
Main Results: 1. The prevalence of general food insecurity was 29.4% (95%CI: 25.0; 34.4), showing a percentage decrease between the beginning of May and the end of June, but with no significant difference in the trend analysis (p value = 0.069)..2. In all rounds of the survey, food insecurity tended to be higher among adults (20-39 and 40-59 years), among respondents with less education, black or brown, and those who lived in households with greater number of residents and in households with residents under 18 years of age (Table 2)..3. Analysis of temporal trends showed that, over time, the prevalence of food insecurity decreased more intensely among the youngest (20-39 years old) and among those who lived in households with at most two people.4. The prevalence of food insecurity was not statistically associated with the number of workers per household and the measures of social distancing adopted by the municipality. .5. Households that had two or more workers showed a sharper drop in the prevalence of this condition..6. A prevalência de insegurança alimentar também foi maior entre os indivíduos que relataram conseguir cumprir muito pouco as medidas de distanciamento social e naqueles que afirmaram sair todos os dias de casa durante a pandemia..7. In complementary analyzes of inequality, the prevalence of food insecurity was more concentrated among younger, less educated individuals who lived in households with a larger number of residents.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This study showed a strong association between food insecurity and the interviewees' sociodemographic aspects, showing a greater concentration of this problem in younger, less educated individuals who lived in households with five or more residents. .2. The results presented here suggest the potential impact of the pandemic on the food situation of households and may be useful in the development of policies and programs to combat food insecurity during and after the pandemic. .3. Such policies and programs are and will be extremely important to reduce the economic effects caused by the pandemic in the DHAA of the population of Bagé and of Brazil as a whole.

author: Ma et al. 2021

Conclusions: 1. It detected higher death rates among older adults, Black/Mixed patients, and those with lower schooling..2. It failed to find a statistically significant association between TDF use and survival in a multivariable analysis..3. These findings suggest that social vulnerabilities related to both HIV and COVID-19 significantly impact the risk of death. .4. People in lower socioeconomic status should be prioritized for prevention interventions in the context of HIV and COVID-19

author: R. Rocha et al. 2021
title: Effect of socioeconomic inequalities and vulnerabilities on health-system preparedness and response to COVID-19 in Brazil: a comprehensive analysis.
Objective(s): To examine the relationship between the availability of health-care resources in different parts of the country, the socioeconomic characteristics of the population (eg, income, housing, and employment status), risk factors for adverse COVID-19 outcomes (age and burden of chronic disease), and socioeconomic vulnerability, with the pattern of spread, response, and outcomes of the epidemic, as measured by the number of deaths by state and municipality
Sample size: NA (They used several publicly available data sources. The combination of these datasets allowed us to characterise the health, economic, and household characteristics of the Brazilian population specifically related to vulnerability to adverse outcomes with COVID-19)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive anaylysis and correlations. .2. Pearson coefficients for bilateral correlations between state-level indicators and COVID-19 deaths.3. Using linear regressions on a municipality-by-month dataset from February to October, 2020, to characterise the dynamics of COVID-19 deaths and response to the epidemic across municipalities..4. Spatial distribution of socioeconomic vulnerabilities
Type of social stratification: -Socioeconomic vulnerability: Socioeconomic vulnerability index / Housing vulnerability (%)/ Informal workers (%).-COVID-19 deaths per 100 000 people, age-adjusted.-Health vulnerability: Population with health risk factors (%)/ Population aged =60 years (%).-Pre-existing hospital services: SUS ICU beds per 100 000 people /Private ICU beds per 100 000 people /ICU physicians per 100 000 people.-Policy stringency index.-Increase in physical distancing adherence since February, 2020
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Place of residence.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. The standardised COVID-19 death rate was highest in the North region, where, according to the SVI (Socioeconomic Vulnerability Index), some of the most vulnerable states are located. .2. The number of ICU beds per capita was roughly twice as high in the South region as in the North region, not only in the private sector but also in the SUS (Sistema Único de Saúde)..3. The most vulnerable states in terms of SVI were also the ones where the SUS provided greater coverage of primary health-care services, in particular when measured by the share of the population covered by community health agents. These states also have greater coverage of the Bolsa Família programme..4. COVID-19 deaths were positively correlated with socioeconomic vulnerabilities and negatively associated with the level of hospital resources..5. Pre-existing hospital capacity is negatively correlated with SVI, housing vulnerability, and the share of informal workers, but positively correlated with health risk factors and age..6. The correlation between the policy stringency index and number of ICU beds was negative to June, 2020 (-0·07, p=0·73), but positive to October, 2020.
Policy or intervention associate: Bolsa Família programme, a conditional cash transfer programme for low-income families in Brazil, as a proxy for social assistance
Conclusions: 1. Pre-existing hospital resources, in particular ICU capacity, were positively correlated with vulnerabilities in population health..2. It observed negative correlations between pre-existing hospital capacity and vulnerability in terms of other socioeconomic markers, such as housing conditions and informality in the labour market..3. Despite the political turmoil and absence of overall coordination at the executive branch of the federal government, the most socioeconomically vulnerable states were able to expand hospital capacity and to enact stringent COVID-19-related legislation in an attempt to increase physical distancing. These measures were not sufficient to prevent the most socioeconomically vulnerable states from having higher COVID-19 death rates during the initial spread of the disease..4. Physical distancing behaviour was less evident in municipalities with stronger electoral support for the current political leadership, especially after public events and presidential speeches in which the leadership directly referred to and advised against it.. .
Funding sources: None: There was no funding source for this study.

author: Benítez et al. 2020
title: Responses to COVID-19 in five Latin American countries
Objective(s): To focus on the first months of the pandemic in five Latin American countries: Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru. It analyses how the pre-pandemic context, and the government’s responses to contain and mitigate the spread together with economic measures have affected the COVID-19 health outcomes.
Sample size: NA (Publicly-available epidemiological data and federal and state/regional policy documents)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities - Extensive qualitative documentary analysis
Type of social stratification: NA
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Place of residence.-Features of relationships (e.g. smoking parents, excluded from school)
Main Results: 1. Brazil has by far the largest population, followed by Colombia that has around a quarter of its population. Peru, Chile and Ecuador, in that order, are the ones with lower populations. The large population size may make it more difficult to ramp up the capacity of the health sector..2. Colombia and Eduador have the highest density..3. Poor access to sanitation infrastructure and clean water, in all countries except Chile..4. High level of informality is present in all five countries..5. Income inequality and access to basic social infrastructure, Chile is clearly an exception, with the highest Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita and considerably better development indicators, but with a relevant level of inequality, as all the other countries analyzed..6. Brazil is the only country with a national health system with comprehensive free access to healthcare services, while Chile, Ecuador and Peru have mixed systems in terms of health insurance (public and private). Colombia has a Social Health Insurance system, where individuals contribute a fixed amount of their incomes and have access to a defined health plan..7. The five Latin American countries have a younger population than the OECD, but Chile, Brazil and Colombia have a higher prevalence of obesity and diabetes..8. Brazil and Chile have also the highest incidence of cardiovascular diseases.9. In terms of smoking and alcohol consumption, the five countries perform better than OECD, except Chile with a very high prevalence of smoking..10. Excluding Brazil, all four countries closed schools, prohibited massive gatherings and, except for Colombia, implemented curfews..11. Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru aimed at containing the spread, while Chile's objective was to mitigate it (reducing the rate of contagion)..12. In the economic area, all countries have adopted policies to achieve mainly two objectives. First, to allow for compliance of the measures imposed, which is highly relevant for the health outcomes of the virus, and second, to minimize the negative effects of the containment and mitigation measures to the economy (at the macro and micro level)..13. All countries under analysis implemented the range of measures described, except for Ecuador which did not reduce the interest rate, impose tax reductions or support for informal workers..14. Peru the first country of the group to implement a national lockdown (7 days after the first confirmed case). In contrast, Brazil was the latest of the group to declare state of emergency and closing borders..15. All countries reduced interest rates at least one time (except for Ecuador), created special conditions for credit during the pandemic (for micro, SME and families), and established measures to protect labor at early stages..16. Considering the days after the first case was reported and the average date the measures were taken in each country, Colombia proved to be the fastest with an average of 16 days, almost half of the average of the rest of the countries.
Policy or intervention associate: 1. Mitigation and containment measures (State of emergency declared, Borders closigns, Lockdown, Local Lockdown centrally defined, National Curfew (night), School closing, Prohibition of mass gatherings, Flexibilization/reopening. .2. Health (Health alert/Emergency, Central coordination of health, Addtional health funds (on top of health sector budget), Massive testing, Extensive tracing/tacking..3. Economic (National interest rate reduction, Liquidity measures for families/enterprises, Tax relief, No disconnection from basic services, Income support, Labor protection, Food baskets, Informal workers support, Support for the vulnerable).
Conclusions: 1. All five countries adopted strict measures early on to contain the first wave of COVID-19, including lockdowns (national or focalized) and curfews. However, the effectiveness of the measures was undermined by the existing fragility of the health systems, which are characterized by insufficient investment in health resources, regional disparities, modest information systems and poor communication and coordination..2. The health systems have been overwhelmed in the first 100 days of the pandemic, with ICU beds reaching nearly 100% occupancy in some regions..3. This study highlighted the importance of early emergency preparedness and the need to improve the capacity of health systems to mitigate the spread of the virus..4. Among the countries analyzed, the only one that is presenting a constant decrease in COVID-19’s incidence is Chile, after the country applied strength mitigation and containment measures, an extensive strategy of tracing and tracking and a substantial improvement on economic support.

author: Casas and Palermo 2021
title: ¿El virus afecta “a todos (y a todas) por igual”? Una mirada crítica acerca del trabajo doméstico remunerado en Argentina en tiempos de pandemia por COVID-19
Journal: Revista Interdisciplinaria de Estudios de Género de El Colegio de México
Objective(s): To address the impact of the COVID-19 crisis in the paid employment sector in Argentina, with the Metropolitan of Buenos Aires (AMBA)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The 6.4% combined care activities with cleaning tasks, 6.9% only performed cleaning tasks and 0.9% other types of activities, considered non-essential. It means that the employers did not respect the right of the worker not to attend and get paid the same. Based on this, they were able to identify one of the strategies they used: the change of category of cleaning and general tasks workers —category 5— to category 4 of care and assistance..2. Caring for and assisting people is considered an essential activity, but the same - worse - conditions of precariousness and low wages continue to be maintained..3. Between five and six of every 10 workers — 55.9% — have worsened their employment situation since the Preventive and Compulsory Social Isolation (ASPO) was decreed..4. 3.6% suffered a dismissal, 20.2% their employers did not pay their salary, 13.1% had their salary reduced compared to the previous month, 7% did not know if they were going to pay their salary and 6.6% - workers in several homes - she stated that in some they paid her and in others they did not.
Policy or intervention associate: Preventive and Compulsory Social Isolation (ASPO)
Conclusions: 1. Negative impact on the working and living conditions of domestic workers. In other words, the pandemic has shed light on the inequalities and conditions of vulnerability that previously existed, deepening them..2. Changes in categories, decrease in working hours, decrease in salary, anger, including threats of all kinds.

author: Orellana et al. 2021
title: Excesso de mortes durante a pandemia de COVID-19: subnotificação e desigualdades regionais no Brasil
Objective(s): To estimate the excess deaths and their differences in adults 20 years and older in Manaus (Amazonas State), Fortaleza (Ceará State), Rio de Janeiro, and São Paulo, according to place of death, demographic characteristics, and trajectory over time
City or municipality: Manaus (Amazonas), Fortaleza (Ceará), Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo
Sample size: n=74,656 (data from the Mortality Information System and the Central Information Office of the National Civil Registry)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Estimates of expected deaths in 2020 were obtained through generalized additive quasi-Poisson model adjustments with correction for overdispersion. The variables age, sex, period of epidemiological week and the interaction of these variables with the year of occurrence were considered as predictors in the respective models for each city. The variable year of occurrence was non-parametrically adjusted (spline), in order to capture possible non-linear trends in mortality over the period evaluated..2. The estimate of excess mortality: descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: -Age.-Gender: Male/Female.-Occurrence of death at home or on public roads.-Observed and expected natural deaths, excess of natural deaths, specific mortality by COVID-19, Epidemiological Weeks and year/calendar.
Main Results: 1. In Manaus and São Paulo, there was a number of deaths from natural deaths about 3% and 2% higher than in the civil registry, respectively. In Fortaleza, this difference was less than 0.5% and in Rio de Janeiro the number of deaths was 1% higher in the Mortality Information System.2. Between February 23 and June 13, 2020, 74,656 natural deaths were recorded, 32,338 in São Paulo, 26,236 in Rio de Janeiro, 9,784 in Fortaleza and 6,298 in Manaus..3. Based on the predicted values for 2020, 51,422 deaths would be expected, resulting in an excess of deaths of 45% (95%CI: 44-47). The greatest excess of deaths occurred in Manaus, 112% (95%CI: 103-121), followed by Fortaleza, 72% (95%CI: 67-78), Rio de Janeiro, 42% (95%CI: 40-45) and São Paulo, 34% (95%CI: 32-36)..4. The excess of deaths, in relative terms, was similar between the age groups, except for São Paulo, and significantly higher in males, regardless of the city (Table 1)..5. It is noteworthy that the excess of deaths was lower in Epidemiological Weeks (SE) 9-12 in all cities, with the exception of São Paulo, where observed deaths exceed by 11% (95%CI: 7-15) the expected deaths , probably because of the higher mortality among men aged 20 to 59 years..6. The greatest excesses of mortality occurred in SE 17-20, with more expressive values in Manaus, Fortaleza and Rio de Janeiro, respectively, 296% (95%CI: 266-329), 172% (95%CI: 156-189) and 103% (95%CI: 96-110) (Table 1)..7. In SE 21-24, after the peak in SE 17-20, Manaus and Rio de Janeiro showed the sharpest drops in excess deaths compared to Fortaleza and São Paulo..8. Over SE 9 to 24, the excess of deaths not directly explained by COVID-19 was higher in Manaus, 111% (95%CI: 99-124), followed by Fortaleza 52% (95%CI: 45-59) , Rio de Janeiro 50% (95%CI: 44-55) and São Paulo 47% (95%CI: 43-53)..9. With regard to the occurrence of deaths in households and on public roads, also along SE 9 to 24, Manaus stands out with 96% (95%CI: 79-114) of excess mortality in homes or on public roads, followed by Fortaleza with 62% (95%CI: 51-74), Rio de Janeiro with 54% (95%CI: 46-62) and São Paulo with 32% (95%CI: 26-38).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The high percentage of excess deaths and deaths outside the hospital, as well as the possibility of significant underreporting of mortality by COVID-19 in the four cities in the first four months of the epidemic in Brazil, reinforce the extensive dispersion of SARS-CoV-2 in the country and the failure of public policies to confront it..2. Draws attention to the need for studies aimed at reviewing all causes of deaths associated with respiratory symptoms by epidemiological surveillance services, especially in the first months of the pandemic..3. Excess mortality is an extremely important indicator for monitoring and setting priorities by decision makers, especially in developing countries, where the difficulties in properly diagnosing and coping with the disease are well known.

author: R. Soares and Naegele 2021
title: Segregação vertical na área da química durante a pandemia de covid-19 no Brasil
Objective(s): To analyze and generate reflection on the relationships of gender in S&T, with special focus on the area of Chemistry, and offer visibility in its production and dissemination during the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive analysis.2. The qualitative approach presents greater theoretical methodological freedom

Main Results: 1) The Institute of Chemistry of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (IQ--UFRJ) no longer has a symmetrical and parity relationship between the number of male and female teachers: the total community consists of 156 teachers, being 53% men and 47% women, respectively .2) Small male dominance (6%) has been identified in IQ- -UFRJ, the Chemistry as a specific discipline of science has achieved significant recent achievements for women in early stages of their academic careers..3) Comparing the distribution of teaching qualifications by gender: teachers who have only the Master’s degrees been practically non-existent (< 3%). The distribution is almost equal among the academics who have a PhD (47%) and those who obtain the certification of post-doctorate (50%). most male professionals.5) (˜ 60%) are between those bearing the certification and representative status of a post-doctorate (Figure 1)..6) Male teachers have 50% to more professionals, when compared to teachers with only the master’s degree, this fraction is also practically null in this gender (< 4%).7) Except for the Department of Analytical Chemistry, male teachers predominate numerically in degree of qualification, when compared with the respective teachers, possessing or more Post-doctoral certifications or more PhD degrees in an interdepartmental analysis8) the higher the level of the PRODUCTIVITY FELLOWSHIPS (PQ) bag in the Chemicals area, the lower the corresponding fraction of women who own it
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1) Quantitative disparity (6%) regarding gender..2) Men have 16% more in the number of individuals when considering only the most important positions in the teaching career at IQ-UFRJ (Top 4), thus obtaining greater renown and professional status, .3) (...) this disparity (...) may become even worse in because of the COVID-19 pandemic and which may bring discouragement to future generations women in chemistry who wish to persist in the academic area or to gain positions in leadership and prestige..4) The total number of IQ-UFRJ FP grants approximately 65% belongs to male teachers..5) Only individuals holding the most valuable PQ grants (PQ-1A and PQ – 1B) in which exactly 2/3 are held by male teachers..6) IQ-UFRJ can assume the role of national protagonist and stop reiterating stereotypes through subjects’ attitudes who take over the management and other formal power spaces,

author: Hebert Luan Pereira Campos dos Santos et al. 2020

Journal: Revista Ciência & Saúde Coletiva da Associação Brasileira de Saúde Coletiva

Regarding mild COVID-19 cases, in the state of Pernambuco, 60,5% of patients were black (non-white) while in the state of Rio Grande do Norte, 39% of patients were black (non-white)..2. Alagoas and Pernambuco informed that 66,5% and 77,7%, respectively, of all confirmed SARS (from COVID-19) patients were black..3. Race/color data is a valuable tool for developing racial inequality indicators during the pandemic. Access to tests has been a privilege (and not a right), and the numbers point to greater morbimortality in the black population

author: Pontes et al. 2021
title: Increased vulnerability to SARS-CoV-2 infection among indigenous people living in the urban area of Manaus.
Objective(s): To assess the magnitude of the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and its transmission risk factors among the biggest multiethnic urban indigenous community located on the west side of Manaus, Amazonas state, Brazil.
Sample size: n=280 Indigenous residents in the community of Parque das Tribos (the biggest multiethnic urban indigenous community in Manaus), between October 10 and November 14, 2020
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive statistical analysis was used to evaluate the sociodemographic variables and serum levels of SARS-Cov-2 antibodies observed in the study population..2. The prevalence rates were estimated based on the positivity for anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgG. .3. Multivariate analysis using logistic regression was performed to assess the relationship between sociodemographic characteristics and IgG positivity to SARS-CoV-2 infection..4. The odds ratio (OR) analysis was performed on the following variables: genders, age, marital status, level of schooling, housing type, COVID-19 information sources and frequency of leaving the home. .5. One-way ANOVA and a Tukey post hoc test were used to compare serum levels of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies (optical density values) among age ranges..6. The efect of household crowding on the risk of exposure to infection was evaluated through OR analysis and Fisher’s exact test.
Type of social stratification: -Age.-Gender: Male/Female.-Level of schooling: Up to middle school /Middle school completed /High school incomplete/ High school completed / In higher education
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Socioeconomic status .-Education.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. A total of 181 individuals (64.64%; 95% CI 59.01–70.28) were positive for SARS-CoV-2 .2. The positivity rates for IgA were 60.71% (95% CI 54.98–66.45) and IgG were 55.71% (95% CI 49.89–61.54) observed in the study population .3. Mild or moderate COVID-19-related symptoms were present in 107 individuals (59.11%) who were positive for SARS-CoV-2. Te most common symptoms were headache, fever, body aches, loss of taste or smell and/or joint pain (see Figure 3A)..4. The total positivity rates were similar between women and men (p=0.207) and no signifcant diferences between age groups were observed (see Table 1)..5. The level of education of the study population was considered low. Only 29.7% of the study population had received a high school diploma (see Table 1). .6. The level of social isolation was directly related to the increased risk of infection. People who declared leaving the home 2–4 times a week were more susceptible to infection (95% CI 1.00–1.49; p=0.044) (see Table 1)..7. These findings demonstrate that the higher the number of individuals per house the higher the susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection..8. The highest prevalence (64.77%) was observed among individuals living with fve or more people..9. The level of purchasing power of the study population was very low. Over 83% of individuals earn up to one minimum wage (approximately USD 192 dollars in Brazil), which hampers efective access to adequate nutrition and healthcare assistance (see Figure 5A)..10. The majority of the study population (90%) declared using traditional medicine to treat or prevent COVID-19 and other infectious diseases. .11. Most of the individuals (>60%) declared that they partially trust the ofcial Brazilian government COVID-19-related information.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This study indicates that indigenous peoples living in urban areas are being dramatically afected by SARS-CoV-2, especially because of their poor socioeconomic conditions and lack of access to adequate health assistance..2. They need coordinated national actions that prioritize ethnic vulnerable groups in the battle against COVID-19. .3. They need public policies that promote health, adequate housing and sanitation for these populations. Otherwise, indigenous people living in urban areas are doomed to sufer at unprecedented levels during the current pandemic..4. About 90% of the study population reported using medicinal plants or herbs to treat or prevent SARS-CoV infection. The use of medicinal herbs is an important part of indigenous culture and must be respected..5. This data showed that most of the individuals partially trust the information coming from the Brazilian government..6. These findings demonstrated that individuals living in households with six or more people had an almost fivefold increase in risk. Tis situation is worsened by poor-quality housing..7. They observed that the individuals of the study population who lef home more ofen (2–4 times a week) had an increased infection risk. The main reasons for leaving home were either to work or to buy food..8. The positivity rate for anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgA Abs found in this study was 55%. A high IgA ratio was detectable in almost 90% of individuals after more than four weeks of the onset of their symptoms. All individuals with symptoms on the day of blood collection were positive for both IgA and IgG.
Funding sources: Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior—Brasil (CAPES) under Finance code PROCAD AMAZÔNIA 88881.200581/201801, Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado do Amazonas (FAPEAM-Pró-Estado Program) and Rede Corona-ômica BR MCTI/FINEP afliated to RedeVírus/MCTI (FINEP=01.20.0029.000462/20, CNPq=404096/2020-4)

author: Boschiero et al. 2021
title: One Year of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Brazil: A Political and Social Overview.
Objective(s): To provide an overview of the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic, in Brazil, from a social and political point of view, and to discuss the perspectives from now on.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Among the federation states, Paulo, which has both the largest population and highest population density, accounted for the highest number of reported cases, while Rio de Janeiro had the highest lethality rate..2. The indigenous population can be more vulnerable to the pandemic’s impact, given their poor social and economic conditions and poor access to health care services..3. Other ethnic groups in Brazil should be looked at more carefully, as there is evidence of increased mortality in Pardo and Black individuals, and individuals who live in the North region as a whole..4. Disparity between patients with COVID-19 treated in public and private health systems..5. The main consequence of these disparities in a pandemic setting is that the occupation of ICU beds is lower in private health care units than in the public ones, yielding several idle beds. Solving this issue becomes more difficult in Brazil, as most states in the country do not inform the data about the occupation of ICU beds in the private setting. In some cases, such as the states of Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, the data concerning public and private networks are merged..6. The lack of a well-set testing policy, along with the slow distribution of tests across the country makes COVID-19 very difficult to be handled in Brazil..7. The criticisms of the scientific community did not stop President Jair Messias Bolsonaro from promoting the use of hydroxychloroquine for COVID-19 treatment. In the State of Rio de Janeiro, the drug started to lack in the stocks of pharmacies, after an uncontrolled search by people..8. Brazil has a large territory and is marked by social contrasts among different regions and states, which showed contrasting data regarding the impact caused by COVID-19.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Factors associated with this failure: the low availability of SARS CoV-2 RT-PCR tests, lack of efficient health policies, political instability (especially in the Ministry of Health), use of knowingly inefficient treatment approaches, lack of special attention for the most susceptible populations, lack of accessibility to health care facilities, high treatment costs, and, most important, the sabotaging attitudes by President Jair Messias Bolsonaro during the pandemic, which is not at all expected from authority and to which an important part in the country’s current situation can be credited. .2. Brazil is maybe the best example of what not to do during a pandemic and indicates a need for a suitable government that can base its health policies on science and not personal political issues or guesswork.

author: Lopes 2021
title: Ausência de raça e gênero no enfrentamento da pandemia no Brasil
Journal: Revista Eletrônica de Comunicação, Informação & Inovação em Saúde
Objective(s): NA
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Blacks (blacks and browns) account for 56.4% of the Brazilian population, and black women constitute the most vulnerable group. They account for 28% of this population, but they are over-represented in poverty, corresponding to 32.8%, and 9.1% of Brazilians live in extreme poverty.2. At the onset of the pandemic, data on cases of virus infection and disease deaths were released without color/race specification..3. The federal government's failure to provide guidance to federation entities has resulted in little collection and insufficient processing of statistics on race/color and gender, as shown by the survey, carried out in April 2021, in epidemiological bulletins published in all 26 states of the federation and in the Federal District..4. Most states (17) do not disclose information on ethnic-racial membership in the daily epidemiological bulletins. .5. If these data are disaggregated by region, we have the South as the most silent in this regard, since none of its three states bring statistics. On the opposite side appears the North Region, where four of the six states present race in the data communication. In the Northeast, only three of the nine states do so; in the Southeast, two states..6. In June 2020, it can be seen that the number of states that started to incorporate race in the collection and dissemination of data on Covid-19 has doubled. From five in 2020, it became 10 states in the following year..7. When looking at the collection of data disaggregated by gender and ethnic-racial membership, we have 15% of the states that disclose this information, that is, only four of the 27 units of the federation. They are: Amazonas, Acre, Roraima and Espírito Santo. As well as in the production of statistics on color/race, the North Region also appears in data collection by sex as the most representative, as three out of six states in the region specify them..8. It is important to highlight how blacks and black women figured as the first people to be immunized in most states. In three states (São Paulo, Minas Gerais and Espírito Santos), the strategy adopted places the governors, white men, alongside black women.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This process as a game, in which white and male institutions have the power to appropriate race and gender with the intention of showing themselves to be diverse, less racist and sexist, valuing black women..2. Racial and gender identities are used to acquire political and social visibility without, however, leading to measures to confront racism and promote equality in this time of health crisis..3. Although states and municipalities have autonomy in managing the pandemic, the federal government has a central role in managing the measures and in guiding federated entities – which fails, above all, in dealing with the racial and gender issue.

author: T. D. Silva and Silva 2021
title: Trabalho, população negra e pandemia: notas sobre os primeiros resultados da PNAD Covid-19
Objective(s): To present a brief description of the conditions of the Brazilian labor market before the effects of the pandemic; during the pandemic and their differences in racial terms
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. By the end of May 2020, the total employed population had already decreased by around 7 million people, compared to the same period of the previous year, and, in the accumulated result for the year up to this period, there was already a negative balance of more 1.1 million formal jobs..2. The estimated unemployment rate rose from 11.8% to 12.8% between February and May 2020, and was only not higher due to the substantial drop in the labor force participation rate (from 62% to 56%) in the same period, mainly due to the portion of the population without a job that stopped seeking relocation due to the necessary measures of sanitary prevention..3. Estimates point to an absolute fall in employment of around 9.9 million between February and May 2020, in addition to an increase in the depressed population (+1.2 million) and a drop in those employed with social security contributions (-3.3 millions). As a result, the mass of income effectively received decreased by R$37 billion, down 16.5%..4. The first data from PNAD Covid-19 already indicated that 5.2% of Brazilian households (about 3.5 million) survived in the month of May only with the income received from emergency aid from the federal government, moving the following month to 6.5%, 4.5 million households.5. Practically all economic sectors registered a decline in employment compared to the same period of the previous year, with the most affected being: commerce, civil construction, food and accommodation, in addition to the category of domestic services, strongly marked by informal ties ..6. The only sectors that did not suffer a retraction were: agriculture, services for companies (information, communication and financial, real estate, professional and administrative activities) and public administration.7. According to data from PNAD Covid-19, people who declared themselves black and brown corresponded, in June 2020, to 54.9% of the workforce,3 being 52.5% of the employed4 and 60.3% of the unemployed this month of reference. During the first months of the pandemic in the country, the unemployment rate grew for all groups of color or race, with a general average going from 10.7% to 13.1% between May and July. Considering only the black population – men and women – this increase was even higher: it went from 10.7% and 13.8% to, respectively, 12.7% and 17.6% (Table 1)..8. The effects of these measures on economic activity led several companies to reduce their productive activities, or even close them, reducing the demand for work or even taking advantage of government initiatives to temporarily suspend employment contracts..9. the black population, which corresponded to 52.3% of the employed, represented 58.4% of those temporarily on leave in May. This overrepresentation is also verified in the following months. The distancing was more intense for the group of black women. Despite corresponding to 21.5% of the total employed, they represented 30.9% of people temporarily away from work. As shown in table 2, although the percentage of absences decreased in the following months, the group of black women, in particular, remained as the most affected by absence from work..10. Occupations with weaker ties were the most affected by social distancing. While employees without a formal contract in the private sector and self-employed accounted for 9.6% and 29.0% of those employed, they were, respectively, 11.8% and 35.0% of those on leave due to social distance..11. Black women workers were the ones who had the greatest reduction in working hours, with consequent repercussions on earnings, the data also show that, even among professionals with higher education, black women were the only ones who spent less than a workload. 70% of usual. (Graphic 1).12. More than 8.7 million workers continued to work remotely, corresponding to 10.3% of those employed in May, with a reduction in this rate in the following months. Remote work was the reality for 17.6% of employed (not on leave) whites and for only 9% of blacks in this situation (Table 3). Only about a third of the total number of workers employed in remote activities were black workers..13. As shown in table 4, in July, 36.9% of the population over 14 years old out of the labor force (inactive), about 28 million people, was in a situation of discouragement. Of this set, about two thirds (65.3%) corresponded to black individuals. It is noteworthy that 67.0% of the total discouraged attribute this condition to the pandemic, which we call in this text discouraged by the pandemic.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The multiple and intersectional inequalities that weigh on the black population have been intense and aggravated during this time of pandemic..2. In addition to paying attention to the direct effects of health conditions and access to medical care, the prospects for subsistence and labor insertion are essential to, at least, not allow for the expansion of racial inequalities, which are so striking and structuring in the country..3. They formed the vast majority of the labor capacity subject to the situation of hidden unemployment due to despondency, largely justified by the impossibility of seeking employment during the pandemic..4. In the absence (or insufficiency) of social safety nets, the horizon becomes more than worrisome..5. In addition to policies to guarantee employment and encourage productive activity, especially in labor-intensive sectors, the expansion and strengthening of social and labor protection networks are fundamental measures in order to prevent the current effects of the crisis lead to the intensification of the already expressive level of racial inequality existing in the labor market

author: Cotrim Junior and Cabral 2020
title: Crescimento dos leitos de UTI no país durante a pandemia de Covid-19: desigualdades entre o público x privado e iniquidades regionais
Journal: Revista Ciência & Saúde Coletiva da Associação Brasileira de Saúde Coletiva
Objective(s): To investigate the expansion of ICU beds in different regions of Brazil
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The Southeast Region concentrates (51.9%) of the national ICU beds, while the North (5.2%) and Central-West (8.5%) regions do not reach 10% of the total beds..2. There was a jump in the number of beds in the country, from 46,045 in December 2019 (pre-pandemic moment) to 60,265 (post-pandemic) in April 2020. In other words, in approximately four months, there was an increase in 14,220 beds, which represents a total increase of 23.59%, and which is quite significant..3. 3,104 are from the Health Unic System, that is, available to the entire population, including those with a private health plan. This timid advance of the Health Unic System represents only 21.82% of new ICU beds..4. With its growth, the private sector managed to install over 11,116 beds, which represented 78.18% of new intensive care beds across the country, expressing unprecedented inequality in the recent history of the country, that is, since the implementation of the Health Unic System ..5. With the pandemic, the numbers were very inverted and the country had an offer of 26,153 public beds compared to 34,112 private ICU beds, resulting in a difference of 7,959, very different from the old 53 beds, the largest in the public sector..6. A country in which only 22.41% of the population has a private plan, representing a total of 47,084,565 people, and the other 77.59% (or 163,062,560 people) depend exclusively on the SUS..7. In the North Region (8.77% of the national population), 90.72% are exclusively dependent on the Health Unic System, and they dispute 1,793 SUS ICU beds, which means that there is approximately one SUS bed for every 9,325 people. Also in this region, it can be seen that 9.28% of the population have health insurance and dispute 1,335 beds, resulting in an approximate proportion of one bed for every 1,281 people..8. In the Northeast Region, (27.15% of the country's population). Of these, 88.43% depend solely on the SUS, competing for 5,968 beds, making up the approximate proportion of one bed for every 8,456 people. As for the beneficiaries of health plans, it is noted that they are 11.57% of the population in this region competing for 6,512 ICU beds, which results in approximately the proportion of one bed for every 1,013 people.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Public regulation of beds (single-line) seems to be a measure of justice that urgently needs to be implemented, unless it is validated, once again, that some lives are more important than others.2. Regional differences in bed supply, rather than being an argument against bed unification, is actually an argument in favor.3. 77.59% of the Brazilian population depends exclusively on the SUS, but they only have 26,153 beds spread across the country, while the situation of beneficiaries of health plans is absurdly more comfortable (in relation to the supply of ICU beds, it is clear).4. Despite a little more than three quarters of the population being dependent on Health Unic System, the great expansion of intensive beds occurred in the private sector, making up, until April 2020, 78.18% of the national growth, while the increase of SUS beds resulted in a timid 21.82% of the total growth..5. This, in turn, contrasts with the desires and speeches of sanitarists, that the Health Unic System is getting stronger in the pandemic, which certainly occurs within the scope of society's perception, but from the concrete point of view, of improvements in the system, as the expansion of the ICUs, an exponential growth of the supplementary sector can be seen.

author: Ferraz et al. 2021
title: COVID Health Structure Index: The Vulnerability of Brazilian Microregions
Objective(s): To create a COVID Index to verify whether the hospital structures in 543 Brazilian microregions are adequate to deal with COVID-19 and to verify whether public policies were implemented in the right direction.
Sample size: These databases capture information from 2,748 municipalities and represent 86.92% of all inhabitants of Brazil in 2020. The municipalities are divided into 543 microregions (Data from seven variables of the official databases from April 16 to May 8, 2020)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Mathematical method based on linear programming: analyzing the coronavirus pandemic in Brazil using a two-stage model.
Type of social stratification: Hospital structure - Five variables: Healthcare equipment (respirators, intensive care units (ICUs) and hospital beds) and human capital (physicians and nurses).
Main Results: 1. Analyzing the 543 microregions in Brazil, these findings reveal that, in April, 20 microregions (3.68%) presented the worst COVID Index (1.0)..2. Southeast region and Sao Paulo state were considered the epicenter of the pandemic, 60% of the regions classified as experiencing an inadequate situation were concentrated in Brazil’s North or Northeast because of the inadequate hospital infrastructure of these poor regions, where the health system struggles with a lack of resources and professionals..3. 26 microregions (4.78%) presented the worst performance in terms of the COVID Index. These microregions were concentrated in the North (46.15%) and Northeast (39.62%). 60% of the regions with the 20 best COVID Index performance scores (0.0 to 0.25) were concentrated in the South, Southeast and Midwest of Brazil.
Policy or intervention associate: 1. The Federal Government’s actions were limited to distributing financial resources, respirators and other materials to hospitals in several regions, especially in urban centers..2. Federal Program to Combat Coronavirus (Programa Federativo de Enfrentamento ao Coronavírus) created by the Federal Government allocated the fixed amount of 60 billion Reais (R$) [U$11,353 billion] from the Federal Government to states and municipalities.3. According to the law, authorities can spend R$ 50 billion [U$ 9,461 billion] on several economic purposes. Authorities are obligated to spend R$ 10 billion [U$ 1,892 billion] on health assistance. However, only R$ 2.8 billion [U$ 529 million] were destinated taking into account the number of people infected by coronavirus.
Conclusions: 1. These findings reveal the inequality of hospital infrastructure across the Brazilian microregions, which follows the patterns of economic and social discrepancies in Brazil..2. The COVID Index reveals that microregions in the North and Northeast of Brazil need more attention from policymakers.3. The metafrontier shows that the Brazilian situation became worse from April to May 2020.4. Through the COVID Index, policymakers have straightforward information to decide which regions must receive new investments, hire health professionals, and reallocate resources
Funding sources: None: Open Access funding enabled and organized by Projekt DEAL. There is no funding

author: Mancini 2021
title: Confinement risks and social inequality in Latin America: Evidence from Argentina
Objective(s): To investigate, from the sociological approach of risk-taking, the relationship between confinement, secondary risks and social inequality.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The first group contains people of low social origins or belonging to the working class (Their jobs do not allow them to work from home; this is the group that performs the most essential services). The second group comprises the typical Argentinian middle class. The third group is made up mainly of the upper-middle class..2. Everybody is confined (to the extent that it is mandatory), but not everybody is confined under the same conditions..3. Seven large groups of secondary and experiential risks produced by the confinement have been identified in the analysis: .a. The first group is comprised of subjective or emotional risks. The second group comprises what I have identified as temporal risks (social jet lag), namely, sensations and perceptions linked to the loss of social orientation of time during the lockdown. The third group is that of material risks, that is, the material or socioeconomic effects of the lockdown.The fourth group is comprised of health risks, those directly linked to the physical health of confined people, as well as the subjective probabilities of getting infected or being hospitalised. The fifth group is formed by the so-called voluntary risks (They are perceptions that relate confinement to willingness).The sixth group is about moral and normative risks, related to the collective duty of.complying with the confinement. the seventh group is comprised of symbolic and political risks.4. Subjective/emotional and health risks are mainly associated with women, salaried employees who are able to work from home during confinement (but without separate rooms to do so) and middle-class individuals who live in apartments and are between 30 and 49 years old..5. The symbolic/political, temporal and material risks are mainly associated with people between 50 and 69 years old, who have private health insurance, belong to the upper-middle or upper class, are part of nuclear families and are mainly men..6. Voluntary and moral/normative risks are associated with the working and lower classes, between 18 and 29 years old, who do not have access to social security, work in essential jobs and live in extended households..7. The middle and upper classes have increased their cultural consumption during the lockdown (movies, plays, and even operas using digital platforms).While , the cultural consumption of the lower classes has declined..8. Those of a higher social class increased their participation in workshops and online courses (cooking, arts, yoga); the lower classes decreased their participation..9. The ‘family climate’ varies according to socioeconomic status: whereas the upper classes were found to have a very good climate during the quarantine, among the lower classes (where unemployment and overcrowding are higher), family climate was more conflictive..10. Most distinctively upper-class behaviours are associated with men. Women, by contrast, shop less and take fewer courses.11. Women are more afraid of contagion (particularly their own contagion or that of their families) and fear the collapse of the health system.  12. People from the middle and working classes, who receive a regular salary, are less than 70 years old, with middle incomes and social security. This group identifies itself with a centre-left or left-wing ideology; strongly approves the mandatory measures adopted by the government and its performance with regard to the pandemic (it should be remembered that the Argentinian government is left-leaning)..13. Among the upper classes, where a right-wing or centre-right ideology predominates, the evaluation of governmental performance is highly critical..14. The social group comprised of unemployed or inactive individuals who belong to the lower classes and do not have social security. This group stays away from political ideology, from evaluating the government or measures of social control..
Policy or intervention associate: On 19 March 2020, the Argentinian government declared ‘mandatory preventive social isolation’, which prohibited free movement of people throughout the national territory; only minimum and indispensable trips to get medicine and food were allowed. Essential workers or those who needed to go out for emergency reasons (such as visiting the doctor or assisting older adults) were required to have a special permit; otherwise, severe economic fines would be applied.
Conclusions: 1. This main finding is that inequality and social class differences mediate the relationship between secondary risks and confinement. Subjective and emotional risks are the most prevalent across different social strata..2. It also found a relationship between political ideology, perceptions about government performance and attitudes towards communitarian social control.
Funding sources: None: The author received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article

author: Barton, Gutiérrez-Antinopai, and Ulloa 2021
title: Adaptive capacity as local sustainable development: Contextualizing and comparing risks and resilience in two chilean regions
Objective(s): To consider the underlying conditions that shape regional resilience in Chile, based on inter-regional and intra-regional comparisons in the Metropolitan Region of Santiago and the Region of Araucanía.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis (Municipal level data on poverty, health, and public finances in the two regions)
Type of social stratification: -Perceptions of natural hazards .-Socio-economic conditions: relevant regional development dimensions of differentiation in Chile: (rural–urban/ indigenous/non-indigenous.).-Poverty.-AVPP (Years of potential life lost).-Infant mortality.-Municipality spending Covid—Infected / death
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Place of residence.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage
Main Results: 1. Resilience to the pandemic, the advantages of more rural locations due to reduced contact compared with high-density living and public transport systems.2. The pandemic created a divide in terms of adaptive capacities,  the impact of the earthquake, and subsequent tsunami and aftershocks, extended fro between those who could work from home, and those who had no option other than to work.3. In the RMS, infections were concentrated in urban areas, In Araucanía,  most affected areas have been municipalities with a high concentration of rural  areas. .4. Pandemic aggravated existing inequalities in terms of the division between public sector  care and private-sector care, and the concentration of the latter in the largest regional  centers.5. Impacts to be more severely felt in lower income, health and access to educational opportunities, and financial support from public sector agencies such as  local governments, communities, where indigenous peoples are overly represented
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. A focus on system dynamics is useful only in terms of how the agency of development, i.e., governance, shapes these multi-scalar systems in terms of localities and regions..2. Communities manage risks synergistically, according to different time horizons, priorities, and available resources. Some  appear with little or no awareness or preparation, as in the case of Covid-19..3. Northwestern area of the region has been the most affected from a material point of view, as well as from the pandemic; this appears to be linked to the availability of both household and public institution resources. .4. Although there are trends that exhibit health fragilities due to multidimensional poverty, there are factors that require further research at the community level.

author: Funk 2021
title: Challenges for higher education in times of COVID-19: How three countries have responded
Objective(s): To offers a review of some of these challenges and their implication for long-term education policy, touching on the cases of Chile, Canada, and the United States.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Chile and the United States both share higher education systems that combine public and private colleges, although in Chile private universities, by law, must be non-profit. The Canadian higher education system is, with few exceptions, essentially a public system..2. The pandemic has affected higher education financing in several ways. The most obvious, perhaps, is how travel restrictions have impacted the ability of students to travel and study abroad. Funding structures are also important..3. Governments are trying to adjust. It suspended payments on federal (Department of Education) student loans and stopped collection on defaulted loans..4. Governments around the world have offered a series of programs and support for the logistics of higher education in times of COVID-19..5. Geography—as the physical expression of social inequality in a socially segregated society—also matters. COVID-19 was still most prevalent among higher-income residents of Santiago (Chile)..
Policy or intervention associate: Canada Emergency Student Benefit, which in 2020 offered CDN 1,250 every four weeks for a maximum of 16 weeks.
Conclusions: 1. It should perhaps not be surprising that, despite different political systems and educational structures, the needs and problems faced by higher education globally during the pandemic seem to be similar..2. Inequality and poverty also impact students in less obvious ways, such as the capacity to find adequate spaces for learning, food, and income support for students who may no longer have access to part-time employment.

author: Pinheiro et al. 2020
title: Regional and social inequalities related to covid-19 mortality in Brazil
Journal: Revista brasileira de gestão e desenvolvimento regional
Objective(s): To identify the relationship between regional characteristics and epidemiological and social factors and Covid-19 mortality in Brazil.
Sample size: n=41,200 (Data from  the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics (2019 up to August 2020) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Database including information on Covid-19 at the Open DataSUS portal (on September 9, 2020))
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Using descriptive analysis and logistic regression
Type of social stratification: -Age.-Gender: Male/Female.-Race: White/Black.-Education level: illiterate/ primary education/ secondary education/ higher education.-Mortality.-Otros: diabetic, obesity, vaccinated, region, ventilators per 100.000 inhabitants, SUS doctors per 100.000 inhabitants, SUS ICU beds per 100.000 habitants.
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Education.-Place of residence.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Gender/sex.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1. It reflects the overall increase in ICU beds across the country (51.31%). North (69.54%) and Northeast (63.15%), the disparities persist because there was also an increase in the Southeast (45.41%), South (47.49%) and Center -West (55.95%) regions, where the number of SUS and non-SUS ICU beds increased from 24,313 (53.08%) in August 2019 to 35,353 (77.19%)..2. Infection and mortality rates were higher among men than in women and in blacks than in whites. People with only primary or secondary education accounted for the largest number of cases of infection and deaths (32,755 or 79.5% and 14,250 or 34.6%, respectively). The rate of hospitalization and mortality was greater in individuals with diabetes and obesity. Infection and mortality rates showed disparities across regions..3. The probability of death from Covid-19 was greater among men than in women, with the odds ratio indicating that men had a 34% greater chance of dying than women when the other variables were maintained constant..4. Black people had a 16% greater chance of mortality than whites. Lower in individuals with a higher education level, while increasing age indicated a greater probability death..5. Patients with diabetes had a 17% greater chance of dying, while obese individuals had a 69% greater chance..6. Probability of death was greatest in the North (86%) and Northeast (74%) regions and lowest in the South region..7. Having ventilators and ICU beds was shown to have a significant association on with mortality.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. In short, the variables man, black, obese, diabetic, older age, lower level of education, and living in poorer regions of the country showed greater probability of death from Covid -19. On the other hand, being vaccinated, having access to mechanical ventilators and ICU beds, a higher level of education, and living in the South region was associated with a reduction in probability of death..2. These findings provide strong evidence that regional inequalities tend to have an impact on Covid-19 mortality among hospitalized patients, despite the existence of other actors that play a role in the health of these individuals..3. These findings suggest that the historical neglect of health care in Brazil resulting from fiscal federalism, which is incapable of reducing regional inequalities, is aggravating Covid -19 mortality.

author: Oreskovic 2020
title: Violations of independence: ethnicity and COVID-19 in Brazil
Objective(s): NA
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Mixed-effects Cox regression survival analysis to estimate the effects of ethnicity while allowing the baseline hazard function to vary by state.
Type of social stratification: Race: White/Pardo/Black
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. Mortality was significantly higher in Pardo (mixed ethnicity) and Black Brazilians than in White Brazilians (hazard ratio [HR] 1·45, 95% CI 1·33–1·58 for Pardo Brazilians; 1·32, 1·15–1·52 for Black Brazilians)..2. Using public data and code provided by the authors, I re-ran the model to incorporate hospitals within states, which altered the findings: .2a. The HR for Pardo Brazilians decreased from 1·45 to 1·28 (95% CI 1·17–1·41) and the HR for Black Brazilians decreased from 1·32 to 1·12 (0·96–1·30), making the HR no longer statistically significant.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Baqui and colleagues’ model should also have incorporated hospitals within those states as sources of variation and dependence between patients, which would have reflected the hierarchical nature of the data more accurately..2. These two HRs were outside the 95% CIs of the original estimates. The differences were substantial in size and uncertainty, regardless of the excessive focus on statistical significance in quantitative research..3. Although incorporating hospitals into the mixed-effects model yielded smaller HRs for Black and Pardo Brazilians, these HRs remained higher than those for White Brazilians..4. Differences in the quality of care across hospitals are also related to the ethnicity of patients, which calls for additional work.

author: Almeida, Lüchmann, and Martelli 2020
title: The pandemic and its impacts in Brazil
Journal: Middle Atlantic Review of Latin American Studies
Objective(s): NA
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The first fatal victim of Covid-19 in Rio de Janeiro was a 63-year-old domestic worker, a professional category strongly affected by informality, who traveled 120km weekly to reach the employers' homes, from whom she caught the virus..2. The living conditions of this worker portray the social inequalities of Brazilian society and highlight the multidimensional character of the vulnerabilities that affect the majority of the population in the suburbs of metropolises and regions that concentrate poverty: the difficulty in maintaining social isolation in the face of need of seeking income in a context of fragile social protection system; the precarious conditions of housing and sanitation; poor access to health services, racial inequalities, and low education..3. A study showed that the chances of death by Covid-19 in Brazil are higher among blacks compared to whites and people with less education..4.
