States such as São Paulo, served with 260 doctors per 100,000 inhabitants, and Rio Grande do Sul with 244 (located in the South and Southeast regions), Maranhão and Pará (located in the Northeast and North regions) have, respectively, 81 and 85 doctors per 100,000..5. Overall, this pattern of regional inequality is repeated in the distribution of ICU beds, respirators and other health professionals and reflects the differences in the number of deaths between regions of the country, with a clear advantage for the southern region.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Brazil is currently experiencing a tenebrous scenario with the pandemic: it has historical inequalities in the territory and between social groups that cross and reinforce each other; it is going through a context of economic and political crisis that has resulted in a shrinking of protection policies; it is governed by a president who is unprepared and reckless in responding to pandemic control..2. It is in this scenario that the success of some policies to face the country's structural problems takes shape in public opinion, in an international context that attests to the importance of universal public policies.

author: Peres et al. 2021
title: Sociodemographic factors associated with COVID-19 in-hospital mortality in Brazil
Objective(s): To evaluate the association between sociodemographic factors and COVID-19 in-hospital mortality in Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. A multivariable analysis was performed using a logistic regression model..2. The main analysis was based on complete case data, computing odds ratios (ORs) with the respective 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for each variable..3. It conducted a sensitivity analysis by considering missing or ignored values as a single ‘not reported’ category in the multivariable analysis.
Type of social stratification: - Gender:  Male / Female.- Age .- Level of education:  College/university / High school / Up to high school.- Region of residence: South / Southeast / Central-West / Northeast / North .- Number of comorbidities.- ICU admission: No / Yes.- Respiratory support: No / Yes / Yes,invasive .- Place of invasive respiratory support: In the ICU / Outside the ICU
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Gender/sex.-Education.-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1. The proportion of COVID-19 hospitalisations with a defined outcome was 7.5% of confirmed cases (228,196/3,018,397), and the proportion of in-hospital deaths was 85.6% of confirmed deaths (85,171/100,648)..2. The median age of in-hospital adult patients with COVID-19 was 61 years (interquartile range: 48, 73), with 54% aged >60 years, 57% were men and 85% (68,933/82,426) presented with at least one comorbidity (see Table 1).3. Most patients were from the Southeast and Northeast regions of Brazil (57% and 20%, respectively), and almost half were educated up to high school (45%, 34,964/78,511)..4. White patients represented 35.4% (80,853/228,196) of hospitalizations, whereas Black/Brown individuals accounted for 35% (79,914/228,196) of hospitalizations, Asians accounted for 11.2% (2558/228,196) of hospitalisations and Indigenous was the smallest group (0.2%, 449/228,196) (see Table S2).5. Black/Brown and Asian groups were mostly present in the Southeast, Northeast and North, the White population was concentrated in the Southeast and South regions and the Indigenous group was mainly from the North and Central-West of Brazil..6. White (36%) and Asian (34%) patients were admitted more frequently to the ICU than Black/Brown (32%) and Indigenous (28%) patients..7. The proportions of Black/Brown patients (21%) and Indigenous patients (23%) who underwent invasive respiratory support were higher than the proportions of White (19%) and Asian (19%) patients, especially outside the ICU (Black/Brown [17%], Indigenous [28%] vs White [11%], Asian [14%])..8. The total in-hospital mortality was 37% (85,171/228,196) (see Figure 1 and Table 1)..9. Black/Brown and Indigenous patients had higher in-hospital mortality (42% and 43%, respectively) than White and Asian patients (37% and 39%, respectively) (see Table 1 and Figure 2).10. Black/Brown race (OR = 1.15; 95% CI = 1.09e1.22) was associated with increased mortality. .11. A higher risk of mortality was related to education levels lower than college/university, especially the illiterate (OR = 1.77; 95% CI = 1.58e1.98) and up to the high school level (OR = 1.52; 95% CI = 1.4e1.65) groups. .12. Increased mortality was also seen in the residential regions in the North (OR = 2.76; 95% CI = 2.45e3.1) and Northeast (OR = 2.05; 95% CI = 1.86e2.26) of Brazil.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Among hospitalised Brazilian adults with COVID-19, Black/Brown patients showed higher in-hospital mortality, less frequently used hospital resources and had potentially more severe conditions than White patients..2. Public health decision makers should ensure that prevention activities prioritise these population groups, providing regular income support to low-income households, access to testing and shelter to the homeless, in addition to improving healthcare access in the most vulnerable communities.
Funding sources: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnologico (CNPq), Coordenaçao de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior (CAPES) e Finance Code 001,Fundaçao de Amparo  Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro  (FAPERJ) and Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio de Janeiro-(PUC-Rio).

author: Bermejo-Martins et al. 2021
title: Different responses to stress, health practices, and self-care during covid-19 lockdown: A stratified analysis
Journal: International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health
Objective(s): To analyze the differential impact of the first COVID-19 lockdown (3 April 2020) on stress, health practices, and self-care activities across different Hispanic countries, age range, and gender groups.
Sample size: n=1,082 participants.Spain (n = 271), Ecuador (n = 282), Chile (n = 261) and Colombia (n = 268)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive statistics analysis was used to summarize the socio-demographic data..2. Preliminary multiple regression analyses were conducted to determine whether socio-economic variables were associated with the main variables (i.e., stress, health practices, and self-care)..3. Analyses of the relationship between the main variables and factors were conducted using multivariate analysis (MANOVA), where health practices and self-care variables were included as dependent variables, and country, gender and age were included as independent variables. Stress, controlling for income level, was analyzed with a univariate analysis of covariance (ANCOVA)..4. Independent ANOVAs were conducted with each dependent variable. .5. Bonferroni adjusted all multiple comparisons and partial eta square (?p2) was used for test effect size.
Type of social stratification: -Age.-Gender: Male/Female.-Educational level: Elementary/ High School / Technical / University.-Income level: no salary / one mw (minimum wage)/ Two mw / Three mw / Four mw / Five mw.-Changes in the employment situation
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Gender/sex.-Socioeconomic status .-Education.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. Participants’ age ranged from 18 to 95 with a mean age of 43.9 (SD = 15.2).2. 50.9% (551) of the sample was female and 49.1% (531) male. .3. Socio-demographic characteristics were similar across countries with very few differences between genders, most participants having a high educational level and medium and high-income level (see Table 1). .4. The univariate ANCOVA analysis showed no significant interactions among country, gender, and age group (F(12) = 0.75; p = 0.70). However, a significant interaction was found between gender and age group (F(4) =2.76; p = 0.03; ?p2 = 0.01) due to the fact that females from the youngest group showed significantly higher levels of stress compared to females from older groups (p = 0.02; p = 0.005; p = 0.001)..5. Main effects analysis shows that differences in terms of perceived stress across countries are significant (F(3)=6.92; p < 0.001; ?p 2 = 0.02), those from Chile and Spain having higher stress levels compared to Colombian people (p = 0.001; p < 0.001) (see Figure 1A). .6. The interaction found with regards to COVID-19 seriousness perception among country, gender, and age groups (F(12) = 0.83; p = 0.62) was not significant. However, a significant interaction between gender and age groups was found in relation to this indicator (F(4) = 5.04; p < 0.001; ?p2 = 0.20). (see Figure 1B).7. A significant interaction was found among country, gender, and age groups in the case of adherence to health guidelines (F(12) = 2.74; p = 0.001; ?p2 = 0.30) (see Figure 1C).8.Regarding the practice of healthy daily routines, a three-factor interaction was found among country, gender, and age group (F(12) = 3.71; p < 0.001; ?p2 = 0.40). (see Figure 2A). .9. With regards to the total score of self-care activities, the univariate analysis showed no interactions among country, gender and age range for this variable (F(12) = 1.19; p = 0.29; ?p2 = 0.01). However, a main effect was detected for gender (F(1) = 7.00; p = 0.008; ?p2 = 0.01), which can be explained by the fact that females in general scored higher in self-care activities than males (p = 0.008) (see Figure 2B).10. An interaction was detected the indicator of health Consciousness between gender and country (F(3) = 3.08; p = 0.02; ?p2 = 0.01). (see Table 2).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. It is mandatory to optimize public policies to make them more health promoting, taking into account the social determinants of health and by altering social norms so that the health of all members and groups of society is a priority..2. Health policies, measures and media are needed to promote greater health behaviors with a special emphasis on health consciousness and self-care..3. In order to reduce these health inequities and address immediate and long-term consequences, it is urgent to establish strategies for public health emergencies that take a.gender-based approach into account. .4. Community engagement can make a substantial difference in health outcomes and strengthen the capacity to deal with the negative consequences of the pandemic at individual, organizational, and community level.
Funding sources: The Academic Articles Publication Fund of Universidad San Francisco de Quito USFQ, University of Navarra and University of San Buenaventura.

author: D. Gil et al. 2021
title: Employment Loss in Informal Settlements during the Covid-19 Pandemic: Evidence from Chile
Objective(s): The employment loss in informal settlements before and during the Covid-19 pandemic in Chile. To analyze on this dimension to estimate the economic burden caused by the current health crisis on these vulnerable communities.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Regression analysis for each outcome on a dataset that contains information on respondents who were surveyed three times between September 2019 and September 2020.
Type of social stratification: -Regional area: north/ center/ south.-Age.-Gender: Male/Female.-Employment status: worked for pay during the week before the survey in the formal / informal sector.-Cooperation among neighbors ofered help to their neighbors: listening to problems /domestic work/lending money/ in-kind support/ child care.-Government assistance (support from government programs to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic)
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Occupation.-Place of residence.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability).
Main Results: 1. After the pandemic, labor participation in the informal settlements drops around 35 percentage points (Table 1, column 3, post-1; ß= -035, p<0.01), representing a 50% drop relative to the pre pandemic level. ( Table 1).2. Labor force participation decreases by around 40 percentage points (Table 1, column 3, post-2, ß= -0.41, p<0.01), from a pre-pandemic level of 75%..3. Decreasing in employment status is even more signifcant than for individuals with lower education levels living in the same municipalities..4. Immigrants in both surveys display a higher employment rate before the pandemic and a dramatic loss at the beginning of the pandemic ( drops from 80 to 60% between February 2020 and April 2020.). (BUT immigrant dwellers sufered a larger drop, from 80 to 40%, between September 2019 and May 2020.).5. Employment status afecting women, who exhibited lower employment before the pandemic (between 11 and 9 per- centage points lower than men,.6. The employment rate for women falls, roughly, from 73 to 43% between September 2019 and May 2020, and continues to fall through September 2020 to 30% ( larger for women, but not statistically signifcant at conventional levels relative to men.).7. The unemployment insurance program among informal dwellers increased from 6 to 17% between May and September 2020. An important limitation of the unemployment insurance program is the high proportion of informal workers among settlement dwellers, which makes them ineligible. more than half of the respondents reported not having received this beneft during the pandemic.
Policy or intervention associate: Chile has implemented an expansive housing policy, (...) built by the private sector and financed through public subsidies, eligible low-income households become owners of a dwelling unit. (...)  the success of the policy regime implemented is clear. However, many of these housing projects are located in the periphery of urban areas. This location has reinforced the pattern of social segregation and urban inequality that many cities face increase in the price of urban land in many Chilean cities, mak- ing the government’s subsidies inefective.-Unemployment insurance and a COVID cash transfer program (“Bono COVID”) that the government designed to provide economic aid during the pandemic to vulnerable families. (transfers up to approximately USD70 to low-income households belonging to the frst three quintiles of the income distribution who do not have income from work or pensions.)..
Conclusions: 1. Individuals living in informal settlements are in a particularly problematic position to cope with such a crisis..2. In absolute terms, They do not detect statistically signifcant differences by gender, we highlight that the drop in employment is more dramatic for women when we compare percentage changes..3. Residents of informal settlements are more economically vulnerable to external shocks in the economy than the general population because a large proportion performs informal jobs earning subsistence wages..4. In employment status among informal dwellers has been signifcantly larger relative to the Chilean population..5. Declining in employment status among informal dwellers has been signifcantly larger relative to the Chilean population..6. Declining in employment status among individuals with incomplete secondary education living in the same municipalitiesm (...) has been signifcantly larger relative to the Chilean population..7. Immigrant households are substantially less likely to receive government assistance, such as the Bono COVID or in-kind food transfers..8. Women show lower labor participation than men before the pandemic, their decline in employment status is comparable to that of men and probably larger. ( women are often the primary caregivers for children, (and their schools were closed), their employment is probably more afected. .8. Informal settlements often attract less public assistance because they are installed on land without a proper legal title.9. Communities sometimes cope with the lack of aid from government ofces by developing strong social networks among neighbors and with the support of NGOs and other private institutions..10. Governments need to implement mitigation strategies to compensate for the economic loss suffered by severely deprived households. In addition to providing much-needed support, consider the informal economic sector, immigrants, and women.
Funding sources: Partially by TECHO-Chile and the School of Social Sciences of Pontifcia Universidad Católica de Chile and the ANID Millennium Science Initia- tive NCS17_062 and Research Center for Integrated Disaster  Risk Management (CIGIDEN), ANID FONDAP 15110017.

author: Perracini et al. 2021
title: Impact of COVID-19 Pandemic on Life-Space Mobility of Older Adults Living in Brazil: REMOBILIZE Study
Objective(s): To investigate the immediate impact of COVID-19 pandemic on life-space mobility of community-dwelling Brazilian older adults and examine the social determinants of health associated with change in life-space mobility.
Sample size: n=1,482 (data collection between May 18th, 2020 and July 4th, 2020 )
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive analyses were performed, both for the total sample and based on the investigated outcomes, using proportions and means (and standard deviation). .2. The non-parametric Wilcoxon test for paired data to compare the composite score, the score for each level, and the delta score. .3. Univariate analysis of the associations between independent variables and changes in LSA scores was evaluated by Wilcoxon signed-rank (dichotomous variables) and Kruskal-.Wallis tests (categorical variables)..4. Social factors, comorbidities, and adherence to social restriction were selected as multivariate adjusted model variables..5. The results of multiple linear regression are reported as regression coefficients (ß) and 95% confidence intervals (95% CI)..
Type of social stratification: -Gender: Male/Female.-Age group (60–69, 70–79, and =80 years).-Ethnicity: white/ black /pardo /amarelo / indigenous .-Education level: illiterate/ 1–4 years/ 5–8 years/ =9 years of schooling.-Income level: <1 / 2–3 / 4–7/  8–10 / >10 minimum wage salaries.-Employment: active/ inactive/ unemployed
Main Results: 1. Approximately half of the participants reported two or more diseases, and more than 80% totally agreed that they were following social restriction measures..2. The mean LSA score before the COVID-19 pandemic was 64.0 (SD 26.0) and mean LSA score since the pandemic was 37.8 (SD 22.1), and the 1 was -26.2 (SD 25.0). A significant reduction was observed in LSA scores from Level 2 up to Level 5 (p < 0.001; see Figure 2 and Table 2)..3. Pardo (mixed race) individuals had a significantly lower LSA score (p < 0.001) before the pandemic compared with white individuals, and this situation persisted since the pandemic (p = 0.005). A smaller, but significant reduction in LSA (delta LSA) (p < 0.001) was observed among pardo individuals compared with white individuals. A reduction in life-space mobility (delta LSA) was observed among women compared with men (p < 0.008), among older adults aged between 60 and 69 and 70 and 79 years compared with older adults aged 80 years and over (p < 0.001), among older people living alone (p < 0.001), among individuals with a high educational level (5 or more years of schooling) (p < 0.001), and among individuals with a high-income level (four or more minimum wage salaries) (p < 0.001). (see Table 3).4. There were significant relationships between delta LSA and male sex (ß = 3.32, 95% CI = 0.33; 6.32), living alone (ß = -3.75, 95% CI = -7.09; -0.41), age between 70 and 79 years (ß = -4.95, 95% CI = -9.13; -0.78; ref. 80 years and over), black race/ethnicity (ß= -7.76, 95% CI = -13.14; -2.37; ref. pardo), having more than 4 years of schooling (ß = 7.94, 95% CI = 4.60; 11.28; ref. illiterate or 1–4 years), and having an income of =4 minimum wage salaries (ß = 4.76, 95% CI = 1.77; 7.75; ref. <3 minimum wage salaries). The fit of the regression equation found in the final model was [F(11,1,389) = 8.36, p < 0.001], R 2 = 0.055. (see Table 4). ç
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This results showed significant changes in life-space mobility, particularly outside of the home environment (in the neighborhood, in the town, and beyond town)..2. Reductions in life-space mobility were higher among older people living alone, those aged between 70 and 79 years compared to older people aged 80 years old and over, and black individuals compared to pardo individuals, exposing underlying inequalities that might have been aggravated by the pandemic..3. They found post-pandemic reductions of around 20 points in LSA scores. A score above 10 points is considered a marker of poor health outcomes.4. The continuous restriction in life-space mobility due to COVID-19 might increase the risk of developing chronic conditions and functional decline..5. They found older adults who were male, who had a moderate to high educational level, and who had a higher income level enjoyed more life-space mobility compared to women, individuals with lower educational and income levels..6. That compared to older women; older men already had greater life-space mobility before the COVID- 19 pandemic. .7. The life-threatening situation of the COVID-19 pandemic might have not alarmed older men. Men were found twice as likely to be at increased risk of severe COVID-19 in all age groups.8. Higher reductions in life-space mobility were observed among black individuals compared to older pardo individuals. Employment inequalities in this population might in part explain this reduction..9. Low socioeconomic status and physical inactivity during the pandemic combined with underlying health conditions that are common in this population may increase the risk of poor management of non-communicable diseases, disability, and frailty..10. This results underline the need to structure urgent comprehensive responses to mitigate pandemic consequences among older adults living alone, among black individuals, and for people with lower income and education levels. Prioritized actions should be set up urgently to assist these vulnerable groups in the community, strengthening existing policies in the public sector, particularly the Family Strategy Program in the National Health Service (or SUS)..11. Innovative digital technologies should be envisioned to scale up best-buy interventions, such as digital platforms to deliver physical activity and rehabilitation programs.12. Social restriction measures due to a pandemic caused substantial limitations in older adults’ life-space mobility in Brazil. Social inequalities should be recognized, and concerted action should be taken to overcome the deterioration in life-space mobility among the most vulnerable groups of older people.
Funding sources: MRP has received a researcher productivity grant (309838/2017-7) from the Brazilian National Council for Scientific and Technological Development.

author: Sanhueza-Sanzana et al. 2021
title: Desigualdades sociais associadas com a letalidade por COVID-19 na cidade de Fortaleza, Ceará, 2020
Objective(s): To analyze the association among social inequalities related to health conditions, socioeconomic status, spatial segregation and apparent case fatality rate (CFR) due to COVID-19 in neighborhoods of the city of Fortaleza
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive analysis..2. The Moran index (I) was used as a measure of spatial autocorrelation in order to verify whether there is a spatially conditioned pattern by the epidemiological indicators of Case Fatality Rate (CFR), specific mortality and incidence of COVID-19, and socioeconomic, sanitation, sociodemographic and spatial segregation indicators.
Type of social stratification: -Sex (female/male).-Age group (ten years apart).-Neighborhood of residence.-Sanitation conditions (Home ownership/ households with access to proper sewage disposal/ water supply system/  waste collection/ access to electricity)Family members (households with more than 4 residents, with elderly 65 years or older as the head of family (and if they help or not with expenses), with an illiterate person over 15 years of age;  and headed by women;Socioeconomic status (with monthly income of less than 1 minimum wage; Median monthly family income per capita, in Reais (R$); Median monthly income of women over 10 years of age, in Reais (R$), extreme poverty; Infant mortality rate; Human Development Index (HDI-B) by neighborhood, Population density (inhabitant/km2).
Main Results: 1. Covid-19 Incidence was more concentrated in neighborhoods in northern and eastern zones of the city, the same neighborhoods showed the worst socioeconomic status and sanitation conditions, ranging from 76 to 236 cases per 10,000 inhabitants..2. High mortality rate was found in the southern zone of the city, a region of high social vulnerability such as poverty, illiteracy and low income. Lower mortality rates – below 6.7 per 10,000 inhabitants. – were found in areas of the city where the population presented the highest income and most favorable sanitation conditions (Figure 1B)..3. The neighborhoods with the highest CFR (Case Fatality Rate) (Figure 1C) also had the worst living conditions, presenting (i) a high percentage of households in poverty, (= 39%) (Figure 2A), (ii) low monthly income, up to R$ 600 (Figure 2B), (iii) a higher proportion of households headed by women, ranging from 31.2% to 36.8% (Figure 2C), (iv) a lower proportion of people aged 65 years or older (Figure 2D) and (v) a higher proportion of illiteracy, between 5.1% and 11.7% (Figures 2E and 2F).
Policy or intervention associate: The neoliberal political measures adopted aggravated the pandemic in Latin America.
Conclusions: 1. Neighborhoods with high Case Fatality Rate (CFR) due to COVID-19 also present precarious socioeconomic conditions, which are reflected in a high spatial segregation of the population, associated with the worst disease outcomes. .2. Unequal structure in risk exposure, strongly associated with social exclusion and precarious living conditions. .3. Segregation by socioeconomic class and race/ skin color is a strong determinant of health.  .4. CFR due to COVID-19 reflects another pattern of social stratification: the highest proportion of households headed by low-income women, most of whom work in central areas of the city, in informal employment relationships, with greater exposure to the virus. 4) In the areas with higher CFR, there is greater difficulty in accessing tertiary health care (of greater complexity), due to spatial segregation and distance to Primary Healthcare Centers (PHC).

author: Fellows et al. 2021
title: Under-Reporting of COVID-19 Cases Among Indigenous Peoples in Brazil: A New Expression of Old Inequalities
Objective(s): To estimate the incidence and mortality rates as well as the lethality of COVID-19 among the Indigenous Peoples of the Brazilian Amazon. .To analyze how external threats that occur in traditional territories can contribute to the dissemination of the disease in Indigenous Lands, threatening lives and ancestral knowledge.
Population: Indigenous population: COVID-19 Cases and Deaths
Sample size: n = 25,356 confirmed cases (Data from SESAI regarding Indigenous cases, information relentlessly collected by COIAB and their Indigenous leaders, Indigenous health professionals, and its partners in the Brazilian Amazon).
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Geospatial analysis was to use a correlation matrix to determine the connection between the environmental variables and the risk for an Indigenous person to get infected or die from COVID-19..2. The GLM (Generalized Linear Model) with Poisson distribution to select the variables that together better predict incidence and mortality rates..3. The models in pairs using the Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) to test if an addition of a variable improved the prediction of Indigenous cases and fatalities..4. To compare the models, we used the AIC index (Akaike information criterion), that determines the best models prioritizing its goodness of fit (how well the model reproduces the data) and simplicity (the least number of variables)..
Type of social stratification: - Race: Indigenous population of the Amazon versus non-indigenous population of the Legal Amazon .- Geographic: Indigenous population of the Amazon (COIAB and SESAI), contrasting with non-indigenous population by states of the Legal Amazon. .-The vulnerability index
Main Results: 1. The results indicate the distinct contamination dynamic for Indigenous Peoples when compared to the remaining groups..2. Concerning the total cases in Brazil, it is possible to outline the trajectory of the spread of the disease over time, which has led to almost five million cases by October 1st (see Figure 2A)..3. The Legal Amazon’s tally follows a similar path to Brazil’s, characterized by a sharper initial curve (see Figure 2B). .4. The Indigenous new cases are distinguished by their particular fluctuation (see Figures 2C, and 2D)..5. The data demonstrate that after the curve peaked by the 22nd epidemiological week, the number of deaths per week remained stable, followed by a decrease in the latest weeks examined..6. The graphs for Indigenous deaths exhibit an oscillation in the number of fatalities per week, resembling the values for confirmed cases, as the virus spread throughout the communities (see Figures 3C and 3D)..7. It is noticeable that in the first weeks, COIAB’s tally accounted for a larger amount of deaths caused by coronavirus in comparison with SESAI’s reports, which indicates an expressive under-reporting..8. The incidence rate for Indigenous communities is 106% higher than the Brazilian rate and 48% higher than the one observed in the Legal Amazon..9. The Indigenous mortality rate per 100,000 inhabitants, it is 110% higher than the Brazilian average and exceeds the Legal Amazon mortality rate by 89% (see Figures 4B and 5B)..10. According to SESAI's the mortality rate for Indigenous Peoples is lower than the Legal Amazon, and only 3.5% higher than Brazil’s rate. The lethality also indicates a serious under-reporting as SESAI’s values are 51% smaller than COIAB’s numbers (see Figure 4C)..11. Northwest of the Amazonas state, this Sanitary District has twenty-seven ethnical groups, it has the fourth-highest incidence rate and it is first in mortality rate, which got to this level in the first period of contagion due to the contact of an infected health professional with the local communities.12. The results show that the DSEIs Vilhena, Cuiabá, Maranhão, Altamira, and Xavante are expected to face a higher number of losses (see Figure 6B). Each region requires crafted individualized attention, as they have their own socio-cultural, geographical, and demographical dynamic.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. These results indicate that Indigenous Peoples in the Legal Amazon are 136% more affected by COVID-19 than the rest of the country. Whilst mortality rate is 110% higher among Indigenous Peoples than the general population..2. The administration’s handling of environmental stressors such as illegal economic activities (i.e., gold miners, loggers, land grabbers) on IL increased the risk of spreading coronavirus in all nine states of the Brazilian Legal Amazon..3. The spread of the coronavirus deserves maximum attention from health agencies, as confirmed by this study and COIAB’s Emergency Action Plan.
Funding sources: Institute for Climate and Society (iCS), by the Stiefel Behner Charitable Fund, by Vinny Smith, from Toba Capital, and the Environment, Diversity and Health research group of the Oswaldo Cruz Foundation.

author: Sahasranaman and Jensen 2021
title: Spread of COVID-19 in urban neighbourhoods and slums of the developing world: Spread of COVID-19 in urban neighbourhoods and slums of the developing world
Objective(s): To systematic the differences in the spread of COVID-19 across slum and non-slum neighbourhoods in these cities..To create a network model of infectious spread through an urban system (city) to provide a candidate explanation of the empirically observed variation in caseloads across slums and non-slums.
Population: Neighbourhoods with slums and other neighbourhoods
Sample size: n=40,261 average population of sub-city unit
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The unequal nature of this spread across neighbourhoods using the k-index, which is a measure of the inequality in the distribution of an attribute across a population. Given the cumulative distribution of COVID-19 caseload across neighbourhoods, the k-index (kf ) has the property that kf proportion of neighbourhoods contain (1 - kf ) proportion of the cases and consequently the remaining (1 - kf ) proportion of neighbourhoods account for kf proportion of the cases.
Type of social stratification: The k-index.Geographic: slum/non-slum
Main Results: 1. The k-index of the distribution appears to remain consistent for Rio de Janeiro.2. The distribution of cases across the states of Brazil yield kf of 0.65..3. The resulting list of neighbourhoods with slums is 41 out of 163 bairros in Rio de Janeiro (Rocinha, Jacarezihno, Mare, Cidade de Deus, Complexo do Alemao, Mangueira, Penha, Acari,.Tijuca, Costa Barros, Ramos, Benfica, Pavuna, Encantado, Lins de Vasconcelos, Manguinhos, Madureira, Inhaumos, Rio Comprido, Iraja, Anchieta, Vigario Geral, Guadalupe, Cordovil,.Piedade, Jacare, Parada de Lucas, Copacabana, Tomas Coelho, Magalhaes Bastos, Realengo, Bangu, Jacarepagua, Andarai, Bras de Pina, Honorio Gurgel, Engenho Novo, Turiacu, Padre Miguel, Coelho Neto, Engenho de Dentro)..4. The only exception here is Rio de Janeiro, where we find that neighbourhoods with slums have a lower caseload per capita than non-slum neighbourhoods..5. This finding suggests that neighbourhood population density is a critical mediator of the dynamics of infectious spread in a city, and that the urban poor in slums are starkly worse off iin terms of epidemy outcomes.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. There is evidence to suggest that slum populations scale super-linearly with city size, meaning that larger cities have more than proportionally larger slums..2. This finding appears to hold across scales, with national case distribution across these states/provinces also displaying similar inequality in case distribution..3. Finding that neighbourhoods with the highest case densities—both in terms of population and area—contain the largest slums in these cities, and that consequently the urban poor in slums are at the highest risk in this epidemic.
Funding sources: None: The authors received no funding for this work..

author: F. Ribeiro, Ribeiro, and Leist 2020
title: Who is going to pay the price of Covid-19? Reflections about an unequal Brazil
Journal: International Journal of Equity in Health
Objective(s): To discuss who will pay the price of the Brazilian government denying the impact of COVID-19 pandemic and suggest some measures to ensure that clear information and protection reach this population.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Given that women in Brazil are those who integrate the most significant numbers of informal jobs, it is possible to suppose that more women will be affected by COVID-19 when compared to countries with greater gender equality..2. Hospital admissions, the percentage of white persons hospitalized for COVID-19 is higher than the rates of black and brown persons. However, about 54.8% of deaths are of the latter, which are overwhelmingly users of the public health system.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The population of Brazil needs to be tested, and contacts of cases need to be traced, to provide precise data on the pandemic and stop further spread. Without testing and tracing, there can be no effective healthcare response

author: Bilal, Alfaro, and Vives 2021
title: COVID-19 and the worsening of health inequities in Santiago, Chile.
Objective(s): To show a worsening of pre-existing inequities in mortality in the municipalities that make up the metropolitan region of Santiago (Chile) during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The association (relative risk (RR)) between log(mortality) and average years of school-ing or proportion overcrowded households using a linear model for each period separately.
Type of social stratification: -Average years of schooling among adults aged =25 years.-Proportion of households living in overcrowding (>2.5 people/bedroom)
Main Results: 1. It found a strong association between socio-economic status (SES) and mortality in both periods..2. It found a 9.0% lower mortality per 1-year increase in the average schooling years in the pre-pandemic period [relative risk (RR) = 0.91, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.87 to 0.93] compared with a 13.8% lower mortality in the 2020 period (RR = 0.86, 95% CI 0.83 to 0.89). .3. It found that a 5% increase in the proportion of overcrowded households was associated with a 22% and 32% higher mortality in the pre-pandemic and pandemic periods, respectively (RR = 1.22, 95% CI 1.16 to 1.28; RR = 1.32, 95% CI 1.23 to 1.42).
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. It found a worsening of pre-existing inequities in mortality in the metropolitan area of Santiago de Chile during the COVID-19 pandemic..2. There is no relationship between mortality due to COVID-19 and poverty.3. There are existing structural inequalities in Chile, including inequities in healthcare access and utilization by type of insurance both before6 and during the pandemic, along with social determinants of health beyond the health system..4. factors that influence not only incidence and increased exposure to the virus, such as more precarious employment conditions, loss of income and the need to work outside the home, but also an increased prevalence of conditions that aggravate the consequences of the disease, which show a strong social patterning in Chile.
Funding sources: Office of the Director of the National Institutes of Health under award number DP5OD26429 and Salud Urbana en Ame ´rica Latina (SALURBAL)/Urban Health in Latin America project, funded by the Wellcome Trust (205177/Z/16/Z).

author: Kind and Cordeiro 2020
title: Narrativas sobre a morte: a gripe espanhola e a covid-19 no BRASIL
Objective(s): To discuss narratives about death in two pandemics, the Spanish flu (1918-1920) and the Covid-19 (2020) in the Brazilian context.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Exponential increase in infection and death by Covid-19, given the unfavorable demographic density to the measures of self-protection and social isolation advocated to fight the pandemic..2. Highlight numbers that associate poverty with race, housing conditions, illiteracy rate, schooling and informal work to highlight who will pay the price of Covid-19 in Brazil..3. It was denounce the lack of registration of race indicators in Brazilian epidemiological bulletins..4. "Funeral rituals that can favor the farewell process and the elaboration of meaning for the loss, such as wakes and burials, are prohibited or carried out with restrictions during the pandemic".5. If during the Spanish flu the print media was the main vehicle for mass communication, Covid-19 gained very different image interpretations. The images generated fake news distributed by government supporters, questioning whether there were really dead people in all those coffins
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The narratives both about the Spanish flu and about Covid-19, expose the fragility of humanity, reveal the inequalities in death, the health irresponsibility of government officials, the weaknesses of health services and the suspension of funeral rites..2. Among the most obvious differences, the Spanish flu was more lethal for the young population. Young men returning from the fronts of the First World War took the virus with them to their countries. .3. The high transferability of Covid-19, with an evidently greater international circulation, is accompanied by the vertigo of rapidly shared information. .4. The internet and its ways of narrating, which do not always depend on official spokespersons for registering the pandemic, weave narratives of disinformation about the lethality of the virus, but also of the poetics of lost lives.
Funding sources: CNPq, processo n. 309393/2018-3. Bolsa de Produtividade em Pesquisa (L.K.).

author: Nasser et al. 2021
title: Vulnerabilidade e resposta social à pandemia de Covid-19 em territórios metropolitanos de São Paulo e da Baixada Santista, SP, Brasil
Objective(s): To analyze vulnerability and ways of tackling the Covid-19 pandemic in metropolitan territories of São Paulo and Baixada Santista, objects of the research Inequalities and vulnerabilities in the Covid-19 epidemic: monitoring, analysis and recommendations10, in light of the theoretical framework of vulnerability and human rights
City or municipality: 16 metropolitan territories of São Paulo and Baixada Santista (State of São Paulo, Brazil)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Performing in thematic axes: violence, mental suffering, intensive use of substances, access to benefits, solidarity networks, vulnerability, risk, housing, income, meaning of prevention, and food insecurity.
Type of social stratification: -Subnormal clusters: vulnerability.-Class: Middle Class, Communities.-Gender: Male/Female/Cisgender/Transexual.-Schooling.-Employment: informal/ unemployed/ employed.-Government’s emergency financial help and food programs
Main Results: 1. Frequent presence of indigenous Latin American immigrants who worked at garment sweatshops and presented a higher number of positive tests for Covid-19..2. Communities, precarious housing, informal work, unemployment and lack of transportation characterize the living conditions, aggravated by the Covid-19 pandemic, with income loss for 87.3% of the 450 people who mentioned changes in their income..3. Hunger increased in the Communities, with 79% in situation of food insecurity. .4. For women more unequal labor division due to the pandemic, regarding care of the children, including schooling, home maintenance, organization of the family’s food, and work outside the home..5. Domestic violence and gender violence emerged only when women were actively asked about these issues..6. The support networks were headed mainly by black women..7. In middle class most of the interviewees could adopt telework, but many had their income reduced or lost their jobs..8. As the pandemic progressed, the financial help and donations became rare..9. Demand for serological tests incompatible with the purpose of studying seroprevalence, both in the Communities and Middle Class...
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The Covid-19 pandemic brings situations of exposure to the populations that inhabit the urban metropolitan territories of São Paulo and Santos, articulating the axes of vulnerability - individual, social and programmatic -, revealing and aggravating inequality. .2. Solidarity networks developed by the social movements and other actors of each territory are very powerful due to the formulation of proposals and actions .3. Elements of individual and collective vulnerability, to Covid-19 infection were identified, related to housing, employment and income, lack of leisure and public policies for youths, limited access to the Internet, and the different faces of violence..4. It requires the identification of trails, the recognition of specific needs for the route, and the joint walk of subjects and collectives..5. Programmatic vulnerability to Covid-19 infection14, conditioned by access to services, protection materials and hospitalization, when necessary, was much (...) higher in the Communities..
Funding sources: Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior (Capes).

author: Pizzinga 2021
title: Vulnerabilidade e atividades essenciais no contexto da COVID-19: reflexões sobre a categoria de trabalhadoras domésticas
Objective(s): To analyze the context of the domestic workers activity in the COVID-19 pandemic regarding the vulnerabilities of the category and the definition of essential activities by federal decrees.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Illnesses and deaths related to COVID-19 are not evenly distributed among the population due to the country’s socioeconomic, racial and gender inequalities..2. Political context surrounding epidemiological research in Brazil and may be directly linked to the way the pandemic is unfolding, in addition to making it impossible to carry out risk analysis among the various professional categories..3. Concerning the way in which white and black women are divided between economic sectors, a greater concentration of black women is seen in groups that have less stable employment relationships, thus increasing their vulnerability to the economic crisis generated by the pandemic..4. The relation between the visibility/invisibility of domestic work and its lower social and economic value compared to what is considered essential activity by legislation has spawned some controversy in Brazil..5. In the context of a pandemic, not being considered an essential activity is positive, and such workers should not be forced to commute to work.
Policy or intervention associate: The analysis was based on four federal decrees published in the first half of 2020, which defined the essential activities in the pandemic.
Conclusions: 1. The discrimination of variables such as occupation, skin color/race, sex/gender, among others, helps understand the social aspects of the pandemic and enables the design of public policies to minimize its harm..2. The available data are still incomplete and incipient in Brazil, they reveal that it is essential for the government to reduce workers’ vulnerability levels.

author: Sousa Júnior, Gonçalves, and Cruz 2020
title: COVID-19: Local/regional inequalities and impacts over critical healthcare infrastructure in Brazil
Objective(s): To address regional inequalities about critical healthcare infrastructure for coping with the COVID-19, based on geo-spatial analysis and compartmental modeling (SEIR)
City or municipality: São Paulo Macro Metropolis and the Metropolitan Region of Vale do Paraíba/Litoral Norte
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Geospatial analysis and compartmental modeling (SEIR). I was a SIMULATION
Type of social stratification: -Concentration of ICUs Index.-Metropolitan regions.
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Time-dependent relationships (e.g. leaving the hospital, respite care, other instances where a person may be temporarily at a disadvantage)
Main Results: 1. Most of the municipalities in the Metropolitan Region of Vale do Paraíba/Litoral Norte (RVPMLN) are in critical health infrastructure conditions..2. The collapse of the health systems would have been imminent at the sub-regional level, in sub-regions 1, 3 and 5. .3. Sub-region 5 (municipalities on the North Coast of Sao Paulo) would have been due to its limited health infrastructure, as well as its relationship as one of the main tourist destinations for the population of Sao Paulo city, one of the epicenters .4. Despite having good health infrastructure at the regional level, is is the most populous sub-region and showed a more accelerated evolution of cases at the beginning of the pandemic..5. Half of hospitalised, (2350%–46.2%) were slum dwellers..6. 1.86% died of Covid- 19, of whom 150 (20.6%) resided in a slum.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Disparity between public and private provision of critical healthcare infrastructure is clear..2. Concentration of ICU beds to assist private health plans is inversely proportional to the percentage of the population in this segment..3. Availability of ICU beds with the adoption of a more realistic current occupancy rate (70% on average for total ICU beds), most regions and municipalities would be in a critical situation.4. Absence of ICU beds in more than 2/3 of the municipalities of Macro Metropolis and Metropolitan Region of Vale do Paraíba/Litoral Norte..5. For future resilience, it’s essential to address the inequalities in terms of the healthcare infrastructure available for public and private access.
Funding sources: MacroAmb Project (FAPESP 2015/03804-9), researchers from the REDEVALE network (www.redevale.ita. br)

author: Yagiu et al. 2021
title: Participação social de lideranças comunitárias em um contexto de desigualdade social e no enfrentamento da pandemia da COVID-19: um enfoque psicossocial
Objective(s): To understand the psychosocial elements of social participation and the involvement of community leaders in a local peripheral village, by pointing their strengths and weaknesses - discussion on the aspects of social participation and political involvement of community leaders of a peripheral community of the Baixada Santista, coastal area of the state of São Paulo, by observing psychosocial elements that concern the role of socialization processes in the potentiation of collective actions.
City or municipality: Casqueiro River and the Anchieta Highway, Baixada Santista, São Paulo
Sample size: n=5 workshops, 24 field diaries, and in-depth interviews with 4 leaders (three women and one man) between June 2017 and October 2019
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Research of official data and document analysis.2. Thematic workshops.3. Formation of research groups for in-depth interviews: occurred in four stages meetings for the presentation of the project, formation of the research group, development of research and discussions of the results..4. Participant observation and field diaries.
Type of social stratification: -Weaknesses expressed in the forms of organization and socialization and in the participatory processes of community leaders.-Potentialities expressed in the forms of organization and socialization and in the participatory processes of community leaders.-The COVID-19 pandemic and the intensifying effects of social inequalities
Main Results: 1. The lack of connection and mobilization of people represents one of the great difficulties..2. The gossip is a powerful tool in communication and instrument of social control. In this case, gossip plays a rather negative role in the bonds between the people of the community..3. In this territory, the leaders note the influence of trafficking in the organization of community dynamics..4. The active presence of female leaders from the beginning, based on awareness processes, has opened possibilities for a new praxis, including by effectively participating in the organization and collective mobilization in the current context of the COVID-19 pandemic..5. The covid-19 pandemic arrived in Brazil in 2020, whose advance explained the consequences of social inequality by affecting more directly the populations with greater difficulties of putting into practice isolation and social distancing due to the need to fight for survival and the housing precariousness. .6. The leaders were also able to organize themselves to fight the spread of the virus by raising awareness among residents, by using technological resources offered, and partnering with companies and organizations to obtain the necessary items for protection..7. Aggregating social participation and collective work has allowed leaders to make themselves subjects of history and assume the role that the neoliberal capitalist state is failing to fulfill..8. The COVID-19 pandemic has brought more than just medical and epidemiological consequences, for example: the social, political and economic effects, causing an intensification of existing precariousness such as poverty, vulnerability by the absence of fundamental rights, the unhealthiness of housing, besides the lack of either state interventions or private investments, bringing numerous challenges for leaders in a moment when the emergency aid ends in the country.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. It found that community leaders have a history of achievements related to improvements in living conditions despite the existence of what are considered weaknesses..2. Despite the existence of potentialities such as the processes of awareness, organization and dialogue with the community to achieve some objectives, most actions have not yet resulted.in an implementation of public rights and policies of health, education, assistance or culture..3. It found that making people appropriate the territory is one of the great challenges. These processes can advance public policies and lead the State to a path of greater social equity by.denouncing social inequalities, being, therefore, an important object of scientific research and reflection..4. This study has the gap related to the development of other themes related to the phenomenon of social participation, such as: overcoming assistance and voluntarism; gender issues, considering the leading role of women in this community; the aspects that lead to leadership in this community and the role that the State plays in vulnerable communities.

author: Maciel et al. 2021
title: Living conditions, seroprevalence and symptoms of COVID-19 in slums in the Metropolitan Region of Vitória (Espírito Santo).
Objective(s): 1. To estimate the prevalence of infection by SARS-CoV-2 in residents of the Greater Vitória region, residents of AGSN and non-subnormal agglomerations (“aglomerados não subnormais”, AGNSN);.2. To compare sociodemographic and clinical characteristics of total residents (infected and not infected with SARS-CoV-2) between conglomerates.
Sample size: n=714 in subnormal agglomerates (“aglomerados subnormais”, AGSN).n=733 in non-subnormal agglomerations (“aglomerados não subnormais”, AGNSN)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Descriptive analysis.2. The two groups were compared in terms of prevalence and factors associated with COVID-19 in bivariate analyses (sociodemographic profile, COVID-19 positivity outcome, household characteristics, comorbidities and symptoms), using the ?² association test.
Type of social stratification: -Geographic: subnormal agglomeration, AGSN / no subrnormal agglomerations, AGNSN  .-Antibody detection test against SARS-CoV-2: positive / negative.-Gender: Male/Female.-Age group (up to 20 years old,/21–40 years/ 41–60 years /61–80 years / 81 years and over).-Ethnicity: white/ brown/ black/ yellow/ indigenous.-Education: illiterate/ incomplete 1st-4th grade of elementary school/ complete 4th grade of elementary school/ incomplete 5th-8th grade of elementary school/ complete elementary school/ incomplete high school/ complete high school/ incomplete higher education / complete higher education.-Number of house hold members: 1/ 2/ 3/ 4 or more.-Education of the person with the highest level of education in the household: illiterate/ elementary school/ high school/ incomplete higher education/ higher education.-Time on public transport per day (no resident uses/ less than 30 minutes/ between 30–60 minutes/ more than 60 minutes).-Often needs to use transport perweek (no resident uses it/ up to three times/ four times or more).-Bathroom (does not have a bathroom/ exclusive bathroom/ bathroom shared with another household/family).-Bedrooms (does not have a bedroom/ one bedroom/two or three bedrooms/ four bedrooms or more).-Water supply (no access to potable water/ irregular supply/ access on some days of the week/ regular supply/ available all days of the week).-Comorbidities (hypertension/diabetes mellitus/ asthma/  cancer/ kidney disease/ heart disease/ obesity and other comorbidities) went to the health unit (yes/ no).-Signs and symptoms of COVID-19 15 days prior to the interview, with yes or no answers: cough/ myalgia/ fatigue/ sore throat/ anosmia/dyspnea/ diarrhea/ fever/ tachycardia/ abdominal pain/ vomiting and other symptoms/ other unrelated symptoms.
Main Results: 1. Excess risk of 17.8% in the most vulnerable group, with no statistical difference between groups by the ?2 test..2. Tests in the subnormal agglomerates (“aglomerados subnormais”, AGSN) group, at least one contact with a reagent test was found in 6.3% of the households, while in other sectors the percentage was 4.1 % (p = 0.057)..3. Higher percentage of people who declare themselves brown is seen in AGSN, while in the AGNSN, the highest percentage was self-declared white (p < 0.001)..4. Higher percentage of illiterates and people with only elementary education in the group of residents in AGSN compared to the highest percentage of people with complete higher education in AGNSN (p < 0.001), .5. In AGSN:  higher number of residents per household (p = 0.012), lower educational level of the resident with more years of education (p < 0.001), longer stay in public transport (p < 0.001), bathroom shared with another household (p < 0.001), fewer bedrooms per household (p = 0.002) and higher frequency of irregular water supply (p = 0.009). .6. Regarding comorbidities, there were no statistically significant differences between residents of different types of agglomerates, as shown in Table 3.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Adequate living and mobility conditions help not only the prevention of chronic-degenerative diseases and the promotion of well-being, but also the control of infectious diseases such as dengue, chikungunya, zika and, currently, COVID-19..2. Did not find a statistically significant difference between the prevalence of reactive tests in the two types of clusters, despite the statistical differences in the housing conditions and transport habits of the residents, However, variables related to the place of work and leisure activities were not included in the questionnaire of this survey..3. Old issues are highlighted at this time of pandemic, such as sanitation, household den- sity, precarious housing and mobility..4. Inequality increases daily, and the COVID-19 pandemic shows us how this discrepancy is harmful to everyone, even those who live in adequate conditions and have access to sanitation..5. Cultural and economic relations of groups in their collectivity materialize, actions that can disproportionately reduce severe cases should be prioritized in government public policies aimed at the socially vulnerable.

author: Baggio et al. 2021
title: COVID-19 in Brazil: spatial risk, social vulnerability, human development, clinical manifestations and predictors of mortality - a retrospective study with data from 59 695 individuals.
Objective(s): To analyse the spatial dynamics of COVID-19 in Alagoas, Brazil, and its relationship with living conditions, to describe the clinical and epidemiological profile and to identify predictors of mortality in the population.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. For the association between social and epidemiological indicators, Moran’s bivariate spatial correlation was used..1. Logistic regression analysis was applied to determine the predictors of death.
Type of social stratification: -Ethnicity: Yellow/White/Indigenous/Brown /Black.-Gender: Male/Female.-The municipal human development index (MHDI): three dimensions (longevity, education and income), and the index ranges from 0 to 1. The closer to 1, the greater.-The social vulnerability index (SVI): three dimensions (urban infrastructure ,human capital and income and work), and it ranges from 0 to 1; the closer to 1, the greater the degree of social vulnerability)
Main Results: 1. Cumulative incidence rate was 1788.7/100 000 inhabitants; the mortality rate was 48.0/100 000 and the case fatality rate (CFR) was 2.7%. .2. The rates of incidence (I = 0.217; p = 0.001) and mortality (I = 0.425; p = 0.001) showed global spatial dependence, with the highest values concentrated in the central (agreste) and eastern (metropolitan) regions of the state..3. The CFR did not show global spatial dependence (I 0.051; p = 0.09); consequently, local Moran statistics were not applied..4. The highest incidence rates were observed both in municipalities with higher human development (overall municipal human development index (MHDI) (I = 0.1668; p = 0.002), MHDI education (I = 0.1649; p = 0.002) and MHDI income (I = 0.1880; p = 0.005)) and in those with higher social vulnerability (overall SVI (I = 0.0599; p = 0.033))..5. For mortality rate, with one additional indicator (social vulnerability index (SVI) human capital (I = 0.0573; p = 0.046))..6. CFR was associated with greater social vulnerability in two dimensions (SVI human capital (I = 0.0858; p = 0.004) and SVI urban infrastructure (I = 0.0985; p = 0.040)).7. Cases analysed, 55.4% (n = 33 087) were female. deaths,  57.4% were male (p < 0.0001)..8. The ages were between of 19 and 44 years.The median age of the population was 41 years (IQR = 21); the median age of deaths was 69 years (IQR = 20), and the median age of survivors was 40 years (IQR 22, p < 0.0001). .9. The most common clinical manifestations were fever (52.4%; n = 31 281), cough (55.2%; n = 32 922) and headache (31.8%; n = 18,985), with a higher frequency in survivors. On the other hand, dyspnoea was more frequent in individuals who died (p <0.0001). The frequency of diarrhoea was similar between groups (p = 0.861)
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. It found the main predictors of mortality to be male sex, advanced age, cardiovascular disease, diabetes mellitus, chronic respiratory disease, systemic arterial hypertension, obesity and chronic kidney disease..2. High incidence and mortality rates in the central (agreste) and eastern (metropolitan) regions of the Alagoas state and hand, high fatality rates have been observed in the interior..3. The lower incidence in those most vulnerable municipalities may express underreporting of the disease due to the low testing of the population. Thus, assessing the real incidence of COVID-19 in the poorest regions of the country is an even greater challenge, as people lack access to diagnosis and, consequently, appropriate treatment

author: Zhu et al. 2021
title: COVID-19 pandemic in BRICS countries and its association with socio-economic and demographic characteristics, health vulnerability, resources, and policy response.
Objective(s): To evaluate the association of daily new COVID-19 cases with socio.economic and demographic factors, health vulnerability, resources, and policy response among BRICS countries through a comparative study
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Using a descriptive statistics and estimated Pearson coefcients for bilateral correlations between socioeconomic and demographic factors, health vulnerability, resources, policy response to the COVID-19 pandemic and daily new cases in BRICS countries..2. A log-linear Generalized Additive Model (GAM) model was used to analyze the associations between the expectation of the response variable (daily new cases) and the nonparametric predictor variables..
Type of social stratification: -Extreme poverty.-Human development index.-GDP per capita (current USD)
Main Results: 1. Brazil: Extreme poverty 3.40; Human development index 0.77; GDP per capita (current USD) 14 103.45..2. Daily new COVID-19 cases correlated with socio economic and demographic disadvantages, health and  resource vulnerabilities, population mobility, and policy response in BRICS countries: See Table 2.Positive correlation with population density, extreme poverty, proportion of population aged 60 and above, prevalence of open defecation and policy stringency in BRICS countries (P<0.001). .Negatively correlated with life expectancy at birth, human development index, GDP per capita, hospital beds per thousand people, and access to improved drinking water (P<0.001)..3. Diferent lag structures also indicated similar results on the association of daily new COVID-19 cases with socio-economic and demographic disadvantages, health and resource vulnerabilities, population mobility, and policy response in the sensitivity analysis (all P<0.001)..4. The exposure–response curves showed that the number of daily new COVID-19 cases increased with the rise in policy stringency index (rapid surge: 0 to 45 / climbed slowly ranged: 46 to 80 / decreased: above 80 (after controlling other potential confounders))
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. In BRICS countries, daily new COVID-19 cases were afected by socio-economic and demographic status, health vulnerabilities, resources, and policy response..2. Important to reduce socio-economic inequalities and strengthen the resilience of health systems to better respond to public health emergencies.

author: J. B. de Souza et al. 2020
title: Pandemia e imigração: famílias haitianas no enfrentamento da COVID-19 no Brasil
Objective(s): To understand the experience of coping and repercussions of COVID-19 from the perspective of Haitian immigrant families in Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The Freirean Research Itinerary comprises three dialectically interconnected phases: 1) Thematic Research, 2) Codification and Decoding 3) Critical Unveiling
Type of social stratification: -Unemployment.-Class (Poverty)
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Socioeconomic status .-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. The 10 Haitian families participating in the study are in Brazil between two and six years old, consisting of the couple (10 men and 10 women) and children under six years old. .2. The concerns of the families were summarized as follows: work and subsistence of the family in Brazil and Haiti; uncertainty of the future; risk of contamination and of dying in Brazil; cancellation of children's classes; discouragement and loneliness..3. Finally, the families reflected on the importance of participation in the Virtual Culture Circle (CCV) and highlighted as main contributions: the clarification of doubts about the pandemic and especially, the space to promote mental health. They emphasized that the CCV provided an exchange of experiences at an important moment in their lives, when they felt isolated and discouraged, also offering an opportunity to alleviate the lack of family members in Haiti.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article.
Conclusions: 1. The mainly economic conditions of Haitian migrants is precarious and there is not enough help from the Government..2. Migrants are unnecessarily exposed to labor exploitation..3. Seeing the shortcomings in social, cultural and economic aspects helps to create strategic plans to improve the situation of migrants.
Funding sources: Coordination for the Improvement of Higher-Level People (CAPES). National Post-Doctoral Program fellowship granted to Jeane Barros de Souza, Process no. 88887.357993/2019-00.

author: García-Echeverry et al. 2020
title: El derecho a la salud en tiempos de pandemia en Colombia: entre la inequidad endémica y el estado de emergencia
Objective(s): The COVID-19 pandemic and subsequent health emergency allow analyzing, from bioethics and biolaw, problems related to the principle of distributive justice in the structural context of endemic inequality in Colombia.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The unequal response that the different regions have implemented in the face of the evolution of the pandemic follows the same rhythm that has characterized the socio-political evolution of the country: the capital city and the main cities have reacted with greater efficiency and anticipation than other regions..2. Although various strategies have been implemented by the central government to mitigate the effects of the pandemic in regions such as this one, these initiatives have been insufficient to alleviate the precariousness of the hospital infrastructure in these territories, and lacking a differential health approach ..3. The number of beds and fans has expanded since March, but coverage has been slow and uneven, and neglected needs persist in many areas of Colombia, as revealed by the reaction to the increase in cases in departments such as the Amazon or Nariño..4. Regarding the progressivity of the right to health, the regulatory adjustments to address the health emergency are still limited..5. Socioeconomic variables such as multidimensional poverty and corruption have a greater impact on health equity indicators (such as maternal mortality) than the variable health coverage..6. Sanitary measures that are indicated in public health to face the pandemic, such as preventive social isolation, in the absence of effective social mitigation programs, negatively impact various dimensions of poverty in socially and economically vulnerable populations..7. The state of emergency has been insufficient to alleviate not only the availability and expansion of health resources at the national level, but also the economic aid packages and financial relief necessary to comply with an essential principle..8. The social and necessary supports must be guaranteed to mitigate the negative impacts generated by preventive isolation and physical distancing (such as unemployment subsidy, payroll subsidy, implementation of basic income for informal workers, financial relief , etc.)
Policy or intervention associate: Colombia adopted three types of measures for the crisis: a) sanitary and sanitary emergency measures; b) social and economic emergency measures c) measures of order and other ordinary measures..Resolution No. 385 of March 12, 2020.Decree 417 of March 17, 2020.Resolution No. 470 of March 20, 2020.Decree 438 of 2020.Decree 476 of 2020.Decree 531 of April 8, 2020.Decree 538 of 2020..Resolution 628 of 2020.
Conclusions: 1. Universality and equity: there is inequality in the development of the infrastructure required for the care of the most seriously ill patients in the most remote regions of the country, where especially vulnerable population groups are also concentrated.2. Continuity of care: the measures implemented have generated delays in the timely care of patients with conditions other than COVID-19.3. Protection of indigenous peoples and Afro-descendants: the inefficiency of the state response for risk management and in the development of containment and mitigation strategies in regions such as Amazonas, Chocó, Nariño, among others, has been verified..4. The pandemic forces us to question the effectiveness of delegating to public and private networks the effective guarantee of the right to health without adequate supervision and control, which has also made the forms of hiring of health professionals precarious..5. It is necessary to critically reflect on the organization of the insurance and service delivery system, as well as on the role of public health, primary health care, and the relevance of the social determinants of health in a country with significant social debt in terms of equity.
Funding sources: None: The authors did not receive resources for their or for the writing of the article.

author: Câmara et al. 2020
title: Vulnerabilidade socioeconômica à COVID-19 em municípios do Ceará
Objective(s): To analyze the vulnerability of the black population in Brazil to the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic
Population: Black population with COVID-19 (Data from coronavirus epidemiological bulletins published by the Ministry of Health of Brazil)
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: Ethnicity: white/ black (black and brown)/ yellow / indigenous
Main Results: 1.Among indigenous peoples, the lowest rate of hospitalization was found in bulletins 09 and 14 (0.2%) and the highest in bulletin 18 (0.42%). Among people of yellow race/color, the lowest rate was found in bulletin number 18 (1.48%) and the highest rate of hospitalization in bulletin number 9 (2.9%)..2. The rates of white and black people showed significant divergences. White people showed a progressive decline in hospitalization rates for severe acute respiratory syndrome (SRAG) in all epidemiological bulletins studied, decreasing from 73% in epidemiological bulletin 9 to 43.3% in bulletin 18..3. Among black people, the hospitalization rate for SARS increased in all epidemiological bulletins studied, going from 23.9% in epidemiological bulletin 9 to 54.7% in bulletin 18..4. Death rates from COVID-19 among indigenous and yellow patients also remained stable in all epidemiological bulletins studied. Among indigenous peoples, the lowest death rate was found in bulletins 14 and 15 (0.3%) and the highest in bulletins 10, 11, 16, 17 and 18 (0.5%). Among people of yellow race/color, the lowest mortality rate was found in bulletins 17 and 18 (1.6%) and higher in bulletin 11 (2.7%)..5. People of white race/color showed a progressive decline in death rates from COVID-19 in all epidemiological bulletins published by the Ministry of Health, decreasing from 62.9% in epidemiological bulletin 9 to 36.5% in epidemiological bulletin no. 18..6. Among black people, the mortality rate from COVID-19 increased in all epidemiological bulletins studied, going from 34.3% in epidemiological bulletin no. 9 to 61.3% in bulletin no. 18.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The study evidenced the sustained increase in hospitalization and death rates among people of black race/color and the constant reduction in hospitalization and death among white people..2. It appears that black people are more likely to be hospitalized due to SRAG and death due to COVID-19 in Brazil, which implies a greater situation of vulnerability for people in this racial group..3. It is believed that this unfavorable scenario among black people is due to the difficulty or impossibility of carrying out social isolation, the prevalence of comorbidities that precipitate serious cases of COVID-19, difficulties in accessing health services and institutional racism..4. With this, it is necessary to implement a social protection network for this racial group, with the objective of reducing the onset of the disease and the lethality of the virus..5. It is believed that actions should cover the most diverse sectors: social, economic and assistance..6. Actions in the communities must be guided through the assessment of territories, with identification of risk groups, guidance on hygiene measures, offer of 70% alcohol gel for families with limited access to water and guarantee of spaces for quarantine of confirmed cases..7. Furthermore, it is essential that the State ensures that black people can achieve social isolation with financial support for their livelihoods and the implementation of employment protection policies..8. In addition, it is necessary to train health professionals, both in primary care and in the hospital network, to care for the black population, in an attempt to control the spread of the disease and early evaluation of people with greater potential for evolution to the serious condition of the disease.

author: A. S. da Silva et al. 2021
title: The COVID-19 epidemic in Brazil: how statistics education may contribute to unravel the reality behind the charts
Objective(s): To propose a discussion on the role that statistics education might play in supporting the acquisition of such knowledge, contributing to the development of critical citizens, aware of their social responsibility.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. They can see the diference in mortality rates between countries and that all curves show a positive slope at the end of 2020, seeming to show a tendency of growth of this accumulated rate. (see Figure 1A).2. The diferent colors represent the COVID-19-cumulated mortality rates per million inhabitants of each of the five regions..3. The Central-West region (composed of three states and the Federal District, where the country’s capital Brasília is located) presents the highest mortality rate, while the Southeast region has the lowest. (see Figure 3A).4. The states in the southernmost region have the lowest death rates per million inhabitants; on the other hand, the highest rates, represented by the darker colors, are from two states in the North region, and one state and the capital located in the Central-West region..5. Te North region is precisely the one with the worst socioeconomic and health indicators, the highest dependence on the Unifed Health System, and the worst ratio of hospital beds per inhabitant. (see Figure 4, 5 and 6).6. The map of the Northern region and its 64 micro-regions, with the colors representing COVID-19 death rate intervals per million inhabitants as of December 2020, divided by quintiles. The values indicated in these rates were rounded up and the colors get darker as mortality rate is higher. (see Figure 7).7. Indigenous peoples have quite diverse living conditions; they may live in isolated groups in the forest or concentrate in small urban areas. This population could be more vulnerable to infectious diseases. .8. The immune system of the isolated population tends to be weaker, and this population has less access to vaccines and healthcare assistance. .9. The population living in the urban areas is more exposed to poverty. With all aspects and vulnerabilities considered, these groups are among those with a higher priority for getting the COVID vaccine in the country.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The pandemic revealed how poverty and inequality in the world afect everyone. Furthermore, it demonstrated how some health systems and government policies were unable to protect their citizens from the disease.  .2. Underscores the significance of universal healthcare coverage for the entire population, as advocated in the World Health Organization report.  .3. A country, with such regional inequalities, produces diferent efects according to the regions and micro-regions..4. This document identifed the need for national observatories and regional data-sharing centers to compile, analyze, and disseminate health-related indicators, thus reinforcing the importance of the widespread use of statistics and the need for its understanding by non-scientists.

author: Lage and Rodrigues 2021
title: Pandelivery 1: Reflections on black delivery app workers experiences during COVID-19 in Brazil
Objective(s): To reflects on how the COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of black men who work as app delivery workers in Brazil.
Population: Black men who work as app delivery workers
