Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: -Socioeconomic: delivery services.-Race: Black/Indigenous/Latin
Main Results: 1. With the advent of COVID-19 and social isolation measures, delivery services were elevated to essential activity status (Decreto nº 10.282, 2020). Labor on the last mile is characterized by intense time pressure, standardization, algorithmic management, and digitally enabled surveillance on the one hand, and platform-driven precarization and flexibilization on the other .2. As previously presented, race and, more specifically, in the Brazilian context, skin color acts as a criterion for defining which bodies can occupy specific spaces .3. It is undeniable that companies profit directly or indirectly, taking advantage of inequality by hiring marginalized groups (people of color, refugees, immigrants, women, criminals, e.g.), precisely because they have the lowest wages and working conditions .4. To not be seen as a threat, black delivery workers often avoid interpersonal and intimate interactions as much as possible, even if it means a substandard delivery service. Therefore, late deliveries because of previous encounters with racism can generate serious consequences, even losing essential customers.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article.
Conclusions: 1. From the reflections described here, it became possible to reflect more on how there is an undeniable reinstatement of gender, race, and class inequalities during the pandemic. At the intersections of race, gender, and class, black men app delivery workers' experience has been shaped by precariousness and resistance movements. The fear, anger, and anxiety that already affect the black population can rise substantially with the stress of delivery activity.

author: R Undurraga and Gunnarsson 2021
title: The fragility of women’s work trajectories in Chile
Objective(s): To discuss the challenges and weaknesses of the Chilean women’s labor outcome and presents recent data to extrapolate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on vulnerable work trajectories.
Sample size: n=50, professionals and non-professionals, between the ages of 24 and 88.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: The information was analyzed based on grounded theory. Interviews were analyzed creating categories and subcategories, to finally create  conceptual network through maps that allowed organizing the information, selecting the topics related to the research questions, and gathering the main findings.
Type of social stratification: -Class: lower-middle class women.-Preparation: (professional with a terminal university degree engaged in professional tasks) / non-professionals(not have a university degree and carry out jobs that do not require higher education) .-Occupation: active in the labor market (with and without paid work)/ retired/ Waged Worker/ Independent Worker/ Out of the Labor Market.-Marital status:married/ cohabited/ single/ wodow/ separated/ divorced.-Mean or percentile of income: Average earnings were $ 15 a day.-Age: 20,35/ 36–45/ 46–60/ 61–75/ 76 and over)
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Occupation.-Education.-Socioeconomic status.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. They identified 4 types of Chilean women’s work trajectories: (...) That are connected to sociodemographic factors, such as educational level, socioeconomic level, age, marital status, and children, embracing an intersectional approach to unfold inequalities in the labor market..2. The type of trajectory can change(... )due to external events, such as a crisis like the COVID-19 pandemic..3. Improvised-work trajectory, women are more exposed and vulnerable to abuse since they have fewer educational, cultural, and labor resources to address gender inequalities..4. Improvised-work trajectory derives from the social and economic vulnerability of these women and from their families, (...)and generates a life-long cycle in which women lack sufficient social and economic resources to escape this situation of vulnerability..5. In order to belong to the higher tier of the primary labor market, women should be young, single, professionals without children and for the women that do not meet these requirements, they will have to settle for less success, stability, and lower salary..6. Being single can be a positive factor for the young women belonging to the self-realization work trajectory, since it allows them to devote time and effort to work (...) On the other hand, in the case of the women that have children, being single is a factor that negatively affects their work-life..7. Work trajectories of Chilean women in the context of poor social protection, hang by a thread that can be easily cut in the face of a crisis like the pandemic that we are experiencing..8. Their degrees and the good economic situation in which they have lived pre-pandemic do not guarantee stability or job security. In times of crisis, the fragility of this type of work trajectory is revealed..9. Women in the assured-work trajectory(...) in the pandemic(:..) have children and caretaking responsibilities, they are possibly facing a triple burden, which could generate stress, caretaking overload, and mental exhaustion, among others..10. During the coronavirus pandemic, most likely women in the improvised-work trajectory have had to continue working since the type of work they do does not allow them to work remotely (...) in a very fragile position to support themselves and their families
Policy or intervention associate: -Institutional offerings of the State for low-income families do not meet their needs, and do not offer the resources required to pay a private person to take care of the people depending on them..-Pensions are not enough to afford a living.-The legal retirement age represents an external requirement rather than a decisive milestone to finalize their work trajectories.
Conclusions: 1. In times of crisis, the factors that drive changes toward more insecure work trajectories become more severe, highlighting the fragility and vulnerability of female work trajectories..2. Professional women are better off than non-professional, though educational attainment does not  guarantee fair working conditions. .3. There are still gender discriminatory laws and cultural male chauvinist.work environments that put off women from the labor market(...) eg: Maternity penalties in the labor market and family penalties for working mothers.(...), however, women belonging to the improvised-work trajectory and the work trajectory depending on the family, face stronger cultural, social and economic barriers for paid work..4. People with greater economic resources look to the private market as a way of responding to their care needs, whilethose with fewer resources have no choice but to exclude themselves from the labor market to care for their dependents..5. labor trajectories of women are tremendously influenced by fluctuations related to family situations. In the current coronavirus context, this could become even more critical, due to school closings and the increase in care work and housekeeping,.6. Strengthening the care services offered by the State is crucial; private care services are high cost, so only few families could access and afford private childcare..7.costs of parenthood are not shared between genders, neither culturally nor legally, it is necessary to create more public policies focused on work-family conciliation, to be applied both to men and women. As such, it is necessary to promote joint responsibility for caretaking..8. Serious rethinking of the pension model to integrate components of greater solidarity, such as generating a social security system, rather than individual security in which the risks fall on individuals.
Funding sources: Comisión Nacional de Investigación Científica y Tecnológica, Chile. CONICYT/FONDECYT, grant number 11150862.

author: Cuéllar et al. 2021
title: Educational continuity during the pandemic: Challenges to pedagogical management in segregated chilean schools
Objective(s): To explore the challenges facing pedagogical management, as perceived by actors working in Chile’s three different administrative and financial school governance systems in the framework of remote education during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Population: Participants working in private and public schools
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Exploratory, descriptive and comparative approach, statistical, descriptive and bivariate analysis
Type of social stratification: -Challenges to pedagogical management: Technological/ Curriculum/ Methodological/ Assesment.-Administrative governance system: Municipal/ Subsidised /Private
Main Results: 1. Technological domain represents the most challenging aspect for the continuity of learning during the pandemic for participants working in municipal schools (Mo= 4,00) and in subsidised schools (Mo= 3,00). On the other hand, for participants working in private schools, the technological domain is one of the least challenging (Mo= 1,00)..2. The greatest challenge facing private schools is the aspect knowledge of methodological strategies for remote work (76%). This probably reveals that participants working in schools with greater socio-economic advantages have more access to tools and hardware enabling them to devise remote learning experiences of a superior quality..3. Private schools face fewer challenges than municipal and subsidised schools, since they display the lowest numbers in every domain, as shown in Table 2..4. Network availability represents a challenge for most participants in municipal establishments (59%) and subsidised establishments (52%). By contrast, in private schools only 7% of participants consider this aspect to be challenging. This same pattern is repeated with the item hardware availability.5. The major challenge facing municipal and subsidised schools is student access and connectivity (87% and 80% respectively), in contrast to participants from private schools in which only one third consider this aspect to be a challenge..6. The greatest challenge facing private schools is the aspect knowledge of methodological strategies for remote work (76%). This probably reveals that participants working in schools with greater socio-economic advantages have more access to tools and hardware enabling them to devise remote learning experiences of a superior quality.
Policy or intervention associate: School system characterised by standardisation and accountability in which non-compliance has strong consequences for schools, as occurs in Chile, instead of focusing on the selection of contextualised learning contents
Conclusions: 1. Participants who work at schools with less socio-economic advantages are trying to deal with new issues such as access to networks and the necessary devices for connectivity..2. Municipal and subsidised schools face greater challenges in practically every domain of pedagogical management compared to private schools. This situation has been exacerbated in the context of the health crisis, Public schools have more difficulty than private ones when it comes to exercising an ideal pedagogy..3. Inequities within the Chilean school system, which are not only based on limited economic resources, but also on the conditions of professional development achieved in the public sector, making pedagogical management more complex in the current scenario..3. Efforts should be aimed at developing competencies that allow the school to manage autonomous and contextualized decision processes that guide comprehensive pedagogical actions, always in favor of enriched learning..4. In this line, it would be substantial to (...)the improvement of instrumental tools, but should also move towards the promotion of social-emotional skills, especially for those in low-income socio- economic settings.

author: Brandão and Da Silva Cabral 2021
title: Reproductive justice and gender: Theoretical and political challenges in brazil amplified by the covid-19 pandemic
Objective(s): To reflect on the Brazilian government’s neglect of women’s health, especially in relation to users of the country’s unified health system, violating the principles enshrined in the constitution
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. Women were affected in different ways: overload of domestic work; care for children (in the absence of schools and day care centers); care of sick or elderly family members; need to earn income for family survival inside or outside the home; unemployment; and physical and mental exhaustion..2. Much has also been said about structural racism; the invisibility of social groups that make up the formal and informal workforce; and gender-based violence that erupted in domestic environments, perpetrated by powerless men, who attack and rape women, producing victims of different ages..3. Again, with Covid-19, the majority of working women, in formal/informal markets or in the domestic environment, and their health needs related to contraception, prevention of STIs, care for sexual violence, prenatal care and at childbirth they remain invisible and despised..4. The measures of social distancing enacted as a result of the pandemic created difficulties for the displacement of women to public health services, reoriented towards priority care for those infected with the coronavirus..5. Social inequality, combined with inequality of gender and race, push these women to their fate. Burdened with domestic duties and child care, in confined spaces, without the support of partners (when they exist and are close), they only have help from other women in their social network of kinship or neighborhood, whether they are daughters, mothers, sisters , godmothers or friends.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. The Covid-19 pandemic arrived in Brazil at a particularly difficult time for women, due to the moral and religious conservatism that prevails in the current government, in line with the broader anti-gender offensive, which affects several countries other than Latin America and has in the struggle anti-abortion is one of its main pillars..2. This right turn transcends national borders. Brazil's recent alignment in the United Nations Human Rights Council with ultra-conservative countries in voting against the inclusion of universal access to sex education in a draft resolution to combat discrimination against women and girls highlights the total shift to the right of our diplomacy..3. Inequalities produce illnesses and deaths. The context of health crisis brought about by the Covid-19 pandemic is greatly aggravated by the intentional dismantling of several public policies developed in recent decades. .4. The accelerated dismantling of several rights, such as labor, reproductive, health and education. It can be said that the current context is marked both by the absence of policies to confront multiple social inequalities (which results in the production of more inequalities in health), as well as by the institution of a way of managing life and bodies that have in its core is letting die/making die, so well presented in Mbemb's concept of necropolitics.

author: Lopera-Zuluaga 2020
title: Social network replies that denounce inequalities of the #AprenderDigital strategy in time of Covid-19
Journal: Revista Internacional de Educación para la Justicia Social
Objective(s): To classify in categories of analysis the citizen replies made to the publications of the National Ministry of Colombia on Twitter and Facebook under the hashtag #AprenderDigital. .To discuss, within the framework of citizen replies, the expressions of educational inequality exacerbated by the digital strategy, in addition to offering some lessons learned for post-pandemic digital educational policy in Colombia.
Population: Population affected by technological inequities and access to education
Sample size: n=169 citizen replies to the publications of the Ministry of Education National under the tag #AprenderDigital, tracked in the social networks of Twitter and Facebook between March 15 and April 30.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Qualitative analysis NCT -Noticing, Collect, Thinking-.2. They collected codes that harbored similar meanings or could be grouped in codes with a higher level of abstraction
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The digital strategy is considered good and innovative, but it is distorted because everyone do not have Internet access from home. .2. The digital strategy does not know the condition of families without the capacity to accompany and develop virtual learning, it also seems to turn its back on the priorities of the rural life project..3. The limitation of the politics digital education is restricted to schools, but with little impact on the fight against universal digital divide..4. Transformations require not only individual wills but policies that value investing in transforming learning environments that provide new ways of learning interact, new roles and flows through which information and knowledge. .5.  Covid-19 is the opportunity for families to understand that they can also learn with children and girls. Education can be an integration platform between school and family..6. It seems that the format is changed, but they continue accentuating the same inequalities and outlining a single way of being appropriate for the school..7. Policies should consider differential and territorial approaches in the which appeal to equity is to enable, of quantity and quality, everyone to achieve the same opportunities to learn..8. The crisis reveals the scarce execution of political promises..9. For disadvantaged and forgotten social sectors listening to a digital strategy to confront the closure of schools is to confront them with nonsense and with the true necessity and existential urgency for them: to supply the basic needs to survive.
Policy or intervention associate: #Aprenderdigital
Conclusions: 1. The quarantine status and the mass closure of schools meant appealing to the digital proposal as a solution, by default, greater difficulty for social sectors embodied in the figure of the suburban boy and girl, the rural family or the teacher serving indigenous communities..2. The citizen replicas (Twitter and Facebook) are the same voice that, in unison, demand targeting, personalization and territorial approach for the justified digital transformation, not only that of emergency on the occasion of covid-19, but also the one intended in the current economic policies in Colombia..3. The present study promised to categorize citizen replicas with the aim of reveal educational inequalities aggravated by the massive closure of schools and by the application of a homogeneous digital strategy to confront the exceptional situation..4. It finds a fertile space for a necessary foray into social science research that involves expanding the range of potential information sources. If they do, they will have a broader perspective of social reality. Limiting ourselves to traditional sources of information, otherwise, it will imply the loss of citizen voices that are worth capitalizing on due to the high informational value that they bring with them, as they will appreciate in the results section..5. They offered evidence to strengthen the complaint that estimates historically disadvantaged social sectors such as those who suffer most intensity the consequences of the current exceptionality..6. A school do not accept the technological solution as an easy way out of all your criticisms, but rather move forward towards the collective construction of wills to enable with technology conditions individual and institutional for better learning. It implies moving towards digital educability as a notion to generate training projects that make visible their own needs, enable opportunities and foster hope among so many inequalities..7. The development of school projects with technologies that link management and planning, the professional development of teachers, curriculum development, digital culture and the school-community relationship make it possible that, even under adverse conditions, school learning is possible.

author: Millalen et al. 2020
title: COVID-19 and Indigenous peoples in Chile: vulnerability to contagion and mortality
Journal: AlterNative: An International Journal of Indigenous Peoples
Objective(s): To investigate whether Indigenous Populations are disproportionately vulnerable to COVID-19 infection and deaths in Chile
Sample size: The data are aggregated of cases and deaths due to COVID-19 at the municipal level (Data from the Ministry of Health of Chile (Ministerio de Salud, 2020))
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Two regression models to determine whether municipalities with larger Indigenous populations see more cases and deaths of COVID-19 than the municipalities with smaller Indigenous populations.
Type of social stratification: -Number of COVID-19 cases and number of deaths due to COVID-19 per 100,000 people in each municipality. .-Percentage of Indigenous population.-Gender: Women/men,.-Geographic: Urban/rural.-Age group (eight categories).-Unemployment (percentage(.-Population with higher education and years of schooling
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Socioeconomic status .-Education.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination (e.g. age, disability)
Main Results: 1. An increase of 1% of the Indigenous population per municipality implied an increase of 5.1 cases of COVID-19 per 100,000 people at month 3 of the pandemic, 12.5 and 17.5 cases at months 4 and 5. .2. The rate of contagion among municipalities with a high concentration of Indigenous citizens has increased as the virus has spread to the general population. (see Table 1). .3. As COVID-19 has spread across the country, the mortality rate linked to the Indigenous population has risen. (see Table 2). .4. An increase of 1% of the Indigenous population per municipality implied an increase of 0.22 deaths per 100,000 people month 3 of the pandemic, 0.39 and 0.50 deaths at 4 and 5 months.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. This analysis confirms that municipalities with a higher proportion of Indigenous people are not only more susceptible to the virus, but also evince more deaths to COVID-19..2. This analysis illustrates that the municipalities with a higher percentage of Indigenous peoples present a higher rate of infection and mortality to COVID-19..3. These findings are consistent with previous studies demonstrating that Indigenous Peoples are more vulnerable to infection and deaths of COVID-19..4.  The pandemic may exacerbate the precariousness, vulnerability, and poor living conditions that Indigenous people have been subjected to because of the history of colonization, neoliberalism, and neo-extractivism in Chile..5. The pandemic has revealed underlying inequalities in hegemonic health care systems, including intercultural models that were already inadequate before COVID-19. In the face of this adversity, Mapuche communities, they have activated diverse community responses to confront the pandemic based on their strong tradition of organizing.

author: L. A. de Oliveira and de Aguiar Arantes 2020
title: Neighborhood Effects and Urban Inequalities: The Impact of Covid-19 on the Periphery of Salvador, Brazil
Objective(s): To offer a brief diagnosis about the potential impacts of Covid19 on the peripheries of Salvador in terms of neighborhood effects. .To address the following question: to what extent does urban location determine health and socioeconomic risks in the current pandemic?
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The third sector constitutes the most important activity of the economy in Salvador. About 20% of the population is unemployed, whereas informality represents 35%, and the average income is US$430 per month..2. 37% of citizens have a per capita income of up to ½ minimum wage (U$100), an empirical condition of poverty..3. Precariousness is even more perverse when we consider race: unemployment and informality are higher among the black population, which is 83% of the city.4. Many of these peripheral neighborhoods have a high population density, deficiencies in health services and a lack of basic sanitation. Recently, there have been complaints of water rationing in some neighborhoods, just now when the recommendation is for everyone to stay at home and increase hygiene measures..5. Poorer neighborhoods tend to suffer from poor health services; on the other hand, there are inequalities associated to the place of residence in relation to those who have access to private health plans and those who depend on the Unified Health System (SUS).
Policy or intervention associate: 1. The Salvador City Hall also created a project called “Salvador For All”, which will transfer US$52 over three months to 20,000 informal workers. .2. The State Government, in turn, will exempt low-income citizens from water and electricity bills for the same period
Conclusions: To avoid a catastrophe that is already on the horizon, the public authorities must work with peripheral communities to offer the conditions for a “safe isolation”.

author: De Negri et al. 2021
title: Socioeconomic factors and the probability of death by Covid-19 in Brazil
Objective(s): To estimate the effects of individual socioeconomic characteristics on the risk of death by Covid-19.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Logistic models to estimate the Covid-19 mortality risk in all workers in the formal labor market.
Type of social stratification: -Gender: Female/Male.-Race: no/yes white.-Eduation: complete primary/complete secondary/complete higher.-Geographic: Metropolitan region.-Vulnerable occupations (security, healthe-transport): No/Yes.-Occupations: Police officers, firefighters and protective workers/Health professionals /Customer services clerks / Other occupations.
PROGRESS-plus (https://methods.c: -Place of residence.-Education.-Gender/sex.-Race/ethnicity/culture/language.-Occupation.-Socioeconomic status.-Personal characteristics associated with discrimination
Main Results: 1. Greater vulnerability of the non-white populations to the epidemic..2. Working in the Metropolitan Region of the city of Rio de Janeiro also results in higher risks of death from Covid-19..3. The public order and safety activities are only significant in the last specification when protective workers previously allocated in the public administration (especially police officers and firefighters) are allocated for the public order and safety activities..4. The results show that with each additional year of age, the risk of death from Covid-19 increases by 18%..5. Workers employed in establishments in the human health and public safety sectors present, respectively, a risk of dying 2.46 and 2.25 times higher than those employed in other activities.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Workers in essential activities such as health and security and those who could not work remotely, became more vulnerable to death by Covid-19..2. That is further evidence suggesting that social distancing measures managed to protect the portion of workers for which it was possible to either interrupt work activities or carry them out remotely.

author: Manfrinato et al. 2021
title: High prevalence of food insecurity, the adverse impact of COVID-19 in Brazilian favela
Objective(s): To investigate food insecurity (FI) prevalence in two favelas in Brazil in the early weeks of the social distancing policy, from 27 March 2020 to 1 June 2020.
City or municipality: Heliopolis favela and Vila São José São Paulo
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis: statistics Crude and relative distributions and median and inter-quartile ranges
Type of social stratification: -Role in the house: householde/the person in charge of food acquisition.-Income per person, USD: =62 / =61 .-Bolsa família recipient: No / Yes .-Years of education: =9 years / =8 years.-Age.-Gender: Male/Female.-Occupation: Cleaner, kitchen assistant and driver, deliveryman / Salesman, freelance and autonomous / Unemployed, housewife and retired
Main Results: 1. Majority of the households included young women working as cleaners or kitchen assistants and in sales services. .2. Moderate and severe FI ( Food insecurity) was associated with a low level of education, occupation, income, presence of children (P < 0·001), living in Heliopolis (P = 0·001) and being a Bolsa Família recipient (P = 0·05). The Bolsa Família recipients, a federal cash transfer programme for individuals with extreme poverty, families with children who attend school and lowincome pregnant women. .3. In the multivariate model, factors associated with moderate and severe FI were low income, being a Bolsa Família recipient, low level of education and householdswithout children
Policy or intervention associate: São Paulo city, the financing of social programmes has been reduced, including the family farming.
Conclusions: 1. Families with children were less likely to report moderate and severe food insecurity..2. Nationally established social programmes like Bolsa Família were protecting those families, as well as solidarity from non-profit organisations and private sectors that offer food kits..3. In the favelas (...) More than half of the participants experienced moderate or severe food insecurity, and close to 10 % experienced hunger. Half were unable to eat healthy and nutritious food

author: G. Andrade 2021
title: Covid-19 vaccine hesitancy, conspiracist beliefs, paranoid ideation and perceived ethnic discrimination in a sample of University students in Venezuela
Objective(s): To assess whether vaccine hesitancy varies across ethnic groups, in a sample of 273 Venezuelan university students.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: 1. Scores for the five questionnaires plus the question regarding the intention to get the vaccine, were compared in terms of gender, age groups and ethnicity, running a one-way ANOVA statistical analysis. Statistical significance was placed at p < 0.05. Chi-square analysis was done comparing the intention of different ethnic groups in getting the vaccine. Statistical significance was placed at p < 0.05..2. Spearman’s coefficients were calculated for the correlations between each of latter five constitutive parts of the questionnaire.
Type of social stratification: Ethnicity: White/Afro-Venezuelan/Indigenous/Mixed Race/other.Gender: Male/Female
Main Results: 1. There are no statistically significant differences between genders or age groups in scores to responses..2. There is no statistically significant difference between ethnicities in scores regarding paranoid ideation.3. There are statistically significant differences between ethnicities in scores regarding plans to get the vaccine, vaccine conspiracy beliefs, generic conspiracist beliefs, and perceived ethnic discrimination..4. Chi-square analysis of intention to get the vaccine by ethnicity See  Table 3, with a statistically significant result regarding differences across ethnicities..5. Persecutory Ideation Questionnaire (PIQ) scores have statistically significant but weak correlations with intention to get the vaccine, Vaccine Conspiracy Beliefs Scale (VCBS), Generic Conspiracist Beliefs Scale (GCBS) and Brief Perceived Ethnic Discrimination Questionnaire-Community Version (Brief PEDQ-CV)..6. Brief PEDQ-CV has statistically significant strong correlation with plans to get the vaccine and VCBS, and statistically significant moderate correlation with GCBS. .7. GCBS has a statistically significant moderate correlation with plans to get the vaccine, and strong correlation with VCBS. .8. VCBS has a statistically significant strong correlation withplans to get the vaccine.
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. That differences amongst ethnic groups regarding their intention to get the vaccine, are statistically significant. The lowest levels for vaccine hesitancy is Whites, marginalized ethnicities (Wayuu natives and Afro-Venezuelans) have the greatest levels of vaccine hesitancy..2. The greatest predictor of vaccine hesitancy in Venezuela is acceptance of vaccine conspiracy beliefs..3. Perceived ethnic discrimination has a moderate correlation with vaccine hesitancy and conspiracy beliefs..4. In the short term, policymakers must devise programs that provide special vaccination incentives to members of marginalized ethnic communities.

author: H.L.P.C. dos Santos et al. 2021
title: Public expenditure on hospitalizations for COVID-19 treatment in 2020, in Brazil
Objective(s): To analyze the percentage of public expenditures on SUS hospitalizations for clinical treatment of COVID-19 patients in Brazil, between February and December 2020.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Descriptive analysis
Type of social stratification: -Number of hospitalizations.-Total cost of hospitalizations .-Cost of professional services.-Cost of hospital services.-Average cost of SUS hospitalization (by specialty or procedure/ in a given geographical space/ in the year considered).-Average length of stay (average total number of days for the IHA approved in the period) .-Lethality rate (ratio between the number of deaths and the number of approved.-Hospital authorizations (IHA), in the period/ computed as hospitalizations/ multiplied by 100)..National Registry of Health Establishments: .-Public hospitals: federal public administration/ state or Federal District/ municipal / public administration – others.-Corporate hospitals: public company or mixed-capital company /other business entities.-Non-profit hospitals: non-profit entities
Main Results: 1. The South and North regions presented, respectively, the highest and lowest average cost per hospitalization.2. The higher expenses and number of hospitalizations found also refer to coronavirus infection.3. Hospitalizations taken place in Brazil under Unified Health System (SUS)=  4.9% had as main procedure the treatment of COVID-19, corresponding to 15% of the expenditures with all hospitalizations in the country. ( the latter lasted longer).4. Southeast region showed the highest number of hospitalizations, highest total amount spent, highest average length of stay in days, and higher lethality rate..5. A higher percentage of expenditures with non-profit hospitals (58%) and corporate hospitals (15%) in the South region
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Urgent to expand the availability of beds by SUS with equitable availability, so that certain areas are prioritized by government investment before the emergency situation established by the COVID-19 .2. Disparities in inpatient expenditure for similar procedures between regions of the country..3. It is important to analyze the gaps in the process of standardizing clinical and care practices and to elucidate the difficulties and differences found in each location that justify such disparities..4. Covid- 19 hospitalizations for this purpose were more costly when compared with those for treating ARI and pneumonia or influenza.

author: Paulo Ricardo Martins-Filho, de Souza Araújo, et al. 2021
title: COVID-19 fatality rates related to social inequality in Northeast Brazil: A neighbourhood-level analysis
Objective(s): To investigate the association between social inequality and COVID-19 fatality rate in Aracaju municipality, Sergipe state, Northeast Brazil.
City or municipality: Aracaju municipality, Sergipe state, Northeast Brazil.
Method of inequalities/inequitie: Cochran–Armitage test was used to evaluate the trend of the incidence rate and Case fatality rate (CFR) by Living Conditions Index (LCI) stratum
Type of social stratification: Living Conditions Index (LCI) - ranges from 3 to 90: high (3–24)/ intermediate (25–44)/low (45–60) / very low (62–90)
Main Results: 1. The median time from onset of symptoms to death was 14 days (Q1 = 8; Q3 = 23)..2. The incidence rate of COVID-19 was 322.8 cases per 10 000 population and the Case fatality rate (CFR) was 2.0%..3. The COVID-19 CFR was 2-fold higher for neighbourhoods with very-low LCI compared with neighbourhoods with high Living Conditions Index (LCI)..4. Geographically, the highest mortality estimates have been observed in the North andWest zones, which have a large number of socio-economically deprived neighbourhoods in Aracaju..5. The most vulnerable populations have been disproportionately impacted by COVID-19, where areas with the greatest inequities are those most affected
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. Differences in COVID-19 infection and mortality rates are emerging as a result of the co-occurring non-communicable diseases and the existing poor social conditions..2. In Aracaju, COVID-19 pandemic has exposed historical inequalities and poor communities have shown limited testing resources and higher fatality rates from COVID-19 compared with communities with better living conditions..3. People living in socio-economically disadvantaged communities are substantially less likely to have education, adequate sanitation, access to clean water to wash hands, opportunity to work from home office and healthcare access. Are more likely to live in crowed homes and present underlying medical conditions including hypertension and diabetes that are considered risk factors for severe COVID-19. .4. This scenario calls to urgent strategies to reduce the spread and mortality from COVID-19 in high-deprivation communities.

author: dos Reis et al. 2020
title: Gender and race inequalities in the COVID-19 pandemic: implications for control in Brazil TT - Desigualdades de gênero e raça na pandemia de COVID-19: implicações para o controle no Brasil
Objective(s): To synthesize scientific evidence on gender and race inequalities in the Covid-19 pandemic, focusing on women’s productive/reproductive work, gender-based violence, and the access to Sexual and Reproductive Health Services (SRHS).
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. In Brazil and other low- and middle-income countries, there was a higher risk of death among women with Covid-19 during the pregnancy-puerperal cycle, differently from what occurred in Asia and Europe..2. In Brazil, an analysis of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome cases identified 124 deaths during pregnancy and in the postpartum period between February and June. Pregnant women with comorbidities are more affected, and there is evidence that these women faced barriers to accessing intensive care..3. In Latin America, Argentina, Colombia, Mexico and Brazil also register an increase in emergency calls related to domestic violence. In Argentina, calls have increased 25% since the lockdown began on March 20, and femicide crimes have increased 50% compared to the same period last year. In Colombia, 91%, and in Mexico, 60%. The Brazilian scenario is similar and, according to the National Ombudsman for Human Rights, of the Ministry of Women, the Family and Human Rights, the number of complaints registered by the Dial 100 and Ligue 180 services rose 18% between the 1st and the 25th March 2020.4. In Brazil, the arrival of the Covid-19 pandemic took place at a time of increasing poverty and extreme poverty, which had been occurring since 2015, reversing the downward trend of previous years..5. The greater exposure of women to infections such as Covid-19 is not explained only by its over-representation among health professionals. This is also due to the segregation of gender and race: black women are the most inserted in occupations with less prestige and remuneration, in domestic employment and as caregivers for the elderly and people with special needs, in informal and precarious work, making it difficult to compliance with the recommendation of social distancing and placing them in situations of greater physical proximity to people with Covid-19.
Policy or intervention associate: To reduce maternal deaths, UNFPA recommends that parturients with Covid-19 should be seen in places that ensure respiratory care, and that pregnant women with other respiratory diseases should be treated as a priority and separated from infected pregnant women.Alternative monitoring schemes should be adopted, such as home consultations, telehealth or WhatsApp, to identify the symptomatic ones and ensure care for the infected, especially high-risk pregnant women and health professionals, more exposed to the epidemic
Conclusions: 1. The results of this review offer an overview that contradicts the widespread myth about the 'democratic' character of SARS-CoV-2, pointing out the gender and racial inequalities that condition the occurrence of Covid-19 and its implications for compliance with recommended measures for its control..2. In previous epidemics, structural inequities of race and gender and the fragility of health services were neglected. This pattern has been repeated in the Covid-19 pandemic, mainly in Latin American countries, which have not recognized Sexual and Reproductive Health services as essential. Brazil finds itself in a more serious situation, considering the dismantling of health services and the loss of conquered rights, especially sexual and reproductive rights..3. Access and timely care must be guaranteed to parturient women and their newborns, as well as to women suffering from abortion, with precautions taken for their safety. Attention to symptomatic pregnant women for Covid-19 should also be ensured, with guidance to women about referral services..4. During the pandemic, the full performance of care networks for women in situations of violence must be preserved, particularly abortion services in cases provided for by law..5. Intersectional approaches are incipient, and many questions are posed, requiring the construction of a strong research agenda, with an intersectional approach to gender, race and class. In this way, the formulation of policies will be based on scientific knowledge that incorporates human rights – in particular, sexual and reproductive rights – and that meets the needs of the groups most vulnerable to Covid-19 and its consequences.
Funding sources: Góes EF is funded by the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Global Health Research Program (GHRG/16/137/99). Aquino EML has a Research Productivity Scholarship from the National Council for Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq) (Process no. 306295/2017-2)

author: Mascayano, Bruni, and Susser 2021
title: Implications of Global and Local Inequalities in COVID-19 Vaccine Distribution for People With Severe Mental Disorders in Latin America
Objective(s): NA
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. The COVID-19 pandemic has seriously affected the provision of mental health care for people with SMD in Latin America, including partial or total disruptions of medication, psychotherapy, and counseling services..2. SomeLatin American countries (eg, Argentina, Brazil) participated in large trials of some vaccines (eg, Pfizer), they will not be receiving enough to inoculate their entire populations anytime soon..3. In this context, some countries (eg, Argentina, Bolivia,Venezuela) are using vaccines that are more accessible and may be efficacious but have less transparent data..4. The distribution of vaccines inLatin America will have to deal with a large variety of longstanding social, economic, health, and racial/ethnic inequalities.
Policy or intervention associate: It not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. They use vaccines to illustrate the challenges posed by the pandemic in Latin America.We contend that the US has a special obligation to Latin America in mobilizing support for COVID-19 vaccines for historical reasons..2. Many people with SMD in Latin America have limited income, are socially marginalized, have very limited access to health and social services, and live in crowded and impoverished urban areas.

author: Bojorquez et al. 2021
title: Migration and health in Latin America during the COVID-19 pandemic and beyond. Lancet
Objective(s): To expose the migratory conditions during the pandemic
Method of inequalities/inequitie: It does not directly measure inequalities (narrative synthesis)
Type of social stratification: NA
Main Results: 1. COVID-19 has created a syndemic scenario that is deepening pre-existing structural inequalities for migrants in Latin American countries .2. During the COVID-19 pandemic, food insecurity, unemployment, and reduced socioeconomic agency have led to considerable insecurity and anxiety for migrants living in LACs.   .3. The region faces one of the largest mass migrations worldwide; more than 5·5 million refugees and migrants have left Venezuela, 4·6 million of whom now live in the Latin American region. .4. For decades, migration fuelled the economic and cultural development in the region. Today, migration has increasingly become an issue of risk and precarity.  .5. In LACs, migrants face barriers in accessing regular health services due to inadequate information, the absence of culturally appropriate care, or insufficient legal provisions. Additionally, there have been challenges in the prevention of COVID-19 among migrant populations as a result of poor public health communication, reduced access to public health prevention measures, and living or working in conditions where it is difficult to isolate  .6. COVID-19 has reduced human mobility within and across borders. Border closures and changes to migration policy across Latin America interrupted migrants’ movement, leaving thousands stranded across the region. Others were forced to return to the same danger, social exclusion, inadequate health care, and poverty they had fled   .7. Migrants who were trapped in transit, or who were living with undocumented or irregular status, became even more vulnerable to family separation, trafficking, or exploitation
Policy or intervention associate: It is not mentioned in this article
Conclusions: 1. However, the detrimental impacts of COVID-19 on migrants and failure of inclusive health policies and systems have revealed the vulnerability of migrants to the consequences of politics designed without considering migration and human mobility in government agendas.   .2.  Explicit commitment from governments to include migrants in all phases of the evolving public health response to COVID-19 is needed. This response must include ensuring access to vaccination and social protection programmes without discrimination and addressing the broader socioeconomic inequalities that affect migrants’ health..3. Sustainable and inclusive approaches to migrant health should go beyond humanitarian response and meet the needs of local and mobile populations alike, in line with the Sustainable Development Goals agenda.
